Felician regnyd emperour in the Cyte of Rome, In the empeire of
whom þer was a kny&yogh;t þat hadde weddid a yong
damese&llbar; to wi&ftee;.  And withinne fewe yerys þis woman
lovid by wey of synne an oþer kny&yogh;t, vndir hire
husbon&dtail;, and þat so mocℏ, þat she ordeyned for
hire husbonde to be ded.  Happyn>ee; þat þis kny&yogh;t
wold goo on pilgrimage ouer þe see; And þerfore he seide
to his wi&ftee;, "Dame, y wo&llbar; goo on pilgrimage, ouer þe
see; And þerfore gouerne the wele the while til I come home
a&yogh;en."  And with that she was glad, and seide, "Sir, wiþ
þe grace of God a&llbar; sha&llbar; be wele y-do."  And shortly
for to touche þis mater; he tooke his leve, and &yogh;ede his
wey.  Nowe þis false quene, his wi&ftee;, ordeyned for his dethe
in a&llbar; þat she cowde, and spake þerfore to a
nigromauncer in þis forme: "Myn husbond," quod she, "is
bi&yogh;ende þe see; I wo&llbar; wite, if þou cowde helpe
þat he were ded by ony Crafte.  Aske of me what þou wolt,
and þou shalt have hit."  Then spake he to hyre a&yogh;en, and saide, "&YOGH;is,
forsotℏ, lady, that I can.  That kny&yogh;t sha&llbar; dye by my
crafte, yn what cuntre of the wordle so euer þat he be ynne. And
y wo&llbar; haue no thing of þe for my trauayle but þe
love of thyne hert." And she it grauntid to him.  So
þis nigromancien dyd make an ymage of erþe, And fastenyd
it in þe wa&llbar; afore him.  And þe kny&yogh;t,
þat was gon on pilgrimage, walkyd yn the same day in the stretys
of Rome.  So þer met wiþ him a clerke, the whicℏ
hielie behel&dtail; him.  And when þe kny&yogh;t perceyvid it,
he seide to him, "goode Sir, te&llbar; me why and what skile,
þat þou so beholdest me?"  Thenne seid the clerke,
"Forsotℏ, Sir, for þy detℏ; For douteles þou
shalt yn þis same day be ded, but i&ftee;
þou be the better holpyn."  And he told þe kny&yogh;t how
þat his wif was a strompet, and whicℏ purveitℏ in
þat day that hire husbond shuld be ded.  And when þe
kny&yogh;t hurde theise wordes, he had grete merueile, and seide, "A!
Sir, I knowe we&llbar; þat my wi&ftee; is an hore, and long tyme
haþ y-be; But þat she euer pursuyd for my detℏ,
þat is vnknowe to me, and þerfore I pray þe
te&llbar; me if þer be ony remedye ayenst my detℏ; and if
þou mowe save my ly&ftee;, sotℏly a&llbar; my goodys
shu&llbar; be at þyne owne wi&llbar;."  "&YOGH;ys," quoþ
þe clerk, "A Remedye þer is, Iff þou wolt do aftir
my conseil."  "&YOGH;is, &yogh;is," seide þe kny&yogh;t, "I am
redy to fulfi&llbar; a&llbar; in dede þat þou wolt sey
vnto me."  Thenne seide þis clerke, "Thy wif," he seide,
"hatℏ this day spoken with a ma&ntail; that can of nigromancye,
to sle the by his crafte and sotilte; and so the nigromancien
hatℏ y-made an ymage, and sette it in a wa&llbar;; and anoon he
wo&llbar; take a bowe and arowis, and shete att it.  And if he wounde
þis ymage, þyne herte sha&llbar; brest, where so euer
þou be in þe wordle.  And so þou sholdiste dye;
Neuertheles do aftir my Conseil, and sone I sha&llbar; save þi
life.  Do of alle thy cloþis, and be naki&dtail;, and go into a
baþ, þat I sha&llbar; make for the."  And þe
kny&yogh;t dyd ri&yogh;t as he bad him.  And when he was in þe
baþ, þe clerk toke him a myrour in his hond, and seide,
"Nowe þou shalt see in this myrour a&llbar; that I spake of to
þe."  And thenne seide he, "ye, sotℏly I see a&llbar;
opynly in myne hous, þat þou spakist of to me.  And now
þe myster-man takitℏ his bowe, and wo&llbar; schete att
þe ymage."  Thenne seide the clerk, "Sir, as þou lovist
þi lif, what tyme that he drawitℏ his bowe, Bowe thyne
he&dtail; vndir the watir; For if þou do not, certenly þy
ymage sha&llbar; be smytene, and þou botℏ."  And when
þe kny&yogh;t sawe him begynne forto drawe his bowe, he dyd as
þe clerke conseilid him.  And thenne seide þe
clerk, "What seist þou now?"  "Forsotℏ," quoþ he,
"now hatℏ he schote an arowe at the ymage; And for þat he failitℏ of his
strook, he makitℏ mocℏ sorowe."  Thenne seide þe
clerke, "&YOGH;e, that is goode tydyng for þe; For if he had
smyten þe ymage, þou sholdist have I-be de&dtail;.  But
loke nowe on the myrour, and te&llbar; me what þou seist."  "Now
he takitℏ an oþer arowe, and wo&llbar; shete a&yogh;en."
"Do thenne," quoþ the Clerke, as þou dyd afore, or ellis
þou shalt be ded."  And þerfore the kny&yogh;t putte
a&llbar; his hede vndir þe water.  And whenne he had so y-done,
he raisi&dtail; hit vp a&yogh;en, And seyde to þe clerke, "He
makitℏ sorowe nowe more þan ony man wo&llbar; trowe, For he
smot not þe ymage; And he Cryed to my wif, seiyn>ee;,
þat if I fayle the thir&dtail; tyme, I am but ded my selfe, And
þyne husbond sha&llbar; lyve; And my wif makiþ
þerfor mocℏ lamentacion."  "loke a&yogh;en," seide þe
clerke, "and te&llbar; me what he doþ."  "Forsoþe," seide
he, "he hatℏ bend his bowe, and goitℏ ny to þe ymage
for to shete; and þerfor I drede now gretly."  "Do
þerfore," seide the clerke, "do as I bade doo afore, and dred
þe noþyn>ee;."  So þe kny&yogh;t, whenne he sawe
the scheter drawe his bowe, he swapte his hed vndir þe watir, as
he dyd afore; And thenne he toke it vp a&yogh;en, And lokid yn
þe myrour, and he low&yogh; with a gret myrtℏ.  "I sey,"
quod the clerke, "whi law&yogh;ist þou soo?" "For the archer
wold have y-schot at the ymage, And he hatℏ y-schotte him selfe
in þe lunge&ntail;, and lyetℏ ded; And my wif makitℏ
sorowe with oute ende, And wo&llbar; hyde his body by hire beddys
syde."  "&YOGH;e, Sir," quod the clerke, "now þou haste þi
lif savid, do &yogh;eld to me my mede, and go; farwe&llbar;."  Thenne
the kny&yogh;t &yogh;af him mede as he wo&llbar; aske.  And þe
kny&yogh;t went hom, and fond þe body vndir the bedde of his
wi&ftee;; and he &yogh;ede to þe Meyre of þe towne, And
told him howe his wife hadde don in his absence.  Thenne when þe
Meyre and þe statys sawe þis doyng, þey made
þe wif to be slayne, And hire herte to be departid yn to
þre parteis, in tokne and emsampi&llbar; of veniaunce.  And the
goode ma&ntail; toke an oþer wif, and faire endid his liffe.

MORALITE. Seitℏ nowe, goode men; þis emperour I Ca&llbar; owre
lor&dtail; ihesu Criste; þe empire is þis wordle, in
whicℏ is mocℏ aduersite; For a&llbar; þat is in
þe wordle oþer it is fals couetise of flescℏ, or fals
couetise of yen, or prowde of lif.  The wif that lovitℏ not hire
husbon&dtail; is þi flescℏ, þat dispisitℏ
a&llbar; werkis that þe spirite lovitℏ.  Now in
spekin>ee; gostely of þis mater, while þat a man
goitℏ in pilgrimage, Serys, that is to sey, In werke of ony goode
dede to be fu&llbar;-fille&dtail;, Thenne the flesℏ spekitℏ
with þe nigromancier, scil. þe devi&llbar;; And þat
he dotℏ as ofte tyme as he grucchitℏ a&yogh;enst þe
spirit, and sesitℏ fro werkis of penaunce, wherby þe spirit
may be slayne.  For it is as þe aposti&llbar; seitℏ, Caro concupiscit aduersus spiritum, et spiritus adversus
carnem , This is to vndirstonde, The flescℏ
desiritℏ thing þat is a&yogh;enst þe spirite, And
þe spirit desiritℏ thing a&yogh;enst þe flescℏ.
The clerke þat helpitℏ þe kny&yogh;t is a discrete
confessour or a prechour, Whicℏ techitℏ a man How þat
he sha&llbar; defende him a&yogh;enst þe dartys of þe
devi&llbar;.  This nigromancer [that] is þe devi&llbar;,
biginnitℏ to schete an arowe att the ymage,—what is
þat?  The Reso&ntail; within a ma&nmacr;.  But beware þat
he hit not him with his arowe, scil.  Envy or auarice, For if he do,
wi—thoute doute he sha&llbar; dye in euermore lastyn>ee;
detℏ.  And þerfore þou most putte downe
þy&ntail; he&dtail;,—what is þat?  Thyne old lif of
synne, and entre yn to þe batℏ of confessio&ntail;.  And
þou most hol&dtail; in thy hond a myrour, scil. holy doctrine,
þat prelatis and prestis euery day shewitℏ, by þe
whicℏ þou shalt see a&llbar; perilis þat
perteynitℏ to þi soule.  And also holdyng downe of þe
hed in þe batℏ, is to be redy to goo vndir þe
&yogh;oke of penance, and submitte þe to it that sha&llbar; be
enioyned to þe; and þat is not hard, witnessing þe
sauiour him selfe, wher he seitℏ, Jugum meum
suaue, et onus meum leue , Lo! my &yogh;oke, he seitℏ,
is swete, and my charge is ligℏ&ttee;. And if þou do
þus, no doute of þou shalt stonde a&yogh;enst a&llbar; the
shotis þat þe devi&llbar; can shete to þe; And his
shotis sha&llbar; turne to his owne sorowe, and encresing of his peyne
in þe bed of he&llbar;, wher he sha&llbar; be buryed.  Now
þan most a prelate honge the wi&ftee;—what bymenytℏ
that?  Forsotℏ þat consciens and discrecio&ntail; late
þe flesℏ be hongyd on þe iebet of penaunce, Of þe
whicℏ maner of living þe Aposti&llbar; spekitℏ
þis, Suspendium elegit anima mea ,
This is to sey, my soule hatℏ chosen þe iebet, scil. doyng
of penaunce.  And after þe herte is departid ynto thre parteys,
that is, the flesℏ is devidi&dtail; ynto þre, scil.
prayin>ee;, Almysdede, and fastyng.  And thenne þou shalt take
a new wi&ftee;, scil. a spirit obediente to a
new gouernaunce; And thenne per consequens þou shalt have
euermore lastyng li&ftee;, Ad quam nos et vos
perducat, &c.

Lucius was a wise Emperour regnyd in þe
Cite of Rome, yn þe hous of whom þer was a nobi&llbar;
knygℏ&ttee;, þe whicℏ kny&yogh;t as he rode or
&yogh;ede in A Certeyne day in ernndis of þe emperou&rtail;, he
sawe after a serpent and a toode fi&yogh;te to-geder; But þe
tode hadde ny þe victorie, and ny ouercome þe serpent.
And whenne the knytℏ sawe
þis batai&llbar;, he com to, An smot the toode, and deliuered
þe serpent fro detℏ.  So aftirwar&dtail; whenne the
kny&yogh;t was on his bed, and grete lobour þat he hadde on the
day Afore made him to slepe har&dtail;; And alle þe tyme
þe toode ha&dtail; folowi&dtail; him afer.  And whenne the
kny&yogh;t was a-slepe, þe toode enteryd in to his be&dtail;,
And &yogh;ede vp on þe brest of þe kny&yogh;t, afore
þe herte, And ther he fasteny&dtail; his iiij feete.  And when
þe kny&yogh;t was waki&dtail; of his slepe, he perceyvid
þe toode, and with a ferdnesse clepyd his Chambirlayne, and bad
him to geete a li&yogh;t.  And whenne the cande&llbar; was li&yogh;t,
þey sawe fully the toode sitting on his brest; And none of hem
migℏt pluk it awey with no crafte.  And þenne seide
þe kny&yogh;t, "Allas!  þis is þe toode þat I
smot for þe serpent; Allas!  now it wo&llbar; sle me."  And so
sat þe toode alle þat &yogh;ere, and secke his blod, in
maner of a childe att þe pappis of his modir, So that the
kny&yogh;t was ny distroy&dtail; and lost, Nethir þer was no
leche that my&yogh;t helpe him.  Tho þis kny&yogh;t made his
testament, and made him redy to his detℏ; And ofte tyme he vsid to ligge ny þe fire, for to haue comfort and
recreacio&ntail; o&ftee; þe fire.  And as he lay in a certeyne
tyme by the fire, in si&yogh;yngis and gryntingis, he lokid toward
þe dore of þe ha&llbar;, and he saw þe serpent,
whicℏ þat he helpe a&yogh;enst þe toode, stonde in
the dore.  And anoo&ntail; þe kn&yogh;yt cride to his
seruauntis, and seide, "goo &yogh;e out of þe ha&llbar; echon,
for I se it for whos love I suffre this torment; for I trowe that now
he wo&llbar; fi&yogh;t with this toode, that thus noyiþ me."  And chargid hem þat
þei shul&dtail; come a&yogh;en witℏ oute delay, whenne he
cryde after hem, þat þei shulde helpe þe serpent in
a&llbar; þat þei my&yogh;te a&yogh;enst þe toode;
For if þe toode slo þe serpent, þe same toode
wo&llbar; sle him after.  And the seruauntis &yogh;ede out of the
ha&llbar; echon.  And the serpent enterid in to þe halle; And
whenne þe toode saw him come, he drow out on of his feet fro
þe brest, And after þe secunde, and so þe
thir&dtail;, And þe furtℏ.  And he sterte to þe
serpent, in þe myddis of þe ha&llbar;, And þer thei
fou&yogh;te to-geder.  And whan the kny&yogh;t sawe þis, he was
ynly glad, and cryde After his seruauntis, and seide, "helpiþ
now, helpe, helpe, a&llbar; that ben my meyny!"  And whenne þe
seruauntis hirde hire lord crye, they come in with a swift cours, and
slow the toode withe staffis and swerdis.  Tho þe serpent
ascendid in to þe brest of þe kny&yogh;t , wher as the toode had y-fasteny&dtail; his
feete; And yn þe same place wher as the toode had sette his
first foote, he drow out a&llbar; þe veny&ntail; þat was
lefte in þe kny&yogh;t, and [cast] it out afore a&llbar; men.
And þen þe kny&yogh;t commaundid to his seruaunte&yogh;,
þat þei shuld &yogh;eve swete milke to þe serpent;
And so it was y-do in dede.  And þo þe serpent drow to the
dore, and bowid doun his hede to þe kny&yogh;t, As thonkyn>ee;
him for saving of his life; And after þat þe serpent was
no more y-sey&ntail;, and the kny&yogh;t receivi&dtail; hele, And
endid faire his life.

1.1:
Dere frendis, this Emperour is the fadir o hevene; The kny&yogh;t
is euery good cristin man that lovitℏ god with perfite herte; The
serpent is our lord Ihesus Crist; And þe toode is þe
devi&llbar;.  Theise two fowte to-geder vn to þe time þat
þe toode, scil. the devi&llbar;, had ny þe victorie, In so
mocℏ þat he hadde ny take in to his power a&llbar; his peple, afore þe Advente of criste.  And þerfor,
man, do as dyd þe knyte; helpe þi lord a&yogh;enst the
devi&llbar;, by doyng of meritory werkis, and so he sha&llbar; be
confoundid.  So at þe laste þe devi&llbar; had envenemyd
a&llbar; mankynd, And lay vpo&ntail; our brestes, and hel&dtail; in
þe bond of seruitute of synne, scil. oure first faderis,
witℏ a&llbar; hire ofspringe And drowe hem to he&llbar;, vnto
þe time þat þe serpent com a&yogh;en, scil. our lord Ihesu Criste, þat sterte in to
þe crosse, and fowte þer with þe toode, and cast out
a&llbar; þe venym of synne, bi his blessid passio&ntail;.  And
þerfor we sholde &yogh;eve to him swete mylke, scil. by shewing
of goode werkis of kyndnesse, Abstinence fro synne, and almysdede; And
þenne witℏowte dowte we shu&llbar; ende faire, and have the
blisse of heve&ntail;.

Deoclician was Emperour in þe Cite of Rome, in þe
Empire of whom was a philosophre, callid Lenoppus, þe whicℏ
had bi his crafte sette vp an ymage, þe whicℏ put out an
hond with a fynger, and vp on the finger was wretyn wordis percute hic , That is to sey, Smyte here.  This
ymage stode þer long, & many a day after þe detℏ
of þe philosophre; and many come to þis finger, and Radde
the superscripcio&ntail;, but þey vndirstode it not, &
therfore þei hadde mocℏ marvaile what it shul&dtail; mene.
So in a certeyne tyme þer com a clerke of fer&rtail; contreys,
and ofte tymis he sawe þis ymage, And þis finger with
þe scripture.  And in a certeyne day he toke a shovi&llbar;, and
dyggyd in the ertℏ, vndir þe
superscripcio&ntail;.  And ano&ntail; he fond a hous of marbi&llbar;
vndir þe Ertℏ; and thanne he went dow&ntail;, and
enteri&dtail; in to the ha&llbar;, and þer he fond so many riche
iewelis and marvelous þingys, that no tunge cowde te&llbar;.
Aftir þis he sawe a bord or a table, i-sprad with ricℏ
metys y-nowe þer vppo&ntail;. thenne he lokid afer, and sawe
stonding a charbuncle sto&ntail;, the whicℏ &yogh;af li&yogh;t
ouer a&llbar; the hous; And a&yogh;enst hit sto&dtail; a ma&ntail;,
witℏ a bowe in his hond, redy for to schete.  This clerke
perceivid we&llbar; this sigℏt, and þoute, þo&yogh; I te&llbar; þis
si&yogh;tℏ whenne I am a-go hens, no ma&ntail; wo&llbar; trowe
me, And þerfore I wo&llbar; take so&mtail; of þis goode,
in tokne. he stirte to þe bor&dtail;, and tooke a faire
gil&ttee; cowpe, and put it vp; And anoo&ntail; the ma&ntail; with
þe bowe sheet to the charbunclesto&ntail;, so soore, that it
&yogh;ede on sundre, and þo was a&llbar; the li&yogh;t
ago&ntail;, And þe hous was fu&llbar; of dorknesse.  And whenne
þe clerke sawe þis, he wepte soore, for he wiste not how
to passe out, for dorknesse; And þerfore he dwelte þer
sti&llbar;, and þer he endyd his li&ftee;, &c.

1.1:
Goode men, þis ymage that is thus y-paynt, is the deve&llbar;,
þe whicℏ seitℏ euermore, Percute hic , Smyte here, that is to sey, he puttitℏ in our
hertes Erthely thingis, And bidditℏ vs take hem, but he wo&llbar;
neuer speke of hevinly thingis.  The clerke þat smytitℏ
with the shovi&llbar; bitokenytℏ þe wise men of þis
wordle, and ben advocatis, and pletouris, þe whicℏ by
sotilte and wickidnesse getitℏ þe goode of þis
wordle, and þe vanyteys of þis wordle.  And whenne thei
have geten hem with sucℏ worching, they fynditℏ many
marveilous þingis, þat is to sey, dilectabi&llbar;
þingis of þe wordle, in þe whicℏ þei haue
gret dilectatio&ntail;.  The charbunclesto&ntail; þat
&yogh;evitℏ li&yogh;t is þe yowtℏ of ma&ntail;,
þe whicℏ &yogh;evitℏ to man hardinesse to haue
dilectacio&ntail; and liking the wordly þingis.  The archer þat shetitℏ is
detℏ, þe whicℏ stonditℏ euermore redy in awaite,
for to shete his dart.  Now the clerke þanne takitℏ a
knyfe,—what is that?  the wordly man, trowin>ee; to haue
a&llbar; thingis at his owne wi&llbar;; But in that trust The archer
shetitℏ att þe Charbunclesto&ntail;, That is to sey,
detℏ shetitℏ his schotys to þe &yogh;owtℏ of man,
and smytitℏ his strengℏt, and his my&yogh;te; And
þenne lietℏ the
yowtℏ in derkenesse of synne, In the whicℏ derkenesse many
men oftyn tyme deyetℏ.  And þerefore lat vs fle a&llbar;
lustys, and a&llbar; likingys, and þenne we schu&llbar; not
faile of Euerlasting li&yogh;t, Ad quam nos
perducat, &c.

0.1:
Tytus was a wyse Emperour regnyd in þe Cite of Rome; and he
made a lawe, þat euery ded kny&yogh;t shul&dtail; be buried in
his armour and armys, And if&ftee; ony ma&ntail; weere so hardy for to
spoyle him of his armys, after þat he were y-burie&dtail;, he
shul&dtail; lese his life, with oute ony ayenst-stondyn>ee;.  So,
sirys, hit happi&dtail; with In&ntail; a fewe &yogh;eris, þat a
certey&ntail; Cite of þe Empire was biseigyd with envious men
and enemeys of þe Emperoure, in so mocℏe, þat
þe Cite was In pere&llbar;, and in poynt to be loste, Ne

I hadde not taken it out
for a tyme þe armour of the dede kny&yogh;t, ellis þe Cite

1.1:
Worshipfu&llbar; Seris, þis Emperour is þe Fadir of
heuene.  The city bisegid is þis wordle, the whicℏ is

þe Cite were in poynt to be loste, when a&llbar; þat were
afore the passio&ntail; of Criste were in þe power of þe
devi&llbar;, and my&yogh;te not helpe hem selue.  The yong kny&yogh;t
þat comytℏ to þe cite, scil. that is to sey, to
þe wordle, is oure lord, þe do&yogh;ty werrour, ihesu
criste, þat hadde noon armour, scil. manhode, vnto þe-time

es amicus Cesaris , This is to sey, Iffe þou leve him,

&yogh;it þe Iuge cowde not &yogh;eve dome him selfe, as

0.1:
Story. Betoldus regnyd a wis Emperoure yn þe Cyte of Rome; þe
whicℏ ordeynyd for a lawe, that euery woman þat tooke an
oþer man than hire husbon&dtail;, þat þei shuld be
put to perpetue&llbar; priso&ntail;.  There was a kny&yogh;t hadde a
faire wife, þat tooke an oþer vndir him, and in avowtry
was with childe; and þerfore by the lawe þis woma&ntail;
was demyd to
perpetua&llbar; priso&ntail;, In þe whicℏ priso&ntail; sche
bro&yogh;te fortℏ, and bare a faire childe, a sone.  This child
wex vnto the age of vij &yogh;ere.  The lady his modir vsitℏ
euery day gretly to sorowe and to wepe.  In a day þis childe
sawe his moder wepe; he spake to hire, and seide, "Modir, why wepist
þou?  te&llbar; me þe cause of þi sorowin>ee;."
"A!  dee&rtail; sone," quoþ she, "I have gret cause to sorowe,
and þou eke; For ouer our hedis ys passage and goyn>ee; of
peple, and þere shynitℏ the sonne in here clerenesse, and
solas þer is y-had; and þou and I buþ here in
perpetuel derkenesse, In so mocℏ þat I may not
see þe, ne þou me; And þerfore allas!  that euer I
was bore yn to þis wordle."  Thenne spake the childe to his
moder, "sucℏ Ioye or sucℏ li&yogh;t as þou spekist of,
sawe I neuer, and þerfore I knowe not what it meenytℏ; For
here in þis derkenesse I was y-bore, and þerfore if I have
mete and drynke y-nowe, it were plesing to me to
dwelle here stille, a&llbar; the days of my life.  And þerfore,
modir, I pray þe, wepe not, but make me solas and comfort, and
chere me."  In a&llbar; the tyme of this lamentacio&ntail; bitwene
þe moder and þe sone, the emperours stiward stod ouer hire
hedys, and hurd, and hadde gret compassio&ntail; and pite; and went to
þe emperour, and knelid, and praide for hire delyueraunce; and
the Emperour grantyd his bone, and soo they wee&rtail; delyuerd,
&c.
0.2:
MORALITE. Seris, þis Emperour is þe
Fadir of hevene, þat ordeynyd a lawe, that if ony woma&ntail;,

hit schul&dtail; be demyd to perpetuel priso&ntail; of he&llbar;.  And
þerfore, þou soule, if þou trespace in ony dedly

li&yogh;t, and fro þe glorie of hevene above þine
he&dtail;.  The sone þat seitℏ, as long as I may have mete

contricio&ntail; for synnes.  What doith he?  He goitℏt to

wo&llbar; vs selfe be delivery&dtail; out of priso&ntail;, we mow, And

0.1:
Story. Pompeius was a wise Emperour,
regnyn>ee; in þe cite of Rome; And he lete make a
proclamacio&ntail; þor&yogh; a&llbar; his Empire, þat he
wold make a gret genera&llbar; feste, And þat a&llbar;
poo&rtail; and Ricℏ shuld come to þat feste; For þey
shul&dtail; [not] only be wele y-fed, But also that þei shuld
have many faire &yogh;iftis. whenne the bede&llbar; hadde
y-maki&dtail; this proclamacio&ntail;, Ther lay by the wey too feble
men, a blynde And a lame.  Thoo þe blynde seide to þe
lame, his felowe, "Woo be now to me and to þe, For how may we
too do!  The Emperour hatℏ makid sucℏ a proclamacio&ntail;,
þat he wo&llbar; make a genera&llbar; feste, And who that euer
comitℏ thedir, he sha&llbar; Fare wele of metis And drinkis, And
also be avauncyd for euermore; And I am blind, and þou art lame,
And þerfore neyþer of vs may come þere."  "&YOGH;e,"
quoþ þe lame man, "I sha&llbar; shew þe
a goode wit in þis cas; and if þou wolt do after my
conseile, þou shalt not repente.  Now herken me; I am lame and
feble, þat I may not goo, but I may see, And þou art
strong and swifte of foote, but þou may not see.  Take me vpon
þi bak, and bere me, And I sha&llbar; teche þe the
ri&yogh;te way, And so we boþe shu&llbar; come thedir."  "This
is a goode conseile," seide þe blinde man, "come vp fast
vpo&ntail; my bak, and teche me þe ri&yogh;te wey, as þou
seist, and so we botℏ shu&llbar; come thedir, I trowe, as
þou seist," &c. MORALITE. Dere frendis, þis Emperour is
our lord ihesu criste, þat hatℏ y-made a genera&llbar;
proclamacio&ntail;, And a genera&llbar; feste, scil. the Ioye of
hevene, to þe whicℏ ioye he hath callid a&llbar; mankynde;
for he deniitℏ to no man þat ioy, if þey wo&llbar;
come þer to.  By þis lame or halting man buþ
vndirstond prelatis of holy chirche, as ben prechours, and
confessours; and þei ben callid lame, or halting men, for
þey have not of hire owne to lyve with, but of tythingis, and of
almys-dede of seculers.  By þe blynde man we shu&llbar;
vndirstond þe lewde seculers, þat ben blynde, yn as
mocℏ as þei conne not see the rigℏt way toward ioye; and þerfore
if&ftee; theise too men wo&llbar; come to-geder to þe feste
o&ftee; Hevene, þe blind, scil. þe lewde men, most holde vp þe laame men, scil. men of holy chircℏ,
thoro&yogh; almesse offryngys, and tendingys; And that oþer,
scil. men of holy Chircℏ, most leede that oþer þe wey
by hire connyn>ee;, Clergy, and labour of techin>ee;; And
þenne shu&llbar; botℏ come thedir, scil. to þe ioye
of hevene, wher þey shu&llbar; not only have feste, but
euerlasting meede and glorie, Ad quam nos
&c.

0.1:
Adrian regnyd Emperour in þe
Cite of Rome, the whicℏ witℏinne a liti&llbar; while hadde
lost his si&yogh;t; And he ordeyned for a lawe, that þer shuld

þat hadde eny cause þat shuld be shewid, sholde ryng
þilke belle, And þe Iuge shol&dtail; come to sitte in his
seruice, with oute delay; And if any man Runge þe belle, and
hadde no cause, he shuld be ded.  So it happid in A time after
þis lawe was made, A serpent had made his nest vndir þe
Roope of þis belle, And bro&yogh;t fortℏ his briddis
þere, whenne tyme was by nature.  And after a&llbar; þis,
In a hoote day of somer the serpent toke a&llbar; his briddis with
him, And &yogh;ede in to þe feld of sporting; And while she was
absent, þer com a toode, and entrid into þe nest.  And
whenne þe serpent come a&yogh;en, she sawe þe toode
ocupied hire place; and she fo&yogh;t with the toode, but she
mi&yogh;te [not] haue þe victorie, but þat þe toode
contynuely helde hire nest; And For she sawe þat þe toode
my&yogh;te not be ouercome, she lappid hire taile aboute þe
corde of the belle, and so rang þe belle, by cause þat
þe toode vnri&yogh;tfully occupyed hire nest.  And whanne the Iuge was come dow&ntail;, as lawe was, for to sitte in
iugement, he sawe þis si&yogh;t, and &yogh;ede, and tolde
a&llbar; þat he sawe to [the] emperour.  And þe Emperour
seide a&yogh;en, "Anoon goo dow&ntail;, and sle þe toode, that
the serpent may have hire owne nest; and so he dude; And þe
serpent enterid hire owne place, and dwelte stille with hire briddis.
After þat it happid in a tyme, þat þis Emperour
wepte soore, And lordis and kny&yogh;tis þat were aboute him
come, and comfortid him, in a&llbar; that þei my&yogh;te.
"Nay," quoþ he, "howe shuld I be glad, now I have y-lost my
si&yogh;t?"  And soone after þat þe Emperour had made
þis lamentacio&ntail;, þe forseide serpent enterid in to
hys chambre; And whenne þe Emperours seruauntis sawe þe
serpent, þei tolde it to the Emperour.  tho seide the emperoure,
"I charge you, that no
man lette hire to come to me, for y trowe þat she sha&llbar; do

emperours bedde, and att þe last þe serpent openyd his

emperour receivid his si&yogh;t.  And a&llbar; men thonkid god,
þat so hatℏ comfortid þe emperour by þe
serpent, for whom he late sle þe toode, &c.

1.1:
This Emperour may be y-Callid emperour, þe whicℏ hatℏ
y-made a lawe, or a goode life, that a be&llbar; shal be y-Roung.
This be&llbar; is not ellis but consciens, þe whicℏ
owitℏ to be Rounge a&yogh;en vicis.  And þenne þe
Iuge, scil.  Reso&ntail;, owitℏ to come do&ntail;, when

v. Inwittis; For but if þat were y-do&ntail;, we shulde be in
grete peryl, as þe Aposte&llbar; seitℏ, Omne quod fit contra conscienciam, edificabit ad ignem
gehenne , This is to sey, A&llbar; that is y-do&ntail;
a&yogh;enst conscience, bilditℏ toward þe fire of helle.
And for to speky&ntail; gostely, a man is ofte tymys blin&dtail;
thor&yogh; dedly synne, þat lettitℏ his si&yogh;t; And
þat is gretly to sorowe for, as dude the emperour.  The serpent,
þat bilditℏ vndir þe belle, is our lord ihesu Criste,
þe whicℏ bilditℏ in a perfite herte, vndir a clene and
an holy conscience; And per he genderitℏ, scil. bringitℏ
fortℏ goode vertuys.  And he goithe by the medewe , scil. out of sucℏ a conscience,
witℏ his briddis, scil. vertuys, whenne it is infecte; And þenne comitℏ a toode, scil. þe deue&llbar;,
and entritℏ into þe nest, scil.  þe herte of þe
synner.  But thenne þe serpent comytℏ a&yogh;en, scil. our
lord, whenne þat he hatℏ pyte of our wretchidnesse; Thenne
he comitℏ, and knockitℏ at þe dore of our hertys, as
it is wretin in the gospe&llbar;, Ecce sto ad
Hostium, et pulso; si quis michi apperuerit, cenabo cum illo, et ipse
mecum , This is to sey, I stond at þe dore, and knocke;
who þat openitℏ to me, I sha&llbar; sopye with him, And he
with me.  But allas!  for þis toode, scil. þe deve&llbar;,
regnyd in þe hertis of many so stronglye por&yogh; hir continuaunce of synne, and not doyng
penaunce, that god may not come yn,—what is Remedye
þerfore?  Forsotℏ for to drawe at þe corde of
þe grace of god, scil. for to aske grace, And for to sette
þe conscience in to a clere way; And þanne shal god entre
into þyn herte, And he schalle &yogh;eve to þe a stone,
scil. vertue, bi þe whicℏ þi soule sha&llbar; have
li&yogh;t, Ad quam nos perducat.  Amen.

0.1:
Folliculus was a wise Emperour regnyd in þe Cite of Rome; He was
mercifu&llbar;, and ri&yogh;twis in his werkis, And he made a worthi
tour in þe Eest, In þe whicℏ he put a&llbar; his
tresour and precius Iewelis; And þe wey toward þe Cite was
stony, þorny, and scroggy; And iij. armyd kny&yogh;tys were in
þe same wey, to fi&yogh;te with a&llbar; þat euer come in
þat wey to þe forsaide cite.  And þe forsaide
Emperour made a proclamatio&ntail;, þat if þer were ony
man þat wolde goo to þe cite by þat wey, and
ouercome þoo þre kny&yogh;tis, Whenne he come to the cite,
he shulde haue habundance of a&llbar; maner richesse & iewels, at
his owne wille.  And after þis he made to be sette in þe
nortℏ an oþer Cite, in þe whicℏ he had ordenyd a
perpetue&llbar; peyne, And alle maner iewelis; And the wey to
þis Cite was faire, and swete to smelle, and dilicius to goo
Inne; And in þis wey were iij. kny&yogh;tys, for to refresshe,
and calle to gestenyng or to ostery, A&llbar; þat went by the
wey.  And þe Emperour lete make a proclamacio&ntail;, that if
ony come, and entrid into þe Cite, he shuld be bound
hond and foote, and cast into prisone, and abide þere vnto
þe comynge of þe Iustice, for to stond to his dome.  Nowe
þer dwelte In a cite twey kny&yogh;tis, þat hi&yogh;te
Jonathas and Pirius.  This Jonathas was a wise man, and Pirius was a
foole, but grete love was bitwix hem too.  In a day Jonathas seide to
Pirius, "Deere frende , þer is y-made
a proclamacio&ntail; bi a&llbar; þe empire, þat þe
Emperour hatℏ sette a cite, in þe whicℏ is a&llbar;
his tresoure; And if ony man may entre into it, he sha&llbar; have
gret multitude of tresoure; And þerfore it is my conseile that
we goo to þis Cite."  "Forsotℏ," quoþ Pirius, "it is
goode conseile, And I assent þerto, that it be do."  Thenne
þe wise kny&yogh;t spake, "If so be þat þat þat þou wolt do
after my consaile, I pray the lat me drinke þi blode, and
þou shalt drinke myne, in tokening that neiþer of vs sha&llbar; forsake oþer, In wele ne in
woo."  "I assent," quoþ þe fole kny&yogh;t.  And so they
were lete blode, and eyþer dranke of otheris bloode, and so
þei &yogh;ede theire way.  And whan thei had made þe
iourney of iij. days toward þis cite, in whicℏ þey
sholden finden þe tresour, þei come in a certay&ntail;
place, where were twey weyes to be chosen, scil. that on stony and
thorny, And that oþer specius and faire, sett aboute withe
lileis and Rosis.  Tho spake þe wise man, "loo!  here ben two
weyes, as þou seist; Neuertheles, if we goo by this stony &
scourgy wey, it shal lede vs to þe plenteuous cyte þat we
desire."  "&YOGH;a, ser," seide þat oþer, "I have greete
mervaile of you, For I trowe more to myne owne yen than to your
wordis.  For I see wel, and so may &yogh;e, þat
þis wey is stony, and
vnesy for to goon; and as I haue y-hurde say, there ben in it iij.
Armyd men, for to turne vs, or to fi&yogh;t with vs, if we come
þerin; And þerfore y do þe to knowe, þat I wol
go by þis wey, and not by þat."  "Certayne," seide
þat oþer, "and if we go by þat wey, we shal be led
into þe Cite that is in þe nortℏ, where as is no
mercy, but gret sorowe and care, to a&llbar; þat goitℏ
þerto."  "&YOGH;e, &yogh;e," quoþ þe foole,
"þis whicℏ I see opynly wol I trowe more than sucℏ;
And þerfor I wo&llbar; algatis holde it."  Tho spake þe
wise man, "Now sitℏ I dranke þi bloode, in tokne of
frendship, forsotℏ I wo&llbar; not late þe goo a&llbar;
one, what so euer happe with me in tyme to come."  So þes too
kny&yogh;tis &yogh;ede fortℏ on þis wey; And
anoon iij. kny&yogh;tis mette witℏ hem, And receivid hem
worshipfully, and servid hem as for oo ny&yogh;t; And on þe
morowe þey arose, and tooke hire wey toward þe forsaide
Cite of the norþ.  And anoon as þei were with Inne
þe Cite, the Cachepollys And the mynistris of the Emperour mette
with hem, and seide, "Siris, what doo &yogh;e here in þis cite?
For it is long a-gon sitℏ &yogh;e wel knewe what was þe
lawe of þis place, And þerfore, seris, &yogh;e most haue
þe lawe."  Anoon þei bond the wise kny&yogh;te, and put
him in priso&ntail;; and þe fond kny&yogh;t þei cast in a
dicℏ place.  And so it happid after a&llbar; this, þat
þe domys-man come to þe Cite, for to sitte vp o&ntail;
brekers of þe lawe.  And anoo&ntail; a&llbar; þat were in
priso&ntail; apperid afore þe Iuge, Amon>ee; þe
whicℏ come þes too kny&yogh;tis, þat is to sey,
þe wise kny&yogh;t and þe lewde, scil. the wise
kny&yogh;te out of priso&ntail;, And þe lewde kny&yogh;te out of
þe dicℏ.  Anoo&ntail; the wise man seide, "Sir, I make
he&rtail; complaynt vpo&ntail; my felowe, and sey that he is cause of
my detℏ.  For whenne bothe we we&rtail; atwene þe too weys,
þat is to sey, bitwene þe Cite of þe Eest And
þis Cite, I tolde to my felowe the peri&llbar; of þis
Cite, And þe profit of þat oþer; And he wolde not
trowe me, but seide, that he trowid mo&rtail; to his owe&ntail;
ye&ntail; þan to me; And for he was felawe, I wold not late him
goo by him selfe, but come with him; And þerfore, sir, I say
þat he is cause of my detℏ."  Thenne spake þe lewde
kny&yogh;te, and saide, "sir he is gilty of my detℏ, and I
sha&llbar; te&llbar; you cause why.  For &yogh;e knowe wele
echo&ntail;, that I am a foole, And he is a wise man, And
þerfore he shold not so li&yogh;tely haue levid my lewdenesse,
but I-goo þe goode wey; For if þat he had lefte þat
wey, I wold at þe last haue folowid him."  Then spake the Iuge,
"For þat þou so li&yogh;tly consentedist to his
lewidnesse, And þou, foole, for þou woldist not folowe
þe consaile of þe wise man, Therfore I deme yowe bothe to
be hongyd."  and so it happid in dede; And a&llbar; men hiely commendid þe Iuge, þat
&yogh;afe so rightfully a doom, &c.

7.1:
MORALITE. Siris, þis
Emperour is to vndirstond our Lord ihesu crist.  The Cite in þe
Eest is þe kyngdom of hevene, In þe whicℏ is tresour
vntold, But to þis Cite is a þorny wey and a sharp,
scil. penaunce and tribulacio&ntail; in erþe; For it is
wrety&ntail; thus , Arta et angusta est via que ducit ad
vitam , This is to sey, Strait and disesy is þe wey
þat leditℏ to life.  And in þis ben kny&yogh;tys
iij. scil. þe flesℏ, þe wordle, and þe
devi&llbar;, with þe whicℏ þou most fi&yogh;t, and
haue þe victorie, or thowe come to Hevene.  By þe Cite in
þe Northe is vndirstond He&llbar;, As it is wretin, Pandetur omne malum , This is to sey, fro þe
nortℏ sha&llbar; be shewid a&llbar; Ive&llbar;.  And to þis
Cite in þe nortℏ, þat is to vndirstond Helle, is a
broode way, And is bisette with many thingis dilectable; And by
þis wey goitℏ many.  By þe iij. kny&yogh;tis
þat ben in þis wey, þat fyndith necessarijs, ben
vndirstond pryde of lyfe, Couetise of ye&ntail;, And Couetise of
flesℏ, by þe whicℏ iij. a wrecchid man is gretly
delitid for þe tyme, And lad to the
Cite of Helle, þat is fu&llbar; of sorowe.  And by þe
ij. kny&yogh;tis, scil.  þe wise man and þe lewid man, ben
vndirstonde þe soule and þe flesℏ; For þe soule
is wise, and þe flesℏ is euer lewid, and buxom to do Evil.
Theise ij. ben felowis, & fastenyd to-geder, for to stonde to wele
or to wo.  The soule chose þe wey of penaunce, And in a&llbar;
þat it may, it steritℏ the flesℏ þerto, But
þe lewde flesℏ, þat hatℏ no mynde of perilis
þat ben to come, takitℏ dilectacio&ntail; of the wordle,
and fleitℏ þe way of penaunce; So þat in tyme of
detℏ þe soule is y-bondo&ntail; in þe prisone of
helle, And þe flesℏ is castyne in to a dicℏ, scil. a
grave or a burye&llbar;.  And when þe domys-man, scil. our Lord
ihesu crist, comytℏ to deme, Than þe soule sha&llbar;
pleyne vpon þe flesℏ, And þe flesℏ vpo&ntail;
þe soule, But þe domys-man, that wo&llbar; not be stoppyd
for prayer ne for mede, Sha&llbar; þanne dampny þe soule,
for she folewid þe instigacio&ntail; of þe flesℏ, And
the flesh, for it wolde obeye and triste to þe soule.  And
þerfore late vs study to tame our flesℏ, þat it obey
vnto god, And so by argument we shu&llbar; haue euerlastyng life In
blisse.  God graunt vs þat of his endeles mercy! Qui cum patre, &c.

0.1:
Story. Fredrericus was a wise Emperour, regnyn>ee; in
þe Cite of Rome, the whicℏ hadde a faire douter; And whanne
þe Emperour was in his detℏ-bedde, he bequathe to his
dowter a&llbar; his Empire.  So what tyme þat a Certayne Erle
hurde of this, after þe detℏ of þe Emperour, he come
to þe dameselle, and sterid hire to synne, and anoon the
dameselle enclined to his wordis.  So whanne þe dameselle was
filid with synne, he put hire out of hire Empire; And þan she
made lamentacio&ntail; more than ony man can trowe, And &yogh;ede into
an oþer kyngdome or cuntre.  So it happid in a certayne day, as
she sat in hire sorowe and weping, she sawe afer comyng to hire-ward a
faire yong kny&yogh;te, sitting vp on a faire hors; & come to
hire, and salowid hire, and askid of hire þe cause of hire
sorowe.  Thanne saide she, "My worshipfu&llbar; lord, I haue gret
cause to sorowe.  I am come of gret blode & Ria&llbar;; the
Emperour was my fadir, and when he deyde, he made me his ey&rtail;,
for he had no moo children þan me.  Whan he was ded, þer
come a kny&yogh;t, and spoiled me of my virginite; and after þe
synne, he put me out of myne heritage, In so mocℏ that I aske
nowe my brede fro dore to dore; And, lording myne, if it be your
wille, þis is þe cause of my sorowe."  Tho spake þe
kny&yogh;t, and saide, "Now sotℏly, damyselle,
þis is yve&llbar; I-do, and grete compassio&ntail; I haue on
þe; And þerfore, if þou wolt graunte to me oo thing,
sotℏly I sha&llbar; fi&yogh;te for thyne heritage, and behote
þe the victorie."  "A!  lord, alas!"  quoþ she "for I have
nothing to &yogh;eve þe but my selfe."  "And I aske noon
oþer of þe, but that þou be my love, and love
no&ntail; so wele as me."  And þenne saide she, "&YOGH;is, lord,
and þat I behote the."  Thenne spake he, "&YOGH;it I wo&llbar;
haue an oþir certayne of þe, as þis: If it happe me
to dye for þe in bati&llbar;, and not to have victory, þat
þu sette out my blody serke on a percℏ afore, for twey
skilis; the first is, þat þe si&yogh;te of my serke may
meve þe to wepe, as ofte tyme as þou lokist þeron;
The secunde skile is, for I wo&llbar;, that whenne ony man comytℏ
to þe, for to haue þe to wife, þat þou renne
to þe serke, and biholde þe serke, and sey to þi
selfe, "god forbede þat euer I sholde take ony to my husbond,
after þe detℏ of þis lord, whicℏ deyde for my
loue, and Recoueryd myne heritage!'"  And þenne saide þe
lady, "My worshipfu&llbar; sir, a&llbar; þis, with þe
grace of god I sha&llbar; fu&llbar;fi&llbar;."  And when þe
kny&yogh;te hurde þis, he &yogh;afe Bataile a&yogh;en the Erle, and hadde
þe victory. Neuertheles he gate his detℏ ther, and
biquaþ his serke to his love, for whom he deyde,
commaundyn>ee; þat she shold holde covenaunt.  Thenne whan she
hurde of his detℏ, She made grete lamentacio&ntail; many days;
But whenne she sawe his blody serke, a&llbar; her bowelis weere
troubelyd more than tunge may telle; And hongyd it vp on a perche in
hire chambir, And at euery tyme þat she lokid on þe serke,
she wepte fu&llbar; sore.  The lordis of þe lond,
seying howe the Empire was wonne, To hire they come, and wolde have
I-hadde hire to wife.  Thenne whenne she had enteryd þe chambir,
and sawe þe blody serke, she seide with a lamentabi&llbar; voys,
"Allas!  þat I shold take ony husbond, after þe lord that
daide for me, And wan myne heritage!"  And so she answerid to a&llbar;
þat come to hire for that erende, and fay&rtail; endid hire
lyfe, &c.
0.2:
MORALITE. Deere frendis, þis Emperour is
þe fadir of hevyn.  Þe only dou&yogh;ter, that is so faire
and so fresh, is þe soule of man, þat is made to his owne
likenesse, to whom god hatℏ &yogh;evin and bequeþon his
Empire, þat is to sey, paradise.  But þenne comitℏ an
Erle, scil. þe devi&llbar;, and excityþ hire to synne, As
whenne he saide, Quacumque hora inde comederitis,
eritis sicut dii , This is to sey, In what houre þat
&yogh;e ety&ntail; of þis frute, &yogh;e shu&llbar; be as
goddis.  And so, for brekin>ee; of þe commaundement of god, we
were a&llbar; y-put out of the heritage of paradise into þe
kyngdome of þe wordle, and þat in gret wrecchidnesse, as
scripture shewitℏ, In sudore vultus tui
&c. But þenne comitℏ a wele faire
kny&yogh;te and a strong, scil. þat is to sey, our lord ihesu
crist, þe whicℏ hadde compassio&ntail; of mankynde; and he
drowe matrimony with vs, þat is to say, whan þat he tooke
our kynde, and hayl&dtail; batail a&yogh;enst the devi&llbar;, and
gate our heritage.  And þerfore, seris, late vs do as dude
þe dameselle, late us [honge the] serke, scil. a fresh mynde, vp
o&ntail; þe perche of our herte, scil. to sey howe þat our
lord ihesu criste shadde his bloode for vs; And þenne if ony,

Story. Appolanius regnyd in Rome, þe whicℏ maade to

smitℏ in þe Cite, that was y-callid Focus, þe

and &yogh;ede to þis ymage, and saide, "Sey þou, felawe,

sent messagers to him in þe same day, as he was y-wonyd afore,

þe."  "Takitℏ," quoþ þe ymage, "Focus, þe

may not help hym; hym selfe, wherfore, by wey of kyn&dtail;, I am
beholde&ntail; holde to help hym; therfore
thise ij. pens I yel&dtail; to hym for his sustenaunce.  ¶ Also I
lene ij. pens to my sone, [by] supplied from Cambridge MS the whiche [he] supplied from Cambridge MS is
susteyne&dtail;; that whan I come to age, or to poverte, he that he may *helpe me, and omitted yel&dtail; me thise ij. pens agayne, as
I do to now to my fadir.  ¶ Also ij.
pens I lese, and that is on my wy&ftee;."  ¶ The Emperour
sai&dtail;, "Whi on thi wy&ftee;?"  he sai&dtail;, "Where *her&dtail;
ye sawyst thou ever of wyf, but but that she wol&dtail; have one of thise *thre;
First she wille in any wise ij. other she
wolde have her owne wille, or els ellys
she wolde be contrary to her husbon&dtail;, or els omitted hoote of complexio&ntail;; and therfore
what what so I yeve her, I lese.  ¶
Also ij. pens I spende on my sel&ftee;, in mete and dryn&ktee;, and
that is lite&llbar; I-nougℏ."  Than the Emperou&rtail;
sai&dtail;, "*For sothe omitted thou hast
aunswere&dtail; wisely."  And so he was excuse&dtail;.  Sone after
that, the Emperour die&dtail;, ¶ And Foke, the Smytℏ, was
chosen to be omitted Emperour, by cause
that omitted he so profitably ha&dtail;
spende&dtail; his thes viij. pens, and so
afterwar&dtail; he die&dtail; in pease. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperou&rtail; is oure lor&dtail;
Ihesu Crist, that made this lawe, that every man shul&dtail; halow the
holyday.  By virgile, that made the Image, to sey trouthe, Is
vndirston&dtail; the holy gost, that reisetℏ vp the prechour for
to preche, and shew vertues and vices, so that he neither spare nother
riche ne poore, hye ne low.  ¶ But now, yf the prechour say trouthe agay&ntail; synne, ano&ntail; he is that that
thretetℏ and manasetℏ by the enemyes of crist, that are
wikke&dtail; men, that neither love go&dtail;, ne her
Eme-criste&ntail;.  ¶ Wherfore the prechour may say trewly in
thise daies that was write&ntail; in the forhede of the ymage, Tymes
are chaunge&dtail;, that is, fro wikkednesse into worse.  For olde
tymes were wonte to be to vs more profitable than thei be now.  And
men are now made worse; for thei were wonte to be deuoute, meke, and
buxome, and now thei are deuoute in crewelnesse, and have no mercy.
¶ And therfore who so saietℏ trouthe in thise daies, he
sha&llbar; have a broke&ntail; hede.  ¶ Wherfore it is necessary
that arme&dtail; men stonde before the ymage, that is, the
prechou&rtail;.  Tho are goode werkes in every prechour or prelate of
holy chircℏ; And yf it be so, than dare he not drede,
sithe&ntail; thei have go&dtail; and trouthe before hem.  For as the
Apposte&llbar; saitℏ, yf gode be with vs, who is agay&ntail; vs?
¶ Foke, the Smytℏ, that wrought as every goo&dtail; cristen
man, that every day owetℏ for to werke meritorie werkes, and so
offre hym before the Fadir of heve&ntail;.  ¶ This Foke,
Smytℏ, yelde&dtail; ij. pens to his fadir.  ¶ Right so we are holde&ntail; to yel&dtail; ij. pens
to the Fadir of heven, that is, love and worshippe; for whan we
are were ? childre&ntail; of losse and
perdicio&ntail;, and in servage of the fende, he sent his sone only to
bye vs agay&ntail;; sicut habetur in euangelium,
Sic Deus dilexit mundum, &c. Foke, the Smytℏ, lent ij. pens to his sone.  This
ij. pens are ou&rtail; goode werkes, that is, wille and meritorie
dedes; whiche ij.  werkes we owe&ntail; to lene to Ihesu Crist in this
ly&ftee;, that he may yelde vs atte day of dome, whan the body
witℏ the soule sha&llbar; be glorifie&dtail;, that he be our
sone.  ¶ It is writte&ntail; in ysaie the prophete, a childe is
borne to vs, and a childe is yeve&ntail; to vs.  This childe Ihesus
sha&llbar; yel&dtail; this ij.  pens; he sha&llbar; shew to our bodely
eye his blisse&dtail; manhede glorifie&dtail;.  And the othe&rtail;
peny is the sight of oure soule, his glorious godhede, the whicℏ
sight sha&llbar; never faile, but ever be ioye and blisse, bothe to
the body and to soule.  ¶ Also Foke, the Smytℏ, lost
ij. pens on his wy&ftee;.  This wy&ftee; is thyne owne flessℏ,
the whiche thou maist not forsake.  The ii. pens, that thou lesest on
thi flessℏ, is eve&llbar; delectacio&ntail;, and consent to
synne, in as moche as the flessℏ is alway contrarie to the
spirite, and redy alway to eve&llbar;.  ¶ Also he spent ij.  pens
on hym sel&ftee;, for his liflode.  by the first peny is
vndirston&dtail; penaunce for synne, by the whicℏ the soule is
glade&dtail;, and in heve&ntail; glorifie&dtail;.  By the secon&dtail;
peny is vnderston&dtail; goode perseveraunce, the whiche thou owest to hol&dtail; a&llbar; thi
ly&ftee; tyme; For as the Aposte&llbar; saitℏ, he that is
perseveraunt in goode werkyng, vnto the ende, he sha&llbar; be
sau&ftee;.  ¶ And yf ye spen&dtail; thise ij.  pens thus, as Foke
di&dtail;, ye sha&llbar; have everlastyng ly&ftee;.  To the whiche
brynge vs he that reignetℏ in blisse witℏ oute&ntail; ende!
Amen.

0.1:
Story. Lenoppus was a wise
Emperour, and regnyd in Rome; And among a&llbar; othir vertuys he was
mercifu&llbar; And for grete pyte he maade a lawe, that euery man
þat were blinde, shul&dtail; haue an Cs.  Hit happid, þat
xiiij.  felawis were gon to-gedre to þe Cite of Rome out of
þe cuntre, for noon oþer cause, but only for to drinke
wyne.  And whenne þei were sette in the Tauerne, þei
cessi&dtail; neuer drinking by þe space of iij. days or iiij,
and dronke more be mocℏ þan þei hadde money to pay
for.  At þe last the tauernere askid
his payment, and saide, þat noo&ntail; of them shuld passe, til
tyme þat he were pay&dtail;. Thenne spake oo&ntail;
of þe drinkers, and saide to his felowis, "Seris, I can
te&llbar; you a goode conseil in þis cas.  &YOGH;e wete wel, it
is þe lawe of the Emperour, þat euery blind man shuld haue
to his tresour an Cs; And þerfore, seris, lat vs drawe cut, and
drawe out his yen, on whom the cut wol falle; And þenne he may
go to þe palys, & aske an Cs by þe Emperouris lawe,
and qwite vs a&llbar;."  And whenne the other men hurde þis,
they were rigℏt glad, and seide, þat it was goode conseil.
And þei drowe cut; and it felle vp on him þat &yogh;afe
þe conseil.  Thenne his ye&ntail; were don out; and so he wente
to þe Emperouris stiward, and askid an Cs.  "Nay," quoþ
þe senescal, "for þou haddist goode si&yogh;t
&yogh;isterday; nay, felowe, þou vndirstondiste þe lawe
wrong.  The lawe is I-sette for hem þat ben made blinde by
infirmite, or by þe wi&llbar; of god; And þou haddiste ij.
yen in þe tauerne, and nowe þou hast don hem out only by
þi selfe.  go a&yogh;en to the tauernere, and accord with him as
þou may, for sotℏly þou shult of me haue neyther jd,
ne obolus, ne quadrans."  He &yogh;ede a&yogh;en to his felowis, and
tolde hem howe the stiward seide to him. Whenne þe
tauerner hurde þis, he spoiled him of all his clothis, and bette
him soore, and so lete hem a&llbar; go witℏ gret confusio&ntail;,
&c.
0.2:
MORALITE. Deere Frendis, þis Emperour is
our Lord iesu crist, þe whicℏ hatℏ maade a lawe,
þat ecℏ man þat is blind, scil. euery erþely
man that synnytℏ, by instigacio&ntail; of þe devi&llbar;,
of þe wordle, or of þe flesℏ, that if he be sory for
his synnys, as blind men ben for hire dorkenesse, he shalle haue an
Cs, þat is to sey, an hundride sithis ioy of victorie; as he
seyithe, Centuplum accipietis, et vitam eternam
possidebitis, vt supra .  And so is a synner callid blind. The felowis that comytℏ to þe tauerne, er synners,
þat gon ofte tyme to the tauerne of þe devi&llbar;, And
drinkitℏ, scil. wastitℏ & consumytℏ a&llbar;
þe vertuys þat þei Receivid in Baptisme; And so the
devi&llbar; spoilitℏ hem of a&llbar; the goodis that they haue y-do&ntail;.  They drowe cut,
scil. dilectacio&ntail;, and custome of synne; And þe sort of
synne fallitℏ vp on him that is with oute ri&yogh;twisnesse or
mercy.  Suche a ma&ntail; is wilfully blynde, as was Judas, that
betrayd crist, his lord, withoute ony suggestio&ntail;; And
þerfore his synne was þe moo&rtail;.  And þerfore when sucℏ on comitℏ to þe stiwarde,
scil. prelatis of holy chircℏ, he may not li&yogh;tly haue
grace.—Why?  For þey ben not in þe wey to leve hire
synne.  And þerfore late vs not synne wilfully; but if we synne
by sikenesse, or frailte, anoon late vs with shrifte, and
contricio&ntail;, and fulfilling of penaunce, do it away, to haue
remissio&ntail; of our synnes, And ioy perdurable, þat graunte
vs þe lord, Qui cum patre, &c.

10.1:
[Second Version. IV.] Addit. MS. 9066. Story. Teucippus reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, the whiche amonge
other vertues that he ha&dtail;, he was mercifu&llbar;; wherfore of
grete mercy he ordeyne&dtail; a law, that every blynde man shul&dtail;
have an hundre&dtail; shelynges of his tresoure.  ¶ It fille on a
tyme, that xxiiij.  men come to the Citee, for to drynke wyne; and
a&llbar; thei went into a Taverne, and there satte drynkyng iij.
daies or iiij. tille thei hadde dronke&ntail; more wyne than they
ha&dtail; money to paye.  ¶ Than the Taverne&rtail; aske&dtail; hem for his wyne, and sai&dtail;, "none o&ftee; you sha&llbar; go,
tille that I be pai&dtail;."  ¶ Than sai&dtail; one of the
drynkers, "Wille ye have a goo&dtail;
counsaile?"  And they sai&dtail;, "Ye, I pray the."  Than he
sai&dtail;, "ye know a&llbar; wele everychone, that the Emperours law
is, that every blynde man sha&llbar; have an hundre&dtail; shelynges of the Emperours tresorye.
¶ Therfore cast we lotte amonge vs, and lette se vpone whom the
lotte sha&llbar; falle, and his bothe eye&ntail; lette be put out; and
so he may go to the paleys, and after the law aske in the tresorye of
the Emperour an hundre&dtail; shillynges; ¶ And witℏ tho
hundre&dtail; shillynges we may acquyte vs a&llbar;."  Whan his
felawes hadde herde this, thei were right gla&dtail;, and saiden,
"this is right a goo&dtail; counsaile."  ¶ And so ano&ntail; thei
cast lotte, and the lotte fille vpon hym that gafe the counsaile; and
so his felishippe put out his eye&ntail;.  And whan he was
blyn&dtail;, one of his felawes la&dtail; him to the paleys; and than
he aske&dtail; of the Stewar&dtail; an hundre&dtail; shillynges, as
the law was.  ¶ The Stewar&dtail; sai&dtail;, "Frende, yisterday
thou sawe clere i-noughe, and thou knowest not how the law is made.
The law was ordeyne&dtail; only for men, that of infirmyte or of
goddes sonde were made blynde, and not for suche as have dronke&ntail;
out her eye&ntail; in the Taverne; wherfore go thi way, for here thou
shalt have no money."  ¶ The wrecche&dtail; blyn&dtail; man went to his felawes, and tol&dtail; hem this aunswere of the
Stewar&dtail;.  ¶ Whan the Taverne&rtail; ha&dtail; her&dtail;
this, he spoyle&dtail; hem a&llbar; out of her clothes; and so with
grete confusio&ntail; thei went out of the Citee, and were no more
say&ntail;. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is oure Lor&dtail; Ihesu
crist, that made this law, that every blynde man shul&dtail; have an
hundre&dtail; shillynges, that is, every man that synnetℏ of
infirmyte, or instigacio&ntail; of the fende, or of his flessℏ,
withe oute doute, yf he enterly sorow for his synne, he sha&llbar;
have an hundre&dtail; shillynges, that is, an hundre&dtail; ol&dtail;
more Ioye; ¶ Iuxta illud, Centiplum
accipietis, &c.  ¶ Therefore eche man that
synnetℏ dedely, is made blynde.  Thise men, that comy&ntail; to
the Taverne to drynke wyne, are synners, that ofte sithes gone to the
Taverne of the fende, an&dtail; drynke&ntail;; so that thei consume&ntail; all the vertues that thei
resceive&dtail; in her baptyme; wherfore the deve&llbar; spoyletℏ
a&llbar; suche of a&llbar; the goodes that thei have done.  And than
thei cast lotte, and the lotte of synne falletℏ on hym that is
witℏ out rightwisenesse and mercy, and sucℏ one is made
blyn&dtail;, that is, a synner most vile, as Iudas traitour, that betraie&dtail; crist, witℏ out any
suggestio&ntail;; and therfore he
synne&dtail; the more.  ¶ Suche, whan thei come to the
Stewar&dtail;, that is, the prelate of holy chirche, to aske the
hundre&dtail; shillynges, that is, grace; and he sha&llbar; aunswere
as the Stewar&dtail; di&dtail;, ¶ Go thi way, for thou gettest
none while thou stondest in dispaire, as Iudas di&dtail;.  Therfore
studie we a&llbar;, witℏ a&llbar; oure diligence, to please god
in a&llbar; thynge, and than we mow have everlastyng mede.  Amen.

0.1:
Polemus was a wise Emperour,
regnynge in þe Cite of Rome, þe whicℏ hadde a passyng
faire do&yogh;ter, callyd Aglaes.  Ther was a kny&yogh;t in [the]
palis, that hyely lovid þis faire may; And in a certeyne day
þis kny&yogh;t hadde a speche with hire, and shewid to hire
þe love of his herte, þat he hadde to hireward.  Whenne he
hadde maade his reuelacio&ntail; to hire, she seide a&yogh;en, That
sittℏ he openyd his harte to hire, so Sche wold openy hire herte
to him; and saide, That she hadde lovid him in privite, witℏ
prive affeccio&ntail;, bifore a&llbar; men, and þat by long
tyme.  Thenne þe kny&yogh;te was glad, and saide, "I mot visite
þe holy lond; and þerfore &yogh;if me þi truthe, and
þou shalt haue myne, that I shal not this vij. &yogh;ere haue no
wife but þe, ne þou none husbond but me þis
vij. &yogh;ere; And if I come not a&yogh;en þis vij. &yogh;ere
day, I wo&llbar; þat þou take an husbond where þe
shal best like." The maide saide, she wold consent; and þer they
pli&yogh;t hire truthe; And þe kny&yogh;t tooke his leeve, &
went his way.  Sone after þe Emperour spake with þe kyng
of hungery, for mariage to be maade bitwene his dowtyr and
him.  A day was set whanne the king shuld come and see hire; and he
com; And he was so hiely plesid witℏ hire faire perso&ntail;, and
Ientilnesse, and bewte, þat anoo&ntail; the Emperour and he were
in fu&llbar; accord, yf þe damesé&llbar; wolde assent.
The damese&llbar; was I-callid, and hire fadir sei&dtail; þus,
"Dee&rtail; douter, he&rtail; I haue spoky&ntail; with a king to be
thyne husbon&dtail;; Neuertheles I wo&llbar; in this cause knowen
þi wille.  What seyist þou?" "A!  fadir," quoþ she,
"me likitℏ the kyng fu&llbar; wele, but I beseche you for goddis loue, that &yogh;e
ordayne no man to me theise vij. &yogh;ere, for I haue avowid chastite
þis vij. &yogh;ere:" Anoon þe Emperour wrot þis
answere to þe king, and askid if he wolde abyde.  And whenne
þe king har&dtail; this, he þo&yogh;te it was but as
þe space of vij. days, he hadde so hye love to hire; and
grauntyd to abide hire.  So the vij. &yogh;e&rtail; were ycome to
þe ende; in þe last day of hem þe maide stoode in a
wyndowe of a chambir weping, and saide, "Allas!  allas!  for my love
bihi&yogh;t me for to come to-morowe fro þe holy lond, And
to-morowe is þe day of þe kinge of hungry, to haue me to
wife; And if my love come not to-morowe at his our, a&llbar; þe
love is lost þat I hadde to him!"  So whenne þe day com,
the king maade him redy to come to þe Emperour, with a gret
oost, for to wedde his dowter, as covenaunt was; And he come y-clothid
alle in purpre & bisse.  And as he roode by þe way, the
kny&yogh;te come fro þe hooly lond on a faire palfray, and roode
toward þe king.  And þe king saide to him, "Deere frend,
whens art þou, and whodir art þou boun?"  "Sir," quoth he,
"I am a kny&yogh;t of the Empire, and I come now fro þe holy
lond; And I am a seruaunt of yourys in a&llbar; þat I can and
may."  Anoon þer come a gret rayne, and shent þe kingis
clothis; and þo þe kny&yogh;t saide to þe kyng,
"Þou hast ydo&ntail; Ivel and vnwisely, for þou
bro&yogh;tist not þy&ntail; hous with þe." Thenne saide
þe king, "Myne hous is large, and maade of lyme and stone; and
how shold I haue brou&yogh;t myne hous with me?  þou spekiste
lewidly." "I trowe wel I do," quoþ þe kny&yogh;t;
"Neuerþeles &yogh;it shalt þou not fynde me a foole."  And
so þei rede&ntail; fortℏ ti&llbar; þei come to a
water; and the king knewe not þe depnesse þerof, but he
smot his hors with þe sporys, and roode in, and was ny dreynt.
The kny&yogh;t roode in þe oþer side of
þe water, and hadde no peril at a&llbar;; And þenne he
seide, "Þou were in gret peril, and þerfore þou
didist lewdelicℏ, þat þou tooke not þi brigge
with þe."  "Thowe spekist merveilously," seide þe kinge;
"My brigge is y-maade of lyme and stone, and is in lengþe
mo&rtail; than halfe a myle; howe shold I have y-brou&yogh;t it with
me?  I sey þou art a lewde man."  "In happe," saide þe
kny&yogh;te, "my foly shal turne in to wisedome."  And when þei
hadde riden a while, þe king askid what hour of þe day it
was; and þe kny&yogh;t seide, "Sir, who so lust ete, It
we&rtail; tyme for to ete; And þerfore, my lord þe king,
If þat &yogh;e wo&llbar; voche-safe to take a soppe with me, it
shal be no dishonoure to you, but rather worshup and þonking
afore the lordys of the
Empire."  "That wol I," quoþ þe king, with a goode chere,
"take mete of þe." So þey sette yn a faire grene place;
and þe king, and a&llbar; þat were with him, hadde
þere, by þe purviaunce of þe kny&yogh;t, a goode
dyner. whenne þe dyner was y-do, þe kny&yogh;t seide to
þe king, "sir, &yogh;e did lewidly, þat &yogh;e bro&yogh;t
not your fadir and your Modir with you."  "What spekist þou?"
quoþ þe king; "my Fadir is ded, and my modir is an old
wife at home?  Howe sholde I haue y-Caryed hem with me?  Forsotℏ
a mo&rtail; foole þan þou art, fond I neuer."  "Preyse at
þe parting," seide þe kny&yogh;t, "And bihold wele
þe ende."  They rode fortℏ; and whan þei drowe ny to
þe place, þe kny&yogh;t askid leeve to ryde by an
oþer way, that was ne&rtail;; And he dude in thilke entent to be
afore, and haue awey the dameselle.  But he toke his leve at þe
king in þis maner.  When he askid leeve to go, the king askid
whodir he wold go?  "Forsotℏ," seide the kny&yogh;te, "this day
vij. &yogh;ere I lefte a nette yn a certayne place; yf I fynde it
y-broke, I wol leeve it; if y fynde it cleene, and hoole, I wol take
it with me."  And so he bade þe king fare wel, and roode
fortℏ on his wey; And þe king helde þe hye way.  Whan
þe Emperour hurde of þe king, he roode a&yogh;enst him
with a grete ost, and Receyvid hym worthely; and made him to do of his
clothis, and &yogh;af him oþer.  So when þe king was sette
by þe emperour at mete, þe emperour dude him che&rtail; as
he my&yogh;te, and cowde.  Whenne þe mete was y-don, the
emperour askid tythingys of þe king; And þe king answerd,
and seide, "I shal telle you what maner talking I hurde þis day,
in the wey.  I mette with a kny&yogh;te in þe wey,
and he salewid me curtesly; and when we hadde y-ryde&ntail; awhile
to-gedre, a gret Rayne come, and shende my Clothis; and þenne
saide the kny&yogh;te, that I dude lewdely, for I bro&yogh;t not my
hous with me." "A!"  quoþ þe emperour, "what Clothing
weryd he?"  "Certenly," seide the king, "I sawe no clothing on him but
his cloke, and his hoode on his hed."  "Nowe i-wis," quoþ
þe Emperour, "he is a wise man in þat word, For þe
hous that he menyd, was þi cloke.  He seide &yogh;e dude
vnwisely, that &yogh;e vsid not your cloke, For if &yogh;e hadde on
your cloke, the reyne shuld not haue y-towchid your clothing."
"Sire," quoþ þe kinge, "we redyn further; by a casuel
happe or by chaunce I was ny dreynt in a water; and the kny&yogh;te
rood withoute, and was safe.  & whenne he sawe me in peri&llbar;
of watir, he seide to me, þat I dude lewdely, for I brou&yogh;t not my brigge with me."  "A!
by my lewte, that ma&ntail; was no fole," said the Emperoure, "for he
seid the grete wysdome; for thou shuldest, or thou haddist
auntre&dtail; thi owne body, have I-had othir to have I-go to-fore
the, and haue ypreve&dtail; the water; and that he calli&dtail; the
bryg."  "In the name of God, be it," quod the Kyng.  "And the&ntail;
we ride&ntail; forth in the wey, and he made me to dyne with hym; and
when we had ydyne&dtail;, he seid to me, that I did lewdly, that I
brougℏt not with me my sire and my dame." tho said the
emperou&rtail;, "that wise man calli&dtail; thi sire and thi dame
brede and wyne, that þou shuldest haue I-take with þe,
with oþir vitails."  Tho seid the kyng, "As we ride&ntail;
fortℏ, he asked leve of me to passe by anoþer waye; and I
asked of him whethir he wol&dtail; go, and he seid to me in this
fourme; this day seve&ntail; yere I lefte a nette in a place, the
which I wol now visite; And i&ftee; I fynd hit as I left hit, I wol
bere hit with me; and I find hit corrupt, I wo&llbar; let hit duelle
stille."  And when the emperoure hard that, he cried with an hy vois,
"Where beth any seruaunt&yogh;?  where?  rennyth fast, and lokith my
doughter in her Chamber, for with oute doute she is þe same
nette that he spake of."  The seruaunt&yogh; yede to her Chamber,
& founde no body, for the knygh&ttee; had I-fette her while
þe emperou&rtail; met with þe kyng. and so, shortly to
sey, the kyng had lost his pray, and yede home with confusio&ntail;.

11.1:
MORALITE. Sirs, this Emperoure is oure Lord
Ihesu Crist; the doughter þat is so faire is euerlasting
ly&ftee;, the which god o&ftee; his goodnesse hathe ordeine&dtail; for
kynges, knyghtis, symple me&ntail;, and pouere men.  The knyght
þat lovith this lady, this damese&llbar;, is euery good
Criste&ntail; ma&ntail;, that wole haue the kyngdome of heve&ntail;,
for love þat he hath therto; and holdith him vnworthi
þerto, as þapposti&llbar; seith, Non
sunt condigne passiones huius temporis ad futuram gloriam ,
þat is to sey, the passions and tribulacio&ntail; that beth had
in this worl&dtail; are not worthi for to haue the Ioy that is [to]
come.  ¶ The knygℏt þat goth on pilgremage
vij. yere,—what is þat?  that eche good Criste&ntail; man
owith to labou&rtail; contynuelly, as doth a pilgryme, in a&llbar; the
tyme of his lyf, in the vij. werkes of mercy; and so withoute doute he
may haue the euerlastyng ly&ftee; in blisse.  ¶ By the kyng
þat come withoute cloke, & was y-wet in þe rayne, may be vndiston&dtail; grete
me&ntail;, and mighti me&ntail; of the worl&dtail;, as beth Iustices,
Bailyfs, and othir.  ¶ By the cloke þat coverith oþer
clothis, we vndirston&dtail; charite, the which, as the Apposti&llbar;
seith, koueryth multitude of synnes; but many oon haue not this cloke
of charite, & þerfore thei beth wete, & foule&dtail;
with the ray&ntail; of pride, covetise, gloteny, and lechory.  ¶
Also the kyng was ny dreynt, for he had no bry>ee;,—what is
that?  For rigℏt as hit is hard to passe a depe water withoute a
brig, So hit is har&dtail; to be save&dtail; withoute feitℏ.  But
the&rtail; be many o&ftee; vs that wo&llbar; rathir put her lyf &
trust in to the help of the worl&dtail; þan to the help of god,
þe which is not oonly myghti but almyghty; and þerfore
seith oure saviou&rtail;, ¶ Si habueritis
fidem vt granum synapis, poteritis dicere huic monti transi, et
transiet , That is to sey, if ye haue feitℏ, as moche as
hath þe corn of synewey, ye shu&llbar; mow sey to a
mounte&ntail;, passe, and hit passetℏ at a wor&dtail; of you. but
many of vs havith fu&llbar; feble feitℏ, & þerfore many
oon fallith in to þe diche of desperacio&ntail;, & of dedly
synne.  Also the kyng had not with him his fader, neither his modir;
by the fadir, that is cause of oure generacio&ntail;, is
vndirston&dtail; mekenesse or humilite, withoute which þere
abideth no vertue in a ma&ntail;; as seith Seint Gregory, ¶ Siquis ceteras virtutes sine
humilitate portat, quasi in ventum portat , This is, who so
euer þat berith othir vertues withoute humilite, he berith hem
as in to þe wynde, or as men berith poudir in þe wynde.
The modir is hope; for as the Apposti&llbar; seitℏ, ¶ Spe salui facti sumus , We bethe made
save thorugℏ hope.  And þerfore, i&ftee; a man wi&llbar;
haue this fai&rtail; lif that euerlastitℏ, he moste leve the
brode weye, and go by a strayt waye, that is to sey, the wey of
penaunce & of fastyn>ee;; of þe which wey seith the
Apposti&llbar;, ¶ Stricta est via que ducit
ad celum, et pauci ambulant per eam , This is to sey, the wey is strayt that ledith to heue&ntail;, & few
gotℏ þerby, but many goth the brode wey, scil. flesshly
likynges, þe which ledith to helle.  & certenly suche
me&ntail; shul be deceyve&dtail;, for her goyng fro euerlastyng
li&ftee;; And þerfore, sirs, lete vs vse to loue excellently
this fai&rtail; ly&ftee;, & wisely vse the cloke of Charite, &
the bryg of the feith, þe Fadir of loulynesse in hert, the modir
of hope, the wey of penaunce and of fastyn>ee;, and then by good
argument, then shul we haue the fai&rtail; ly&ftee; that is euermore
lastyn>ee;. Ad quam perducat nos,
&c.

0.1:
Agyos was a wyse
emperoure in the Cite of Rome, and lovi&dtail; wele batai&llbar;; the
whiche had a knygℏt with him yname&dtail; Gerinaldus, a strong
man and a myghty; in the fel&dtail; he was a lyo&ntail;, and in halle
he was a lambe.  this forseid Emperou&rtail; had a fei&rtail;
doughter, the which the erle of Palester had previly ravisshede and
deflouri&dtail;; the which Erle was a grete wariou&rtail;, &
strong in batai&llbar;; and þe deflouryng of this maide
greve&dtail; the emperou&rtail; more tha&ntail; did the ravisshing
& withdrawing of her.  And to wete what were best to be do in this
cas, he made a grete Counsei&llbar; to be had; And sei&dtail; to his
lordis, "Dere Frendis, ye know wele what dispite is ydo to me by the
defloracio&ntail; and violence that is ydo to my doughter.  And þerfore I purpose to yeve batai&llbar; aye&ntail; this
Erle; And þerfore beth redy, eche man in his degre, aye&ntail;
such a day to passe with me."  "lor&dtail;," quo&dtail; thei, "we shul
be redy to ston&dtail; with you [in] ly&ftee; and detℏ."  When
thei were in batai&llbar;, there was har&dtail; stry&ftee;, and alle
the Emperours me&ntail; were yfel&dtail; to grounde, and þe
Emperou&rtail; was in poynt to be behede&dtail;; But in this
har&dtail; cas com þe forsai&dtail; knyght Gerinaldus, &
fougℏt bytwene this Emperoure and his enemys; and witℏ the
manly fightyng of him the emperoure passi&dtail; with þe
li&ftee;; but the knygℏt abode, & reste&dtail; neuer tylle he
had kille&dtail; the erle; Neuertheles he had many sore woundis, &
he fougℏt ty&llbar; the blode ra&ntail; to his fote.  When the
Aduersaries saw that the lor&dtail; was de&dtail;, thei fled awey; And
the knygℏt pursue&dtail; vnto the tyme that he come where the
emperoures doughter was y-sette; And he brougℏt her oute to the
Emperoure, her Fader; For the whiche victory and bringing agein of the
doughter, he was hily commendi&dtail; by a&llbar; the empire.  Hit
happid after this, that the knygℏt had a grete cause to be sped
in the Court of the emperoure; and þerfore the knygℏt come
to the emperoure, and praie&dtail; him to be fauorable in his cause,
in as moche as reaso&ntail; wol&dtail; suffre.  And the Emperoure went
to his Iustices, and sei&dtail;, "Goth, and yeveth rigℏt vnto
this knygℏt, as reaso&ntail; wol asky."  And when the knygℏt
had her&dtail; thes wordis, he crie&dtail; with a lowde voys, and
sei&dtail;, "Allas!  allas!  who wol&dtail; haue ytrowe&dtail; that
the emperoure wolde haue sei&dtail; this!  For what tyme þou was
in batai&llbar;, & shul&dtail; haue lost thi hede, anon I set my
sel&ftee; for the, and so thou ascapidist; now in my cause thou
sendist anoþer then thi sel&ftee;, and þerfore alas!
þat euer I was ybore, for sorowe!"  And eve&ntail; forthwith he
strepi&dtail; him, and shewi&dtail; his woundis that he had
receiue&dtail; for him in batai&llbar;, and seid, "loo!  what I haue
suffre&dtail; for the, where as I put non vnworthier thing for the
then my owne body; and now thou sendist anoþer to sit in my
cause!  Forsoth I servi&dtail; neuer suche anothir lor&dtail;!"  When
the emperoure her&dtail; þes wordis, he was confusi&dtail; in
hym self, and seid, "O!  dere fren&dtail;, this that þou seist
is sotℏ; þou savedist me fro dethe; thou keptist me, and broughtist aye&ntail;
my doughter; & þes woundis þou haddist for my love.
now, sothly, I shal come doune, & sytte for the in my
owne persone, þat shal turne the to grete ioy & comfort."
& so hit was ydo; the Emperoure discendi&dtail;, and
determyne&dtail; the knyghtes cause, in so grete plesaunce to þe
knygℏt, þat a&llbar; men commendi&dtail; the emperoure,
þat disposi&dtail; so wele for his true knygℏt.

1.1:
Good men, this emperoure may be calli&dtail; euery good Cristene
man, or els a&llbar; mankynd; the whiche hadde a feire doughter,
scil. the soule y-made to þe liknesse of god.  The erle is the
devi&llbar;, that by etyng of the appi&llbar; ravisshe&dtail; þe
soule, & deflouri&dtail; her; And so a&llbar; mankynde was in his
seruitute vnto þat þere come a strong knygℏt,
scil. oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist, þat fougℏt bytwene
þe devi&llbar; and mankyn&dtail;, when he heng on the crosse;
for i&ftee; þat had not be&ntail;, we had be loste, and
perpetuelly dampne&dtail;; and he brougℏt ayene the doughter,
scil. þe soule, for the which he suffre&dtail; smert
woundis. but then the knygℏt havith a cause to spede, scil. oure
lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist wol&dtail; fynde in vs a perfite lyf, and
þerfore he knokkith on vs eche day, that we be redy to him; for
he seitℏ, ¶ Ecce sto ad ostium, &
pulso; siquis apperuerit, introibo ad eum, & cenabo cum illo,
& ille mecum , This is to sey, lo!  I stond atte the
dore, and knok; who þat openyth to me, I shal go in to him, and
I shal sowpe with him, and he with me.  But many do&ntail; as did the
emperoure, þei settith anoþer ma&ntail;; scil. i&ftee;
thei shul&dtail; do penaunce, þei settith anoþer to
fulfi&llbar; her fawtis.  ¶ Non sic impii,
non sic , This is to sey, Not so wikked ma&ntail;, not so.
Do hit thi sel&ftee;, for god set not anoþer for þe, but
he suffred his owne bodye be woundi&dtail; for þe; And
þerfore in confusio&ntail; of vnkynd me&ntail; he hongith opynly
on þe Cros nake&dtail;, to shew hem his woundis.  And
þerfore, seres, let vs be kynd aye&ntail; & suffre for him
som penaunce or peyne, þat we be not founde&ntail; in þe
daye of dome withoute som good thing or dede; for he þat
suffrith for the loue of god any peyne in this worl&dtail;, he shal
haue þerfore an hundri&dtail; folde mede, and euerlastyng
li&ftee;. Ad quam, &c.

0.1:
Adrianus regned a wys
emperoure in þe Cite of Rome; þe which ordeine&dtail; for
the lawe, þat euery knygℏt aftir þat he mygℏt no
more vse armys, for feblenesse, he shul&dtail; be put oute of the
empire; and i&ftee; þat
he mygℏt be founde within þe empire, aftir that he were
impotent, he shul&dtail; be ded withoute pite.  There was a
knygℏt name&dtail; Porphirius, a wise man, and witty in armys
& in alle his werkys.  When he come in to age, & loste his
strengthe, he callid to him his sone, that was a knyght, & seid,
"Dere sone, thou knowest what is þe lawe of the emperoure; &
now I am feble, and may no lenger vse armys, I mote be put oute of the
empire, and þerfore I not how I shalle lyve."  then seid his
sone, "Fader, if hit happe the to dye, I am redy to dye with the.
Neuertheles in sigℏt of a&llbar; me&ntail; thou shalt entry in to
a shippe, and at nygℏt I shal previlye send aftir the; and then
we shul duelle to-gidre alle oure ly&ftee;, and non shal know
þero&ftee; but I & my wi&ftee;, þat shal servy the in
my absence."  then spake the fadir, & seid, "sone, I thonke the
moche, but i&ftee; þou do so, I drede that þou shalt be
accused, & suffre deth for me."  then spak the Sone, "fadir, drede
the not; þou shalt abide with me, and I sha&llbar; fynde the
a&llbar; the daies of my li&ftee;." then the fadir entri&dtail; in to
a Shippe, in sigℏt of folke, as who seith, now go I oute of the
empire, aftir the lawe; but in the nygℏt he come prevely agein to
his sones hous, and his sonnes wi&ftee; servi&dtail; him.  And euer
when eny Counsei&llbar; shul&dtail; be ydo in þe Empire,
þe yong knygℏt was callid þerto; and þere was
non that yaf better Counsei&llbar; tha&ntail; the yong knygℏt
did.  At þe last, lordis of the empire had grete envy of his
wisdo&mtail;, and thei seid to þe emperou&rtail;, "lor&dtail;,
wheþer the sone of Porphirie, þat yevith so wise
Counsei&llbar;, haue not þe wisdom of his ol&dtail; fader
Porphirie?  sothely, we trowith þat he hath a&llbar; of his
fadir, & þat he holdith him in þe empire in previte, þougℏ he ascendi&dtail; in to Ship; And if
hit be founde&ntail; so, he were worthi a foule detℏ."
"Hol&dtail; you sti&llbar;," quo&dtail; the Emperoure; "I trow to come
to soth of this mater wele ynow."  Anon he let calle the sone of
porphirie.  When he was come, the emperoure seid to him, "I commaund
the, vpo&ntail; peyne of thi li&ftee;, that þou bryng me thre
thynges to-morowe, that is to sey, thi best frend that þou haste
in the worl&dtail;; Thi moste comfort; and thi moste enemy."  "sir,
hit shalbe do," quo&dtail; he.  he yede home to þe castel, but
he wist not how he mygℏt haue suche thre.  He yede to his fadir,
as he was wonte to do, when he had any grete Counsei&llbar; to do, and
he askid Counsei&llbar; in this matter."  "A!"  quod þe fadir,
"a&llbar; þis is for me, for to know whethir þou holdist
me or noo; but take with the thi hound, thi litel Sone, and thi
wi&ftee;; & þou shalt make satisfaccio&ntail; to þe
wi&llbar; of the emperoure."  & so the knygℏt did; he toke tho thre, The Hound, the
Chil&dtail;, and his wife; & yede to the emperoure.  Þo seid
the Emperoure, "Hast þou ydo as I commaundi&dtail; the?"  "Yee,
sir," seid the knygℏt, "For, ser, the best frend þat I haue
in this worl&dtail; is my hounde; & þis is my cause and my
reaso&ntail;, For he wo&llbar; neuer faile me ne forsake me, in wele
ne in wo; and though I bete him as sore as I can, yit i&ftee; I profre
him brede, or any chere do to him, he wol come to me ayene with good
chere; and a&llbar; nygℏt he wo&llbar; rest by my bed, and kepe
me and my hous, þat no man greve vs; & ofte tymes I
shul&dtail; haue be robbi&dtail; & yslay&ntail;, ne had my hound
ybe.  And, sir, here is my sone, my moste comfort; & þis is
my skile, For when I am in moste anger or tribulacio&ntail;,
þe&rtail; is no iogoloure þat can make me so fast lawe, as
wo&llbar; my sone; For he wo&llbar; with his praty wordis & pleys
make me foryete my anger, þougℏ I we&rtail; as hote as
fire.  Also, ser, here I haue brougℏt my moste enemy, my
wi&ftee;; For grete labou&rtail; & thougℏt I haue in diuers
contres & places for his sustentacio&ntail;, as wele as for me
& for my childry&ntail;, & yit she is euermore contrary to my
wi&llbar;, & so is non but she."  When the wi&ftee; her&dtail;
this, she crie&dtail;, and sei&dtail; with a vois, as hit had be an
horne, "O!  wrecche, clepist þou me thi most enemy?  Sir
Emperoure, I pray you," she sai&dtail;, "here me, what I shal
sey. this ma&ntail;, that is here present, susteyneþ in thi
empire his sire, a&yogh;ens you&rtail; lawe; and in his
hous he hath duelli&dtail; sith the tyme that he was worthi to be put
oute."  And when she had put oute her venemous hert in this manere,
then seid the knygℏt, "lo!  ser," he seid, "what I tol&dtail;
you; is she not my enemy, þat accusith me so hily?  wherfore I
mygℏt be ded, but i&ftee; you&rtail; grace ordeine&dtail; othir
weys for me."  then the emperour seid, "Ne were thi wi&ftee;, I
mygℏt not haue know þe sotℏ, and þerfore
þou shalt lede thi li&ftee; with thi enemy.  Go thi wey; I
wo&llbar; not dampne the, and as long as þou levist, susteyne
thi Fadir?"  thenne the knygℏt yel&dtail; thonkyng to the
emperoure, and yede home, and feire ende made.

1.1:
Dere Frendis, this emperou&rtail; is the devi&llbar;, þat
makith lawe among synners, scil. þat eche knygℏt, aftir
that he hath passid tyme of Armys, scil. that eche good ma&ntail;
þat truly hatℏ, levi&dtail;, and kept him, & servid god
in a&llbar; the tyme of his yongith, þat he then in his elde be
put a-bak fro þe kyngdome of heve&ntail;, by the vice of
Covetice.  For that vice is more redy to an ol&dtail; ma&ntail;
þan to a yong, as we mowe se alday; and þerfore seitℏ
Seneca, Cum omnia peccata senescunt, sola
cupiditas iuvenescit , This is to sey, When a&llbar; vices
wexith ol&dtail;, oonly Covetise wexith yong, þat is
to sey, in an ol&dtail; man.  The knygℏt, þat susteyneth
his Fader, is euery good Criste&ntail; ma&ntail;, that is ybound to
susteyne in the hous of his hert, by meritory werkes, oure Lor&dtail;
Ihesu Crist, þe which heng for vs vpo&ntail; þe cros; but
many puttith him oute by synne.  Þe hounde, þat is
þe moste frende, is the tong of a good Criste&ntail; ma&ntail;,
þe which praieth continuelly, like a berkyng hound: wherof seith
holy Writ, Breuis oracio, scil. iusti, penetrat
celum , þat is to sey, A short oriso&ntail; of the
rigℏtwis ma&ntail; or o&ftee; the iust ma&ntail; thirlith or
perissheth heue&ntail;.  By the lite&llbar; Chil&dtail; þat
pleietℏ, So we shulle vndirstond a clene soule, vywassh by
baptyme; þe which pleieth and hath dilectatio&ntail; in
penaunce, by the which a ma&ntail; getith the loue of god, &
þe ioy of heue&ntail;, & by the which a man is
deliuere&dtail; oute of tribulacio&ntail; & of angir; vnde
ieronymus, whero&ftee;, as seith Jerom, ¶ Penitencia est secunda tabula post naufragium ,
þat is to sey, Penaunce is þe secunde table aftir Shipbreche.  By the wi&ftee; þat accusith the
ma&ntail;, is vndirston&dtail; the flesshe, þat bryngith many
yuels in to a ma&ntail;, & tiseth him to synne; as seith the
Apposti&llbar; paul, Datus est michi stimulus
Carnis mee, angelus sathane, vt me colaphizet , þat is
to sey, there is yove&ntail; to me a pryk of my flessh, an
aunge&llbar; o&ftee; þe devylle, to turment me; and
þerfore this flessh is to be chastice&dtail;, þat hit be
not founde in synne, in tyme of deth, lest hit be founde&ntail;
þi enemy.  And þerfore let vs study for to norissh
ou&rtail; Fadir, and hol&dtail; oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist so within
vs, þat the devi&llbar; in þe day of dome haue no
þing to putte forth ayens vs, þat may greve ou&rtail;
soulis; and then we shul veriliche trust to come to þe kyngdom
of heue&ntail;.  To þe which he vs bring, qui cum Patre &c.

0.1:
Story. Theodosius regned a wys emperou&rtail; in the Cite of Rome, &
myghti he was of power; the which emperoure had thre doughters.  So
hit like&dtail; to this emperou&rtail; to knowe which o&ftee; his
doughters lovi&dtail; him best; and tho he sei&dtail; to the eldest
doughter, "How moche lovist þou me?"  "Forsoth," "quod she,
