Story. Ancelmus was a wise emperou&rtail; regnyng in the cite of Rome;
the which edifie&dtail; in the ende of his empire a passing fai&rtail;
Caste&llbar; & sette þere a Stiwar&dtail;, commaundyng to
him, vp-peyne of detℏ, for to kepe wele þat caste&llbar;.
And this Stiward kept wele this caste&llbar; during long tyme, but at
þe last he was traitou&rtail; to þe emperou&rtail;, &
loste the caste&llbar;.  And when the Emperoure her&dtail; this, he
was hily meve&dtail; in a&llbar; his bowels, & gert make a grete
counsei&llbar;, how þat he mygℏt best gete this
caste&llbar; oute o&ftee; the hondis of his enemys.  So there ros vp a
knygℏt, and seid, þere were thre weys for to gete hit,
scil. þe wey of strength; þe wey of wisdo&mtail;; and the
wey of love.  "& suche iij. knyghtes þere beth now in
you&rtail; Empire; þe first knyght is strengist of any þat
is in any place, and he berith a scocho&ntail; of gol&dtail;, with a
lio&ntail; in þe mydde&llbar;; the second is wys, and berith a
scocho&ntail; with a pecok; & þe thrid knygℏt is
amorous & lovyng, and lovith you more þan may be
trowi&dtail;, and he berith a golde&ntail; scocho&ntail;, with a white
dove.  And, ser, by my counsei&llbar;, thes thre are to wynne the
caste&llbar; to you aye&ntail;; and þerfore sendith for hem, for
if strength be not wortℏ, wisdom shalbe wortℏ, and i&ftee;
wysdom may not do hit, love shalle gete þe victory."  The
emperou&rtail; liked welle this counsei&llbar;, and let send aftir
hem, and seid to hem, "Dere frendis, o&ftee; you thre I haue herd
spoke moche good.  ye know wele how þat my caste&llbar; is lost, therfore to
recouere hit aye&ntail; I send you thre; for the first of you is a
strong wariou&rtail;, the second a grete &yogh;ever of counsei&llbar;,
the thrid is a subti&llbar; sercher in love.  Goth to dyner, and I
shal geve you a competent mede." When þe knyghtis herd
this, thei armed hem strongly, and yede her wey.  Whe&ntail; thei had
ride&ntail; the space of iij. daies, thei come to a forest; and as
thei shul&dtail; haue entrid in to the forest, a nyghtingale sat
vpo&ntail; a tre, & made a passing swete sonet-song.  At þe
last, oon of the knyghtis spak to his felawis, and seid, "Sirs, I
vndirstond the song of this brid; the which is not ellis but a shewyng
to vs that the&rtail; ben thefes in þis forest, & þat
in grete plentith; the which haue I-her&dtail; telle that we come for
to rekeuere the caste&llbar;, & here thei purpose for to kille
vs." then seid þe strong knygℏt, "I was for my strength
sent hider, & þerfore with my strength I shal defende me."
Then spake þe wise knygℏt, "& as þou wilt defende
þe by thi strengtℏ, so shal I me by my wisdom."  Then spak
the thrid, "I am neiþer strong ne wys, as ye betℏ, and
þerfore god help me!"  Whenne þis was seid, thei entrid in to þe forest, and þei met
with her aduersaries.  So the strong knygℏt bega&ntail; to
defende him, & to figℏt manfully; but atte þe last
þere came an arowe, & smote him at þe stomak, & he
fe&llbar; dou&ntail; ded.  Whenne þe wise man saw þat, he
ga&ntail; to alegge resons, & to putte forthe wise wordis; but
thei yeve not grete heryng to his resons, but at þe last oon
smote him to þe hert, and slow him. then the thrid knygℏt
seyng this, he shet an arowe to þe maister of the thevis, &
he was ded þerby; and when þat oþer meyne saw
þat her maister was ded, thei fled.  And þe knygℏt
pursued forth to þe caste&llbar; þat was lost; and when he
come, he founde the yatis ope&ntail;.  He entrid, & slow hem that
were therin, & sette vp in a toure the baner of the
emperou&rtail;.  And when the emperou&rtail; her&dtail; telle how
wisely and strongly þat he had ywonne þe caste&llbar;, he
avaunced the knygℏt to grete honou&rtail; and richesses; þe
which bare him and shewid hym to be a doughti body in a&llbar; his
ly&ftee;, and faire ende made. MORALITE. DEre Frendis, this Emperou&rtail; is oure lord Ihesu Crist; the
caste&llbar; is paradys, the Stiward is Adam, ou&rtail; first fadir,
þat lost the caste&llbar; of paradys.  Þe iij. knyghtes,
of whom oon was strong, anoþer wys, & þe thrid
amerous, betℏ the thre kyndis o&ftee; men, to þe which god
hath commaundi&dtail; to recouere aye&ntail; Paradys, that Adam lost.
By þe strong knygℏt we moste
vndirstonde þe myghty men o&ftee; this worl&dtail;; þe
which berith a scocho&ntail; ouergilt,—how so?  For
outewar&dtail; thei shyne by hye power, and withynne
[stynkene.]—And how bere thei a lyo&ntail; in the myddis?  For
the lio&ntail; is kyng o&ftee; a&llbar; bestis, & a&llbar; men
dredith him.  And so hit is by thes myghti me&ntail;, for thei be ouer

Story. Caclides was a wys emperoure regnyng in the cite of Rome; in
þe Empire o&ftee; whom the&rtail; were two knyghtis, oon was
ol&dtail;, and þat oþir was yon>ee;.  the ol&dtail; man

weddid an ol&dtail; woma&ntail;; and botℏ thes men duelli&dtail;

this yong knygℏt had a grete y&yogh;e on the yong wif, that was
yweddi&dtail; to the ol&dtail; knygℏt, and was hily ravisshed in
to hir love; and þougℏt "þat hit had be more
conuenient me to haue had this yonge woma&ntail;, and þe
oþer man my wi&ftee;."  And in dede he spak to this yong
woma&ntail;, & she grauntid him; but she was kept, þat she
mygℏt not breke oute, to do no trespas.  So þis woma&ntail;
lokid oute oft tyme at her chamber wyndowe, for to here the swete
song that the yong knygℏt vsid to syng; and afore this wyndow
stode a feire fygge-tre, vpo&ntail; þe which a nyghtingale vsid
to sit & syng; and therfore þe yong lady vsid ofte tyme to
rise in the nygℏt to here this brid syng.  At þe last the
old man, her husbond, perceyved hit, and seid to hir, "Telle me the
cause whi þou risest so ofte fro thi be&dtail;."  "A!  ser,"
quod she, "þere is sittyng in þe tree suche a bri&dtail;,
þat syngeth swetly, and I arise to here him." & þe
knygℏt arose vp, and toke an arowe and a bowe, and shet at
þe brid, & slowe hit; & drow his hert oute, & cast
hit to her, & seid, "Take þere the hert o&ftee; him, for
whos song þou ros vp so anygℏt fro me.  And þerfore
fro hennys forwar&dtail; hol&dtail; thi be&dtail;."  When þe
yong knygℏt her&dtail; telle how that he had slawe this brid,
he thougℏt, "i&ftee; he knew how moche I love his wif, he
wol&dtail; do to me as he hath do to þe brid; but hit shal not
be so."  He armyd him, and entrid in to the hous o&ftee; the ol&dtail;
knygℏt, and slow him; & sone after his ol&dtail; wi&ftee;
die&dtail;, and þo he weddid the yong wi&ftee;. MORALITE. DEre frendis, this Emperoure is oure lorde Ihesu Crist, Fader of
heve&ntail;.  In his empire beth two knyghtes,—how so?  Þe
yong knygℏt was moyses, þat weddid the ol&dtail; wi&ftee;,
scil. þe ol&dtail; lawe, þat was byfore the natiuite of
Crist: the ol&dtail; knygℏt is ou&rtail; lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist,
the which is withoute, begynnyng; and he weddid a yong wi&ftee;, when
he made the new lawe, & fylid not þat othir, as is seid in
the gospe&llbar;, Non veni soluere legem, sed
adimplere , I come not to lose or vndo þe lawe, but to
fulfille hit.  but moyses & a&llbar; othir profit&yogh; and
patriarkes desired for to se this new lawe of Crist, and to be

The lady ros vp ofte tyme for to here the swete song of the

þe which praied his fader for vs on the
cros; and þere in þat tre was slay&ntail; by men for oure synnes.  And þerfore we shul&dtail; [wed]
his wi&ftee;, scil. his lawe, & lede þerwith pesable

&c.

made a cry, and men shal arme hem, & ayenstond vs; ano&ntail; the
yatis shulbe shit; and þerfore I wol&dtail; we had better
counsei&llbar; in þis cas, how þat we mygℏt recouere
this cite, withoute crying or makyng of noise." then spake oon, &
seid, "My lord, ye shul haue good counsei&llbar;; let vs pesibly Entre the cite, and abide there
as by space of iij. daies; and let vs cry a feste, and we shul make a
drynke of suche a vertue, that euery man that drynketh
þero&ftee; shal slepe anon aftir; and when thei beth on slepe,
we shu&llbar; haue oure desire, withoute shedyng of blode."  "This is
good counsei&llbar;," quod he.  And þerfore this knygℏt
with his meyne entrid þe citee; and thei bedde a&llbar; men to
feste, & made suche a drynke; and ano&ntail; as men dronke on this
drynke, thei slept ano&ntail;.  And while thei slept, thei
entre&dtail; the cite, and spoile&dtail; hit; and aftir that thei set
hit on fire, the which brend a&llbar; vp; but a&llbar; maner of
me&ntail; were in suche pligℏt, that þere was [none] to
crye; "fire is in the cite; go ryng you&rtail; bellis, and steke the
&yogh;atis!"

17.1:
MORALITE. Swete frendis, this Emperou&rtail; is oure lorde Ihesu Crist;
þe which ordeine&dtail; a lawe, þat as oft tyme as
þe fire o&ftee; synne is in thi soule, that thou renne swiftly
to þe belle of confessio&ntail;.  So that þere be at
leste, for reso&ntail; of the trynyte, thre bellis, scil. þat is
to sey, contricio&ntail;, confessio&ntail;, and satisfaccio&ntail;.
and aftir shit the yatis, that is to sey, thi v. wittes, that deth
entre not by the yatis.  The knygℏt, þat comyth with his
meyne, is þe devi&llbar;, the whiche goth aboute for to seche
whom he may devoure; and þerfore be ye strong in the feitℏ,
and defend you.  his folowers betℏ the vij. dedly synnes; &
he makith a feste as ofte tyme as he puttitℏ fortℏ the
vanytes of þe worlde to a ma&ntail;.  And the erthly ma&ntail;
hath so grete appetit in þe worldly vanytes, þat he
slepitℏ, scil.  hath so grete dilectacio&ntail; in hem, þat
he perceyvetℏ not the peri&llbar; of his soule. & þe
wordly drynke is perilous drynke, for i&ftee; a ma&ntail; drynke oonys
þereof, he may vnnetℏ be ful&dtail;; he faritℏ as doth
a ma&ntail; þat hath the dropcy, þe more he drynketh,
þe more he thristetℏ.  And so hit is of worldly goodis, for
þe more that a man hatℏ of hem, þe more he
covetitℏ and þerfore sucℏ me&ntail; take non hede
o&ftee; this text þat folowitℏ, ¶ Totus mundus in maligno ponitur , þat is to
sey, A&llbar; þe worl&dtail; is set in wikkednesse.  And
þerfore i&ftee; there be any suche, hit were nedeful þat
he ronne to þe bellis of confessio&ntail;.  But we see somtyme
þat bellis may not wele be yronge, for thei beth bounde so
strongly to a tre, þat they may [not] be ymeve&dtail;.  Yn
þe same wise beth tongis of synners boundy&ntail; by the
Deuy&llbar;, þat thei may not be yshrive&ntail;.  The Devil doth
as dotℏ thefes; for if thefes here berkyng of houndis, thei
castith hem brede or flessℏ, & so thei leve berkyng; and so
the thef entritℏ þe hous, and holdith men by the throtis,
þat thei cry not for help; & doth oute the fire, vnto
þe tyme thei haue sped o&ftee; her pray.  So þe
devi&llbar; castith fortℏ a delectacio&ntail; or a
þougℏt in to a ma&ntail;, and makith him to thenk thus,
&YOGH;a, I am yong ynow, I may a&llbar; in tyme Shryve me, when I am a lite&llbar;
elder.  And so the man rennytℏ not to confessio&ntail;; For
i&ftee; he do, he takith him by the throte, scil. he puttith in him
shame, that he sha&llbar; not shrive him, and with þat the fire of devocio&ntail; is
slaked.  And þerfore, dere Frendis, let vs fle fro this thef
þe devel, for we knowith not in what hour that the&ftee;, scil.
deth, shal come vpo&ntail; vs, in age or in yongitℏ; and
þerfore let vs euer be redy with the virgynes þat toke
oyle, scil. meritory werkys, and so we mow come to the blisse aboue. Ad quod nos perducat qui viuit & regnat
&c.

0.1:
Andronicus was Emperou&rtail; of Rome, & regne&dtail;
the&rtail; mighty in power: and he had with him a knygℏt,
name&dtail; Temecius, the which was rightwis and good; Neuertheles by
enemys he was accuse&dtail; grevously to þe emperou&rtail;, the
which mygℏt yeve noo sentence ayenst him.  And when the
Emperou&rtail; saw this, he thougℏt how and by what manere
þat he mygℏt grive or noy him; and þerfore he clepid
him to him, and seid, "Dere Frende, þou shalt answere to certein
questions, þe which I shal put vnto the, and þat in peyne
of thi lyf."  "Sir," quo&dtail; þat othir, "I shal do a&llbar;
þat I can or many."  "Telle me how moche is fro heve&ntail; to
helle?  þis is my first questio&ntail;."  "Sir," quo&dtail; that
othir, "as mocℏ as is a sighing fro the hert."  "The second I
aske, how depe is þe See?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "as is
þe cast o&ftee; a stone."  "The thrid, how many galons o&ftee;
salte water be&ntail; in the See?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "let
a&llbar; þe outepassinges o&ftee; fressh water be stoppid, &
I sha&llbar; te&llbar; the."  "The iiij. of what crafte or of what
myster beth moste me&ntail;?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "of
leche-crafte."  "The v. o&ftee; whom beth moste and fewist?"  "Sir,"
quo&dtail; he, "o&ftee; popys."  Then seid the Emperou&rtail;, "The
vj.th shal distroy him;— how many daies iourney beth in þe
sercle of the worl&dtail;?"  then spake [he], "oonly the space o&ftee;
oo day." "now, what difference is bytwene riche and pouere?"  "but
rychesse," quo&dtail; þat othir.  Whenne þe emperou&rtail;
had her&dtail; a&llbar; thes wordis, he seid, "Þou answeredist
to my first questio&ntail;, & saidist, þat heve&ntail; was
fro helle as moche as is a sighyng fro þe hert; te&llbar; me now
how may þat be?" "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "for in turnyng of an y&yogh;e
comyth a syghing fro the hert, &, ser, in so lite&llbar; space may a
good soule passe to heve&ntail;, & a dampnyd soule to helle."
"what is þe depnesse of the See?"  "ser, I sey, the cast of a
sto&ntail;; for eche hevy thing naturely descendith, & for
þe stone is hevy and ponderous, þerfore he wo&llbar;
discende, and þerfore, I&ftee; I were a sto&ntail;, I
shul&dtail; discende to þe grounde of þe see, & telle
you the soth by probacio&ntail;."  Then seid þe emperou&rtail;,
"what if a&llbar; þe outegoyng o&ftee;
the fressℏ water be stoppid?"  "For if þou did so, then I
shul&dtail; telle þe how many galons o&ftee; salt water [were]
in þe see."  quo&dtail; the emperou&rtail;, "Þat were
impossible me to do."  "So were þat oþer impossible for
me," quo&dtail; he, "for to mow bere."  "How of lechecraft?"
quo&dtail; þe emperou&rtail;.  "For þere is no man," seid
þe knygℏt, "but þat he is somtyme seke, & somtyme
medlitℏ with medicynes."  Then seid he, "how of the Pope?"  "For
god is oon," seid he, "and þerfore he hath made a vyker."  "And
also who makith þe daies iourney, þat þou speke
o&ftee;?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "the sonne, þe whicℏ goth
aboute a&llbar; þe worl&dtail; in oo daye."  "Go thi wey,"
quo&dtail; the emperou&rtail;, "for thy&ntail; answeris haue ykept the
fro deth."

1.1:
DEre Frendis, this Emperou&rtail; may be callid eche ma&ntail;,
þat arguytℏ how þat he may in the day of dome answere
to god.  Þe first, how moche is bytwene good and yue&llbar;?
and þat is to þe first questio&ntail;, where as he askith,
how moche is bytwene heue&ntail; and helle?  & þat þou
oughtist to considre in þi hert, what þou shalt haue for
the good, scil. heue&ntail;, and for yvel, scil. helle; and
þerfore fle yve&llbar;, & take þe good.  How depe the
See is?  By þat thou shuldist thenk how moche is þe
peri&llbar; of this worlde, & to fle thilke perils; for hit is
har&dtail; to go in to the fyre, & not to brenne þe solis
o&ftee; þi fete, So it is har&dtail; to go in the worl&dtail;,
& not offend god.  Also o&ftee; what crafte is moste?  Know
þou, that þere beth two maner of medycyns, þat is to
sey, material, and spiritual; and a&llbar; þe chose
childry&ntail; of god moste vse the spiritue&llbar; medicy&ntail;,
& haue nede o&ftee; hit, For withoute hit þere is non helth in no creature.  Also o&ftee;
what crafte or o&ftee; what myster beth moste & fewist?  scil.
þe pope; for eche man is a pope ouer him sel&ftee;, & is
yholde to labou&rtail; for his owne heltℏ.  Also how many daies
iourneys?  Þis terme or this dyet, is not ellis but the terme of
thi ly&ftee;; for i&ftee; that we lyve&dtail; an c. yere, hit is but
an houre as to regar&dtail; of euerlastyng ly&ftee;.  And
þerfore let vs make him, þat settith sucℏ a dyet in
vs, to rise with vs, and lig with vs; and lat vs travei&llbar; so
wele, þat we mowe&ntail; passe oute o&ftee; the worl&dtail; as
clene as we entri&dtail;, thurgℏ meritory werkes.  Also
difference is bytwene ricℏ and pouere, scil. he [is] riche,
þat hath many vertues, by the which he doth plesaunce to god;
& he is pouere, þat lakkitℏ vertue.  And therfore let vs
labou&rtail; for suche richesses, wherthurgℏ we mow come to
þe kyngdom of heve&ntail;. Ad quod
&c.

0.1:
BOnonius was regnyng a wys emperou&rtail; in the cite of Rome, but
in a&llbar; his tyme he lay as he were seke; and þerfore he sent
messangers in to diuers contres, for to wete i&ftee; þere were
any lechis þat mygℏt hele him, þat he mygℏt be
brougℏt vnto him.  And at the last þere was oon yfounde,
calli&dtail; Aueroys, þat was soti&llbar; in crafte, and a good
practiser.  When he was brougℏt byfore the emperoure, and saw
him, he seid to him, "Sir, rest you mery, and ioyeth in oure
lor&dtail;."  And he bad him shew his vryne; and so it was ydo&ntail;.
Whenne he had ysey&ntail; his vryne, he ordeyned a medycy&ntail;, and
yaf hit to the emperou&rtail;, by the which the emperoure had his
hele.  And the Emperoure yaf to him many fei&rtail; yiftis, and made
him to abide with him; and there he heled many seke.  So there were
thre lechis in þe cite, þat had grete indignacio&ntail;
and envie o&ftee; this leche; and þerfore thei counseile&dtail;
to-gidre how thei mygℏt distroy him.  "doth aftir my
counsei&llbar;," seid oon o&ftee; hem, "and we shul distroy him
withoute any hurt, and þat in this maner.  Somday we shul passe
oute of this cite to visite seke me&ntail; o&ftee; his cure, and I
shal stond in his wey, and þat fer from the citee,
by the space of a myle.  And when he comyth to me-war&dtail;, I shal
lifte vp myn hond, and make vpo&ntail; me þe signe of the
crosse, and I shal sey, Allas! allas!  maister, what eiletℏ the,
thou art lepre?  And oon of you shal stond fro me the space o&ftee;
ij. or iij. myle; and when he comyth to him, he sha&llbar; afferme my
wor&dtail;, and sey as I seid.  And þe thrid o&ftee; vs
sha&llbar; be thre or fou&rtail; myle beyonde; and when he seth him
nye, he shal begynne to go, and make lamentacio&ntail; , and seyn, oute, alas!  my
maistre is ymade lepre.  And when he seth vs alle accorde in oon,
he sha&llbar; trow in vs, and then for drede he shal bycome lepre; for
so a lepre may be made."  And then thei seid, this was a good
counsei&llbar;.  And so thei aspied among hem when Aueroys shul&dtail;
ride oute of the cite; and þis forseid ma&ntail; stood oute
o&ftee; the citee, by the space of iij. myle, & made contynaunce
as he had be goyng; the seconde was two myle fro him, and þe
thrid was foure myle.  When Aueroys was y-come, the first mette with
him, and lift vp his hond, and made the signe o&ftee; the cros, and
seid, "maister, what eileth you?"  "nougℏt but good," quo&dtail;
Aueroys, "what, whi seist þou so?  what seest þou in me?"
"Forsotℏ, I se thou art lepre."  "And I sey thou liest in thi
hed," quo&dtail; Aueroys; and smote his hors, and rode forth.
Neuertheles he dradde moche of
the forseid wor&dtail;, and gretly dullid therwith.  Anon aftir an
oþer mette with him, and seid, "Alas!  maister, þat euer I
shul&dtail; see þe in sucℏ astate."  "Why, man?"
quo&dtail; he, "what seest þou in me?"  then seid þat
oþere, "thou art a grete lepre."  And if he dred afore, he
dre&dtail; moche more after; neuertheles he rode forth.  And the thrid
met with him, and crie&dtail; with a lowde vois, "A!  good maister,
turne aye&ntail;, for þou art a foule lepre."  Then he
thougℏt, þat hit mygℏt not be fals, that thre had so
afferme&dtail; & toke so grete drede, that, he becom a foule
lepre; & toke a myrrou&rtail;, and when he saw him sel&ftee;, he
wepte bitterly; he vndirstode not þe malice o&ftee; his
iij. enemys.  Tho he turne&dtail; aye&ntail; to the Emperou&rtail;,
and shewi&dtail; him his sikenes; and þe Emperou&rtail; was hevy
therfore, and seid to him, "good maister, be not hevy, for as long as
þou levist, thou shalt haue a&llbar; thi necessaries o&ftee;
me."  Then seid he, "if I had oo thing þat I desire,
I shul&dtail; be deliuere&dtail; o&ftee; this infirmyte."  "Telle me
what þat is," quod þe Emperou&rtail;.  "Sir," quo&dtail;
he, "i&ftee; I myght bathe in blode of goetis, I shul&dtail; be hole
of this infirmyte."  then þe emperoure, as sone as he
mygℏt, let ordein a [vesselle] fu&llbar; o&ftee; blode; and he
entri&dtail; yn anon, & he was hole as he was ywasshe and ybathed
therin, & he was as clene as the flessh of a
lite&llbar; childe.  When the Emperou&rtail; saw him, he seid, "I am
more iocund þen any ma&ntail; may trowe, þat I se the
hole, but, ser, I mervei&llbar; þat thou were so sodeinly
smyte&ntail; with lepre."  "Now I perceyue wele," quo&dtail; Aueroys,
"þat I was not smyte&ntail; with lepre naturelly; for if hit had
be naturelly, forsoth I had not be hole so sone, but I fynde in
doctrine, that a man may be made lepre thurgh drede.  The felawis
o&ftee; myne met me in the fel&dtail;, and by her assent, echo&ntail;
stonding in diuers places, tol&dtail; me þat I was smyte&ntail;
with lepre, and for drede þerof I was lepre."  When the
emperoure her&dtail; this, and had founde by clere probacio&ntail;
þat it was soth, he made hem to be drawe to the gybet, atte the
tailles of the hors, & so made hem to be hongid.  And a&llbar; men
hily commendid the emperou&rtail;, þat he had yove&ntail; so
iust a dome; and Aueroys duelleth stille with the Emperou&rtail;,
& fei&rtail; endi&dtail; his ly&ftee;.

1.1:
GOod men, this
Emperou&rtail; is eche good criste&ntail; ma&ntail;; the which ofte
tyme is syke thorow synne, Quia nemo sine peccato
viuit , For no man may lyve withoute synne; the which sike
ma&ntail; sendith messangers, scil. praiers, Fastyng, & almesdede,
for help o&ftee; his soule.  Atte the laste þei fyndeth a wys
leche, scil. a discrete confessou&rtail;, afore whom thou must shew water of
confessio&ntail;, and vryne of contricio&ntail;; aftir þe
whiche, this discrete confessou&rtail; hatℏ to deme thi lyfe, and
to considre the vryne of contricio&ntail;, & by þat he moste
ordeine for medicynys of penaunce.  And then þou moste submytte
the to him, and receiue thi penaunce, and so thou maiste duelle with
the kyng, withoute&ntail; ende.  Now, sirs, the iij. envious lechis,
þat hath so grete envy, betℏ the flessh, the devi&llbar;,
and the worl&dtail;, the whicℏ stireth a man to do
yve&llbar;.—And what then?  forsotℏ thei spietℏ when þat he passith the cite, scil. wha&ntail;
þat he goth oute of þe commaundement of god; and then thei
metith witℏ him, for to cry and sey þat he is a lepre,
scil. a synner. for lepre is not callid in holy writte but synne,
ensample of dyna; for as long as she was in the hous with iacob her
Fader, so long she was vnkaugℏt, but when she yede fortℏ, by Sechem she was ravisshed & filed.
And so as long as we beth within the boundis of the
commaundement&yogh; of god, we beth not in the lepre of synne; and
þerfore let vs hol&dtail; vs within þe commaundement&yogh;
o&ftee; god, þat we beth not smyte&ntail; with lepre.  And
i&ftee; hit hap þat we infect, let vs do as did the
emperou&rtail; with Aueroys.  The Emperoure made a vesse&llbar; to be
yfel&dtail; with blode of gotes; and so let vs fi&llbar; oure hertes
witℏ good and meritory dedis or werkis, and let vs be bathid
þerin, scil. be ywassℏ fro a&llbar; thoughtis of synne; and
so by the consequest we shu&llbar; be clansid.  And then serche we
within oure wittes, who hit was þat stired vs to synne; and when
we haue yfounde hem, let vs sette hem to the tai&llbar; of an hors,
scil. fro þe begynnyng of oure ly&ftee; to shew a&llbar;
þat we haue ydo afore to a discrete confessou&rtail;, & for
to hong oure synnys in a gybet, scil. in wille neuer eft sonys to do
synne; and so we may come to euerlastyng ly&ftee;. Ad quam &c.

0.1:
ANtonius was
a wys emperou&rtail; regnyng in the cite of Rome, the which vsid moche
to pley with houndis; and aftir þat pley, a&llbar; þe day
aftir he wolde vse þe chesse.  So yn a day, as he pleide at
þe chesse, & byhel&dtail; the kyng sette yn the pley, som
tyme hy and som tyme lowe, among aufyns and pownys, he thougℏt
þerwitℏ þat hit wol&dtail; be so with him, for he
shul&dtail; dey, and be hid vndir ertℏ.  And þerfore he
devided his Reame in thre parties; and he yaf oo part to þe kyng
of Ierusalem; þe secunde part vnto þe lordis o&ftee; his
Reame or his empire; and the thrid partie vnto the pore people; &
yede him sel&ftee; vnto the holy londe, and the&rtail; he endid his
ly&ftee; in peas.

20.1:
MORALITE. Seth now, good sirs; this emperou&rtail;, þat
lovith so wele play, may be calle&dtail; eche worldly ma&ntail;
þat occupieth him in vanytes of the worl&dtail;; but he moste
take kepe o&ftee; the pley o&ftee; the chesse, as did the
emperoure. the chekir or þe chesse hath viij. poyntes in eche
partie.  In euery pley beth viij. kyndes of me&ntail;, scil. man,
woma&ntail;, wedewer, wedowis, lewid me&ntail;, clerkes, riche men,
and pouere me&ntail;. at this pley pleieth vj. me&ntail;.  the first
ma&ntail;, þat goth afore, hath not but oo poynt, but whenne he
goth aside, he takith anoþer; so by a pouere ma&ntail;; he hath
not, but when he comytℏ to þe detℏ witℏ pacience,
þen sha&llbar; he be a kyng in heue&ntail;, with þe kyng
of pore me&ntail;.  But i&ftee; he grucche ayenst his neighbou&rtail;
of his stat, and be a the&ftee;, and ravissh þat whe&rtail; he
may, þen he is ytake, and put in to the preso&ntail; of helle.
The secund, scil. alphy&ntail;, renneth iij. poyntes both vpwar&dtail;
and dounewar&dtail;; [he] bytokenyth wise me&ntail;, the whiche by
deceyuable eloquence & takyng of money deceyueth, & so he is
made oonly.  The iij. scil. þe kny&yogh;t, hath iij. poyntes,
& goth þerwitℏ; [he] betokenytℏ gentilmen
þat rennyth aboute, & ravisshith, and ioyetℏ for her
kynrede, & for habundaunce of richesse.  The fourtℏ,
scil. þe rook, he holdith length & brede, and takith vp what
so is in his way; he betokenytℏ okerers and false
merchaunt&yogh;, þat rennyth aboute ouer a&llbar;, for wynnyng
& lucre, & rechitℏ not how thei gete&ntail;, so that thei
haue hit.  The fifthe is þe quene, that goth fro blak to blak,
or fro white to white, and is yset beside þe kyng, and is ytake
fro the kyng.  This quene bytokenyth virgyns and damesels, þat
goth fro chastite to synne, and beth ytake by the devi&llbar;, for
glovis or sucℏ maner yiftis.  The vj. is to whom a&llbar; owe to
obey and mynystre; and he gotℏ forth, and bakwar&dtail;
aye&ntail;, & in either side, & takith ouer a&llbar;; so sone discenditℏ in to þe worl&dtail;,
and ascendith to god by praiers; But when he takith [no] kepe of god,
and hatℏ no meyne, þan is hit to
þe man chekmate.  And þerfore let vs not charge of oure
estatis, no more þan is with þe me&ntail;, when þei
be put vp in þe poket; then hit is no charge who be above or who
be bynetℏ and so by the Spirit o&ftee; loulynesse we
may come to þe ioy of heve&ntail;.  And þat graunt vs, qui vivit &c.

0.1:
ANdronicus was a wise Emperoure regnying in the cite of Rome; yn the
empire of whom we&rtail; twey me&ntail;, name&dtail; Pirius and
Plebeius.  And this Pirius hadde a certein Porcio&ntail; of londe,
beside þe londe of Plebeius, the which lond plebeius gretly
desire&dtail;; and he cam ofte to pirius, and praie&dtail; him to
selle him þat porcio&ntail; of lon&dtail;, þat lay so ny
to his, and bad him aske þerfore what he wol&dtail;, and he
shul&dtail; haue hit.  "Nay, god forbede," quod Pirius, "þat I
shul&dtail; selle the heritage o&ftee; my fader; and þerfore I
swere by the helth o&ftee; ou&rtail; emperou&rtail;, I wo&llbar; not
do hit by no wey."  When Plebeius her&dtail; this, he went home aye&ntail; with grete confusio&ntail;;
neuertheles fro day to day he excite&dtail; him to selle þat
londe, but he mygℏt not spede, by no way.  Hit happid þat
Pirius fel seke; and he clepid to him his eldest sone, and seid,
"sone, I warne the vpo&ntail; my blessing, þat þou selle
not þe lond neiþer the heritage of thi eldris; for plebeius hily couetith hit, but he
traveiletℏ a&llbar; in vey&ntail;."  And þo Pirius turnede to þe walle, and deide.  When Plebeius her&dtail; this, he hired thre
fals witnesses, and brougℏt hem þider with him, withe a
fals chartre in his honde, to þe hous o&ftee; the dede
ma&ntail;, and þere he putte a seal in the hond o&ftee; the dede
ma&ntail;, & seid to þe witnesses, "loo!  now, sers, for ye
shul bere witnesse how þis knygℏt shal seal my chartre with
his owne hondis; þerfore betℏ my witnesses, as I accorded
with you."  "yis, ser," quo&dtail; thei, "we shul be redy to stond in
ly&ftee; and detℏ."  tho anon he toke the thome of the dede
ma&ntail;, and made him to seal hit with a fals seal; and whenne
þat was ydo, the knyght seid to his witnesses, "lo!  sers, now
may ye saufly say, þat ye saw this knygℏt seal hit with his
owe&ntail; hondis."  so whe&ntail; hit was yseali&dtail;, thei shewid
þe chartre, & toke seising in the londe.  When the sone of
Pirius here thes wordis, he seid to him, "A!  ser, whi occupiest
þou my londe?" And he answere&dtail;, and seid to
him, "Forsoth þe londe is my&ntail;; thy fader sol&dtail; hit to
me, and seali&dtail; hit with his owne hondis, byfore witnesses."  And
þe witnesses were redy, and seid, "We beth witnesse in this
cas."  Thenne þe sone o&ftee; the dede ma&ntail; had grete
mervei&llbar;, & seid, "Wel I wote, þat þou speke oft
to my fader þerof, and he wol&dtail; not assente to the; and
also afore his dethe, my fadir chargid me, vpo&ntail; his blessing,
þat I shul&dtail; neuer selle the heritage of my Fadres."  "Ye,"
quo&dtail; the knygℏt, "put forth thi rigℏt, for I haue ynow
to shew for me.  I telle þe plainly, this lond shalt þou
neuer haue, as long as I lyve."  The Sone of the ded knygℏt yede
to the emperou&rtail;, and praied him to do rigℏt in þat
cas; and then the rightwis Emperou&rtail; repreve&dtail; Plebeius , þe knygℏt, herfore.  "Sir,"
quo&dtail; Plebeius , "he sol&dtail; to me
þat lon&dtail;, and asseli&dtail; a chartre þerof, afore
iij.  witnesses, with his owe&ntail; hondis."  Then seid
þemperou&rtail;, "I commaunde, þat thou bring thi
witnesses afore me such a day;" & he seid þat hit shul&dtail; be do&ntail;.
& in a certein day he brou&yogh;t forth his witnesses afore the
Emperou&rtail;; & when the emperou&rtail; saw hem, he commaunded
þat two of þem shul&dtail; be departid fro the oþer;
and so it was ydo&ntail;.  & þe first of hem come at his
callyng, and the emperou&rtail; seid to him, "Frend my&ntail;, canst
þou sey here to me thi pater-noster?"  "ye, ser," said he,
"& þat long tyme sitℏ."  "I trow hit not," quo&dtail;
themperoure, "but if þat I here þe sey afore me."  And
þen that othir began to sey his pater-noster fro the begynnyng
to þe ending.  "wele," quo&dtail; the emperoure, "now know y
wele, þou canst thi pater-noster perfitly."  Þen he called
oon o&ftee; his meyne, and seid, "put þis man in an hous by him
sel&ftee;, & lok the dore aftir you, and bring to me the secund
witnesse;" and so hit was ydo&ntail; in dede, as þemperoure
commaundid.  When þe secund witnesse was ybrougℏt
fortℏ, þe emperou&rtail; seid to him, "dere Frend, sey me
soth touching this chartre; for but i&ftee; þou sey soth, as
þi felaw dede, ywis þou shalt be hongi&dtail; þis
day."  then thougℏt he, "I wote wele my felaw hath tol&dtail; the
bare sotℏ o&ftee; the deceyt of this chartre, and but I sey soth
also, I am but ded."  He began to telle a&llbar; þe processe,
& tol&dtail; euery dele, how þe chartre was asseli&dtail;
falsly by the thome of the dede ma&ntail;.  Þo seid the
emperou&rtail; to oon of his seruaunt&yogh;, "Put
þis ma&ntail; in to the hous, þere as he was, & lok
þe dore vpo&ntail; him, and bring to me þe thrid
witnesse;" and so hit was ydo in dede.  And when he was come&ntail;,
the Emperou&rtail; seid to him, "Telle me þe soth o&ftee; this
chartre, for I suppose the first witnesse tol&dtail; the soth, and
þe secund accordid wele to him; and þerfore, frend, but if
þou sey soth with hem, els þou shalt be ded þis
day."  Þen thougℏt he, "I se wele now by the wordis of the
emperou&rtail;, þat my felawis haue I-tol&dtail; to him the
rigℏt, and but I accorde with hem, I shal be de&dtail;."  And
anon he byga&ntail; þe processe, as hit was in dede, and
accorded with the secunde.  When the Emperou&rtail; had herd this, he
callid to him the knygℏt, and seid, "A!  wrecche, wrecche,
þou shalt euermore lyve in wrechidnesse, for þou dedist
this falshode to haue the lond o&ftee; the knygℏt, and occupy
hit; þou madist þe chartre to be asselid with the thom of
the dede ma&ntail;."  And þen the knygℏt asked mercy.  Then
seid þe emperou&rtail;, "Þou shalte haue mercy, as thou
haste deserue&dtail;;" and clepid his seruaunt&yogh; and cacchepolis,
and commaundid hem that thei shul&dtail; blowe trompes, and bynd þe knygℏt and
his witnessis to the Tailles of hors, and after þat hong hem on
a gybet.  And so hit was do&ntail; in dede, as þe emperou&rtail;
commaundi&dtail;; and a&llbar; men commende&dtail; the emperou&rtail;
for his wys & discrete serching in this cas, & for due
punysshing.

1.1:
[G] od Frendis, this Emperou&rtail; is
oure lord ihesu Crist; by thes two knyghtes beth vndirstond a good
Criste&ntail; ma&ntail;, and the devi&llbar;.  Þe good
criste&ntail; man hath londe, scil. a soule, þe which the
devi&llbar; euer coveitetℏ, but þe good Criste&ntail;
ma&ntail; stondith aye&ntail;, and wo&llbar; not assent þerto.
Then the devi&llbar; aspying this, he abideth ti&llbar; he dey, by
doyng of dedly sy&ntail;; and then he takith to him thre witnesses,
scil. pryde of ly&ftee;, wrong covetise of ye&ntail;, and wrong
covetise of flessh; and then he takith the thome, scil. the werkes of
the dede ma&ntail;; for no man may lyve withoute cryme, and as hit is
ysaid, seve&ntail; sithes in þe day fallith þe rightwise
ma&ntail;; & he sealith þe chartre, when he makith a
ma&ntail; to do synne, and so he alleggith in þe
sigℏt of god, þat þe soule is his.  But þen the
Emperoure, scil. oure lord ihesu Crist, makith þe hert of
þe synner, & þe witnessis, scil. pride of lyf, wrong
couetise of flessh, and wrong covetise of ye&ntail;, to be
examyne&dtail; by a discrete confessou&rtail;, how þat he felle
in to synnes; For certein, by suggestio&ntail; of the devi&llbar;,
þat is auctour o&ftee; a&llbar; yvels, man is drawe with hem
withoute&ntail; ende, and hongid in the peynes of helle.  And
þerfore let vs besy to amend oure ly&ftee;, and to duelle in
good werkes, that we may come to euerlastyng gladnes.  Amen.

0.1:
Story. IOvinianus [was] regnyng a wys Emperou&rtail; in the cite of Rome; and
he was riche in possessions.  Hit happid þat he thougℏt in
a nygℏt, as he lay in his bed, whethir þere be any god
withoute me?  And when he aros, he callid his knygℏtis &
Squiers, and seid, "sers, loke ye be redy, for I wo&llbar; go hunte to
day."  Anon thei yede to hunte; and as þemperou&rtail; rode by
the wey, þere toke him a grete hete, and þat so strongly,
þat him thougℏt he was ny de&dtail;, but he may haue
refresshing of water.  And anon þere ros a clowde, so derk and
so thik, þat hit hundri&dtail;, & hit assundri&dtail;, &
departid him fro a&llbar; þe people.  So as he rode
by him sel&ftee;, he saw a water afore him; & he smote the hors
with his sporis, and yede in to þe water, and þere did of
a&llbar; his clothing, and kelid him in þe water.  And as he was
in the water, þere come a man in his owe&ntail; lyknesse, but he
saw him not; and he toke
the Emperours clothing, and clothid him therewith, and lept vpo&ntail;
the Emperours hors, and rode forth to the Emperours men, as he had be
emperoure him sel&ftee;; and as Emperou&rtail; he was receiue&dtail;,
& turnyd home with hem to þe paleis.  Aftirwar&dtail; when
the Emperou&rtail; had I-bathe&dtail; ynowe, he yede vp to londe,
& sougℏt his hors, & his clothing, but a&llbar; was goo,
so he went aboute naki&dtail;.  & he cowde see no ma&ntail;, But
he wept sore, and crie&dtail; with an hye vois, & seid, "Allas!
allas!  what shal I now do!"  and as he crie&dtail;, he thougℏt
in his hert, here ny duellith a knygℏt, þe which I
avaunse&dtail;; I wo&llbar; go to him, and telle him my cas, &
haue clothing of him, & so go home.  He yede to the knyghtis hous,
and knokke&dtail; atte the yate; and þe porter asked o&ftee; him
what he wol&dtail;.  Þen he seid, "Let me yn, withoute lenger
delay, for I am your emperour."  Then anon the porter
openyd the yatis; and when he saw him nake&dtail;, he seid to him,
"what art þou?"  "your emperou&rtail;," quod he.  "thou liest,"
quod the porter, "for þe emperour rode rigℏt now here by
the yate, with a grete multitude with him; and þerfore þou
seist þat þou art Emperou&rtail;, thou shalt appere afore
my lor&dtail;."  And anon the porter brougℏt him byfore the
knygℏt; and the Emperoure had good knoulache of the knygℏt.
And when the knygℏt had her&dtail; þe wordis o&ftee; the
porter, he seid to þemperou&rtail;, "O!  ribawde, seist
þou that þou art Emperoure?"  "yee, withoute doute I am
he, þat avaunce&dtail; the."  "I sey þou liest,
"quo&dtail; the knygℏt, "and þerfore þou shalt sore
aby."  He made him to be sore bete&dtail; and scourge&dtail;,
ty&llbar; þe blode re&ntail; oute, and aftir to be put oute at
þe &yogh;atis.  Then themperour wept sore, & seid, "Allas!
for care how may this be?"  tho he thougℏt, "I wo&llbar; go to an
erle here beside, þat was grete of my counsei&llbar;, þe
which I avaunce&dtail; I wo&llbar; to him, and be refresshid of him,
& so go home."  He knokked at his &yogh;ate; and the
Porter come ny, and aske&dtail; what he knokke&dtail;.  "Ope&ntail;
the yatis," quo&dtail; he, "for I that knok am þemperou&rtail;."
When the porter her&dtail; þat, he opened the yatis, as sone as
he mygℏt fynd þe keys.  When he come, and saw him
nake&dtail;, he seid to him, "O!  rybawde, whi hast þou presumyd
thi sel&ftee; for to sey that þou were emperou&rtail;?  The
Emperour hath be&ntail; here a lite&llbar; afore, and hath y-ete with
my lord the erle, and is go&ntail; to his paleis, witℏ grete
multitude o&ftee; men; and for þat thou callist the
Emperou&rtail;, þou shalt come afore my lor&dtail;, and avow thi
pele."  And when he was y-brougℏt to-fore the erle, he knew the
Erle wele, but the erle knew not him.  When the Erle had her&dtail;,
þat he had callid him themperou&rtail;, he bad him telle, &
sey, what was þe cause þat suche a ribawde as he presumyd
so hiely in him sel&ftee;?  "Forsotℏ," quo&dtail; he, "I am
themperou&rtail; you&rtail; lor&dtail;; and the I avaunce&dtail;,
& made the chie&ftee; of counsei&llbar;, & in this tokene,
þat I treti&dtail; in þe last parlement in suche materes
and erandis."  Þe Erle had þero&ftee; mervei&llbar;, but
he wol&dtail; not trow him, for
he had no knoulache of him; and þerfore he made him
to be presone&dtail;, and to sitte there þe space o&ftee; thre
daies, withoute mete & drinke; and aftir he chargid him þat
he shul&dtail; go oute of his contre, vpo&ntail; peyne o&ftee; lesing
of his ly&ftee;. when themperou&rtail; was withoute the &yogh;atis, he
wept sore, and seid, "Allas!  what shal I do now?  I am but lorne, for
no man knowith me.  Best is, þat I go home to my palys, &
wete i&ftee; þe Emperesse, my wi&ftee;, or any o&ftee; my meyne
wo&llbar; know me."  He yede home; and ano&ntail; a Grehound, þe
which he had lovi&dtail; moche afore, come wyghtly rennyng to him, and
wol&dtail; haue slay&ntail; him, had not be&ntail; þat
her&dtail; him crye had pite o&ftee; him, and holpy&ntail; of
him. then themperou&rtail; yede forth to the yatis o&ftee; þe
palys, and þere he knokke&dtail;; and þe porter
openy&dtail; the yate, and aske&dtail; why he knokke&dtail;.  "Dere
Frend," quod themperou&rtail;, "hast þou no knoulache of me?"
"No," quo&dtail; the Porter, "I haue no knoulache of the."  "I am,"
quo&dtail; he, "you&rtail; Emperou&rtail;, & you&rtail;
lor&dtail;, & þou berist my clothing vpo&ntail; the."  then
seid þe porter, "thou liest, harlot; my lor&dtail; the
emperou&rtail; sittith at mete, & my lady the emperes by his side,
with Erlis & dukys."  Tho seid themperou&rtail;, "good
Frend, I pray the for the loue o&ftee; god, þat þou
herkene what I sha&llbar; sey to the; & go to the emperesse, and
sey to her in her ere by sucℏ tokyns which non knowithe but oonly
she & I; and sey to hir, þat I her husbon&dtail; & hir
lor&dtail; stonde nakyd at þe &yogh;ate; & pray hir to
sende&ntail; me some clothis, þat I may come yn."  And þe
porter in scorne toke hede to his wordis, & with scorne yede to
themperesse, & rowny&dtail; with her, & tol&dtail; to hir
a&llbar; the prive tokyns þat were ysaid bytwene hem two.  Anon
the emperesse made him to be fet yn; and he knew a&llbar; me&ntail;,
and no man knew him.  Þen the Emperou&rtail; seid, þat sat
at the table, "sey, lore&llbar; knave, seist þou that thou art
Emperou&rtail;?"  "Ya, ser," quo&dtail; he. tho spake þat othir
to alle the lordis aboute him, "Sirs and Frendis, I charge you aboute
him, by þe feith ye owe to me, þat ye sey soth, whethir
this man be Emperou&rtail; or I?"  "A!  ser," quod thei, "this
questio&ntail; is not wortℏ for this lose&llbar; saw we neuer
here to-fore, and the we haue yknow long."  Thenne the Emperou&rtail;
chargid hem, þat thei shul&dtail; take him, and tey
him to Tailles of hors, vpo&ntail; the har&dtail; pavement,—"but
I wo&llbar; not þat ye slee him, but, forsoth, if he euer
presume any more so fouly, he shalbe dampny&dtail; to the foulest
detℏ þat I ca&ntail; deme."  And in dede, þe
cacchepolis drow him vpo&ntail; the pavement at þe Tailles of
hors, and putte him oute of the cite.  Sone aftir this Emperou&rtail;
byga&ntail; to thenk, what haue I do, or what haue I grevi&dtail; god,
þat I am thus put oute o&ftee; the Empire, and þat no man
knowith me?  And as he thougℏt these wordis, hit come to his
mynde, how he had I-thougℏt afore in his be&dtail;, is þere
any god but I?—"A!  lor&dtail; god, now I se wele þat was
þe cause þat grevi&dtail; the, and þerfore I shal go
to a confessou&rtail;, and clansy me, and take penaunce
þerfore."  There beside duelli&dtail; an heremyte, þat
vsi&dtail; to shrive him afore;
and he yede to this heremite then, & knokke&dtail; at þe
dore.  "Who is þere?"  quod the heremite.  "Opy&ntail;, opyn,"
quo&dtail; the Emperou&rtail;, "for I am the Emperour, and haue
certein prevites to speke with the."  And the Heremyte openyd the
dore; and when he saw þe Emperou&rtail;, anon he put
to the dore aye&ntail; with a&llbar; his myght, and seid, "nay,
þou art not Emperou&rtail; but the devi&llbar;."
Þe&ntail; themperou&rtail; bygan sore to wepe, and seid, "alas!
alas!  vnappy wrecche þat I am; I pray the, for goddis loue,
here my confessio&ntail; þere as I stonde; and let thi dore
stond yshit, as hit dotℏ."  "For the loue of god," quo&dtail; the
heremyte, "I wolle gladly here the; say what thou wilt."  Tho the
Emperou&rtail; makyd confessio&ntail;, and tol&dtail; how he had
grevid his god; "and þerfore I had suche venIaunce."  When
þe heremite had assoile&dtail; him, he openyd a wyndowe, and
knew him for emperou&rtail;, and kist for Ioye.  "Telle me,"
quo&dtail; the Emperou&rtail;, "hast þou knoulache o&ftee; me
yit, or doutist o&ftee; me?"  "yis," quo&dtail; the heremyte, "I know
þe now, þat thou art emperour; but as long as þou
duelledist in synne, I coude not know the."  "I pray the," quo&dtail;
the Emperour, "lene me som clothis, and kever my body; and þen
wolle I turne home, & loke i&ftee; any ma&ntail; ca&ntail; or
wolle know me."  "yis, my lor&dtail;," seid þe heremyte; "suche
clothis as I haue, thou shalt haue, and I trow to god thei wo&llbar;
know the; but, ser, I mervei&llbar; what he is, þat
occupietℏ thi dignite."  When themperou&rtail; was I-clothid, he
went to his paleis, and knokke&dtail; at þe yate. the porter
openyd the yate, and kneli&dtail; dou&ntail;, & seid, "ser, my
lor&dtail;, by what wey yede ye oute; for I haue here abide &
I-stond long, & I cowde not se you?"  "Knowist þou me,"
quo&dtail; themperou&rtail;. "ye, my lor&dtail;," quo&dtail; he, "and
long haue ydo&ntail;; But yisterday there come an harlot nake&dtail;,
& come to þe halle, & seid he was emperour."  So hit
was, þat the Emperour entrid in to þe halle. when
knygℏtes and lordis saw him come, thei fille dou&ntail; on kne,
eche man in his degre, and salowi&dtail; him, as þei aught to do
to themperour.  And þat oþer Emperour was in chamber with
the lady, & herde a grete noise in the halle; [and] he
commaundi&dtail; his chamberley&ntail; to go loke what hit was.  Whan
þe chamberley&ntail; had I-sey&ntail; what hit was, he come
rennyng vp agein, and seid to þe Emperou&rtail;, "Sir, there is
a fei&rtail; man in the halle, and seith he is Emperour; and he is
like to you, þat there is no man in þis worl&dtail;
þat may know wheþer of you to be Emperoure."  Then seid
the Emperou&rtail; to þe lady, "goth ye forth, and
seth him, and telle me what it is."  And the lady di&dtail; so; and
when she saw him, She had
so grete mervei&llbar;, þat no man wolde trowe hit.  & sone
