Helle.  ¶ Than he gothe to his owne paleys, that is, to his owne
hert, and thynketℏ what and how moche he hatℏ offende&dtail;
ayenst go&dtail;, and may not be resceive&dtail;; for by synne
go&dtail; is put out of the hert.  ¶ And the [e]mpresse, that is,
holy chirche, to the whiche he shul&dtail; be wedde&dtail;,
[kn]owetℏ not a synner, tille he be at the horse-taile, by the
[p]ament, That is, thou owest to have in mynde, fro the begynyng of
thi ly&ftee; vnto this tyme, ¶ what that is, how, an&dtail;
where, and for what cause, and how ofte thou hast offende&dtail;
go&dtail;; and so rynne to the hermyte, that is, a secrete confessour, and shew
to hym how thou hast offende&dtail; go&dtail;.  And so it
folowetℏ, that thou may recover, and gete agay&ntail; thi
clothes, that are the vertues, that is lost by synne; and go to the
paleys of holy chirche, where the porter, that is, the prelat,
sha&llbar; take the in.  and go&dtail; sha&llbar; ope&ntail; to the
the dorre of the kyngdome of heven, whan thou diest; ¶ And
a&llbar; thy&ntail;, that ben the aungels of go&dtail;, sha&llbar;
there know the; and there thou shalt reigne in the hevenly Empire; to
the whiche bryng vs the Emperou&rtail;
of heve&ntail; Ihesu crist!  Amen.

0.1:
Averios was a wise emperou&rtail; regnyng in the
cite of Rome; and he let crye a grete feste, and who so euer
wol&dtail; come to that feste, and gete victory in tour[n]ement, he
shul&dtail; haue his doughter to wy&ftee;, aftir his decesse.  So
þere was a doughti knygℏt, & hardy in armys, and
specially in tour[n]ement, þe which hadde a wy&ftee;, and two
yong childre&ntail;, of age of thre yere; and when this knygℏt
had her&dtail; this crye, in a clere morowenyng he entre&dtail; in to
a forest, and þere he her&dtail; a nyghtingale syng vpo&ntail; a
tre so swetly, þat he her&dtail; neuer so swete a melody afore
that tyme.  The knygℏt sette him dou&ntail; vndre the tre, and
seid to him sel&ftee;, "now, lor&dtail;, if I mygℏt knowe what
this brid shol&dtail; bemene!"  Þere come an ol&dtail;
ma&ntail;, and seid to him, "þat thou shalt go within thes thre
daies to þe Emperours feste, & þou shalt suffre grete
persecucio&ntail; or þou come þere; and i&ftee; þou
be constant, & pacient in a&llbar; thi tribulacio&ntail;, thy
sorowe shal turne the to grete ioy; and, ser, this is the
interpretacio&ntail; of his song."  when this was seid,
þe ol&dtail; ma&ntail; vanysshe&dtail;, and þe brid fly
awey.  tho the knygℏt had grete mervei&llbar;; he yede to his
wi&ftee;, and tol&dtail; her the cas.  "ser," quod she, "þe
wi&llbar; o&ftee; god be fulfille&dtail;, but I counse&llbar;
þat we go to þe feste o&ftee; the Emperou&rtail;, and
þat ye thynk on the victory in the tour[n]ement, by the which we
may be avaunce&dtail; and holpe&ntail;."  when the knygℏt had
made a&llbar; thin>ee; redy, þere come a grete fire in the
nygℏt; and brent vp a&llbar; his hous, & a&llbar; his goodis,
For which he had grete sorowe in hert; Neuertheles, notwithstondyn>ee; a&llbar; this, he yede
forthe towar&dtail; the see, with his wife, and with his two
childry&ntail;; and þere he hire&dtail; a Ship, to passe ouer.
When thei come to londe, þe maister of the Shippe asked o&ftee;
the knygℏt his hire for his passage, for him, & for his wif,
and for his two childry&ntail;.  "Dere Frend," seid the knygℏt to
him, "dere frend, suffre me, & þou shalt haue a&llbar;
thy&ntail;, for I go now to the feste of themperou&rtail;, where I
trust to haue þe victory in tur[ne]ment, and þen þou
shalt be wele ypaie&dtail;."  "nay, by the feith þat I owe to
þemperou&rtail;," quod þat othir, "hit shal not be so, For
but i&ftee; þou pay now, I shal holde thi wi&ftee; to wed,
ty&llbar; tyme þat I be paie&dtail; fully my salary."  And he
seid þat, for he desire&dtail; þe loue o&ftee; the
lady. tho the knygℏt profre&ntail; his two childry&ntail; to
we&dtail;, So þat he mygℏt haue his wi&ftee;; and the
Shipman seid, "nay, sucℏ wordis beth vay&ntail;, for," quod he,
"or I wol haue my mede, or els I wolle holde thi wi&ftee;."  So the
knygℏt lefte his wif with him, and kyst her with bitter teris;
and toke þe two childry&ntail;, scil. on in his oon arme, &
þat othir in his nek, and so he yede forth to the turnement.
Aftir þe maister o&ftee; þe Shippe wolde haue lay&ntail;
by the lady, but she denye&dtail; hit, & seid, þat she had
lever dey þan consente þerto.  So within short tyme,
þe maister drew to a fer lon&dtail;, and þere he
deie&dtail;; and þe lady beggi&dtail; her brede fro dore to
dore, and knew not in what lond her husbon&dtail; was duellinge.  the
knygℏt was go&ntail; towar&dtail; the paleis, and at þe
last he come by a depe water, þat was impossible to be
passi&dtail;, but hit were in certein tyme, when hit was at þe
lowist.  Þe knygℏt sette dou&ntail; oo chil&dtail;, and
bare the othir ouer the water; and aftir þat he come aye&ntail;
to fecche ouer þe othir, but or he mygℏt come to him, there
come a lio&ntail;, and bare him awey to þe forest.  the
knygℏt pursue&dtail; aftir, but he mygℏt not
come to þe lio&ntail;; and þen he wept bitterly, and yede
aye&ntail; ouer the water to þe othir chil&dtail;; and or he
were ycome, a bere had take þe chil&dtail;, and ra&ntail;
þerwith to þe forest.  When þe knygℏt saw
þat, sore he wepte, and seid, "allas!  þat euer I was
bore, for now haue I lost wi&ftee; and childry&ntail;.  O þou
brid!  thi song þat was so swete is yturne&dtail; in to grete
sorowe, and hath ytake away myrth fro my hert."  Aftir this he
turne&dtail; towar&dtail; the feste, and made him redy towar&dtail;
the turnement; and þere he bare him so manly, & so doutely
in the turnement, and þat twies or thries, þat he
wa&ntail; þe victory, and worship, and wynnyng of þat day.
For þe Emperou&rtail; hily avauncid him, and made him maister
o&ftee; his oste, and commaundi&dtail; þat a&llbar; shul&dtail;
obey to him; and he encresi&dtail;, and aros from day to day in honure
and richesse.  And he went aftirwar&dtail; in a certein day in the
cite, [and] he found a precious Stone, colouri&dtail; with thre maner o&ftee; colours, as in oo partie
white, in an othir partie red, and in the thrid partie blak.  Anon he
went to a lapadary, þat was expert in þe vertue of Stonys;
and he seid, þat þe vertue o&ftee; thilke stone was this,
who soeuer berith the Stone vpo&ntail; him, his hevynesse sha&llbar;
turne in to ioy; and i&ftee; he be pouere, he shal be made riche; and
i&ftee; he hath lost any thing, he sha&llbar; fynde hit aye&ntail;
with grete ioy.  And when the knygℏt her&dtail; this, he was glad
and blitℏ, and thougℏt in him sel&ftee;, "I am in grete
heuynesse & pouerte, for I haue lost a&llbar; that I had, and by
this Stone I shal recouere a&llbar; aye&ntail;, wheþer hit be so
or no, god wote!"  Aftir, when he must go to Bataile o&ftee; the
Emperour, he gadri&dtail; to-gidre a&llbar; þe oste, and among
hem he found two yong knyghtis, semely in harneis, & wele I-shape,
the which he hire&dtail; for to go with him yn batai&llbar; of the
Emperour.  And when thei were in the Batai&llbar;, þere was not
oon in a&llbar; þe batai&llbar; þat did so doutely, as
di&dtail; tho two knygℏtis þat he hire&dtail;; and
þerof this knygℏt, maister o&ftee; þe ost, was hily
gladi&dtail;.  When þe batai&llbar; was y-do, thes two yong
knyghtes yede to her oste in þe cite; and as þei sat
to-gidir, thelder seid to þe yonger, "Dere Frend, hit is long
sithe&ntail; þat we were felawys, and we haue grete grace of
god, for in euery batail we haue þe victory; and þerfore I
pray you, telle me of what contre ye were ybore, and in what nacio&ntail;? for I askid neuer this of the or now; & if
þou wilt telle me sotℏ, I shal telle my kynrede, &
where I was borne."  And when oo felawe spak þus to þe
othir, a faire lady was loggid in þe same ostry; and when she
her&dtail; þe elder knygℏt speke, she herkened to him; but
she knew neither of hem, and yit she was modir of both, & wy&ftee;
o&ftee; the maister of the Oste, the which also þe maister of
the Shippe withhel&dtail; for shiphire, but euer god kept her fro
synne.  Then spake the yonger knygℏt, "Forsoth, good ma&ntail;, I
note who was my Fader, or who was my modir, ne in what stede I was
borne; but I haue this wele in mynde, þat my fader was a
knygℏt, and þat he bare me ouer the water, and left my
eldir brothir in þe lon&dtail;; and as he passid ouer aye&ntail;
to fecche him, þere come a lio&ntail;, & toke me vp, but a
man of the cite come with houndis, and when he saw him, he made him to
leve me with his houndis."  "now, sothly," quod þat othir, "and
in þe same maner hit happid with me.  For I was þe sone of
a knygℏt, and had only a brothir; and my fader brougℏt me,
& my broþer, & my modir, ouer the See towar&dtail;
themperou&rtail;; and for my fader had not to pay to þe maister
o&ftee; the ship for the
fraugℏt, he left my modir to we&dtail;; and þen my fader
toke me with my yong brothir, and brougℏt vs on his bak, & in
his armys, ty&llbar; þat we come vnto a water, and þere
left me in a side of the water, and bare ouer my yong brothir; and or
my fader mygℏt come to me ayene, to bere me ouer, the&rtail; come
a bere, and bore me to wode; and þe people þat saw him,
made grete cry, and for fere the bere let me falle, and so with thelke
people I duellid x. yere, and the&rtail; I was ynorisshe&dtail;." When
þe modir her&dtail; thes wordis, she seid, "withoute doute thes
be&ntail; my Sonys;" and ran to hem anon, and fil vpo&ntail; her
nekkes, and wepte sore for ioy, & seid, "A! dere sonys, I am your
modir, þat your fader left with þe maister of the Shippe;
and I know wele by you&rtail; wordis and signes þat ye beth true
brether&ntail;.  But how it is with your Fader, þat I know not,
but god, þat a&llbar; setℏ, yeve me grace to fynd my
husbon&dtail;."  And alle that nygℏt þes thre were in
gladnes.  On þe morow þe modir rose vp, and þe
childry&ntail;, scil. þe knyghtes, folowi&dtail;; and as thei
yede, the maister of þe Oste mette with hem in þe strete,
and þougℏ he were her fader, he knew hem not,
but as þei had manli fougℏt þe day afore; and
þerfor he salue&dtail; hem honurably, and askid o&ftee; hem,
what fei&rtail; lady þat was, þat come with hem?
Ano&ntail; as þis lady her&dtail; his voys, and perceyued a
certey&ntail; signe in his frount, she knew fully þerby that it
was her husbon&dtail;; and þerfore she ra&ntail; to him, and
clypt him, and kyst him, and for ioy fille dou&ntail; to the erth, as
she had be de&dtail;.  So aftir þis passio&ntail;, she was
reise&dtail; vp; and then the maister seid to her, "Telle me,
fei&rtail; woma&ntail;, whi þou clippest me, and kyssist me so?"
She seid, "I am thi wi&ftee;, that þou leftist with þe
maister of the Ship; and thes two knyghtes bene your Sonys.  loke wele
on my front, and see."  Then the knygℏt byhel&dtail; her wele,
with a good avisement, and knew wele by diuerse tokyns þat she
was his wi&ftee;; and anon kyst her, and the Sonys eke; and
blessi&dtail; hiely god, þat so had visite&dtail; hem.  Tho went
he aye&ntail; to his lond, with his wi&ftee;, and with his
childre&ntail;, and endid faire his li&ftee;.

1.1:
DEre frendis, this
Emperou&rtail; is ou&rtail; lord Ihesu Crist, the which callith vs to
the turnement of penaunce, wherthurugh we mow come to euerlastyng ioy.
The knyghtes two sonys and his wi&ftee; is eche good Criste&ntail;
ma&ntail;; þe which owith to redy him towar&dtail; þe wey
of heuen by praiers, fastyng, & almysdede, to take with him his
wi&ftee;, scil. his flessh, þat it obey vnto þe goost in
a&llbar; þinges. the two childry&ntail; bethe reso&ntail; and
wille; i&ftee; þe which two accorde wele togider, thei mow sekirly come to the
tur[ne]ment of penaunce. the brid, þat singeth so swetly, is
þe holy gost, þe which is euer puttyng grace in to vs,
i&ftee; we wol aske hit, as the gospe&llbar; makith mencio&ntail;
thus, Petite, & accipietis ,
þat is to sey, askitℏ, and havitℏ; Pulsate, & aperietur vobis , that is to sey,
knokkith, and hit shalbe openyd to you.  Neuertheles it behouyth
þat ioy of yongith be turnyd to sorowe of penaunce, and alle
ou&rtail; vices be brend vp with þe fire of þe love of
god, So þat we love that in love o&ftee; god ouer a&llbar; thinges, & set a&llbar; erthely thinges atte
nougℏt.  The Ship in which vs owe to entre is penaunce, and
þerfore seith Ierom, Secunda tabula post
naufragium est penitencia, &c. exponitur supra. And
þerfore we se wele by experience, þat if any
man must nedis passe the See to þe holy lond, in fulfilling of
vowys, and behotitℏ þat he made, þerfore þen
i&ftee; hit happe, þat there be in þe water two Shippis,
o&ftee; þe which oon is ychargid, and þat othir is
vnchargid.  Now to ou&rtail; purpos.  Þere bene two Shippis,
scil. baptym & penaunce; baptym is charge&dtail;, for hit is oure
first sacrement, and be þat we be&ntail; ysavi&dtail;, and
þerfore þat is passi&dtail;, and may not be take
aye&ntail;; and þerfore nedefully we must take the Ship o&ftee;
penaunce, as did the knygℏt, with his wi&ftee; & his
childre. but þe knygℏt left his wi&ftee; with þe
maister o&ftee; the shippe, for he mygℏt not pay; So do þou
leve thi flessh with a discrete confessou&rtail;, that is to sey,
flesshly affeccions; & take with the two sonys, as reso&ntail; and
wi&llbar;; reso&ntail; to gouerne thi lif, & wil to do þat
is plesaunt to god. for þere is nothing better þa&ntail;
that þat is yove&ntail; to god with a good wi&llbar;, in so
moche þat in certein places & tymes wi&llbar; is take as for
dede with god.  And so vs must passe ouer the worldly water; But many
doth ofte tyme as did þe knygℏt, þat left oon o&ftee;
his childre&ntail; vpo&ntail; þe lon&dtail;; So þat what
tyme reaso&ntail; is depressi&dtail;, the&ntail; comyth þe
lyo&ntail;, scil. þe devi&llbar;, & gostly ravissheth a
ma&ntail;.  Neuertheles then þe hurde, scil. a prechou&rtail;,
comyth ofte&ntail; tyme, in so moche þat þe devi&llbar;
lettith a ma&ntail; to falle from his power, and þen he is
norisshe&dtail; of holy chirche in good werkes.  Now he wolle seche
the othir, scil. wi&llbar;, by þe which he shul&dtail; please
god, but the bere, scil. þe werkes, ravissheth þe
wi&llbar;, in so moche þat he hath no wi&llbar; to fulfille no
meritory werkes.  But yit ofte tyme prelates, prechours, and doctours
ravisshitℏ by holy Scripture such a wi&llbar;, and makith hit to
be norisshe&dtail; by doctrine of god, vnto þe tyme þat a
man know what & how moche he hathe trespassi&dtail; vnto god.
Then aftirwar&dtail; the knygℏt is ymade maister of the Oste,
& wan þe victory in batails.  In þe same maner, when a
ma&ntail; ouercomytℏ þe devi&llbar;, then he is maister
o&ftee; him sel&ftee;, yn
gouernyng of his owne soule, puttyng awey vices, & plantyng
vertuys.  Aftir al this, the knyght fyndithe
a ston, I-colowri&dtail; with three diuerse colowres, so he, aftir
that he hathe ouercome his enmyes by penaunce, he findithe a stone
scil. Christum , Crist, þat seithe, Ego
sum lapis, &c. þis is to sey, I am a stone, the whiche is
colowri&dtail; with iij. folde coloures, scil. with myte
of þe fadir wisdo&mtail; of þe sonne, & meknesse of
the holy goste.  An&dtail; he þat shal have þis stone,
shal have euerlastyng lyf; an&dtail; so ow&rtail; hevines þat we
have hee&rtail; shalle tourne into Ioye, an&dtail; so we shalle mowe
come with oure wyf, scil. oure flesche, & oure sonys, scil.
Reso&ntail; & wi&llbar;, [to] have ay lastyn>ee; ly&ftee;, aftir
owre dessece. Ad quam nos &c.

0.1:
PLebeius was Emperoure
Regning in the cete of Rome; þe whiche ordeyni&dtail; for a
lawe, that wacchemen shulde eche nyght go aboute þe cete, &
visite eche house, þat þere was no misgouernayle
þere in, wher by þe cite myght peril or har&mtail;, &
þat þere were no manslauter, ne sodeyne detℏ in Eny
house.  So in a tyme þere was an olde knygℏt, name&dtail;
Josias, þe whiche ha&dtail; to wyf a freshe yonge wenche;
an&dtail; this yonge woma&ntail; vsi&dtail; to syng so swetly, that
mony me&ntail; drow for hir love to hir house, an&dtail; speke to hir
for a maner love þat is forbode.  An&dtail; this Emperoure
ha&dtail; in his hous iij. yonge knyghtes, scil. that is to seye,
Pirellus, þat was stiwar&dtail;; Oliuerus, þe whiche
vsi&dtail; to wynne victory in bataile in euery place; and the thirde
was name&dtail; [Lemicius.  The firste] knyght, scil. pirellus, yede
prively vnto the forsaide woma&ntail;, þe olde knyghtes wyf,
an&dtail; proferi&dtail; hir many yiftis, yf so were þat she
wolde assente to his desire. "what wolt þou yeve to me?"
quo&dtail; she, "yf I fulfille thi wille?" "XX. marke," quo&dtail; he.
"Then I graunte," quo&dtail; she; "but telle me what tyme & what
oure þou wolte come with þi money, & I shalle in the
mene tyme avise me yf I wolle fulfille thi wille; I shalle yeve the
aunswere or longe tyme be."  Afftir þat come Oliuerus to hir
& spake to hir for the same mater, but he wist not that his felow
ha&dtail; be þere afore.  Þen she saide to him, "Þou
shalt Come, & do thi wille." when Oliuerus ha&dtail; this
aunswere, he was gla&dtail;, & he yede his weye.  An&dtail;
þoo come the thirde knygℏt, ande spake to hir of the same
mater, but he wist not that his Felawes ha&dtail; ben ther
afore.  An&dtail; tho he saide to hir, "what shalle I yeve to the, In
conducio&ntail; þat I
shalle do my wille withe the?"  "Þou shalt yeve me xx. marke,"
quo&dtail; she, "an then I sha&llbar; tel the when an&dtail; in what
houre, þat thow shalt come & ligge withe me."  "I assente,"
saide he, & yede home to the place.  An&dtail; sone aftir þe
malicious woma&ntail; yede, an&dtail; discouere&dtail; to hir husbonde
þe counsai&llbar; of alle thre knyghtes.  "An&dtail;
þerefore, sir," she sai&dtail;, "I pray þe, sir, yef me
counsai&llbar;, how that I may have alle hir yiftes, an&dtail; save my
selve fro synfi&llbar; werke."  Þen spake hir husbonde,
"Þowe shalt," quo&dtail; he, "sey to the fyrst knyght, þat
he brynge his mony at mydnyte; an&dtail; to the secounde, þat he
bring his money at þe thirde cokkis crow; ¶ an&dtail; to
the thirde knyght, þat he bryng his mony in the morowe.  ¶
An&dtail; I Shalle steke the dore aftir hem, & sle hem, when thei
buthe entre&dtail;; and so we sha&llbar; have þe mony, &
þou shalt be vnfili&dtail;."  Thenne aftirwar&dtail; she saide
to the iij. knightes, as ye haue hur&dtail;, & þat they
shul&dtail; come y&ntail; the nyght folowyng, & thei shulde have
hir wille.  So the firste knyght come at mydnyght, and knokke&dtail;
at the dore, trowing that hir husbonde were absent.  she come,
an&dtail; aski&dtail; the cawse of his cnokkyng.  "A!" quo&dtail; he,
"I am Pirel, the knyght."  "A! be stille," quo&dtail; she, "hast thow
browte þi money?" "yee," quo&dtail; he.  "Entir then,"
quo&dtail; sche; openi&dtail; þe do&rtail;, & he
enteri&dtail; in derknesse. the Olde knyght steki&dtail; the do&rtail;
aftir him, & yede, & slow this knyght, an spoyle&dtail; him
bothe of monye & of clothis, & drowe his body into a prevy
caumbre.  Aftir this, at þe iij. cockis croweyng, come þe
Secon&dtail; knyght, with his money; & as it was I-do&ntail; with
þe first, so was it do&ntail; with the secounde; & his body
was drawe into a chaumb&rtail;.  In the morow come the thirde,
an&dtail; knew nothing of the chaunce of his felowes; & whe&ntail;
he was comy&ntail; in, hir husbonde smote him o&ntail; the hede, &
he fel downe dede, and his body was drawe into þe same chaumbre.
Then spake sche to hir husbonde, & seide, "sir, we have I-do a
perilowse dede; þes knyghtes shul sone be sought, & yf thei
be not I-founde, þere wolle be serche made for hem fro hous to
hous, & yf they be founde with vs, we shulle have a foule dethe;
& þerefo&rtail;, sir, it is goode that we werke wysely."
"Say thi best counsai&llbar;," quo&dtail; he. then saide
she, "Þow knowest wel, þat þere is a lawe I-made,
þat waccheme&ntail; shulle goo aboute in tyme of þe nyght,
& visite Eche house;
an&dtail; o&ntail; of the wacchemen is my broþere; & when he
comythe by the strete, I shal make him Entre priuely, & telle him
of this dede, & so I truste that he wolle deliuer vs." the&ntail;
saide he, "this is a gode counsaille, yf þou do as þou
saist."  So in tyme of the nyght, when wacchemen come blowyng hir
hornes, þis yonge woma&ntail; heryn>ee; the horne of hir
broþere, come to him, & saide, "Gode broþer and
frende, come to my hovse, for I have þere a certe&ntail; previte
to shew to the." he come in, & she saide to him, "take now goode
hede, my swet broþer, of that I shalle sey to the, & helpe
to socour me in this gret nede, for þere fel a cas þe last
nyght.  A knyght come to my hovse, & spake vnRuly wordes to my
husbonde, & so my&ntail; husbon&dtail; kylli&dtail; him, an&dtail;
his body is hi&dtail; in a chaumb&rtail;; & yf oure house were
I-serchi&dtail;, & þe body we&rtail; I-founde, we myght have
a foule dethe; an&dtail; þerefore, de&rtail; broþere, as
thow lovist me & my lyf, Remeve him in to som oþere place,
þat he be not I-founde þere, & þou shalt have
goode mede."  "A! suster," quo&dtail; he, "I wolle not fayle þe,
in lyf ne in dethe; an&dtail; þerefore take me his body in a
sakke, & I sha&llbar; cast it into the see."  She toke him
þo the body of the firste knyght, & she wolde be-knowe of no
mo.  & [he] toke [it] than, & Ranne to the myddis of the cite,
& þere was an arme of the see, & þere he caste it
in. & when þis was done, he Ran a-yene to the house of his
suster, and ba&dtail; hir to yeve him drinke, for he ha&dtail;
deliuere&dtail; hir of the knyght, in grete Ioye to hir. she yede to
draw wyne in to the chaumb&rtail;, wher as þe oþer twoo
bodijs lay; & þenne she cride with a&ntail; hie voys,
an&dtail; saide, "O broþer my&ntail;, helpe me now!  Þe
knyght, þat þou castiste in to the water, is he&rtail;
a-yene." he trowi&dtail; hir wordes, & entiri&dtail; with hir into
the chaumbre, & saide, "how is this?  I caste him into þe
see, & now he is he&rtail; a-yene! take him me, & I sha&llbar;
ordeyne For him in an othir maner." then sche toke him þe body
of the secounde knyght; & he trowi&dtail; that it ha&dtail; be the
first, an&dtail; he tide a grete stone abovte his necke, & so he
caste him into the water.  And þoo he come a-yene to hir house,
an&dtail; tolde how he ha&dtail; I-doone.  Sche rose vp to
fecche drink; an&dtail; as she was in þe caumb&rtail;, she cride
as she di&dtail; afore, an&dtail; saide, "Out! broþer, out! for
he is I-come ayene." when he harde that, he mervayli&dtail; strongly,
Trowing euer that it ha&dtail; be&ntail; the first knyght.
Þe&ntail; in angir
he toke him, & put him in a Sakke, & saide, "I caste the
firste in the see, & sithen I fonde þe he&rtail; ayene;
aftir that I put a gret stone aboute thi necke, & yit þou
Rise; I triste now I shalle pley sikir with the." he yede with the
knyght in to a foreste; and þere he made a grete fire, an&dtail;
caste þe knyght þere in.  An&dtail; as this
wacchema&ntail; yede from him, he purposi&dtail; to sitte down, &
esi&dtail; him selue. & þere come a knyght Ridinge bi
þe same wey, be-cause that þere was made a crye of
Tornement, for the whiche crye many knyghtes come thidir to the
cite. when this knyght þat was accolde&dtail;,—& hit
was grete froste,— & he saw þe fyre, he
descendi&dtail; of his horse, & yede to þe fyre &
warmi&dtail; him.  Ande as he stode so, the forsai&dtail;
wacchema&ntail; come to him, an&dtail; aski&dtail; what he di&dtail;
there, & what he was.  & he saide, "I am a knyght."  "Nay,"
quo&dtail; he, "thow art a devil; firste I caste þe in the see,
an&dtail; that oþere tyme I caste þe o&ntail; þe
water in a sakke, an&dtail; the thirde tyme I caste the in þe
fy&rtail;, and yit I Fynde the he&rtail; with thin horse!" he toke the
knyght, & the hors, & caste hem boþe in the fere; &
yede home, & tolde his suster, an&dtail; she yaf him goode
salarye, & he went his wey.  In the morow þes knyghtes
wee&rtail; I-sought fro house to house, & non was I-founden, &
þerefor was made grete lamentacio&ntail;.  Aftir hit
happi&dtail;, þat þis olde knyght, þat slowe the
knyghtes, fel at stryf with his wyf, in so muche þat he wolde
have smeti&ntail; hir; and whe&ntail; she sawe þat, she cride
with an hihe voyse, "A!" quo&dtail; she, "wolt þou slee me, as
þou didest the iij. knyghtes? nay, þou shalt lye."
Þe peple, þat was þere present, marvayle&dtail;
þere of, an&dtail; tolde it to the Emperoure; & boþ
we&rtail; I-taken, scil. the knyght & his wyf, an&dtail; thei were
compelli&dtail; to sey the sothe, from þe begynnyng to the
endyng afore the Emperoure, & to telle how thei kylli&dtail;
þe iij. knyghtes; and so at the last þei ha&dtail; a foule
deþe.

1.1:
Dere frendes, þis Emperoure is
oure lorde Ihesu Crist, þe whiche ordeyni&dtail; for a law,
þat wacchme&ntail;, scil. prelates & confessoures, owe to go
aboute þe cite of oure herte, puttyng awey vices, an&dtail;
plontyng vertus.  Þe olde knyght is this worlde, the whiche hath
weddi&dtail; a wyf, scil. þe deville; an&dtail; wel may the
worlde be I-calli&dtail; þe wyf of þe devil, for it is
I-sette al in wikednesse.  Now þe wyf, scil. þis worlde, singiþe so swetly,
þat þe iij. knyghtes comithe to hit. by þes
iij. knyghtes we vndirstonde þre kyndes of me&ntail;, scil. men
þat were afore þe advent of Criste; some in tyme of Crist;
& some aftir Criste; For in euery state of þes iij. many ben
deceyvi&dtail; by þe worlde, & kylli&dtail; by the devil,
an&dtail; spoyli&dtail; of all hir goodes, spirituely for to speken.
What is þerefore to be do in þis cas?  Certeynely,
þat a waccheman, scil. a prelate or a confessoure, putte hem in
the sakke of penaunce, to confessio&ntail;; & first late him be
caste into the water of contricio&ntail;; aftir late be put aboute his
necke a grete stone, scil. þe yoke of penaunce, to
confessiou&ntail;; In the MS. by negligence of the scribe, two
lines are here repeated. an&dtail; aftir late him be caste in
to the fy&rtail; of þe love of go&dtail;, scil. that he love
go&dtail; above al thinges, with al his herte, & with al his
soule.  Þe knyght, þat Ridethe to the turnament, is a man
Redy to gete & to fonge vanytes of the worlde, & for to walke
in peryll of synne; an&dtail; siche a ma&ntail; most discende fro his
hors of pryde, an&dtail; not Only to stonde be-syde the fyre of the
love of go&dtail;, but to be cast þere in, scil. þat he
sette fully his hope in go&dtail;, an&dtail; not be dul in the feithe,
ne wauere in the comavndementes of go&dtail;. & yf he do thus, he
shalle have a goode mede, scil. a good Sentence in the day of dome,
when he shalle here that shal be saide to him, Venite, benedicti Patris mei, percipite regnum quod vobis
paratum est ab origine mundi , This is to sey, Comythe ye
blessi&dtail; childerin of my fadre, takithe the kyngdo&mtail; þat was ordeyni&dtail; for
yow fro the begynnynge of þe worlde. Ad
quod &c. x

0.1:
Cesar the Emperoure was a wyse ma&ntail; Reigninge in the cete of
Roome; In whos Empire was a knyght, name&dtail; folliculus, þe
whiche knight loui&dtail; ouer al thinges in the worlde Iusting
an&dtail; tornement. & this knyght ha&dtail; a litle babe to
so&ntail; an&dtail; no mo childerin; & he ordeyni&dtail; for
fostering & noreshing of this childe iij. norisis, scil. o&ntail;
to wasshe his clothis, anoþere to fede or to pasture him with
pappe, & þe þirde to bringe him o&ntail; slepe with songes & Rockynges.
Also this knyght lovi&dtail; passantly
þe grehounde, with the fauco&ntail;, by-cause þat
þei neuer fayli&dtail; of theire pray comunly.  Hit
happi&dtail;, þat this knyght made a tornement to be
proclaymi&dtail; to do&ntail;, in a greene place ny to his castel;
& many come ther to.  when þe day come, the knyght
armi&dtail; him, an&dtail; yede forthe; þe lady, & al his
meyne, an&dtail; the norisse yede forthe also, & lefte þe
childe in the cradille; þe grehounde lay by a walle, an&dtail;
þe favco&ntail; sat o&ntail; a perche. Þere was in a
certei&ntail; hole of the same castell a serpent I-bre&dtail; &
broute forthe, & ha&dtail; be þere longe tyme; an&dtail;
when this serpent harde so grete a noyse of peple goyng oute
towar&dtail; the tornement, she put oute hir hede at an hole, &
sawe the chylde by him selve. she come oute, for to sle the childe;
an&dtail; when the fauco&ntail; sawe that, she made gret noyse with
hir winges, an&dtail; þere with awoke þe grehounde fro
slepe, þat the grehounde myght go & defende þe childe.
Then the grehounde awaki&dtail;, by stirynge of the faucones wynges,
& shoke him selve, & be-helde þe serpent, an&dtail; Rhan
fersly to hir; & þe serpent was o&ntail; the o&ntail; side
of the cradi&llbar;, & the grehounde o&ntail; the oþere, for
to defende the childe in þe crade&llbar;. & þei foute
sore togeder, & þe serpent boot þe grehonde grevously,
þat he ble&dtail; stronge; and the grehounde Ra&ntail; woodly to
þe add&rtail;, & slowhe hir; & so with hir fiting
þe cradil ouertorni&dtail;; but the cradi&llbar; ha&dtail; iiij.
feet, that kepte the childes fase fro the grounde.  & when the
Grehounde ha&dtail; I-slawe þe serpent, he yede to his kenell,
biside the walle, an&dtail; likki&dtail; his wounde. An&dtail; by that
tyme the tornement was cessi&dtail; & doo&ntail; The norisshis come home; & when þei sawe the
cradi&llbar; I-torni&dtail; vpsodoune & þe flo&rtail; blody,
& þe grehoun&dtail; blody, also thei trowe&dtail; þat
the grehounde ha&dtail; slayne þe childe; & þerefor
withoute tareynge, or thei wolde goo to the chylde, thei seide, "Go we, fle awey, or we be dede!"
An&dtail; as thei yede, þe lady met with hem, as she come fro
the play; & she aski&dtail; of hem whi thei fledde? &
þei saide, "wo is to yow & to vs, for þe
grehoun&dtail;, þat ye love so welle, haþe slayne your
sone, & lithe by the wa&llbar; al blody!"  The lady fel downe
o&ntail; a swoune, an&dtail; saide, "Alas! is my sonne dede?"
An&dtail; as she crie&dtail;, þe knyght come fro the tornement,
an&dtail; aski&dtail; the cause of hir criinge. Þenne sche saide,
"Wo is to yow & to me, for you&rtail; grehounde hathe slayne youre
sone!" then þe knight was halfe woode for wo; he Enteri&dtail;
into the halle; an&dtail; [when] the grehounde sawe his lorde come, he
aros, an&dtail; as he myght, he made Ioye with his lorde, as he was
wont to do.  But the knyght ano&ntail; in his woodnesse, trowing the
wordes of his wyf, drowe oute his swerde, an&dtail; smote of his
grehoundis hede; an&dtail; þo he yode to the cradi&llbar;, &
turni&dtail; hit vp with his honde, & saw his childe Safe &
sounde, an&dtail; biside the cradell lay the sarpent dede; & by
that he vndirstode, þat the grehounde ha&dtail; slay&ntail; the
serpent, for defens of the childe.  An&dtail; the&ntail; he cride with
a&ntail; hihe voyse, "Allas! allas! for at the wordes of my wyf I have
slayne my gentil grehounde, þat faili&dtail; neuer of his pray,
an&dtail; also savi&dtail; the lyf of my childe; þerefore I
wolle take penaunce." he brake his spe&rtail; in thre partijs, &
put his wyf in preso&ntail;, and yede him selfe to the holy londe;
& þere he livi&dtail; al his lyfe, & his so&ntail; helde
his eritage; & so he made a fayre ende with the worlde.

1.1:
Dere frendes, þis Emperou&rtail; is the fadir of hevi&ntail;;
the knight in þe Empy&rtail; is eche worldly ma&ntail; þat þat the worlde þat lovithe tornementes & Iustinges, scil. vanitees of the worlde.
Þe childe in þe cradil is a childe wasshe in baptisme;
þe cradil hathe iiij. feet, þat the visage myght not
touche the erþe; so þe contryte hert most have iiij. fete,
that is to sey, iiij. cardinales vertutes, þat hit tovche not
erthely thinges, ne do no thing but that shulde be
plesynge to go&dtail;.  Þe Firste norise, that is sette to wasshe þe childe, is contricio&ntail;,
the whiche wasshithe awey synne of ma&ntail;; &
þerefo&rtail; seithe Ambrose, Lacrime lavant
delictum Quod pudor est Confiteri , ¶ This is to sey,
teris wasshithe synne that is shame to be shewi&dtail; .  the secounde noryse is
confessiou&ntail;, the whiche fedithe a man in goode werkes; for as
the body liuithe be kyndly mete, Right so dothe the sovle by gostly
mete.  Þe þirde norise, þat Rockithe the childe to
slepe, is verey satisfaccio&ntail; for synnis, þe whiche makithe a ma&ntail; to Reste
in euerlasting Ioye.  The knyght yede to the tornement, scil. as ofte
as a man goþe to the Iolytees of worldlye speculacions, &
hathe delectacio&ntail; in hem, in þat þat he is
I-ocupie&dtail; aboute þe worlde, & in vnlefu&llbar;
desiris.  Now þe childe, scil. þe soule, is lefte by hit
selfe withoute helpe; for as þe A-postel seiþe, Non potestis deo seruire & mammone , þis
is to seyne, ye mow not bothe serve go&dtail; an&dtail; the devil, or
to the worlde or to the fleshe.  Þe serpente in the hole is
þe devil, þe whiche euer more goþe abovte to seche
whom he maye devoure, scil. to sle a soule by dedely synne.  Þe
Fauco&ntail; seynge this, makethe a flakeryng with his
wynges,—what is that? this fauco&ntail; is þi consiens,
that hathe twoo wynges, to stire þe grehounde of Reste; oo wynge
is hope to have euerlasting Ioye, þat othir wynge is drede of euerlastinge payne; &
þe&ntail; þe fauco&ntail;, scil. consciens, makithe soun , as ofte as he grucchithe ayens dedely synne;
& þerefore þe apostle seithe, Omne
quod fit contra conscienciam, Edificat ad Jehennam, ¶ vt
supra .  An&dtail; when the grehounde, scil. Reso&ntail;, is
styri&dtail; fro slepe of synne þe&ntail; he fitithe with
þe serpent, in that þat it stirithe a man to goode.  The
serpent, scil. þe devil, woundiþe the grehounde, scil.
Resou&ntail;, as ofte as he bryngithe a ma&ntail; to live wilfully,
& not by Resou&ntail;; & so is þe blode sperkeli&dtail;
aboute the cradil, when þat þe vertus, þe whiche
thow toke in baptisme, be depressi&dtail; & destroye&dtail; by the
devi&llbar;; & so þe cradil of thin herte is torni&dtail;
vpsodowne, scil. to the erthe.  Neuerþeles for þe foure
fete, scil. þe iiij. cardinal vertues, whiche a man Recevithe of
go&dtail;, a soule dieth dieþeth not,
scil. is not dampni&dtail;, as longe as she dwellithe in the body;
& þerefore seithe oure saveoure, ¶ Noli mortem Peccato is, set vt magis
convertatur et viuat , This is to seye,
I wol not the dethe of a synner, but that he be conuerti&dtail;, &
live.  The norisshes seeþ & fleeþe,
scil. contricio&ntail;, confessio&ntail;, & satisfaccio&ntail;,
scil. when a ma&ntail; lithe in synne, an&dtail; wol not be
conuerti&dtail; to go&dtail;.  Þe grehounde sleeþe
þe serpent as ofte as Resoune ouercomithe the devil, &
convertithe a man to go&dtail;.  The lady cryde, & fel to grounde,
þat is when a wrecchi&dtail; soule torniþe to Erþely thinges, & delicates
of þe worlde; & þe&ntail; it criethe so hie, þat
the knyght, scil. þe man, drawiþe oute þe swerde of a frowarde
wille, as ofte as he folowithe deliciousnes of the fleshe; an&dtail;
then he sleeþe Reso&ntail;, þat saui&dtail; þe soule
ayenste þe serpent, scil. þe devil.  An&dtail;
þerefore, ma&ntail;, yf thow hast do&ntail; by instigacio&ntail;
of þe fleshe, do as di&dtail; the knyght; turne vp þe
cradil of thin herte by meritory werkes, & þe&ntail;
þow shalt fynde þi soule saf, & breke þi
spe&rtail;. scil. þi lyf, in iij. partiis, scil. in prayng,
fastinge, an&dtail; almes; & þe&ntail; go to the hooly
londe, scil. þat is to sey, þe kyngdo&mtail; of
hevy&ntail;, &c.

0.1:
Story. Lampadius Reigne&dtail; a
wyse Emperoure in þe cite of Rome, an&dtail; amonge al
oþere thinges he was mersyfulle; an&dtail; for grete mercy he
ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, þat yf ther we&rtail; eny
trespassoure ytake, & browte afore the Iuge, þat couthe seye
iij. trewe talis, so trew that no man mygℏt ayene-seye hem, he
shulde be I-savi&dtail;, & have his eritage.  so
þere was a knyght, name&dtail; plebeus; & this knight
enhabiti&dtail; in a woode, & þere he Robbi&dtail; or slowhe
al me&ntail; that travayle&dtail; by þat way.  An&dtail; when
the Iustice or the Iuge har&dtail; of him, he sente waccheme&ntail;
& spyeris to fecche him; & anoo&ntail; he was I-take, &
browte afore þe Iuge.  & þenne saide þe Iuge to
him, "dere fren&dtail;, ouþere thow most sey iij. trewe poyntes,
þat shul be vnrepugnable, oþere elles þou shalt be
dede."  Þe&ntail; þe knyght avnswerde, "Sir," he saide,
"late silens be made, that me&ntail; may he&rtail; what I shalle seye;
&, sir, I shalle fulfille the lawe."  "Sirs," quo&dtail; he, "this is
my firste sothe worde, that ye know wel echone, þat I have
be&ntail; al my lyf a thef an&dtail; a traytour."  "is that
soþe?" seide the Iuge to oþere men; "may ye argu ayenst
him?"  "Nay, sir," quo&dtail; they, "for yf he ha&dtail; be noo
trespassoure, he hadde not be I-browte he&rtail;; certeyne he myght
not seye a trewer worde than this was."  Þenne saide þe
Iuge, "what is thi secounde point?" "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "it is this,
þat it is displesing to me that I come here." "Sothely," seide al men, "þat trowe we
wel."  "Sey þe thirde point," seide the Iuge, "& then
þou haste fulfilli&dtail; the lawe, & savi&dtail; thi lyf."  "Forsoþe," quo&dtail; he, "yf euer I may
passe fro&mtail; yow, I shalle neuer come he&rtail; ayene, withe
goddis wille."  Þenne seide þe Iuge, "sothely, þou
hast saide wel, and wel I-savi&dtail; thi lyf; goo þerefor,
& be a goode man, & trespasse no mo&rtail;, with thi wille,
ayene the Emperour."  Þe knyght yede his wey, an&dtail; made a
faire Ende. MORALITEE. Dere frendes, this Emperour is oure
lorde Ihesu crist, the whiche hathe ordeyni&dtail; for lawe, þat
euerye synner or Traytoure, þat is I-take thorow þe grace
of go&dtail;, an&dtail; browte afore a Iuge, scil. a discret
confessoure, sey iij. sothefastnes, so trewe, þat no devil con sey ayene hem in þe day of dome;
þe&ntail; with oute dowte he shalle have euerlastynge lyf, with
the eritage off heui&ntail;.  The furste trew worde is, & shalle
be this, "I am a thef, scil. lappi&dtail; with swiche synne, an&dtail;
swiche a cryme, an&dtail; I a&mtail; a grete synner."  The secounde
is, "that it is displesing to me þat I have grevi&dtail;
go&dtail; so muche, for the whiche I am stressi&dtail; to come
heþere."  An&dtail; the thirde is, "þat if I may passe
hens, by the wey of satisfaccio&ntail;, I shulde not then
neuer torne ayene to synne."  An&dtail; yf ye do so, with outen dowte
ye shulle have euerlastynge lyf. Ad quam nos
&c.

26.1:
[ Second Version.  XXXVIII. ] Addit. MS. 9066. Story. Lampadius reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, that was right
mercifu&llbar;; wherfore o&ftee; grete mercy he ordeyne&dtail; a lawe,
that who that were a man-sleer, a Ravenour, an eve&llbar; doer, or a
thee&ftee;, and were take, and brought before the domesman, yf he
myght sey iij. trouthes, so truly that no man myght agay&ntail;-sey
hem, he shul&dtail; have his ly&ftee;, witℏ a&llbar; his heritage.  ¶ There fille a chaunce aftir,
that a knyght whos name was Plebeus, wente to the wode, and a&llbar; that come by the wode, he slougℏ, or
spoile&dtail; hem of a&llbar; that thei hadde&ntail;.  ¶ Whan the
Iustice her&dtail; this, he sente spies for to take hym; and whan he

sai&dtail; to hym, "Frende, thou knowest the law; sey iij. trouthes,
or els without doute thou shalt be hange&dtail; or I ete."  ¶ The
knyght sai&dtail;, "scilence, and I sha&llbar; fulfille the law."
whan scilence was made, the knyght sai&dtail;, "Frendes, the first
trouthe is this, that I sha&llbar; shew to you alle, that a&llbar; the
tyme of my ly&ftee; I have ben a thee&ftee;, a manqueller, and a

hem that stoden aboute, "is it sothe that he saitℏ?" thei
sai&dtail;, "yee, but yf he ha&dtail; be&ntail; an eve&llbar; doer, he

he sai&dtail;."  ¶ Than the domesman aske&dtail;, "Whicℏ is
the secon&dtail; trouthe?" he sai&dtail;, heryng a&llbar;, "it
displeasetℏ me meke&llbar;, that ever I come hedir."  the
domesman sai&dtail;, "forsothe we beleve the wele; telle vs now the
thir&dtail; troutℏ, and thou hast fulfille&dtail; the law."
¶ he sai&dtail;, "the trouthe is this I sha&llbar; shewe to you;
An&dtail; I myght ones scape, I shul&dtail; neuer come to this place
agayne with my goo&dtail; wille."  The domysma&ntail;, whe&ntail; he

an&dtail; haste sauy&dtail; thy lyfe.  Go now therefore, an&dtail;
from hensforwarde be a good man, an&dtail; wil no more offende agaynes
go&dtail; ne the Emperour."  then þe knyght wente, and
Endi&dtail; his life in pease. Reduccio. This paragraph split to add div3, moral Frendes, this Emperour is oure lorde Ihesu Criste, that ordeyne&dtail;

0.1:
Evfemianus was a wise Emperour Reignynge
in the citee of Rome; the whiche Emperour ordeyni&dtail; a lawe,
þat who so euer come to his yate, an&dtail; gaf iij. strokes at
the yate, an&dtail; the porter openi&dtail; the yate, he shulde come
in to the Emperour, & have eny service þat he wolde aske.
So þere was in that tyme a po&rtail; ma&ntail; in the citee,
calli&dtail; Gwido, and
he thought in him selfe þus, in a tyme, "I am po&rtail;,
an&dtail; þerefore it is better þat I go to þe
Emperoure, & serve him, þanne for to dwelle he&rtail; euer
in poverte & sorow."  he come to the yate, an&dtail; as lawe was,
he yafe iij. strokes o&ntail; the yate.  Þe porter openi&dtail;,
& aski&dtail;, whie he cnokke&dtail;?  "For I canne serve my
lorde," quo&dtail; he.  "Þe&ntail; I shall brynge the afore
him," seide the porter.  when he was afore þe Emperoure,
þe Emperoure seide to him, "dere frende, what maner of service
canst thow do?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "I can serve yowe with þe
beste in al maner of service; an&dtail;, sir, the first that I can do
is, I can slepe when oþere me&ntail; wakithe, & I cane wake
whe&ntail; oþere me&ntail; slepe; þe secounde is, that I
can taste goo&dtail; drinke; þe third is, that I can be&dtail; men to mete; þe fourthe is, that I
canne make a fire withoute smoke; the v. is, I can teche men to the
holy lon&dtail;, so that thei shul go saf, & come saf."
"Þes beþe," quo&dtail; the Emperou&rtail;, "goode &
fai&rtail; poyntes, & nedeful to me; thow shalt abide here; I
shalle make þe stiwarde of my house."  & then he
enclini&dtail; his hede, & thonki&dtail; him.  And when Guido was
sett in office, in the hote somer, whe&ntail; alle me&ntail; lust
Reste, he labouri&dtail; swyftly abovte, & purveide
to the Emperour al maner of nedefu&llbar; necessarijs, þat he
spente in wynter; & when oþere me&ntail; labouri&dtail; in
winter, þen he Reste, for he ha&dtail; labouri&dtail; afore; and
thus he fulfilli&dtail; his service fyrst rehersi&dtail;,
scil. þat he couthe wake when oþere slepte, & slepe
when oþere men wake&dtail;.  An&dtail; when the Emperour harde
this, that he ha&dtail; fulfilli&dtail; so welle & so wysely [the
first service], he calli&dtail; to him his boteler, & seide to
him, "dere frende; gvido þe stiwar&dtail; saide to me, that he
cowthe wel taste gode drynke; lat see; take vyneg&rtail;, &
wy&ntail;, & must, & put hem to-geder in a cuppe, &
þenne we shulle he&rtail; what he shalle seye, when he hathe
I-tasti&dtail; it."  Þe boteler di&dtail; as the Emperour
comaundi&dtail;; an&dtail; when Guydo taste&dtail; þe drynke, he
saide, "hit was gode, it is gode, & it shal be gode,"
scil. vyneger was gode, & that is for þe preterit tyme;
wy&ntail; is gode, & þat is for the presente tyme; and muste
shalle be gode, & that is for the future tyme.  an&dtail;
whe&ntail; the Emperour har&dtail; this, he commendi&dtail; þe
stiwarde ouer alle his sarvauntes.  then sone aftirwarde [was] the day
of the nativite of the Emperour; & he clepi&dtail; Gwido to him,
& seyde, "dere frende, þowe knowest wel þat þi thirde service is for to
bi&dtail; me&ntail; to mete; an&dtail; þere for go, an&dtail;
by&dtail; al my frendes in the Empyre, that thei Ete with me in the
day of my byrþe."  Gwido went ouer þer al þe Empi&rtail;, &
he ba&dtail; noo&ntail; of his frendes, but al þe Enmyes of the
Empire, so þat in the tyme of þe feste, the halle was
filli&dtail; with the Emperours Enmyes.  whe&ntail; the Emperour sawe
this sight, he was hilie mevi&dtail; in his spirite, an&dtail;
calli&dtail; gwido, & saide, "de&rtail; fren&dtail;, thow toldeste
me that thow covdest bi&dtail; men to mete, an&dtail; he&rtail; thow
hast I-bede al my&ntail; enmyes, a-yenste my precepte & wyl; what
canst þou seye to this?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "ye
chargi&dtail; me that I shulde bidde al your frendes to your feste,
but I have not I-do so, an&dtail; why? for al-wey when your frendes
come to yow, they we&rtail; worshipfully Reseyvi&dtail;, but so
we&rtail; not yow&rtail; enmyes; an&dtail; ther fore I have bode hem
to feste, that they may, by the goode feste & your good
che&rtail;, bicome you&rtail; frendes."  An&dtail; so it was or tyme
þat þe feste was do&ntail;, alle echo&ntail; we&rtail;,
made his frendes.  Þenne þe Emperour seide, "do now thi
iiij. service." "yis, sir," saide he.  he gaderi&dtail; a grete
multitude of woode an&dtail; stikes, that were
I-drie&dtail; in somer by fy&rtail; & by sonne; & by vertu of
hir drinesse he made a gret fire, withoute smoke, & þat so
clere, þat the Emperour an&dtail; a&llbar; his frendes we&rtail;
warmi&dtail; & commforti&dtail;. Then þe saide the Emperour to him, "do
now thi v. service, scil. teche men how they shul go to the holy
lon&dtail;; for þere comithe mony to me, an&dtail; wolde lerne
to go thedir."  The&ntail; seide he, "sir, lat hem folow me to
þe banke of the see."  & knytes & Squieris folowe&dtail;
him to the see.  An&dtail; when he was þere, he loky&dtail;
abovte in the see, & saide to the peple, "Sirs, se ye not
þat [I] see?"  "what is that?" quo&dtail; they. "lo!" he seide,
"Rochis in þe see; for in a Roche is a bryde, þe whiche is
in a neste, an&dtail; she hathe vij. briddis; & as longe as
þat bridde dwellithe in hir nest, al the see is in tranquilitee,
þat who so euer goþe þere by to the holy londe, he
shalle in pes go & come; but whe&ntail; þe bri&dtail;
fleeþe oute a-wey, then al þe see is I-troubeli&dtail;,
& with oute dowte, yf any ma&ntail; goo þene þenne, he shalle be
dreynte; & þerefore lokithe welle, þat þe
bri&dtail; be in hir neste, when ye shul go." "how shulle we know,"
quo&dtail; þey, "whe&ntail; þe brydde is in hir neste,
an&dtail; when she is oute?"  He aunswer&dtail;, an&dtail; saide,
þat she levithe neuer his nest, but for this cause.  "Þere
is," he seide, "a noþere
birde, hir enmye; & þat birde stodiethe & laborithe with
al hir myght for to infecte hir nest, or hir eyre&ntail;, to distroye
hir & hirs; & when she perseyvithe hir, she fleeþe,
& þen is al the see I-trowbeli&dtail;." Þenne saide
they, "how shulle we defende & lete that bri&dtail;, þat is
enmye to hir, that she come not to the neste?"  then seyde he,
"Þere is no thinge vndir hevin þat þat bri&dtail;
hatithe so muche as she dothe the blode of a lambe, For yf it
we&rtail; in the nest, or a-boute it, she dorste not come þere
to."  Þenne þei dide as Gwido seide to he&mtail;; &
thei passi&dtail; to the holy londe, & turni&dtail; a-yene
withoute hurting or disese.  when þe Emperour harde telle howe
wyslye he ha&dtail; fulfilli&dtail; his services, he avauncy&dtail;
him to hye dygnitee, an&dtail; to grete worshipe.

1.1:
DEre Frendis;
this Emperour is the Fadir of hevin; the whiche made a law, that eche
ma&ntail; þat yaf iij. strokes at the yate of þe palys, or
of holy chirche, þe&ntail; the porter, scil. þe prest,
sholde opy&ntail;. the iij.strokes bethe prayere, almis,
an&dtail; fastyng; for with oute&ntail; dowte, who so euer dothe thes
iij. he shalle entir the yate.  An&dtail; þerefor towching
praye&rtail; hit is I-wrety&ntail; thus, Petite,
et accipiatis, vt supra. an&dtail; towching fastinge
Iero&mtail; seithe thus, Tunc Est preclara apud
deum abstinencia, cum animus Ieiunat a culpa , þis is
to sey, hit is fey&rtail; abstinaunce an&dtail; fastynge to the sight
of go&dtail;, when a ma&ntail; absteynithe fro synne; also it is
I-seide, ioel. ij. Conuertimini ad me,
&c. be ye conuerti&dtail; to me.  An&dtail; towchyng
almes hit is I-seyde, Date elimosinam, & omnia
munda sunt vobis , yevithe almes, an&dtail; al that is clene
shalle be yevi&dtail; to yowe.  Gwido knokkithe, for that he wolde
mynyst&rtail; to þe Emperour—how so?  Eche pore man, that
comithe naky&dtail; out of the wombe of his modir, comithe an&dtail;
knokithe at the yate of baptisme, & askithe baptime, in the whiche
echo&ntail; of vs be-hotithe to do v. maner of services to go&dtail;.
the firste is to wake in goode werkes, when oþere me&ntail;
slepithe in synne, & for to slepe, whe&ntail; oþere
me&ntail; wakithe, as dothe
thevis & mychers; & so ye may in the somer, scil. in þis
worlde, purvey for nedis of þe soule ayenste wynter,
scil. þe day of dome.  Þe secounde service is to taste
gode drinke.  Þe drynk is noute elles but passio&ntail; &
penaunce; & þere of seithe oure sauioure þus, Potestis bibere calicem
quem Ego bibiturus sum , "May
ye," seithe Criste, " drynke of the same cuppe that I shalle drynke of,
scil, suff&rtail; the passio&ntail; þat I shalle suffre.
An&dtail; þerefor seide Gwido, It was goo&dtail;, scil.
penaunce in this worlde was gode to seintis, that bethe now glorious
in hevin; It is goo&dtail;, scil. it is gode that we do penaunce in
this worlde for our synnes; hit shalle be gode,—how so?
whe&ntail; a man shalle be glorifie&dtail; in body & in soule, in
the day of dome.  The thirde is to bidde men to mete, as Gwido
ba&dtail; alle enmyes; after the worde of oure saveoure, ¶ Non veni vocare iustos, sed peccatores ad
penitenciam , þis is to sey, I come not to calle
Rightwysmen, but I come to clepe Synful men to penaunce; an&dtail;
þerefore eche of vs is bounde&ntail; for to shew an&dtail; teche
þe wey of helthe to synful me&ntail;.  The iiij. seruice is to
make fyre with oute smoke.  that fire is not elles but that þou
love go&dtail; & þy neybou&rtail;, scil. go&dtail; aboue al
thinges, with al þi sovle, an&dtail; with al thi
mynde, an&dtail; þi neyboure as thi selve, with oute&ntail;
smoke of envy or wreþe.  The v. is to teche me&ntail; to the
holye londe, scil.  þou muste teche or take the wey to hevene by
the see of this worlde, for as the see Ebbithe & Flowithe, so þe worlde is now Riche, now pore, now hole,
now seke.  Rochis in the see is þe body of ma&ntail;; þe
nest in the Rocℏ is the herte in the bodye; the brydde in the
nest is the holy goste, that dwellithe in the body of man; the
vij. chekenis ben þe vij. werkes of mercy.  An&dtail; dowtles as
long as this bri&dtail;, scil. the holy gost, dwellithe in the nest of
þe herte, as longe may the ma&ntail; passe Restfully by this
worlde towar&dtail; hevene; but yf the holy gooste passe oute, &
fle awey fro synne, þe&ntail; is alle the
see, scil. al the worlde, is trovbeli&dtail;, & whi? for al that
is in þe worlde oþere it is pride of lyf, wrong covetise of ye&ntail; or
wrong covetise of
Fleshe. the bri&dtail; that is enemy is þe devil, the whiche
euery day & in eche hou&rtail; is besy to enfecte the nest of the
holy goste with dedly synne; & whenne hit is so, the holy gost
levithe the, & then hit sha&llbar; be to the a perlewse case.
An&dtail; therfor do as Guido di&dtail;, spercle the blo&dtail; of a
lombe in thi nest, scil.  have mynde of the passio&ntail; of Crist,
that he sufferit for the; & yf thow do so, the holy goste wolle
holde his nest, that thow shalte wel go to the holy londe,
scil. þe kyngdo&mtail; of hevene. Ad quod
nos &c.

text.28:
[ XXIX. ] MARDONIUS ÞAT WAS A WISE EMPEROUR. (THE ATTRIBUTES OF GOD.) Harl. MS. 7333. Mardonius was a wyse Emperour Regninge in the citee
of Rome, yn the londe of who&mtail; ther was a philesophe&rtail;, to
who&mtail; wee&rtail; I-putte iij. sonys of a grete kynge, to be
enformi&dtail; an&dtail; tawte wel & wyselye.  the philesophir
gouerni&dtail; hem, & tawte hem.  Aftirwar&dtail; hir fadir wolde
knowe by hem, whom they shulde mo&rtail; gladliche worshipe for hir
go&dtail;, wheþere Iubiter or mercury?  then the firste sonne
aunswerde, & seide, that Iubiter was a mytier & a strenger
go&dtail; þan mercurye.  An&dtail; then saide the fadir,
"powe&rtail; or myght makithe not oo go&dtail; better than
anoþere, for powe&rtail; but yf it be the better
vsi&dtail;, it may be cause of wickidnes."  Then he aski&dtail; of the
secounde sone, whom he wol&dtail; worshipe for his go&dtail;?
An&dtail; he saide "Iouem."  "whi?"  quo&dtail; the fadir.  "for
Iouem," seithe he, "hathe suche wisdo&mtail;."  Þenne seide the
fadir, " sone , wisdom makithe not oo go&dtail;
better than anoþere, & whye? for hit be cause of wickidnes
& of pryde."  An&dtail; then he aski&dtail; the thir&dtail; sone,
whom he wolde worschipe for his gode?  An&dtail; then he saide,
"mercury."  "whi?"  "for he is benyngne & mercyful."  "Sone,"
quo&dtail; he, "pitee makithe not oo go&dtail; better than
anoþere, for it is not noyng to no ma&ntail;.  An&dtail;
þerefore, de&rtail; sonnes, yf þere be swiche o&ntail;
that is boþe myti, wyse, & gracious, he may wel be
I-clepi&dtail; go&dtail; of goddis."  An&dtail; þerefore thei
made hem a ymage, þe whiche þei worshipi&dtail;, as for
hir go&dtail;; & þei write in on arm, Voco , I calle; an&dtail; in his brest, Expecto , I abyde; an&dtail; in the secounde arme, Remitto , I forgeve.  & þerefore by
goode argument, sithe that Criste is boþe stronge, & wyse,
an&dtail; pacient, vs must worshipe him as for oure go&dtail;, afore
al goddes, & only love him, qui est benedictus
&c.

0.1:
Story. Pwas [was] an Emperoure Reignyng in the citee of Rome, &
a-mong al oþere thinges he lovi&dtail; wel huntinge.  An&dtail;
as he Rode in a certe&ntail; tyme by a forest, he saw a ma&ntail;
Rynne afore him, with al the myght of his bodye, & an vnycorne
Rynnynge aftir him, wher thorowe the man was gretly a-dredde, that for
fe&rtail; he felle in to a gret diche.  neuer þe les he toke holde by a tree,
by the whiche he wa&ntail; oute; & then he loki&dtail; downe,
& he saw at the fote of the tree an hidowse pitte, an&dtail;
a&ntail; orible drago&ntail; þere in, myning at the tree,
an&dtail; abyding with an opin movthe when he shul&dtail; falle; &
beside this drago&ntail; were twoo bestes, þe to&ntail; was
white, the toþere was blak; & þey gnowe at the Rote of
the tree with alle theire myght, to throwe hit downe, in so muche that
the wrecchi&dtail; ma&ntail; felte it wagge; & abowte the sydes of
þe diche we&rtail; iiij.  frogges sterting, the whiche witℏ
hir venemovse brethe envenemy&dtail; al the diche. He cast vp his
ye&ntail;, an&dtail; he saw a passage of hony fallyng fro braunche to
braunche; & he sette his herte so moche to this swete syght of
hony, þat he forgate that oþere pere&llbar;.  So
þere happi&dtail; a fren&dtail; of his go by the wey, & for
he sawe him in so gret perille, he fet to him a laddir, that he myght
come downe Safliche; but he yaf him so muche to this swettnes, that he
wolde not thens, but yete hony, an&dtail; made him murye, &
for-gate þe perillis.  An&dtail; with in short tyme he felle
downe in to the mowþe of the drago&ntail;; an&dtail; the
drago&ntail; yede downe in to the pitte, & devouri&dtail; him.
0.2:
MORALITEE. DEre frendes, this Emperoure is to
vndirston&dtail; Crist Ihesu, þe whiche ouer al oþer
lovithe huntyng of soulis;
& in his hunting he be-holditℏ a man,

Story. Pompeius was a wyse Emperoure Reignyng in the cite of Rome, the
wiche ha&dtail; a faire dowter, name&dtail; Aglaes, an&dtail; she
ha&dtail; ij.  vertues ouer al oþere maydens; þe fyrst
was, she was faire in face, & plesaunt to þe ye of
me&ntail;; the secounde was, sche was so wyght of fote, that no ma&ntail; myght Rynne with hire by a grete
space, but that she wolde come to the marke longe afore him.  when the
Emperour sawe thes twoo vertues in his dowter, he enioye&dtail;
an&dtail; was glad in al his herte; an&dtail; he made a
proclamacio&ntail; in al that londe, that who so euer wolde rin with
his dowter, an&dtail; come to the marke afore hir, he shulde we&dtail;
hir with goodis infinite; an&dtail; yf ther we&rtail; eny, þat
wolde profre him selfe to Rinne with hir, & myght not wynne of
hir, he shulde lese his hede. he&rtail; for lordes of estate, as
dukes, barons, & knyghtes, come thikke, an&dtail; proferi&dtail;
to Rin with hir, but þere was no&ntail; that myght holde fote
with here; þerfor echo&ntail; for hir fayling loste hir hedis, as the lawe was.  so þere was in
þe citee a po&rtail; ma&ntail;, þe wiche thovght in him
selfe, "I am pore, an&dtail; come&ntail; of lowe kynrede; & hit is
a comun crye I-made, that yf eny ma&ntail; myght by crafte or by
cautile passe in Rynnynge the dowter of the Emperou&rtail;, he shulde
wedde hir, & be hiliche avauncy&dtail;.  & þerefore, yf
swiche a po&rtail; felow as I myght ouercome hir by cautil, wherby
that I an&dtail; al my kin myght be enhie&dtail; & honovri&dtail;,
sothely hit wer a goode torne." what dude he but yede, an&dtail;
purveyde him of iij. cautils; scil. of an honest Garlonde of Rede
Rosys, in a Ria&llbar; a-Ray; the secounde cautille of a silky&ntail;
gyrdil, sotilly I-made; for þe damyse&llbar; comunely lovithe
swiche fantasijs; the thirde of a sotil purse made of silke,
honouri&dtail; with precious stonis, an&dtail; in this purs was a
balle of iij. colowris, an&dtail; hit ha&dtail; a
superscripcio&ntail;, þat saide thus, Qui mecum ludit, nunquam
de meo ludo saciabitur, þis is to seye, he that pleithe with me,
shalle neuer have I-nowhe of my pley.  he putt vp in his boso&mtail;
þes iij. lakayns, & yede to the yate of the palys, &
cride, & saide, "Come, fai&rtail; damisel, I am Redy to Rynne with
þe, an&dtail; to fulfille the lawe in al poyntes."  An&dtail;
whe&ntail; thes wordes we&rtail; borne to þe Emperour, he
comaundi&dtail; his dowter to Rinne with him.  Þe damisel
loki&dtail; oute at a wyndow, for to se him; & when she ha&dtail;
sen him, she defie&dtail; him in hir herte, an&dtail; saide to hir
selve, "Alas! þat I, that have ouercome so many noble me&ntail;,
now shulde Rynne with suche a chorlis sone as þou art;
neuerþeles me must fulfi&llbar; the wi&llbar; of my fadir."  She yede,
& made hir Redy to Re&ntail; with him, & come to him; &
bothe thei stode to-geder, for to begynne to Rynne. An&dtail;
whe&ntail; þei hade Ronne a while, the mayde ha&dtail; Ronne
afore him a grete weye. when that oþere sawe þat, he caste
afore hire the fai&rtail; garlon&dtail;; and as sone as she sawe the faire
garlon&dtail; afore hir, then she torni&dtail;, & toke it vp,
an&dtail; sette it vppo&ntail; hir hede, an&dtail; made so gret
dilectacio&ntail; þere in, þat that oþere Ran fer
afo&rtail; hir. when she saw that, she wepte bitterly, an&dtail; in a
grete wrethe cast a-wey the garlonde, & Ran, & ouertoke him.
An&dtail; as sone as she was by him, she toke vp hir honde, an&dtail;
yafe him a grete boffete vndir the cheke, and seide, "lewde wrecche,
wel bysemithe þi siris sonne to wedde me!"  An&dtail; fer she Ra&ntail; afore.  & when he saw that, he toke oute a gyrdille, an&dtail; caste
it in the same maner afore hir ayene; & as faste as sche ha&dtail;
a sight þere o&ntail;, she bowe&dtail; downe, & toke it vp,
& gyrde hir þere with; an&dtail; ha&dtail; so grete lykyng
þere in, þat she lefte Rynnynge, & by þat tyme
he was fer afore hir. whenne she caste vp hir ye&ntail;, & saw
him, she made grete lamentacio&ntail;, an&dtail; toke þe gyrdil
in anger, an&dtail; bote hit with her teþe [in thre] partis;
& Ran ayene in al the myght þat was in hir, & ouertoke
him, & yaf him a grete boffet, an&dtail; Ranne fro him, &
saide, "what, harlot! trowist thow to ouercome me?"  Þat
oþere was wily, & wol&dtail; not caste þe purs, vnto þe tyme þat he come ner þe marke; and
þenne he cast þe purse, as he dude þat othir thing.
& thenne she rest aye&ntail;, & toke it vp, & openy&dtail;
hit, & toke oute the balle, an&dtail; Radde the
superscripcio&ntail;, scil. he that pleithe with me, sha&llbar; neuer
be suffisi&dtail; of my pley. An&dtail; tho she bega&ntail; to pley
with the balle so longe, þat þe Iogeler was afo&rtail; at
the marke; an&dtail; so tho she made muche lamentacioune; & he
weddi&dtail; hir, & ha&dtail; grete Richesses, as the lawe wolde. MORALITEE. DEre frendes, þis Emperoure is oure
lorde Ihesu Crist; þe fai&rtail; dowter is þe soule of
man, made like him selfe, & clansi&dtail; fro original synne by
baptyme; & hit is swyfte in Rynnynge, scil. goode werkes, while
that he is in his innocense, & þat so swifte , that no dedely synnys may ouercome hir;
& so thei lese hir hedes, scil. hi&rtail; powe&rtail;, whenne
þat þey maye not ouercome hir.  Þe po&rtail;
ma&ntail;, þat Imagenithe þes cautilis, is the devil,
þe whicℏ studijthe nyght & day to ouercome innocence;
an&dtail; þerfor he purveithe him of iij. cavtilis, first of a
garlonde.  [By] the garlonde we maye vndirstonde pryde, & by this
Reso&ntail;, For a garlonde is not sett on the arme, ne in
no&ntail; oþere party of the body; hit is I-sette vpo&ntail; the
hede, for it shulde be sene. in the same wyse wol the
prowde man be sen, & sprede his hemmys; an&dtail; þere fore
seithe Austine, Cum superbum videris, filium
diaboli esse non dubites , þis is to sey, when thowe
seist a proude ma&ntail;, doute the not þou seest the sonne of
the devel.  Þerefore when the devil castithe this garlonde of
pryde in thin ye&ntail;, wepe, as di&dtail; the damisel; & do of
that garlonde of pryde, an&dtail; caste it into the diche of
contrucio&ntail;, & so þou shalt yeve þe devil a
buffet, & ouercome him.  Thenne whenne þe devil seeþe
þat he is ouercome, he temptithe a man
yn an noþere synne, & castithe afore him a gurdil of
lecheri; of whiche maner girdil thus seithe Gregorius, Cingite lumbos vestros in Castitate ,
þis is to seye, or þis is to vndirstonde, Gurdiþe
youre lendys in chastite. for who so euer is gyr&dtail; with the
gyrde&llbar; of lechery, certenlye he levithe the Rynnyng of goode
lyf, & is ouercome with the devil; as the Apostle seithe, Nullum Opus bonum sine Castitate , þis is to
seye, Þere is no gode werke with oute Chastite.  & ther-for
do as she di&dtail;; smite the gurdi&llbar; in thre, scil. in
praye&rtail;, fastyng, an&dtail; almesdede, an&dtail; withe oute
dowte, þenne þou shalt ouercome the devil.  Aftir
war&dtail; this po&rtail; ma&ntail;, scil. þe deuil, castithe forthe a purs
with a balle,—what is that? ye wit wel a purs is opin above,
an&dtail; shut be-nethe, & that betokenithe the hart of man, that
shulde euer be opy&ntail; to hevenly thinges, & shut
to Erthely thinges.  Þe twoo cordis, that seruithe to Opy&ntail;
þe purs, & to shitte, signifiethe love of go&dtail; & of
thi neybou&rtail;; the bal that is Rounde, & colovri&dtail; so
diuerselye, betokenithe the vice of covetice, that is meui&dtail; as
wel in the olde as in the yonge; an&dtail; þerefor the
Reso&ntail; that is wreti&ntail; aboute is trewe, wher it is I-seyde, Qui mecum ludit, nunquam saciabitur , for
the covetouse ma&ntail; ca&ntail; neuer be filli&dtail;.  &
ther-fore lete vs be ware that we pleye not with the balle of
covetise, as she dude; for yf we forsake go&dtail;, & yeve vs to
transetorie godis, an&dtail; vanites, sothely we shul neuer
þenne come to the glorie of euerlastynge lyf. Ad quam &c.

Story. DOmicianus
Reigne&dtail; a wise Emperour in þe cetee of Rome, & in his
Empye&rtail; was a gentil knight, þe whiche ha&dtail; only
asonne, that he moche lovi&dtail;.  In a tyme þis
sonne come to him, an&dtail; saide, "fadir I am a yong ma&ntail;;
sothely, yf it be youre wille, I wolle go a-bowte to castelles & kyngdomes, & purchase me
frendes, þat I may, when ye beth go&ntail; henys oute of this
worlde, haue knowlech." "yis," quo&dtail; the fadir, "hit shal wele
like me, so þat þou shew to me, whe&ntail; thow comyst
ayene, what frendes þow hast gety&ntail;."  Þenne seide
he, "yis, fadir, þi wille in that cas shalle be
fulfilli&dtail;."  The yonge ma&ntail; travayli&dtail; by certeyne
kyngdomis, contreis, & cetees; & at the ende of
iij. yee&rtail; he come home to his fadir. & þe fadir was
hili gladdi&dtail; with his presence, & seide, "sonne, how seist
thow? hast þow purchasi&dtail; eny frendes?" "ye, sir," he
saide, "[I have] founde&ntail; iij.  frendes sithe I yede; an&dtail;
the first frende I loue more than my selfe, an&dtail; ther-fore I
wol&dtail; for his love shede my blode, yf nede we&rtail;; the secounde I love as moche as my
selfe; But the thir&dtail; I love litil, in syght of the oþere."
Þenne seide þe fadir, "sone, hast thow previ&dtail; ony of
thes iij. frendes?"  "Nay, sir," quo&dtail; he.  Þenne
quo&dtail; the fadir, "do þou aftir my counsai&llbar;, & hit
shall like the.  Go, & slee a Sweyne, & put it in a sacke;
an&dtail; at mydnyte [go] to þe firste frende, & sey to him, 'dee&rtail; Frende, help me nowe in my grete
nede, for thorow chaunce I have slayne a ma&ntail;, an&dtail; he is
he&rtail; vpo&ntail; my backe in a sacke;' &
the&ntail; thow shalt see what thi fren&dtail; wol sey to the.  Aftir
that, go to þi secounde frende, and so to the thirde; an&dtail;
write al hir aunsweris in thin herte."  Þe sonne yede, as the
fadir saide to him; and at mydnite he co&mtail; to the yate of the
firste frende, þe whiche þat he lovi&dtail; more than him
selfe, & cnocki&dtail; at his gate.  Ano&ntail; as his frende
harde him cnocke, he Ros, & lete him in, & seide, "frende,
þou art welco&mtail;."  "A! frende," quo&dtail; that
oþere, "I am come to the in my grete nede, for I love thi bodye
more than my selfe, an&dtail; þerefore socoure me in this
myschieff; for I have thorow vnhappe slay&ntail; a ma&ntail;, & he
is he&rtail; vppo&ntail; my backe in a sacke; an&dtail;
þerefore, I pray the, that thow wolt hide him, & hele the
cors of this dede ma&ntail; in some prive place of thin house; for yf
þe cors be founde with me, doutles I mot be hongi&dtail; for
him." "ye," quo&dtail; the oþere, "thowhe thowe were my fadir, I
wolde not do that for the; for sithe thow hast slayne the ma&ntail;,
thow arte worthi to be dampni&dtail; for him.  Neuerþeles, for
the gret frendshipe þat hathe I-be a-twene vs he&rtail; afore by
longe tyme, I shalle yeve to the ij. ellene of lynone clothe, for to
lappe i&ntail; or for to keuery&ntail; þy body, when that thow
arte hongi&dtail;."  Thenne the yonge ma&ntail; yede to þat
othir frende, that he loui&dtail; as moche as him selfe, an&dtail;
knocki&dtail; at his yate.  Ano&ntail; whe&ntail; he harde þe
cnokkyng, he ros, & openy&dtail; þe do&rtail;, & kyste
him, an&dtail; worschipfully Resseyvi&dtail; him.  Þenne spake
the yonge man, & saide, "A! goode frende, helpe me nowe in my
grettest nede þat I euer ha&dtail;.  I have thorowe Encomberment
slayne a man, an&dtail; he
is here with me, an&dtail; þer-fore, for al the frenshipe that
is be-twene the & me, leye him in sum previ place of thin house;
for yf he be founde withe me, I am but dede."  "Nay,"
quo&dtail; that oþere, "that þou canst not make me do;
be&rtail; him hens, & make the mury with him,—whi woldist
thow slee him?  But yette frende, I shalle tel
the, I wolle not have a-do withe him; [but] for the grete love
þat hath I-be be-twene vs twoo, I shalle go with the to the
iebet; an&dtail; aftirwar&dtail; I sha&llbar; purveye me of an
noþere frende."  Þe yonge ma&ntail; was hevy with thes
wordes; an&dtail; yede to anoþere frende, scil. him þat he
lovi&dtail; but litle, & cnocki&dtail; at the yate. he ros vp, as
sone as he harde his voyse, an&dtail; lete him in, & kiste him,
an&dtail; saide, "fren&dtail;, þat is halfe my soule, welcome be
þou to me!" þenne saide that oþer, "sothelye I
a&mtail; ashame&dtail; to speke with the, for I have do litle for
þe, or ellis nought, neuer in al my lyve; an&dtail;
þerefore with grete shame I may shew the my&ntail; eronde." "ye,
hardly," seide that oþere, "shew me what thow wolte."  "For
sothe," quo&dtail; that oþer, "I have vnhappili slayne a
ma&ntail;, & he&rtail; I be&rtail; his body o&ntail; my bak,
an&dtail; þere-fore, I praye the, helpe me in this gret nede,
an&dtail; yf ye wolde hide the bodye in youre house, ye myte not do
for me a better torne, for yf it be founde with me, I am but dede."
"Nay," quo&dtail; that oþere, "I wolle not hide the body, but I
wolle dye for the to morow o&ntail; the Iubet; an&dtail;
þerefore, I praye the, love thowe neuer frende so wel as me
aftir my dethe, but yf he wolle dye for the, as I shalle." when the
yonge man har&dtail; him sey þus, he felle downe o&ntail; his
knees, & praide him that he wolde for-yeve him, þat he
ha&dtail; lovi&dtail; the oþere twoo frendes so moche, and him
so litle or not.—"an&dtail; ther-for fro hens forwar&dtail; I
sha&llbar; neuer love my selve so moche as þe."  [The]
oþere tooke him by the necke, & kiste him;
& he yede home, & tolde his fadir how it was with þe
iij. frendes, &c. MORALITEE. GOo&dtail; men, this Emperour is the fadir of hevene;
by the knyght but[he] vnderstonde prelatis of holy chirche; by the
sonne is vndirstonde euery Criste&ntail; man.  An&dtail; so many of vs
getithe vs frendes, but thei faylithe vs in oure nede; an&dtail;
þere-fore seithe þe wise man, Est
amicus meus, et non permanebit in tempore necessitatis , This
is to seye, ther is a frende at the table or at the mete borde, the
wiche wolle not or shal not abide in tyme of nede.  Þe furste
frende, that thow lovist more tha&ntail; thi selve, is this worlde;
for we sethe euery day that me&ntail; wolle for the worlde, &
worldly thinges to be hadde, putte hem selve in perilis of see, in
perelles of batai&llbar;, an&dtail; of dampnacioune.  An&dtail;
ther-for it is wel I-previ&dtail;, that thei loviþe more the
worlde than hem selve, but in tyme of nede, scil. of deth, when the
soule shalle passe fro the bodye, aftir the wille of go&dtail;, &
þat þe body be yevin to wormes, thenne the worlde, &;at
þowe louist so muche, shalle faile þe; In so muche that yf
þou have too elles of lyno&ntail; clothe, to lappe thi body
Inne, it is a grete thing.  The secounde frende, that thow louist as
muche as thi selve, is thi wyfe & thi childerine, the whiche in
tyme of dethe wil go with the to the sepulcure, an&dtail; wepin a
litle for the, but whe&ntail; þou arte in the erthe, þey
gothe home, an&dtail; studiethe whom they mow have in thi stede.  The
thirde frende, that thow lovist so litle, is oure lorde Ihesu Criste,
for yf thowe come to him with a clene herte, in tyme of thi nede, he
wolle not fayle the; & þerefore it is I-seyde, In quacumque hora peccator ingemuerit, salvus erit , þis is to seye, in
what hou&rtail; the synner waylithe, or is sory for his
synns, he shalle be saf.  An&dtail; þerefore when the synner
deservi&dtail; by his wickednesse euerlasting dethe, thenne Crist,
goddis sonne come, & toke dethe for him o&ntail; the Iubet
of&ftee; þe crosse.  An&dtail; þerfo&rtail;, goode siris,
lat vs bowe owre knees,
an&dtail; aske mercy of him, that we plesi&dtail; thes othir two so
moche, & him so litle, þat is an vnmutable frende, a gentil
frende, & a myghty frende.  Now pray we him enterly to be oure
frende, whos frenshipe neuer failithe, Qui cum
patre et spiritu sancto omnia regit secula .  Amen.

Agios was a wyse Emperour Reignynge
in the citee of Rome; the whiche lor&dtail; ha&dtail; iiij.  dowteris,
of wiche o&ntail; was clepi&dtail; Mercy, þe secounde
sothefastnesse, the thirde Ryghtwyssenes, an&dtail; the iiij. Pes. he also ha&dtail; a sone passyngly wyse
an&dtail; witty, an&dtail; was clepi&dtail; vsias, an&dtail; no man
myght be likeni&dtail; to him in no kynne sciens.  he ha&dtail; also a
sarvaunt with him, whom he moche avaunci&dtail;, an&dtail; that
withouten ony deseruinge.  So the Emperoure in this maner is thought
in a certeyne day to preve þat sarvaunt, & seide to him,
"de&rtail; fren&dtail;, I have hili avauncy&dtail; the to grete
dignitee, an&dtail; þerefor thow arte the more be-holde&ntail;
to me.  I commytte here to thi kepynge swiche a contree; an&dtail;,
sir, yf thow kepe it wele, þou shalt have more avauncement;
an&dtail; in the oþer syde, yf I fynde in the eny maner of
tresoune, þou shalte suffre ther-fore þe foulest dethe."
Þenne spake þat oþere, and seide, "sir, in al that I
can or may I shalle fulfille your wille."  Sone aftir
that he ha&dtail; be go&ntail; to this contree, he du&dtail; trespas
& transgressiouns a-yenste þe wille & comaundement of
the lorde.  whe&ntail; the Emperoure harde telle þis, he come
thidir, an&dtail; put a defaute to this forsaide sarvaunt; the
sarvaunte was provde, & sturdy, an&dtail; yaf but litle credence
to him.  Then þe Emperour beynge in gret wrethe, for
violacio&ntail; of his precepte & comaundement, calli&dtail; to
him iiij.  cruell tormentours, an&dtail; comaundi&dtail; to o&ntail;
of hem, þat he & his felowes shoulde bynde him honde &
fote, & caste him in presoune; to the secounde he comaundi&dtail; to helde him qwyke;
an&dtail; to the thirde & to the iiij.  he comaundi&dtail;, that
their shulde finally sle him.  Thenne thes tormentoures purposyng to
fulfille the comaundment of the Emperoure, Thei toke this
wrechi&dtail; ma&ntail;, an&dtail; turmenti&dtail; him with al maner
of peynis.  An&dtail; hit happi&dtail;, that o&ntail; of the dowteres,
scil.  þat is to sey, mercy, yede by the presoune þe same

þat piteful sight, she myght not but have pyte,—for hit is
þe propirte of mercy to have pite & compassio&ntail;.  &
so she Rente of the clothinges of hir body, & of hir hede,
an&dtail; pulli&dtail; of hir hee&rtail;, and yellid, and cride;
an&dtail; Ranne with alle hir myght to hir fadir, the Emperour,

Ano&ntail; come hir syster sothefastnesse, an&dtail; aski&dtail; of
hir fadir whi hir suster wepte so? "for mercy, þi suster,"
