hadde mercy with him, an&dtail; þerefore he hadde no powe&rtail;
but to take him oute of presoune, an&dtail; presenti&dtail; him to his
fadir.  An&dtail; whe&ntail; pes harde telle howe hir brothir
ha&dtail; browte ayene þe trespassoure, she come a-yene to the
Empy&rtail;; & the sone made acorde a-monge the susteris,
an&dtail; that mercy & truthe mette to-gedir, Rightwisnesse &
pes hathe I-kyste.

33.1:
MORALITEE. DEre Frendes, this Emperoure is the fadir of hevin; the
transgressoure, that Resseyve&dtail; þe contree, was Adam, the
first fadir, that dude ayene the comaundement of go&dtail;, when that
he yete of the appi&llbar;; an&dtail; ther-for he was yoven to iiij.  tormentoures.
the firste tormentour, þat sette him in presoune, is þe
priso&ntail; & the exile of this present lyf; an&dtail; ther-fore
it is wreti&ntail; and saide thus, Heu mihi !  quia incolatus meus prolongatus est ,
this is to seye, "Alas! for my dwellynge place is proloyne&dtail; or
y-made fer , scil.  ioye of paradys, that was
lost by synne.  The secounde Tormentour, þat hilde him, is the
wrecchidnesse of this worlde, the wiche Tormentiþe vs with
almaner of peynis & wrecchidnesses.  The thirde, that slowhe him,
is dethe, þe whiche iugylithe an&dtail; sleithe vs alle.  The
iiij.  þat devourithe him, bethe wormes; for when a man deyithe,
he is yevin to the mete of wormes.  An&dtail; therfore the iiij.
tormentours of this worlde bethe þe preso&ntail; of this worlde
or exil, þe wrecchidnesse of the worlde, dethe, an&dtail;
wormes; the whiche wolle have vengeauns an&dtail; peyne, for trespas
of the first ma&ntail;, vnto the ende of the worlde.  for the
preso&ntail; holdiþe vs, wrecchidnesse of the worlde bryngithe
in alle evelis, deþe sleþe vs, & wormes gnawiþe vs. but oure lorde Ihesu Crist,
sone of the hie Emperour, toke mercy with him, an&dtail; lepte ouer
hillis an&dtail; dalis, scil.  þat is to seye, the
wrecchidnesses of this worlde, an&dtail; enteri&dtail; the prisoune of
helle, & toke vs oute.  whenne mercy sawe this, that the sarvaunt
was turni&dtail; ayene, she ha&dtail; no mater to playne, ne
soþefastnesse ha&dtail; no cause to pleyne, for hir fadir was
founde&ntail; true; an&dtail; Ryghtwyssenesse , the thirde suster, was not
pleyning, for in the transgressio&ntail; rightwyssenesse was
excusi&dtail;, so þat dethe was ha&dtail; & lyf ayene,
perisshin>ee; & fyndynge aye&ntail;.  Then pes seynge hir
sistris alle in acorde, an&dtail; Echo&ntail; of hem havinge hir
purpose, she turni&dtail; ayene; For whenne contencions & stryf
we&rtail; cessi&dtail;, the&ntail; pes was felashipi&dtail; among
he&mtail;.  An&dtail; now have ye har&dtail; playnli how that mercy
an&dtail; sothefastnesse mette togeder, & Rightwisnesse & pes
kiste.  To the kyssyng of hevenliche Reconsiliacio&ntail; he bringe
vs, that is name&dtail; saluator Ihesus, Qui cum
patre &c.

0.1:
Story. Theodosius Reigne&dtail; a wyse Emperoure in the citee of Rome,
the whiche loui&dtail; afore al othir thinges the melody of þe
harpe.  hit happeni&dtail; o&ntail; a certeyne day, as he Rode in
huntinge, that he harde the soune of a Swete harpe, an&dtail; hit was
so swete to his hert, that he thowte that he was Ravishi&dtail; in him
selfe.  he Rode aboute this forest, & sowte wher this harpe myght
be founde; an&dtail; at the laste he sawe a pore man, sytting be a
water syde, harpynge:  & þer come oute of that water so
swete a melody, that the Emperou&rtail; har&dtail; neuer non suche
afo&rtail;.  An&dtail; therfore the Emperoure Spake to him, an&dtail;
saide, "how is this, that so swete a melody passithe oute of thin
harpe?"  "Sir," quo&dtail; he, "I shalle telle yowe the sothe.  I have
dwelt by this watir with my wyf an&dtail; with my chylderin xxx.ti
ye&rtail;; an&dtail; go&dtail; hathe yeve me swiche grace, that euer
when I harpe ther is so gentil a melodie, that alle the fishis in the
water comithe evin to my&ntail; honde, an&dtail; so I take my
sustenaunce, wherby I, & my wyf, & my childeri&ntail; bethe I-founde an&dtail;
susteyni&dtail;.  but, sir, ther [is] a muche sorowful cas ayenste me,
for in that oþere side is an hisser or a siblatour, and he
hissithe so swetlye, that nowe a-dayes the fisshe drawithe to him,
& levithe me; an&dtail; þerfor, sir, I praye yow of your
helpe a-yenst this hisse&rtail;."  "I shalle yeve the goode
counsei&llbar;," quo&dtail; the Emperour, "For I have he&rtail; in my
purse a golde&ntail; hoke, the whiche I shalle yeve to the; an&dtail;
þer-for take hit, an&dtail; bynde it to the ende of a longe
yerde, an&dtail; then smite vpo&ntail; thin harpe, an&dtail; what tyme
þou seist hem meve in the water, draw hem with the hoke to the
londe; þan þou shalt see the hissinge of the hisser
sha&llbar; do the none harme."  Þenne the pore man was
gla&dtail;, an&dtail; du&dtail; al as the Emperour comaundi&dtail;
him.  An&dtail; when he beganne to harpe, the fisshis gonne meve to
him-warde; an&dtail; whe&ntail; the hisser saw that, he turni&dtail;
fro&mtail; that place withe gret confusio&ntail;, an&dtail; the pore
ma&ntail; dwelt stille al the tyme of his lyfe, an&dtail; endi&dtail;
gode lyfe.
0.2:
MORALITEE . NOw, sirs , this Emperoure is Criste Ihesu,
that lovi&dtail; welle to go  aboute huntinge of soulis in forest, scil.  in holy
chirche; he lovithe wel the harpe of holy Scripture an&dtail; of
theologie.  Þe pore ma&ntail;, that sittithe by the water, is a
prechoure or a prelat, the wiche owithe to sitte by the worlde, &
not al in hit, scil. not to yeve his herte in worldlinesse; an&dtail;
he owithe to have an harpe in his honde of holy scripture, an&dtail;
ther with to worshipe go&dtail;, after the seinge of the salme, Laudate eum in psalterio et cithera ,
þis is to seye, preysithe you&rtail; lor&dtail; go&dtail; in the
sawtrie & in the harpe.  But in dayes that bethe now prechours may
seye, Allas! for while þey smitithe the harpe, scil. speke the
wordes of go&dtail;, þere comithe an hisser, scil. þe
devil, & he whistelithe so swetly, þat fisshis, scil.
synners, herithe no worde of go&dtail;, but turnithe hem to
dilectacio&ntail; of synne, to whiche the deuil temptithe hem.  for
the devil hissithe be mony diuerse weyes,—& how?  For he
makiþe some to slepe, that they he&rtail; not the wordes of
go&dtail; an&dtail; som he makithe to chatir faste; an&dtail; hem
þat he may not make chatery ne slepe, he makithe hem to have
litle swettnesse or no&ntail; to the worde of go&dtail;; an&dtail;
some he makithe to leve þe gode wordes of go&dtail;, so that in
some snare or grynne he wolle cacche hem. loo! ma&ntail;, al thes
hissinges hathe þe deville, for to de&rtail; the, an&dtail; to
drawe the fro þe worde of go&dtail;; an&dtail; therfor it is
nedefulle to euery prelate or prechoure, that hathe sogettes to
gouerne, to take an hoke, scil. to aske the grace of go&dtail;
a&yogh;enst thes hissinges; & so with grace he shalle drawe many
synneres oute of synne to hevene. he bringe vs thedir, Qui cum patre & spiritu sancto regnat per
secula! Amen.

34.1:
[ Second Version.  VIII. ] Addit. MS. 9066. Story. THeodosius reigne&dtail; in Rome, that amonge a&llbar; the goodes
of the worl&dtail; he chose the harpe, and also for to hunte, in

melodie of an harpe witℏ so swete a sowne, that he was

the ende of the Forest he founde saw sittyng a poore man, beside a watir, havyng in his honde an harpe,
*and harpe&dtail; omitted ; o&ftee; the whiche wente oute so swete a

sai&dtail;, "frende, I pray the telle me, how so swete a melodie gothe

yove&ntail; gyf me grace, that whan I

of the watir there omitted cometℏ an

therfore therfor, sir in this nede I aske

sha&llbar; yeve the.  have it, and bynde it fast in the ende of a

the hissyng of the hissa&rtail; sha&llbar; not availe agay&ntail; the

The hissare , whan he sawe this, witℏ
shame and confusio&ntail; he went away; And the poore man

crist, that meke&llbar; love&dtail; to hunte after soules in the

Some he maketℏ for to slepe; Some he maketℏ to Iangle; and
some he maketℏ to have no savou&rtail; in goddes worde; and some

fu&llbar; spedefu&llbar; for every prelate or prechou&rtail;, that he

heve&ntail;.  To the whiche place go&dtail; brynge vs!  Amen.

0.1:
Story. SOlemius was Emperoure in the citte of Rome, the whiche hadde a
dowter that was fai&rtail; an&dtail; glorious to the syte of me&ntail;
an&dtail; he loui&dtail; hir so muche, that he ordeyni&dtail; to kepe
hir nyght & day with v. arme&dtail; knyghtes; & he
ordeyni&dtail; a gret master, sotil & connynge in many crafftes
an&dtail; artes, for to Enforme & for to theche the kni&yogh;tes
the best maner wher by thei myght kepe the mayde.  Also this Emperoure
ha&dtail; a grehounde, that he lovi&dtail; moche; & he ba&dtail;
the master of kni&yogh;tis to kepe him welle eke.  An&dtail; after
this, the Emperour made a stiwarde in his house, ouer al
thes.  So in a certeyne nyght, as he lay in his be&dtail;, he thowte
to visite þe holy londe, & he thowte to fulfille it in dede;
an&dtail; he ordeyni&dtail; þerefore an&dtail; made al thinge redy for his viage.  An&dtail; when al thing was Redy, he
clepi&dtail; to him his stiwarde, an&dtail; saide, "fren&dtail;
my&ntail;, I purpose to go to the holy londe, & ther-for I
commytte to þy powe&rtail; my dowter þat I love moche as
my&ntail; oune harte; an&dtail; ther-for I charge the she want
nothynge, but þat she have alle thinge that a goode virgine
shulde have, that may torne hir to Ioye an&dtail; to comforte.  Also
þat þow do welle with my grehounde."  An&dtail; he
[saide], "I leve in to thi kepinge the v. kni&yogh;tes, that bethe the
keperes of my dowter, þat hem want or lak nothing; an&dtail; yf
þou do al this wele in my&ntail; absence, þow shalt have,
whe&ntail; I come home ayene, faire yiftes an&dtail; grete
avaunsmentes."  Thenne saide the stiwarde, "ser, whan ye go, I pray
go&dtail; go with yowe, an&dtail; youre wille shalle be
fulfilli&dtail; towching my persone." the Emperoure yede to the holy
londe, an&dtail; the stiwarde kepte wel his charge a longe tyme aftir
his goynge; til in a certeyne day he sawe the damise&llbar; walke by
hir selve in a gardy&ntail;.  Þo was he Ravashi&dtail; into the
love of hir, an&dtail; yede to hir, an&dtail; ayenste hir wille lay be
hir in synne; an&dtail; when the synne was I-do, he hati&dtail; hir
more than euer he di&dtail; eny creature, & put hir oute of the
palyse, in so muche that for defavte she beggi&dtail; hir brede fro
do&rtail; to do&rtail;.  An&dtail; whe&ntail; the kni&yogh;tes sawe
that she was aweye, thei yede to the stywar&dtail; and putte to him
suche a cryme.  What dude he but yede, & spoyle&dtail; al the
kni&yogh;tes of hir goodes, an&dtail; put hem oute of the palys.
whenne they were putte oute of the palyse, some of hem, for defaute of
godes, bicome thevis, some man-killers, an&dtail; dude muche harme;
an&dtail; when þe master of the kni&yogh;tes saw this, he
blami&dtail; him; & þerefore he slowhe him ano&ntail;.
Þe stiwarde kepte wele the grehounde, but at þe laste he
brak loos, an&dtail; Ranne aweye.  At the laste tithinges come to the
Stiwar&dtail;, that the Emperour drewe homewar&dtail;, an&dtail; wolle
sone be at home.  the stiwarde thought to him selfe, "hit may not be
but I shalle be accusi&dtail; of my wicke&dtail; service, þat I
have done.  Aha! I sha&llbar; do wel ynow; my lorde is gracious , & ther-for I sha&llbar; go my
selfe, & accuse me, & put me in his grace." when the stywar&dtail;
harde telle, that the lor&dtail; was nye at the palys, the
stywar&dtail; made him naki&dtail;, an&dtail; toke iij. cordes in his
honde, & met so with his lorde; an&dtail; when the Emperou&rtail; saw the
stiwar&dtail; come ayenste him in swiche aray, he mervayli&dtail;
hilie in his herte.  An&dtail; when the Stiwar&dtail; come in to him,
he kneli&dtail; downe, an&dtail; salude the Emperour.  Þenne the
Emperoure seyde, "sey, man, how is it, þat thowe metist me in
swiche a-Ray, sithe thow art my stiwar&dtail;, & sholdest have
mette with me withe a gret host?"  "A! lorde," quo&dtail; the
stiwar&dtail;, "ther is happi&dtail; with me swiche a cas sithe ye
went, þat it is most semynge that I mete with yow thus."  "what
cas is that?" saide the Emperoure.  "A! sir, ye must aske of me firste
whi an&dtail; wherfore I be&rtail; thes iij.  cordes in my honde."
"whi," quo&dtail; the Emperoure, "berist þou þe iij.
cordes?"  "sir," saide he, "þe first cor&dtail; is to byn&dtail;
me honde & fote, an&dtail; that so strongly, til blode brest oute
in eche side, for I have wel deservi&dtail; hit; The secounde corde is
to bynde me to the fete of horse, so longe, til tyme þat
þe pavement have I-frett the fleshe fro the bone, for, sir, that
peyne is litle I-nowhe in sight of the trespas that I have
trespassi&dtail; to yowe ; an&dtail; the
thirde corde is to honge me withe in a Iebette, so longe, til tyme
that briddis come to my body, an&dtail; have etyn hit vp, for,
si&rtail;, this peyne is litil y-now for swiche a trespas as I have I-do to yowe.  &
þerefor, gracious lorde, I aske grace & mercy, for I dar not
confesse myn synne, tyl tyme that I have graunt of youre grace."  "Sey
what hit is," quo&dtail; the Emperour, "for sothely þou shalt
have grace, what so euere hit be, for the gret pite that I have now in
þi contriciou&ntail; an&dtail; lownesse."  "Allas! lorde," saide
he, "for I have stolne the floure of virginitee fro your douter,
an&dtail; put hir out of the palis, that I wot welle, For grete favte
she beggithe hir mete fro do&rtail; to do&rtail;; an&dtail;, sir,
þi kni&yogh;tes I have Robbi&dtail; & spoyle&dtail;,
an&dtail; put he&mtail; oute of the palys, þat for mischef thei
Robbithe an&dtail; spoylithe, for hir lyf-lode; an&dtail; the master
of hem I have slayne; but thi grehounde I fedde wele, an&dtail; tyde
him with a cheyne, but he brake his cheyne, an&dtail; Ra&ntail; awey,
that I not wher he is."  when the Emperour harde thes wordes, he was
hili mevi&dtail; in mynde, & thought that it was a cursi&dtail;
ma&ntail;; an&dtail; þo he seyde thus, "& hast thowe foyli&dtail; my dowter,
an&dtail; put hir oute of the palis, that I lovi&dtail; so muche;
& hast þou put oute an&dtail; Robbi&dtail; my v. gode
kni&yogh;tes, & slayne the master, hir techer?  Now for sothe,
& be seyntes that I have sowte, we&rtail; not that I graunti&dtail; to the
grace, þow shuldest not scape þe foulest dethe þat I
coude deme; Neuerþeles my worde mot stonde, an&dtail; þou
art a wyli felowe.  Þou shalt go now, & seche my dowter, for
thow shalt wedde hir to wyfe; an&dtail; yf eny harme come to hir hens
forwar&dtail; in thi defaute, soþely þou shalt have dobble
peyne. an&dtail; go brynge the kni&yogh;tes ayene, an&dtail; sette hem
as they we&rtail;, an&dtail; Restore hem to hir goodes ayene,
an&dtail; also the grehounde, an&dtail; tye him stronglye; þat
þere neuer mo&rtail; fro hennys forthewar&dtail; be founde
defavte in the, towching eny of them."  Then the stiwar&dtail;
kneli&dtail;, an&dtail; thonki&dtail; the Emperoure for his mercy
& grace; an&dtail; yede abowte in the Empi&rtail; to seche the
mayde, the kni&yogh;tes, & the grehounde; & he fonde hem,
& browt hem home, an&dtail; with grete worshipe weddi&dtail; the
mayde, an&dtail; Restori&dtail; ayene the goodes to the kni&yogh;tes,
an&dtail; Endi&dtail; fai&rtail;. MORALITEE . DEre bretheri&ntail;, this Emperoure is oure lorde Ihesu Criste;
the fai&rtail; dowter is the soule of man, made to his owne likenesse;
þe v. kni&yogh;tes beth the v. wittes, armi&dtail; thorow vertu
of baptisme, an&dtail; thes bethe yeve to kepe the sovle.  the master
of the kni&yogh;tes is Reso&ntail;, the stiwar&dtail; is euery liuer
to whom go&dtail; hathe yeven a sowle to kepe, vp peyne of lesynge of
euerlastinge lyffe.  But then the wrecchi&dtail; ma&ntail; ofte tymes
hathe no mynde of perilis that bethe comynge; & þe&ntail; he
lesithe his soule by synne, & puttithe it oute fro&mtail; the
palys of hevene, an&dtail; so it gothe fro do&rtail; to do&rtail;, as
a corrupt an&dtail; a fili&dtail; virgine.  & also he puttithe
oute the v. kni&yogh;tes, scil. þat is to seye, ynwittes,
an&dtail; spoylithe hem of goo&dtail; vertues; an&dtail; so sum of hem
beþe thevis, & some lurdaynes.  so þe si&yogh;te
seeþ vnleful sites, þe eris herynge vnhonest an&dtail;
vnleful talkinges, lesynges, & bacbitinges, an&dtail;
detracciouns; an&dtail; no wonder, for hir
gouernour, scil. Reso&ntail;, is slayne, as ofte as a man is
gouerni&dtail; by sensualite, an&dtail; by sterynge of fleshe,
an&dtail; not by Reso&ntail;.  but the grehounde, scil. the fleshe, is
I-fe&dtail; deyntili, & bounde with the chayne of luste, the
whiche ofte tymes brekithe, & dothe many Evelis.  but, sirs,
þe Emperoure comithe nowe fro the holy londe, scil. ou&rtail;
lorde Ihesu Criste is to come fro&mtail; the holy londe, scil.
fro&mtail; hevene, to þe dome; an&dtail; ther-for, yf we do
wysely, late vs do as the Stiwar&dtail; di&dtail;, when he harde telle
of the comynge of his lorde, scil. for to thinke that develis
an&dtail; al the worlde wolle accuse vs to him, but yf we come
afo&rtail;, an&dtail; accuse oure selvene.  An&dtail; þerfore

Story. CEsar was a wise Emperoure Regnynge in the citee of Rome; the

we&rtail; nulye sette.  Ano&ntail; as the keper saw this harme, he

Story. Alexandir was a wyse Emperoure Reignynge in the citee of Roome;

 An&dtail; he ordeyni&dtail; a lawe, that no man shulde at his borde

 & anoon he was accusi&dtail; to the Emperou&rtail;; an&dtail; the

þow do homage to me fro hens forþewar&dtail;, an&dtail;
þat þou have no lorde but me; an&dtail; þe&ntail; I
foryeve the þy defaute an&dtail; trespas in this cas."

38.1:
MORALITEE. DEre frendes, þe Emperoure that makithe this law, is oure
lorde Ihesu Criste, þat ordeyni&dtail;, þat yf a childe,
scil. a clene soule, yif to a ma&ntail; for to norisshe in goode
werkes & vertues, deye, or be hurt, he shulde [lese] euerlastinge
lyfe.  but for sothe ther bethe mony men of holy chirche, that havithe
cure of&ftee; Sowles, goþe to the feyris, vnprofitable
si&yogh;tis, as tavernys, wrestelynges, huntynges, an&dtail; swich
vanyteys of þe worlde, that Ofte the wolfe, scil. the devil,
takithe in hir defaute the soule out of the cradille of holie chirche,
& Rynnitℏ þere withe to wode of helle.  but thenne
þe herde, scil. a goode prelate or a prechoure, [that] dwellithe
in the tree of holy writte, blowithe,
scil. prechiþe with the horne of goddes grace; an&dtail; so the
soule is delivere&dtail; fro the powe&rtail; of a synner, an&dtail;
berithe a signe, þat it was som tyme in the seruitute of the
devil, an&dtail; now is lyvery&dtail;.  An&dtail; þerefo&rtail;
it behovithe vs to be sarvauntes, an&dtail; submitte vs to go&dtail;,
as longe as wee live in this worlde, to plese him, that we mowe come
to him, Qui cum Patre
&c.

0.1:
SElestinus Reigni&dtail; a wyse Emperoure in Rome, an&dtail; he
ha&dtail; a faire dowter; an&dtail; in his tyme ther was a kny&yogh;te
that lovi&dtail; this dowter, but he thowte in him selfe that he dud al in
veyne, fo&rtail; he thow&yogh;t as for sothe, that the Emperoure wolde
not late him to have hir, for he was vnworthi ther to.
Neuerþeles he thought, yf he myght be ony wey have love of the
damiselle, it were I-nowe to me.  he yede ofte tyme to the
damise&llbar;, an&dtail; aspie&dtail; hir wille; & she saide to
him a-yene, that he travayli&dtail; al in veyne.  "for trowist thow,"
quo&dtail; she, "with thi deseyvable and faire
wordes to begile me?  nay, sir, be my soule, hit shal not be so!"
Þenne saide the kni&yogh;te, "what shal I yeve to the, and late
me lye by the a nyght?" "Not þowh þou woldest yeve me an
c. marke of florens," quo&dtail; she, "þou shalt not lye by me a nyght."
"Þe&ntail; hit shal be as þou wilte," quo&dtail; he.  what
dude he but purveyde him of so muche mony, scil. an c. marke of
floreyns, & yaf hir.  whenne nyght come, þe kni&yogh;te
enteri&dtail; in to the bed of the mayde, an&dtail; a-noo&ntail; he
was a-slepe; an&dtail; she dude of hir harnes, & come, & laye
downe by him; so the kni&yogh;te laye slepynge al the nyght.  O&ntail;
þe morow she Ros, & di&dtail; o&ntail; hir clothis, &
wishe her hondes; an&dtail; the kni&yogh;te a-woke of his slepe, &
thenne he saide, "come hedir to me, that I may do my wille with the."
"Nay, by the helþ of my fadir, that wolle I not," quo&dtail;
she, "for, frende, I do the no wronge.  Þow accordiste with me
that I shulde lye withe þe al nyte, an&dtail; so it is
I-do&ntail;; for I lay by the al nyght, & þou sleptest,
& proferdest me no solace; an&dtail; þerefore blame thi
selfe, & not me."  An&dtail; þe kni&yogh;te was hevy,
an&dtail; seide, "what shal I yeve to the, & lete me lygge by
þe anoþere nyght?"  "As muche," quo&dtail; she, "as
þou di&dtail; afo&rtail;, & no lasse."  "I assente," seide
he.  An&dtail; the kni&yogh;te yede, an&dtail; solde a&llbar; his
mevable goodes, an&dtail; made Redy an c. marke of floreynse; but se
now a marvelovse case!  for Right as hit was þe furste nyght, so
hit was in the secounde.  thenne the kni&yogh;te mervayli&dtail; more
þanne man may suppose, an&dtail; hevy he was, an&dtail; saide,
"Allas! fo&rtail; now have I spen&dtail; al my godes withe oute spede,
an&dtail; þerfore, þowhe þow I shu&llbar; dye þerefore, I wolle make
anoþere Ende.  how moche sha&llbar; I yeve the, an&dtail; late
vs be to-geder the thirde nygℏt?"  quo&dtail; the kni&yogh;te to
the damise&llbar;.  "sothely," she saide, "yf þou have me, as
þou paide afore, fiat voluntas
tua ." "I assent," quo&dtail; he, "þou shalte have þin askynge an&dtail; thi
wille."  Þe kni&yogh;te yede in to fe&rtail; contree, Til he
come to a grete citee, in the whiche we&rtail; many marchauntes, &
many philesophers; amonge the wiche was master Virgile, þe
philesofere.  then the kni&yogh;te yede to a grete marchaunt,
an&dtail; saide, "I have [nede] of monye, & yf thow wolt lende me
an c. marke vnto a certeyne day, I wolle ley to the al my londes,
vndir this conducio&ntail;, þat If I holde not my day, thow
shalt have my londes for euere."  Þenne seyde the marchaunt,
"De&rtail; fren&dtail;, I sette not so muche be thi londes, but yf
thow wolt make this covenaunt, þat I shalle sey to the, I wolle
fulfi&llbar; þi wille." "yis," saide he, "I am Redy to do thi wille, yf þou wolt do my
petucio&ntail;."  Þenne seide he, "whe&ntail; this couenaunt is
made, þat I shalle sey vnto the, þenne I shalle fulfille
þyne askynge; an&dtail; þe covenaunt shalle be this,
þat þou make to me a charter of thin owne bloo&dtail;, in
conducio&ntail;, that yf thowe kepe not þi day of payment, hit
shalle be lefulle to me for to draw awey alle the flesℏ of thi
body froo the bone, with a sharp swerde; an&dtail; yf thow wolt assent
he&rtail; to, I shalle fulfille þi wille." The kni&yogh;te
loui&dtail; the damise&llbar; so mocℏ, þat he
graunti&dtail; al this; an&dtail; made a charter of his owne bloode,
an&dtail; seli&dtail; it; & after the selying, this marchaunt toke
him the mony þat he aski&dtail;.  when he ha&dtail; the moneye,
he þoute to him selfe, "yf I gete [not] my wylle by this moneye,
I am but dede; nay, nay, it may not be so."  whe&ntail; he harde telle
of the grete name of maister virgile, he yede to him, an&dtail; seide,
"gode sir, I have previ counsei&llbar; to speke a-twene vs too,
an&dtail; I be-seche yowe of youre wise counsei&llbar; in this cas."
"Sey o&ntail;," quo&dtail; virgile, "an&dtail; I shalle telle the,
aftir my discrecio&ntail;."  "sir, I love the dowter of the Emperoure,
mo&rtail; þa&ntail; ye wolle trowe; an&dtail; I accordi&dtail;
with hir for a certe&ntail; sum of money.  I have be disceyvi&dtail;
two nyghtes i&ntail; swiche maner,"—& tolde alle þe
cas, as welle as he coude,—"an&dtail;, sir, nowe I have
borowe&dtail; of a marchaun&ttee; so moche moneye, for the same cas to
be fulfilli&dtail;, an&dtail; vndir this conducio&ntail; þat yf
I holde not my day of payment, hit shalle thenne be lefulle to him to
helde of alle the skynne of my body with his swerde, an&dtail; then I am but
dede; an&dtail; ther for, sir, I am come to yow, to have
counsai&llbar; & wyt, how I may bothe have helpe ayenste swiche a
pari&llbar;, an&dtail; also to have the love of that lovely lady."
"Þou hast made a lewde covenaunt," seide virgile; "For as a man
bindithe him withe his owne wille, right so he sha&llbar; be
serui&dtail;, be lawe of the Emperoure; & þerefore þou
shalt do wysely for to kepe þe day of thi payment, alle thinges
lefte.  An&dtail; towchinge þe damese&llbar;, I shalle yeve the
a tale of truthe.  bi-twene her shete & hir couerlyte of hir
be&dtail; is a letter of swiche vertu, that who so euer gothe with hir
to be&dtail;, he sha&llbar; ano&ntail; falle in to a dede slepe, &
he shalle not wake til tyme þat hit be put awey; an&dtail;
þerefore when thowe comest to hir be&dtail;, seche a-twene the
shete an&dtail; the couerlyte, an&dtail; þow shalt fynde the letre; an&dtail; whe&ntail; þow hast
founde hit, caste hit fer fro&mtail; the bedde, an&dtail; thenne Entre
in to the be&dtail;; for þou shalt not slepe til tyme that thow
hast doo&ntail; thi wille withe the damiselle, an&dtail; that shalle
torne to the gret honou&rtail; an&dtail; Ioye."  The kni&yogh;te toke
his leve at Virgile, an&dtail; thonki&dtail; him moche of his hie
counsei&llbar;; an&dtail; yede to the damyse&llbar;, an&dtail; yafe
hir the monye.  when ny&yogh;t come, the kni&yogh;t enteri&dtail; the
chaumbe&rtail;, an&dtail; preveli putte his honde bitwene þe
couerlite an&dtail; the shete, an&dtail; þere he fonde the
letter; & whenne he hadde hit, he caste hit fer fro the bedde,
an&dtail; lay downe, & feyni&dtail; as he hadde I-slepte.
An&dtail; thenne the damiselle, trowing that he ha&dtail; y-slepte, as
he dude afo&rtail;, she caste of hir clothis, & went to bedde.
Ano&ntail; þe kni&yogh;te sette hande to hir, as is þe
maner of be&dtail;; an&dtail; she perceyvi&dtail; that, and
pray&dtail; him of grace, an&dtail; to save hir
maydinhode.—"An&dtail; I sha&llbar; dovble al the monye that
thow hast yevin to me, an&dtail; yeve it to the."  Þenne said
he, "Thow lokist at a wronge hole; þy wordes bethe in wast; I
sha&llbar; now do in dede that I have longe labovri&dtail;
fo&rtail;;"—an&dtail; ocupij&dtail; him with hir body, as cours
is of kynde.  An&dtail; aftir he lovi&dtail; hir so muche, that he
drow so moche to hir compane, that he for-&yogh;ate þe
marchaunt; an&dtail; the day of payment was passi&dtail; by the space
of xiiij. dayes.  An&dtail; as he lay in a certe&ntail; nyght in his
be&dtail;, hit come to his mynde, the day that he made to the
marchaunt, an&dtail; a&llbar; his bowelles we&rtail; stori&dtail;
þere withe.  & þenne [he] saide to hir, "Alas!
woma&ntail;, þat euer I saw the, for I am but dede!  I
borowe&dtail; for thi love swiche a some of mony, for to pay at a certeyne day,
bi this conducio&ntail;, þat yf I pay not at my day, he
sha&llbar; have fu&llbar; powe&rtail; for to hilde of the fleshe of my
body, with out contradiccio&ntail;; an&dtail; now my day is
passi&dtail; fourtenyte ago, so hili I sette my&ntail; hert in the."
then seide she, "sorowithe not so moche; gothe to him, an&dtail;
debbelithe the mony to him; an&dtail; yf he wolle not, aske howe moche
he wolle have, an&dtail; I shalle paye it."  Þo was the
kni&yogh;te comforti&dtail;; he yede to the citee, an&dtail;
þere he mette with the marchaunt in the stret, an&dtail; lowly
he salui&dtail; him.  Þo saide the marchaunt, "so sey I not to
the." Þenne seyde the kni&yogh;te, "ser, for the trespas that I
have made ayenst youre conuencio&ntail;, I wolle dowble þe
payment."  "Naye," seide the marchaunt, "þat spake we not of; I wolle
have Right as þou dudist bynde the to me."  "Aske of me,"
quo&dtail; the knight, "as muche mony as thowe wolte, an&dtail; thowe
shal&ttee; be paide for my trespas."  "It is veyne that thow spekist,"
quo&dtail; the marchaunt, "for thowhe thow geve to me al the gode of
þi citee, I wolle have the covenaunt I-holde; & no&ntail;
oþere wolle I have of the, þan as the charter
asseli&dtail; makithe menciou&ntail; of."  An&dtail; ano&ntail; he
made the kni&yogh;&ttee; to be I-take, an&dtail; la&dtail; to the
caste&llbar;, an&dtail; sette him in a safe warde, abydinge the
Iustice.  when the Iuge was come, & satte in the dome, the
kni&yogh;t come to bar&rtail; amonge oþer presoners; an&dtail;
the marchaunt shewi&dtail; his letre afo&rtail; the Iuge.  Anoo&ntail;
as þe Iuge sawe þere his owne dede, he saide to alle that
stode aboute, "sirs, ye know welle it is the law of the Emperour, that
yf enye ma&ntail; bynde him by his owne free wille, he shal Resseyve
as he servithe; an&dtail; þerefore this merchaunt shalle have
covenaun&ttee;, as lawe wolle."  Now in al þis tyme þe
damyse&llbar;, his love, ha&dtail; sent kni&yogh;tes for to aspie
an&dtail; Enque&rtail;, how the law was pursue&dtail; a-yenst him;
& whenne she harde telle that the lawe passi&dtail; ayenst him,
she kytte of al the longe he&rtail; of hir hede, an&dtail; cladde hir
in precious clothing like to a man; an&dtail; yede to the palys
þere as hir lemo&ntail; was to be demy&dtail;, an&dtail;
saluy&dtail; þe Iustice; an&dtail; al they trowi&dtail;
þat she ha&dtail; be a kni&yogh;te.  An&dtail; þe Iuge
Enqueri&dtail;, of what contree she was, an&dtail; what she ha&dtail;
to do ther? She sai&dtail;, "I am a kni&yogh;te, & come of
fe&rtail; contree, an&dtail; he&rtail; tithinges that þere is a
kni&yogh;te amonge yowe, that shulde be
demi&dtail; to dethe for a&ntail; obligacio&ntail; that he made to a
marchaunt; an&dtail; þerefore I am come to deliuer him."
Þenne þe Iuge saide, "it is lawe of the Emperoure,
þat who so euer byndethe him with his owne propre wille &
consente, with oute enye constraynynge, he shulde be serui&dtail; so
ayene."  when the damise&llbar; harde this, she turni&dtail; to the
marchaunt, an&dtail; saide, "de&rtail; fren&dtail;, what profite is it
to the that this kni&yogh;te, that stondithe he&rtail; redy to the
dome, be slayne? it we&rtail; [better] to the to have monye, than to
have him slayne."  "Þou spekist al in veyne," quo&dtail; the
merchaun&ttee;, "for with oute dowte I wolle have the lawe, siþe
he bonde him so frely; an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; he shalle have
noo&ntail; oþer grace þan lawe wolle; for he come to me,
an&dtail; I not to him; I desiri&dtail; him not þereto
a-yenste his wille."  Þenne seide she, "I praye þe howe
moche shalle I yeve to have my petucio&ntail;?  I shalle yeve the thi
monye double, an&dtail; yf that be not plesynge to the, aske of me
what þou wolte, & þou shalt have?"  Þe&ntail;
saide he, "thow harde me neuer seye, but that I wolde have my
covenaunt kepte."  "Soþely," seyde she, "an&dtail; þou
shalt, trowe me.  Afo&rtail; yowe , sir iuge,
an&dtail; afore yowe alle, I sey now, sir iuge, yevithe a Rightwisdome
of þat þat I shalle sey to yowe.  ye have I-harde howe
moche I have proferi&dtail; this marchaunt for þe lyf of this
kni&yogh;te, an&dtail; he forsakithe a&llbar;, an&dtail; askithe the
lawe; an&dtail; that likithe me moche.  An&dtail; therfo&rtail;,
lordinges, that beþe he&rtail;, herithe me what I shalle seye.
ye knowithe welle, þat the kni&yogh;te bonde him neuer by
letter, but that the marchaunt shulde have powe&rtail; to kitte his
fleshe fro the boons, but þere was no couenaunt made of sheding
of blode; þere of was nothing I-spoke.  An&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; late him set hon&dtail; o&ntail; him anoo&ntail;;
an&dtail; yf he shede ony bloode with his shavinge of the fleshe, for
soþe then shalle the kynge have goode lawe vpo&ntail; him."
An&dtail; when the marchaunt harde this, he sai&dtail;, "yef me my
monye, an&dtail; I foryeve my accio&ntail;."  "For soþe,"
quo&dtail; she, "thowe shalt not have oo penye; for a-fo&rtail; al
this companye I proferi&dtail; to the al þat I myght, an&dtail;
þou forsoke hit, an&dtail; saydist withe a lowde voyse, I shalle
have my covenaunte; an&dtail; þerfo&rtail; do
thi beste withe him, but loke þat þow shede no blode, I
charge the, for it is not thin, ne no covenaunt was þere of."
Þenne þe marchaunt seynge this, yede awey confus,
an&dtail; so was the kni&yogh;tes lyf saui&dtail;, & no penye
I-payde.  An&dtail; she yede home ayene, an&dtail; dude of that
clothinge, & clothi&dtail; hir as she was afo&rtail;, like to a
woma&ntail;.  An&dtail; the kni&yogh;te yede home a-yene; an&dtail;
the damise&llbar; turni&dtail;, an&dtail; met him, an&dtail;
aski&dtail; howe he ha&dtail; I-spedde, as thowhe she ha&dtail; not
knowen ther of.  "A!  lady," quo&dtail; he, "þis day was I in
poynt to be dede for þy love, but as I was in point to be
dampni&dtail;, þere come in sodeynlye a knite, a fai&rtail;
an&dtail; wel I-shape, the whiche I sawe neuer afo&rtail;; an&dtail;
he deliueri&dtail; me by his Excellent wisdam, boþe from dethe
an&dtail; eke fro&mtail; payment of moneye."  "Þenne were thow " quo&dtail; she, "vnkynde, þat woldest
nat bidde that kni&yogh;te to mete, that so faire ha&dtail;
savi&dtail; the."  He aunswerde þere to, & saide, þat he come
sodenly, an&dtail; sodenly yede.  Þenne seide she, "knowiste
þow him, if þou seye him?"  "yee,"
quo&dtail; he, "Rigℏt wele."  She yede vp, an&dtail; cladde hir
as she dide afore; an&dtail; þen she yede forthe, an&dtail; the
kni&yogh;te knewe her thenne wele, an&dtail; for Ioye fel dovne
vpo&ntail; hire, an&dtail; saide, "blessi&dtail; be thow, &
þe houre in the whiche I fyrste knew the!" An&dtail; he wepte;
an&dtail; aftir he weddi&dtail; hir, an&dtail; livi&dtail; & deyde
in the service of go&dtail;; an&dtail; yelde to go&dtail; goode
sowlis.

1.1:
DEre frendes, þis Emperou&rtail; is þe Fadir of hevin,
oure lorde Ihesu Criste; þe dowter, þat is so faire, is
the sowle I-made to the similitude of go&dtail;.  Þe kni&yogh;t,
that stirithe hir to synne, is Euery worldly ma&ntail;, the whiche is
aboute bothe nyte an&dtail; day to foule his soule; an&dtail;
þerfo&rtail; he proferithe many grete yiftes, scil. veyne
worldly goodes.  [But as longe] as þe letre lithe in the bedde,
scil. vertues whiche þe soule receyvi&dtail; in baptime, so
longe he may not foule þe soule; an&dtail; so bethe they
contrarij&dtail; to-gedyr, scil. the sprite & þe fleshe;
& þerefo&rtail; seithe þe Apostle, Spiritus concupiscit aduersus carnem, et caro aduersus
spiritum, &c. This is to seye, Þe sprite
coveitithe ayenste þe fleshe, an&dtail; the fleshe ayenste the
sprite.  Þen þe kni&yogh;t, scil. þe fleshely man,
gothe to the marchaunt, scil. to the devil, as ofte as he delitithe in
dedly synne; & he writithe the charter, whe&ntail; he consentithe
to synne; he selithe hit, when he dothe the synne. for in holy writte
Effucio&ntail; of bloode is not elles but trespas in synnyng, or
effucio&ntail; bi cause of synne; as Crist shadde his bloo&dtail; by
cause of synne; an&dtail; so al that dothe synne bethe sarvauntes of
the devilis, as thes wordes witnessithe, Cuius
opera quis facit, seruus Eius est , This is to seye, Eche man
is seruaunt of him, whos werkis he worchiþe.  An&dtail;
therfo&rtail;, yf we do synne, we bethe servauntes of the devil.
virgile, that meuy&dtail; him to meve þe letre, is pryde of lyf,
þe whiche suffrithe not that a soule livithe not in clennesse.
For as sone as vertues bethe Remevi&dtail; by assentyng to synne,
assone the soule fallithe, an&dtail; a ma&ntail; is deliti&dtail; in
synne, þat he foryetithe þe euerlastyng lyf whiche he lost
for synne, til tyme that sekeness come of feblenesse, by povert, or
tribulacio&ntail;; & þenne swiche men bethe ofte tyme
attachi&dtail; by the marchaunt, scil. þe devil, in so moche
that the wrecchid ma&ntail; shalle have no powe&rtail; to make
satisfacciou&ntail; or sorowe for his synnes, but outerly stondithe in
perilis of dethe. thenne the damiselle seing this, she clotheithe hir
like to a knight. right so we shulde do; we shulde caste fro vs the
olde lyf, an&dtail; cloþe vs with a newe, scil. goode vertuys,
an&dtail; assende vpo&ntail; the palfrey of Resoune, an&dtail; so go
forthe to holy chirche, & þere pray go&dtail; with a fulle
herte, & allegge ayenst þe devil, that he sle vs not, by
cause that go&dtail; bowte vs. but then vs muste take awey the fleshe,

þat þere be no synne, elles þe Emperoure of hevene

du&dtail; a-yenst the marchaunt, witheouten dowte þenne shalle
the flesshe & þe sprite be marij&dtail;, to live in blisse,
&c.

0.1:

þe forsayde wedowe mette withe him, knelyng vppo&ntail; hir
knees, an&dtail; seide to him, "My lorde, do Right an&dtail; lawe, as thow haste ordeyni&dtail; þi selfe. for

þe Emperoure, "Þanne shalle I a-swage the lawe in him,

þerefo&rtail; takithe oute o&ntail; ye of my&ntail; hede,

1.1:
DEre Frendes, þis Emperoure is oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Crist;
that ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, that yf eny ma&ntail; fouli&dtail; a
virgine, he shulde lese his ye&ntail;, þat is, the light of
hevene. but the sone of the Emperoure deflouri&dtail; a virgine, scil.
a Cristen man, þat foulithe his soule by synne; an&dtail;
þerfo&rtail; the Emperoure Criste sorewithe, whenne þat
þe wedowe, scil. consciens, pleynithe; & þerefore he
for-soke his light in hevene, what tyme that he come dovne fro&mtail;
hevene, an&dtail; for oure transgressio&ntail; & oure trespas
putte him selve out fro&mtail; the light of hevene, takynge the forme
of a symple sarvaunt; an&dtail; not only di&dtail; oute one ye, but
suffri&dtail; al his body to be woundi&dtail; to dethe.  An&dtail; so
he wolle that þou, synner, suffre to have out an oþer ye,
scil. to do stronge penaunse wiþ him for thi synne, that
go&dtail; may seye that þou Gode may right ,
"as I suffre&dtail; penaunce fore þe, Right so do þou,
whenne þow art in dedlye synne." an&dtail; so, sir, þe
lawe of the Emperoure may be kepte, an&dtail; þou be saf, and
have þe empire of hevene. Ad quod nos perducat &c.

0.1:
Story. POlemius Reigni&dtail; a wys Emperoure in the citee of Rome,
an&dtail; he weddi&dtail; a wyf of the kyngdo&mtail; of spayne; the
whicℏ woman bare in his tyme iij. childeri&ntail;.  In a day
whene þe Emperes was a-grevi&dtail; wiþ the kynge, she
saide to him, "I telle þe sothely, on of thes childerin is
þi sone, an&dtail; the oþere too beþe not thin."
Þe Emperoure herynge thes wordes, seide to hire, "I pray
þe, tel me whiche is my sonne?"  "Nay," quo&dtail; she, "I wol
not, for yf I dude, þou woldest sette al thi cure & þi
love in him that we&rtail; thi childe, an&dtail; not o&ntail; the
Oþere; an&dtail; þerefore as longe as þou livist,
þou shalt have of echo&ntail; lik cu&rtail;, & love in
herte."  Þenne the Emperour heilde him stille, & wolde speke
no mo&rtail; of that mater.  An&dtail; whenne he laye o&ntail; his
dethe-be&dtail;, he calli&dtail; the iij. childeri&ntail; to him,
& seide, "deere frendes, I moste nedis dye nowe, an&dtail; I may
not eschew hit; an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; I have he&rtail; a
Rynge, þe whiche I yeve & bequethe to him of yow þat
is my sone."  An&dtail; aftir þes wordes he dide; & þe Emperoure was, as is þe maner & Resou&ntail;,
wurshipefulli burie&dtail;.  Aftir his buriinge the iij. childerin
made distaunce for þe Ring, an&dtail; that longe, til tyme
þat þe yonger broþer seide, "Þis is not worthe
to make suche a stryf; late vs go to the kynge of Ierusalem, þat
dwelliþe he&rtail; beside vs, & late vs stonde to his dome."
Þenne seide þey, "Þat is gode counsei&llbar;,"
Þey yede to þe kynge, & tolde him howe, & vndir
what wordes, þat hir fadir ha&dtail; biquethe his ring þing .  Anoo&ntail; þe kynge
made þe Emperour to be ha&dtail; out of þe Erþe,
& made his body be y-bounde to a tree; & he made echon of hem
to take a bowe & an arowe, an&dtail; ba&dtail; hem shete at him,
echo&ntail; aftir oþere; for he that smote deppest in to the
herte of him, he shulde have þe Rynge. they made hem Redy to
this werke, in so moche that the firste toke an arowe, & shet a
depe stroke in to the herte of
the dede body; þe secounde smote deppere than the firste; &
the yongest stoode a-fer, an&dtail; be-helde the folis shete.  "Come
nere," quo&dtail; the kyng, "an&dtail; shete thow; now late see, yf
thow mow passe hem." water fel fro his ye&ntail;, an&dtail; he saide,
"nay, go&dtail; forbede, sir, that I shul&dtail; do swiche a dispite
to him þat me gate! I nolde do it for al the
wordle."  Thenne seide the kynge, "I am now sekir þat thow art
his lawfull sone, an&dtail; the othir too bethe bastardes, an&dtail;
not of his blode, an&dtail; that is wel sene now; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; have he&rtail; this Ringe, as for thi Right. wel
wist youre fadir what he ment, when he bequathe the Ringe, &
saide, 'I yeve hit to him of yow, that is myn'" &c.  Amen!
0.2:
MORALITEE. DEre frendes, this Emperoure is oure lor&dtail; Ihesu Criste; þe
Emperes is holy chirche; þe iij. childerin bethe iij. kyndes of
me&ntail;; þe ringe that is rounde betokenithe hevene. by the
firste sone we vndirstonde Iewes & sarsinis; by the secounde sone
fals Cristen men, that aftir hir baptim drawithe towar&dtail; þe
devil; an&dtail; by the thirde sone we vndirstonde the chosy&ntail;
childerin of go&dtail;.  Nowe þe firste childe shetithe, scil.
Iewes & sarasins, the whiche trowithe not that he was I-bo&rtail;
of a virgine, & toke passio&ntail;, & suffri&dtail;
deþe, an&dtail; was I-burie&dtail;.  Þe Secounde sone is a
fals Cristen ma&ntail;; he smitethe depper, whenne he dothe a dothe a
dedely synne, þe whiche in tyme of baptime made
homage to go&dtail;, & forsoke the devi&llbar; an&dtail; alle his
pomperis; & in þat that he made an homage, he grevithe
go&dtail; mo&rtail; þa&ntail; a Iewe or a sarasyne, þat
nevir made none.  But the thirde sone, scil. a gode Criste&ntail; man,
he sorowithe muche, whanne he sethe go&dtail; so smite&ntail; by
synne, & he wolle not
shete by no maner; an&dtail; ther-fore to him, as to the worthi childe
an&dtail; a trewe sone, is yeve&ntail; the Rynge, scil. þe Ioye
of the kyngdo&mtail; of hevene. Ad quod nos
perducat &c.

0.1:
ARchilaus Reigni&dtail; a wise Emperoure in the citee of Rome, a semly
ma&nmacr;, an&dtail; of grete stature; an&dtail; this Emperour
desiri&dtail; gretly to have a sherte sotelyche I-made for his body,
an&dtail; wolde have it I-made by þe hondis of a virgine
vnfouli&dtail;.  An&dtail; therfore he sente messageris ouer al the
Empire, to loke yf eny swiche myght be founde, þat coude make
swiche a shirte, but they coude fynde noo&ntail;, but that they
we&rtail; corrupte, or vnperfite of the crafte, or vncunnynge in the mystery.  So o&ntail; a day, as this Emperoure went in
his orcharde, þere come to him a Secretarie, þat was nye
of his counsei&llbar;, an&dtail; saide to him, "sir, ther is a
damise&llbar; dwellyng he&rtail; in this londe, faire an&dtail;
gracious, an&dtail; merveilouslye sotil in crafte, þe whiche can
wel werche your sherte, aftir youre desire & vse." whe&ntail; the
Emperoure hurde that, he was gla&dtail; an&dtail; iocounde; he
calli&dtail; to him a messager, & saide to him, "go, in al the
haste þat þou may, for swiche a damesel, an&dtail; make to

& wise, & clene, for to do my desyre; an&dtail; yef to hir in

but iij. ynchis; an&dtail; sey to hir, that she make for me a shirte
of so litle cloþe, longe & brode y-nowhe for my body; &
yf so be that she by hir sotill crafte fulfille my wylle, in this cas
[she] shalle be my wyf."  The messager come to the damiselle,
an&dtail; in the name of the Emperoure he worshipfully gret he&rtail;,
an&dtail; seide to hir, "damisel, my lorde the Emperou&rtail; sendithe

lynne clothe, havinge in quantite iij.  inchis; an&dtail; he praythe

"Þat we&rtail; a wondirfull thing," quo&dtail; she, "neuertheles

Þe messager heringe thes wordes, he turni&dtail; home ayene,

0.1:
SAturninus was a wys Emperoure Reigning in
the citee of Rome; the which ha&dtail; iij. dowteris, that he
marij&dtail; vnto iij. dukes, with grete Ioye & withe grete

Aftir þis dethe, þe Emperou&rtail; come to the first

ma&ntail;, an&dtail; a worthi."  "Nay," quo&dtail; she, "I wolle
noo&ntail;, an&dtail; that for this skylle. ye wote welle, that I am
neyþere feire, ne semlye, ne plesynge to mannis ye; an&dtail; þerefore no ma&nmacr; wolle take
me for love, but for my Richesse; an&dtail; þerefore I make
my&ntail; avowe to go&dtail;,
þat swiche o&ntail; wol I none take."  Thenne the Emperoure come

lesse; an&dtail; yf I lovi&dtail; him lasse, þenne ther shulde
be no trew love bitwene vs, an&dtail; yf
I lovi&dtail; him as moche as I dude the firste, that ha&dtail;
my maydinhode, þe&nmacr; I dide out of Reso&ntail;, as me
semithe."  The Emperour yede to the Thirde, an&dtail; seide, "wolt
þou þat I gete to the a&ntail; husbonde; yf thow wolt
telle me, an&dtail; I shalle gete the o&ntail; fallyng to thin
Estate?" "A! go&dtail;
forbede," quo&dtail; she, "for holly chirche tellithe vs, þat a

1.1:
DEre Frendes, þis Emperoure is
go&dtail;; by the iij. dowteris, that bethe I-marij&dtail;, we may

0.1:
Story. FOlliculus a wise Emperoure
Reigni&dtail; in the citee of Rome; the whiche ordeyni&dtail; for a
lawe, that if a woma&ntail; dude avoutri vndir hir husbonde, þat
the man shulde be departi&dtail; fro hir, & euer aftir he shulde
be Redy with þe Emperour in bataile; an&dtail; yf so we&rtail;
þat he wa&ntail; þe victorie, he shulde have in the furste
day of his victorie iiij. honoures, an&dtail;
in the secounde day he shulde sustene iiij. hevynessis, þat he Enpridi&dtail; him not for the honours.
So in thilke dayes þer was a knyght I-calli&dtail;
Achero&ntail;, þe whiche hadde a fayre woma&ntail; to wyve;
an&dtail; this woma&ntail; lovi&dtail; anoþere kni&yogh;t, by
weye of synne.  hit bifel a cas, þat hir husbonde was
I-Redde&ntail; to his contre, of the whiche Ridinge that oþere
kni&yogh;t ha&dtail; certificacio&ntail;; & so he come in, &
lay by his wyf al nyght. An&dtail; in this place
we&rtail; iij. cokkes, that vsi&dtail; muche to crowe; An&dtail; as
the lady laye in hir bedde withe the kni&yogh;t, she harde the cokke
crowe, an&dtail; she seide to hir sarvaunt, "what menitℏ this
cok, that crowithe thus?"  Þe sarvaunt answeri&dtail; in this
maner, "the cok seithe in his songe, that thow dost thin husbonde
wronge."  then the lady seyde he shulde be dede; & so he was
indede.  Ano&ntail; the secounde coke bega&ntail; to crow,—"what
menithe this?" quo&dtail; the lady.  & þe servaunt saide,
"My felowe for his sothe sawe, hathe loste his lyf an&dtail; lithe ful
lawe."  "An&dtail; seithe he so?" quo&dtail; the lady; "Now for
soþe he shalle lese his crowinge."  The coke was dede
Anoo&ntail;; An&dtail; the lady was lede downe Anoo&ntail; Ayene;
An&dtail; the thirde cokke crewe, with a gret voyse & a bolde.
"Seye," quo&dtail; the lady, "in the develis name, what seithe he
now?" An&dtail; the mayde avnsweri&dtail; in this maner, & saide
thus, "seiþe the cokke, 'he&rtail;, an&dtail; see, & sey
nowte, þenne þu maiste have alle thi wille .'" See note in paper edition. Versus: Audi, vide, tace, si tu vis viuere
pace. ¶ Þen saide the lady, "sle not that cok,
by no wey."  Aftir al this, þe kni&yogh;t hir husbonde come
home; an&dtail; or he ha&dtail; be longe at home, he was certifij&dtail; of the dethe of the
cockes.  He yede to the Emperoure, an&dtail; aski&dtail;
a devorce, as the lawe wolde.  Þenne sai&dtail;e þe
Emperoure, "thow most go with me in to bataille."  "Ser, I assent,"
quo&dtail; he, "but I aske what sholde be to him that browte home the
victorye."  Þenne seyde the Emperoure, when the victor of the batai&llbar; we&rtail; come home,
he shulde have in the first day iiij.  worshipis; of the whiche this
is þe first, he shalle be sette in a char&rtail;, &
iiij. white hors shulle drawe hit to the palyse of the Emperour; The
secounde is, þat a&llbar; his trespassours & Aduersarijs
shulde folowe his chare behynde him, withe bounde&ntail; hondis &
fete; The thirde is, that he shalle be cladde withe a cote þat
is I-calli&dtail; Tunica iouis , ¶
an&dtail; alle men shul knele afo&rtail; him; an&dtail; the fovrthe
is, that he shalle sitte that day be-syde the Emperoure.  But the
secounde day he shalle sustene þerfor iiij. hevinessis; For in
the firste his cote shal be taki&ntail; fro him, & he shall be in
Reputacio&ntail; as a fool.  So withoute ony mo&rtail; of þis
mater, he yede forthe to bataile, an&dtail; ha&dtail; þe
victorye; an&dtail; after took boþe honoures & dolours, as
is seide befo&rtail;, lowely & obedientlye; For
whiche grete lowlinesse þe Emperoure hilye avaunci&dtail; him,
& he Endi&dtail; a fai&rtail; Ende, &c.
0.2:
MORALITEE. God men,
þis Emperoure is Crist.  Þe Emperour made a lawe, that If
thi wyf, scil. thi flesh, do avoutry, þou moste be
departi&dtail; fro hir, scil. fro fleshely affecciouns; for by synne
is a ma&ntail; deply in-dreynt in dethe euerlastyng.  for synne is not
ly&yogh;t, but it is hevy, an&dtail; weythe mo&rtail; than lede; for
yf lede fa&llbar; fro a grete he&yogh;t, hit gothe downe no
forþere but þriliþe a litle downe in to the Erthe,
but synne in twynkelynge of an ye þrillithe þrilli&dtail; alle the
erþe, an&dtail; Restithe not or it come to helle.  helle is in
the middis of the Erthe scil. in the cent&rtail; of the erþe, as
seithe the Philesophir; an&dtail; þerfo&rtail; a man moste be ware of synne.  an&dtail;
þerefore go&dtail; wolle, þat as sone as the fleshe hathe
I-done avoutrye by synne, þat thow putte thi selfe to the
bataile of penaunce, an&dtail; sustene þere mekely that is
I-putte to the; an&dtail; therfo&rtail; seiþ Matth. Jugum enim meum suaue est, et onus meum leue ,
þis is to seye, My yoke, scil. penaunce, is swete, scil. for it
turnithe to swetnesse, & my charge or my burdy&ntail;,
scil. commaundement, is li&yogh;t.  The kny&yogh;t, that weddi&dtail;
the wyf, þat dude þe avoutrye, an&dtail; slow the cockis,
is þe sone of go&dtail;; for he weddi&dtail; the soule, &
the soule trespassi&dtail; vndir him, by the synne of Adam, the first
fader.  by the firste cokk that is slayne, vndirstonde prophetis, the whiche prophesie&dtail; an&dtail; tawte a&yogh;enst
synne; as seithe Matth. Jerusalem! ierusalem! que
occidis prophetas, et lapidas eos qui ad te missi sunt , this
is to sey, Jerusalem! that sleist prophites, & steynist hem that
bethe I-sent to the, whi dost thow so?  The secounde cok þat
crowithe bethe apposteles & martris, that we&rtail; I-slayne for
sothefastnesse; an&dtail; the thirde cok, that is not slayne,
beþe prelates & prechovris that beþe now, that dare
not, ne wolle not seye sothe, but plesithe al me&ntail;; an&dtail; the
mo&rtail; har&mtail; is.  The worthi kni&yogh;t Criste, seinge so many
wronges do&ntail; to him by synne in this cas, he suffri&dtail;
mekelye boþe honours an&dtail; hevinessis, as dude the
kni&yogh;t; for he satte in the chaire, scil. vppo&ntail; an asse,
an&dtail; iiij. white horse drow hit, scil. iiij. cardinall vertues,
that we&rtail; euermo&rtail; withe him.  The secounde honou&rtail;
was, that alle his Ivel doers sholde folow, scil. a multitude of peple
come bifo&rtail; Crist & behynde, seinge, Osanna filio dauid! benedictus qui venit in nomine
domini! Þe sone of dauid make vs safe! blessi&dtail;
be he that comyþe in the name of the lor&dtail;!  The
þridde honour was, that he shulde be clad with the cote
y-calli&dtail; tunyca iouis , þat
was whenne þe iewis strewi&dtail; clothis & flowris in the
weye.  The ferþe honoure was, þat he shulde sitte at the
table withe the Emperou&rtail;, an&dtail; so dude he; he
satte in the temple of Jerusale&mtail;.  but in tyme of
passiou&ntail;, scil.  in goo&dtail; friday, the four honoures turni&dtail; in to
iiij. hevinesse[s], for þere as he furst Rode vpo&ntail; an asse,
aftirwar&dtail; þei toke him, as he ha&dtail; ben a thef; &
þerfor he saide, Tanquam ad latronem
existis, cum gladiis & fustibus comprehendere me , As to
a thef ye come oute, with swerdes & battes to take me.  Ayenest
þe secounde honour, wher as they come & mette him so
Reuerently, þey browte him shamfully to þe house of
Kayfas, withe many Reprevis & scornes.  Ayenste the thirde
honoure, that he shulde be cladde withe the cote of iouis, þei
spoyli&dtail; [him] of al his clothinge; an&dtail; ayenste þe
ferþe, þey di&dtail; him vpo&ntail; the crosse, an&dtail;
spette o&ntail; his face, an&dtail; buffeti&dtail; him.  Loo! goode
siris, what scornis an&dtail; Reprevis that ou&rtail; lorde Ihesu
Criste sufferi&dtail; for the sovle þat dude avowtrye. late vs
þerefo&rtail; suff&rtail; for his love penaunce in this worlde,
that we mowe come to his blisse.  Amen!

0.1:
Story. GOdfridus regni&dtail; a wise Emperour in the
cetee of Rome, & he ha&dtail; childeri&ntail; that he loui&dtail;
moche.  An&dtail; when he laye o&ntail; his dethe-bed, he calli&dtail;
to him his eldest sonne, an&dtail; saide to him, "De&rtail; sone, the
heritage that my fadir lefte & biquathe to me, holly I yeve hit to
the."  Aftir that he clepi&dtail; the secounde sone, an&dtail; saide
to him, "De&rtail; sone, I have certeyne possessions, londis an&dtail;
tenementes, þat come of my purchas ,
& þerfor, sone, I yeve [the] al tho, an&dtail; alle
oþer that I have, with oute my heritage."  An&dtail; he made the
thirde to be calli&dtail;, & seide to him, "sone, I have noo
mevable goodes to yeve the, but only þe iewe&llbar; , scil. a presious Ringe, a gay broche,
& a Ria&llbar; clothe; an&dtail; thes iij. I bequethe the.
An&dtail; the vertu of the Ringe is this, that who so euer be&rtail;
hit vp-o&ntail; him, he shalle have love of al me&ntail; The vertu of
the broche is this, that who so euere be&rtail; hit vpo&ntail; his
brest, late him thinke what he wolle, an&dtail; he shalle mete þerwith at

iij. gete gode I-nowhe."  when this was seyde, he turni&dtail; his
body to the walle, an&dtail; yelde vp þe gost.  The childerin
with the moder Reuerently burye&dtail; him, an&dtail; gret

a&ntail; vnlawfu&llbar; maner of love, & spake to hir

live; an&dtail; as ye coveyte me to be Redye to youre wille, I pray

ye make so many festes, & havithe so muche goode, & havithe no

be that I telle þe my counsei&llbar;, I trowe þat

"whi?"  quo&dtail; Ionathas, "what perile myght falle?"  Þenne

þer thow my&yogh;test les hit by some chavnse; An&dtail; for to

day she lay aboute him to seye

An&dtail; Ionathas seide thenne ayene, "Soþely, modir, yf so be

the&ntail; he saide, "for soþe, I hadde leuer slepe then al

a&mtail; worthi al this bale, for I tolde to the woma&ntail; al my
counsei&llbar;."  he loki&dtail; abowte o&ntail; euerye side,
an&dtail; sawe no thinge but wilde bestes, an&dtail; briddis fleing in the hei&rtail;;
an&dtail; of hem he hadde grete drede in herte.  An&dtail; he Rose vp,

my modir!"  Aftir this he Rose, & yede, an&dtail; sawe the

an&dtail; toke of the frute with him, an&dtail; liui&dtail; welle

frende, whens erte thowe?"  "I a&mtail;," quo&dtail; he,
"a leche of fer contrees hennys."  Þenne saide þei,
"Þe kynge of this caste&llbar; is a lep&rtail; man, & manye
lechis comithe to him, an&dtail; vndirtakithe to hele him, vp peyne of
hir hedis, an&dtail; þei havithe y-fayli&dtail; euerychone;
an&dtail; þe&rtail; fo&rtail; thow maiste see hir hedis sitte in
the wallis of the castelle.  an&dtail; þere fore we telle the
for certeyne, yf þow vndirtake my lorde, an&dtail; not hele him,
þou shalte lese þy lyfe."  Þenne saide he, "yis, I
shalle hele him."  tho he was browte [to] him, an&dtail; he yaf the
kynge of his frewte to ete, & also he yafe him of his secounde

to Ionathas Riche yiftes, an&dtail; fai&rtail;, plentefully, & mo
be-hite him, yf he wolde abyde withe him, but he wolde not assent to

þerin, to aspie yf ther we&rtail; enye shippe, that myght bringe
him home.  & at the laste, in a certeyne day þere come
towar&dtail; xxx. shippis, an&dtail; alle in a morow reysi&dtail;
þere.  Þenne Ionathas enqueri&dtail; amonge hem, yf eny
shippe we&rtail; þere Redy for to go to swiche a londe, wher as
he havnti&dtail; scole.  At the last he founde a shippe
redy, þat wolde to the same contree.  Þenne Ionathas was
gladde, an&dtail; enteri&dtail; into the shippe, aftir that he hadde
take leve of the kynge.  Sone aftir that he was come to the citee,

ha&dtail; knowleche of him, for longe tyme, that he ha&dtail; be
devouri&dtail; with wilde bestes. whenne Ionathas was in the citee,
a-noo&ntail; he toke cure of Syke peple, & he heli&dtail; alle;
an&dtail; by that tyme his lema&ntail; was þe Richeste of that
citee, by vertu of the Rynge, & of the broche, an&dtail; of the
clothe, but she was gretly turmenti&dtail; withe sikenesse.  An&dtail;
whenne [she] harde telle, that sucℏ a soti&llbar; leche was come

he wolde vouchesaffe to hele hir of hir sykenesse.  Ionathas come to
hir, & þere he fonde his lemma&ntail; o&ntail; be&dtail;;
an&dtail; he knewe hir welle, but she knew not him.  An&dtail; whenne
he hadde I-seyne hir vryne, he seide to hir, "worthi ladye, thow haste
oo sekenesse that may not be heli&dtail; but by oo way; an&dtail; yf
þow wolt preve that wey, þowe may be
heli&dtail;." then seide she, "I am Redy to do what so euer þow
comaundist, so that I be hole ther by."  Ionathas saide to hir,
"Þou moste be clene I-shriven; & yf þou have
withe-drawe owte fro eny ma&ntail; with wronge, thow moste
Resto&rtail; hit ayene, an&dtail; thenne I shalle warante the to be
hole; an&dtail; ellis my medicinis wolle not stonde in stede."
an&dtail; so by cause that she was grevousely holde withe sekenesse,
she made an opy&ntail; confessio&ntail; afore al me&ntail;, how
þat she ha&dtail; deseyvi&dtail; the sonne of the Emperoure, as

þat þou withe-drew fro him, scil. þe Ringe, þe
broche, & the Clothe?"  An&dtail; she tolde him, that thei
we&rtail; at hir beddis fete, in a chest. "an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail;," she saide, "ope&ntail; þe cheste."
An&dtail; þere he fonde as she saide, with gret Ioye to him;
& he toke the Ringe, &
put hit o&ntail; his fynger; he sette the broche o&ntail; his breste;
an&dtail; toke the clothe vndir his arme.  An&dtail; he toke hir
drinke of his Firste cruet, scil. of that water that drow awey the

Resseyvi&dtail; hit, she was in swiche a likenesse, that no ma&ntail;

that hathe iij. sonnes. by the firste sone we must vndirstonde
angelis, to whome go&dtail; hathe yevin swiche confirmacio&ntail;

wee&rtail; falle do&ntail;, go&dtail; so confermi&dtail; hem, that

iij. iewe&llbar;, a Ringe, a broche, & a clothe.  By the Ringe we

go&dtail; an&dtail; of aungles; an&dtail; þerefore seithe oure savioure, Si habueritis fidem, sicut
granum sinapis , ¶ &c. ut supra ut
c w , þis is to seye, yf ye have feithe,
as the see&dtail; or as the greyne of synevey, as is saide
befo&rtail;. an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; he that hathe þe

þerfore it is seyde, Mittam vobis spiritum
paraclitum, & suggeret vobis omnia quecumque dixero

oute dowte he may be translati&dtail;.  Ionathas may be calli&dtail;
euery Criste&ntail; man þat is fally&ntail; to synne. thenne his

him, for synne; an&dtail; the clothe, scil. charite, is drawi&ntail;

te Christus , þis is to sey, Arys þou þat

che&rtail;, in maner of a lep&rtail; man; as it is wretin of Crist, ¶ Vidimus

¶ Sampso&ntail; slept in the skirte of dalyda, and lost his
strengtℏ. he arose, and entre&dtail; the watir, that is, the
watir of penaunce, that departitℏ the flessℏ, that is,
flesshly affeccions.  ¶ Than he ete of the frute of sharpnesse,
that chaungetℏ his semblaunt to the likenesse of a lepre; as it
is redde of crist, we saw hym as a man that ha&dtail; no chere, but as
a lepre.  So it is of the soule that is in bittirnesse for the synnes
that he hatℏ done.  ¶ wherfore it is sai&dtail; in figure of
the soule, I am bla&ktee;, but I am semely and faire, that is to sey,
I am bla&ktee; in body, but I am faire in soule.  ¶ Than he went
into the secon&dtail; watir, that restore&dtail; hym.  ¶ This
watir is comvnyon aftir penaunce; wherfo&rtail; ou&rtail; saviour seitℏ, "I am the welle
of ly&ftee;; he that drynketℏ of this watir, he sha&llbar; not
thrist after." he than etetℏ of the frute
of the tre the secon&dtail;, that restore&dtail; a&llbar; that was
lost, that is, whan a&llbar; is glorifie&dtail; in ever lastyng
ly&ftee;.  ¶ Also he cure&dtail; the kyng, that is, his
reso&ntail;, and so he entre&dtail; the shippe of holy chircℏ,
and to his love, that is, the flessℏ, he ga&ftee; the watir of
contricio&ntail;, and the frute of penaunce and of sharpnesse, [by]
the whicℏ the flessℏ, that is, the affeccio&ntail; of flesshly lust, is
slay&ntail;. and so a man getitℏ by penaunce goodes that are lost
by synne, and gotℏ to his countrey, that is, the kyngdome of
heven. to the whicℏ brynge vs Ihesu crist, that bought vs
witℏ the price of his precious bloo&dtail;!  Amen.

0.1:
Story. ENlopius was a gode
Emperoure in þe citee of Rome, the whiche lovi&dtail; moste
passingli love an&dtail; pes; an&dtail; þerfor wher so euer he
knewe þat eny discorde or vnrest was Regnynge, he labovri&dtail;
to make Reformacio&ntail; of pes. so in that tyme þere we&rtail; two knyghtes, o&ntail; of baldak, that oþer of
lumbardye; an&dtail; thes twoo lovi&dtail; to-gedir Right muche,
an&dtail; sent letteris eiþer to oþere by messagers; so
that what euer the knight of lumbardy hadde of marchaundise in his
londe, he sent hit to the toþere; in þe same maner
þe kni&yogh;t of baldak sent to the knite of lumbardye, of al
maner thinges an&dtail; noveltees that we&rtail; in baldak, an&dtail;
not in lumbardye.  So in a tyme þis kni&yogh;te of lumbardye
þo&yogh;te, as he lay in his bedde, "switcℏ a frende I have
in baldak, & I have sent to him many grete yiftis, an&dtail; so
hathe [he] to me wel mo. for sothe now wolle I go visite him or
þat I be dede."  He come to the londe of baldake, & come to
the house of his felow, the w[h]iche he saw neuer afore; an&dtail;
whenne his felow saw him, he fel for gladnes vpo&ntail; him, &
kiste him, an&dtail; wepte for Ioye; an&dtail; he saide, "thow art welcome to me as halfe my soule!"  And
whenne he hadde abide ther certeyne days, he saw in the house the
fayrest damise&llbar; to his ye, that euer he sawe; & he was
Ravishi&dtail; in his mynde for hir, in so moche that he kepte his
bedde, an&dtail; myte
neyþer ete ne drynke wele. the&ntail; the
oþer knight, þe lorde of the hovse, come to him, an&dtail;
aski&dtail; the cause of his hevinesse, & of his seknes.
Þenne saide he, "Þer is a damiselle in thin house, that I
love, an&dtail; coveyte in my&ntail; herte ouer al thinge in this
worlde; an&dtail; dede I mot be, but I have hir love."  An&dtail;
thenne he badde him be stronge, an&dtail; of goode che&rtail;, and
saide that he shul&dtail; have al thinge that his soule wolde desire,
yf it we&rtail; in that house.  an&dtail; a-no&ntail; he shewi&dtail;
him al the wome&ntail; of the house, Exsepte oo&ntail; damesel;
an&dtail; thenne he saide, "De&rtail; frende, is she he&rtail; amonge
this company, þat þou desirist?" an&dtail; he saide,
"naye."  An&dtail; at the laste he shewi&dtail; afore him the
damiselle; & whenne he sawe hir, he seide to his felaw, "[This is]
she þat is my lyf an&dtail; my dethe bothe!"  An&dtail; thenne
he saide, "Þis damise&llbar; is coume of gentil kynrede,
an&dtail; I have norishi&dtail; hir of a childe, for she shulde have
ben my wyfe; neuertheles þow arte come from fer contrees, for
grete fervente love þat hathe I-bene a-twene vs of longe tyme,
an&dtail; therfo&rtail; I wouchesaf þat thow have hir to wyf; I
shalle yeve to the with hir grete habundaunce of Richesse."  whenne
the kni&yogh;t herde the wordes, he Ros, & was hole; & saide
to him, "de&rtail; frende, go&dtail; the yelde for the
gentilnesse that thowe seist to me, & hast doo&ntail; for me many
a tyme; but how that hit shalle be Rewarde & yolde&ntail;, for
soþe I not."  Soone aftir ther was cride a genera&llbar;
bridale, an&dtail; alle men that come to that feste, hadde grete medes
& benefetis or they yede.  an&dtail; aftir al this the knigℏt
toke his leve, an&dtail; yede home ayene in to lumbardye withe his
wyf; an&dtail; a Riche ma&ntail; he was, an&dtail; alle his frendes
were avaunsi&dtail; by þe goodes & Richesses that he browte
fro&mtail; baldak; an&dtail; his wyf was lovi&dtail; gretly of all
men, an&dtail; browte forthe a faire dowter.  Aftir hit happi&dtail;,
that the forsayde knyght of baldak was falne in to grete poverte, in
so mucℏ that he ha&dtail; not to lyve with. he thovte in a
certeyne tyme, þat hit we&rtail; beste for him for to go to his
olde frende, þat he avaunsi&dtail; an&dtail; yaf to his
damise&llbar;, & be founden of him; an&dtail; that him thowte
hadde ben the better þa&ntail; for to have livi&dtail; in wrecchidnesse, as he dude.  he
yede to lumbardye in pore araye, like a pore man, for he hadde litle
in his purse; an&dtail; when he was in lumbardye, he enteri&dtail;
into the cetee ther as his felowe was dwelle.  An&dtail; whenne he
come in to the citee, þe nyght was darke, an&dtail; he thowte to
him selfe, "it is now nyght, an&dtail; my clothis
beþe not faire for a kni&yogh;te, an&dtail; also I am barfote;
an&dtail; yf I goo nowe to the hovse of my felawe, he shalle
vnneþe knowe me in this clothing.  nay," quo&dtail; he, "hit
shalle not be soo." he loki&dtail; abowte him, & he sawe a parishe
chirche; an&dtail; he enteri&dtail; in to the yerde, & yede in to
the In-gange, scil. in to the porche, an&dtail; þere he lay al
nyght.  & as he laye þere in the porche, too me&ntail; foute
þere in the strete, an&dtail; that o&ntail; slowhe the
toþere; an&dtail; sone the mankille[r] Ra&ntail; in to the
chircheyerde; an&dtail; sone a multitude of peple ra&ntail; in to the
chirche-yer&dtail;, & þere they sowte, but none thei coude
fynde, but only the kni&yogh;te in the chirche-porche.  An&dtail; thei
saide to him, "where is he that slowhe the man?"  "I am he,"
quo&dtail; he; "takithe me, & bringe me þerfo&rtail; in the
iebet."  An&dtail; this he sai&dtail;, for he hadde leuer have ben
dede, than so to live in pouertee.  & thanne thei toke him, &
browte him to presou&ntail;; an&dtail; o&ntail; the morowe he was
demi&dtail; to be dede, an&dtail; he was ladde to the iebet; an&dtail;
many folowi&dtail; him, an&dtail; amonge the peple was the kni&yogh;t
his felawe. an&dtail; whe&ntail; he ha&dtail; beholde&ntail; his felowe, he saide in his herte "What! howe is þis? this
is my felawe of baldak, that thei lede here to dethe."  An&dtail;
withe oute any tariinge he creyde withe an hie voyse, an&dtail; saide,
"How! ma&ntail;, abide, abide, lete him leve! it is not he that slowe
the ma&ntail;, hit is I?"  An&dtail; tho they toke him, an&dtail;
ladde hem bothe to þe Iebet, to be dede.  An&dtail; among al
oþir, the man that killi&dtail; the dede ma&ntail; was þer
present; an&dtail; he thowte in him selfe, "I am gylti of this dethe,
an&dtail; the too kni&yogh;tes bethe innocentes; for sothe it may not
be, but that go&dtail; shalle take vengeaunce of me.  hit is beste for
me, that I now opy&ntail; my synne, an&dtail; take penaunce
therfo&rtail; than late thes innocentes perishe."  An&dtail; he cride
withe an hie voyse, "beþe ware, that ye do none har&mtail; to
the me&ntail;, for I am gylti in the dede; þei beþe
innocentes, an&dtail; I am he that slowhe the ma&ntail;: takithe me,
and dothe me o&ntail; the iebet."  Þenne the peple sette honde
vpo&ntail; him, an&dtail; browte him with the two knites to the Iuge,
& saide, "sir, we ha&ntail; grete mervayle of thes iij. men, for
the first saide, with his owne mouthe, that he slowhe the ma&ntail;;
an&dtail; that oþere come, & saide, nay, for he
saide that he slowhe him; an&dtail; now the thirde comithe, an&dtail;
seide that thei bothe bethe innocentes, an&dtail; that he slowhe him
withe his own hondes; an&dtail; þerfo&rtail;, sir, we beþe
I-come to youre dome, for to loke what ye wolle seye in this cas."
Þenne saide the Iuge to the firste knight of baldak, "whi, &
for what cause seyde þou, that thowe slowhe the ma&ntail;?"
"For soþe," quo&dtail; he, "& I s[h]alle seye soþe.  I
was some tyme a worthi knight, and a Riche, an&dtail; mony me&ntail; I
fonde an&dtail; susteyni&dtail; vndir me; but withe in fewe yeris I
felle in to grete poverte, in so moche that I have no thinge to
spende, but as I begge my brede fro do&rtail; to do&rtail;.  An&dtail;
so whe&ntail; that I thinke of my grete nobilite that I have be&ntail;
Inne, an&dtail; of grete pouerte that I a&mtail; Inne nowe, I hadde
leuere be dede than live; an&dtail; þerefore I saide that I
slowe the ma&ntail;, in the entente that thei shulde slee me."  Thenne
seide the Iuge to the secounde kni&yogh;t, "tel me whi that thow saide
that þou slowhe him?" "for sothe, sir," quo&dtail; he,
"an&dtail; I shalle tel yow. this knight he&rtail; hathe hiliche
avaunsi&dtail; me, an&dtail; yafe to me my wyf; an&dtail; þere
fore I lovi&dtail; him as moche as myselfe; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; whenne I sawe him go to deþewar&dtail;, I cride withe a lowde voyse, an&dtail; saide that I slowe the
ma&ntail;, in the entente þat I sholde be dede, an&dtail; he
I-saui&dtail;."  An&dtail; thanne saide the Iuge to the thirde man,
"telle me whi that thow saide that þow kyldest him?"
"Forsothe," quo&dtail; he, "an&dtail; I sha&llbar; telle yowe opinlye
þe sothe; for sothelye I slowhe him with my&ntail; oune hondes; an&dtail; þerfor
when I sawe thes two knites we&rtail; ladde to be dede, I thovte to my
selfe, that go&dtail;, that sethe al thinges, wol&dtail;
þerfo&rtail; have I-takin vengeaunce of me, yf I ha&dtail;
suffri&dtail; hem so go to dethe, sithe&ntail; I was synner; &
þerefore I þou&yogh;te I wolde not do so grete synne,
an&dtail; that I wolde Rathir save þe Innocentes & dy my
selfe, than for to dampne my selfe perpetuelly.  &
þerefo&rtail;, sir, he&rtail; I have seide opinli the sothe, how
that I slowhe þe ma&ntail; with my&ntail; ovne hondes."  The[n]
aunswerde þe Iuge, seinge þus, "sithen þou haste
seide the sothe for salvacio&ntail; of the Innocentes, sothely
þou shalt not be dede."  an&dtail; alle me&ntail; comendi&dtail;
the Iuge, that ha&dtail; so hilie an&dtail; so graciouslye demy&dtail;
for the trewe trespassoure. MORALITEE. DEre frendes, þis Emperoure is the fadir of hevene; The twoo
kni&yogh;tes beþe oure lorde Ihesu Criste an&dtail; the fadir
Ada&mtail;, the whiche was shapin & formi&dtail; in the felde of
Damaske; & go&dtail; was with oute begynnyng, an&dtail; is withe
oute endynge. messagers we&rtail; atwene hem, whenne the fadir saide
to the sonne & to the holy gost, Faciamus
hominem ad ymaginem & similitudinem nostram , This is to
seye, lete vs make ma&ntail; vnto our ymage an&dtail; to oure
likenesse.  but the kni&yogh;t þat come to the howse of that
oþere kni&yogh;t, that was translati&dtail; fro the felde of
Damaske; & þere he sawe a faire mayde, scil. þe soule
y-made to the likenesse of go&dtail;, the w[h]iche Adam desiri&dtail;.
An&dtail; go&dtail; seinge that, yaf the soule to Adam, the
w[h]icℏ was made to his oune likenesse, withe alle godes of this
worlde.  Aftir that, Crist come to grete pouerte, an&dtail; toke oure
fleshe; as thes wordes berithe witnesse of his pouertee, Vulpes foueas habent, et volucres celi nidos; filius autem
hominis non habet vbi capud suum inclinet , þis is to
seye, lo! foxis
haviþ dennys, & briddis of hevene haviþe nestis; but
the sonne of man haþe not we&rtail; he may reclyne or enbowe his
hede.  Þenne he enteri&dtail; in to the porche of the chirche,
scil. in to the wombe of oure seint marie the virgine; & þere he lay fro tyme of his consepcio&ntail; vnto the
tyme of his nativite. in the tyme fitiþe to-gedir ij. me&ntail;,
scil. the fleshe & þe sprite; but the fleshe slowhe þe
sprite, what tyme mankynde brake the comavndement of go&dtail;.
Thenne the peple ronne in to the chirche-yerde, scil. deuelis yede
abovte, for to make that al mankynde shulde perisshe.  The kny&yogh;t,
that profiri&dtail; to dye, was oure lorde Ihesu Criste, whenne he
sayde, ¶ Quem queritis? whom seke
ye? Ego sum , I am he that ye seche.
Þenne the peple toke him, & ladde him to the Iubet.  thenne
whenne that oþer kny&yogh;t, his trewe frende, sawe þis,
&c.  by the secounde kny&yogh;t we must vndirstonde aposteles
an&dtail; martiris, the whiche suffri&dtail; dethe in the name of
Criste; & þerefore seide Crist to his disciplis, Potestis bibere calicem quem ego sum bibiturus ,
þis is to seye, may ye drinke of the same cuppe þat I am
to drynke, scil. suffre passio&ntail; as I shalle; an&dtail; thei
seide, Possumus , We mowe.  An&dtail; the
thirde, þat sei&dtail;, "sothely I slow him with my&ntail; owne
hondys," þat is euery synner, þat owiþ to graunte
þe sothe in confessio&ntail;, for the entente þat the
Innocent soule sholde not be slayne; & þenne yf he do so,
withe oute dowte he shal not dye, but he shalle have euerlastyng lyfe. Ad quam &c.

bedde hole, and sai&dtail;, "O! dere frende, go&dtail; quyte the, for

ofte sithes! how may I yel&dtail; *the a&llbar; omitted the benefetis that þou hast done

he went alone into lumbardie as a poore man, for he ha&dtail;

was an Emperour in the citee of Rome; þe which hadde a faire
dowter, whom he moche lovi&dtail;.  so i&ntail; a certeyn daye, as he

place, & he cnocki&dtail; at the yate; an&dtail; a noo&ntail;
þe lorde of the place openy&dtail; þe yate, an&dtail;

nyght, an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; I praye the, for the love of
go&dtail;, that I may be loggi&dtail;
he&rtail; al nyght;"—but he tolde him not þat he was

Damascenus was a
wyse Emperoure Reignyng in the cete of Rome; þe whiche
ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, þat yf Eny ma&ntail; deliueri&dtail;
a virgine fro the honde of hir Ravisshe&rtail;, it shulde be in the

ne she shulde not be weddi&dtail; to noo&ntail; oþer ma&ntail;,
withe oute&ntail; graunte & assente of him that ha&dtail;
taky&ntail; hi&rtail; fro the hondes of the Ravisher.  So hit felle in
a tyme, that ther was a tiraunt nami&dtail; Pompeius, & he hadde
I-Raveshi&dtail; a virgine, an&dtail; browte hir into a wilde forest;
an&dtail; whenne he ha&dtail; synne&dtail; with hir, he wolde have slayne hir.  ther come Ridyng by the forest a gentil
kny&yogh;t; an&dtail; whenne he harde the horible crie of a
woma&ntail;, he smote the hors withe the sporis, & Rode to hir.
An&dtail; whenne he come, he sawe hir ston&dtail; naki&dtail;, save
hir smokke; an&dtail; thenne he aski&dtail; of hir, "ert thow she that
cridest?"  "ye, sir," quo&dtail; she, "for this ma&ntail;
Raveshi&dtail; me, an&dtail; hathe take&ntail; fro&mtail; me my
virginitee; an&dtail; now he wolde sle me, & he hathe thus
naki&dtail; me, for to smyte of my&ntail; hede; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail;, for the love of go&dtail;, helpe me I pray yowe."
thenne saide the teraunt, "sir, she lithe, for she is my wyfe,
an&dtail; I fonde hi&rtail; in borde&llbar; withe a-noþer man;
an&dtail; þer for I wolde sle hir nowe."  Þenne saide the
kny&yogh;t, "I trowe mo&rtail; to the woma&ntail; þanne to the,
for I se opy&ntail; signys in hir visage, that thow haste
Ravishi&dtail; hir, an&dtail; Oppressi&dtail; hir withe mastrie; an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; I an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; I an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; I wolle Fite for hir."  An&dtail; so thei
fo&yogh;te to gedir, an&dtail; grevousely thei we&rtail;
I-woundi&dtail;, but the kny&yogh;t ha&dtail; the victory, & that

She yede to his castelle, an&dtail; þer she was worshipfulli

& yf þou wolte not sette by thi feithe, loo!  he&rtail; the

þat yf a ma&ntail; deliuer enye virgyne fro the hondes of hir
Rav[i]sher, it is in the powe&rtail; of the deliuerer to have the

MORALITEE. DEre frendis, þis Emperoure is the fadir of hevene; the wiche

þenne he that deliueri&dtail; hir shulde wedde hir to wyve.  The
woma&ntail;, that was Ravishi&dtail; an&dtail; ladde into the forest,

whe&rtail; [s]he livi&dtail; in grete wrecchidnesse, an&dtail; [was]
deflowri&dtail; by the Ravissher, scil. the devil; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; it is wreten, ¶ Ierem. iii. tu autem fornicata es cum amatoribus
multis , þis is to seye, he seithe, "for sothe thow
hast do fornicacio&ntail; withe many lovers."  An&dtail; this
Ravisher, the devil, deflowrithe not the soule only, by lost of blisse, but also he wolde have slayne
hi&rtail; in euerlastinge peyne.  & þenne she cride
witℏ an hie voyse; scil. the wrecchidnes an&dtail; the perille of
hit was her&dtail; with the kny&yogh;te Ihesu Crist, ¶ or elles

Oyle of mercy, & whenne patriarkis an&dtail; prophetes cride for
Remedye, seinge, O!  domine, visita nos ,
O!  lorde, come an&dtail; visite þou vs, þenne þe
kny&yogh;t, scil. Ihesu Criste, come do&ntail; fro hevene, &
heilde bataille withe the Ravisher, scil. þe devil; an&dtail;
thenne they two foute to-geder, that eyþere of hem was grevously
woundi&dtail;, scil. Crist in his fleshe, an&dtail; the devil in his
lordshipe; an&dtail; þerfore saithe Isaye, Fortis impegit in fortem, et ambo conciderunt ,
¶ þis is to seye, A stronge delte or fel in vp o&ntail; an
oþer strong, an&dtail; bothe they fil doune to-gedir. Aftir this

¶ I trowe or I beleve in go&dtail;, fadir Almyti.  Aftir that

dome, in Ioye.  But in the mene tyme comythe the
Ravissher, scil. þe devel.  & he with his sotil cautellis

euere opy&ntail; to me, I shalle enter to him, an&dtail; I shalle

This is to seye, O!  ye al that goþe by the wey, herkenithe
