Story. CEsar was an Emperoure Reignynge in
the citee of Rome, þe whiche weddi&dtail; a faire semli
damiselle; þe whiche damiselle was the kynges dowter of sirie,
an&dtail; she browte forthe a faire sonne.  So whe&ntail;
this chil&dtail; was come to age, he awayti&dtail; an&dtail; caste him, in alle that euere he myght,
for the dethe of his fadir, in so muche þat the Emperoure
ha&dtail; grete marvayle, an&dtail; come to the Emperesse, an&dtail;
aski&dtail; of hir, yf that eny man lay bi hir mo thanne he, scil. the
Emperour him selfe.  An&dtail; when she harde thes wordes, she was
hevy in herte, by cause that he ha&dtail; suche suspecio&ntail; to
hir; & swo&rtail; grete othis,
that she was neuer como&ntail; to no ma&ntail; flesshelye, but with
him aloone.  An&dtail; thenne spake he, "Ne was not this yonge man
gety&ntail; by me?"  "yis, sir," quo&dtail; she, "dowtithe hit
not, for he is your lawefully bigete&ntail; sone."  The&ntail; the
Emperou&rtail; was ameki&dtail;, an&dtail; saide to his sonne, "Son,"
quo&dtail; he, "I am thi fadir, an&dtail; I gate the into this worlde,
an&dtail; of me þow come into this worl&dtail;, an&dtail; by wey
of generacio&ntail; þou shalt be my&ntail; hey&rtail;; an&dtail;
þerfo&rtail; whi erte thowe a-bowte my dethe, that have norisshe&dtail; the vp with deynteys, an&dtail;, per
dieu, al that is my&ntail; is thyn?  leef, sone, thi wicki&dtail;
purpos, an&dtail; sle me not, for yf þou do, it is a foule synne
in the syght of go&dtail;, an&dtail; hit wolle be awreke."  ¶
Þe sone toke noo&ntail; hede to his woordes, but Eche day
mo&rtail; þa&ntail; [other] he was abowte to kille his fadir.
An&dtail; whe&ntail; the fadir saw that, he yede into deserte, & toke his sone
withe him, an&dtail; a swerde; an&dtail; when he was ther, he saide to
his sone, "sone, sle me he&rtail;, for he&rtail; is a prevy place,
an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; it is welle the lesse synne, & lesse
shame to the, þanne yf hit we&rtail; in an opy&ntail; place."
whenne the sone har&dtail; thes wordes, he cast a-wey the swerde
fro&mtail; him, & kneli&dtail; a-downe a-fore him, an&dtail; mekly
aski&dtail; mercy, for he saide that he ha&dtail; trespassi&dtail;
vnto him,—"& þere fo&rtail;, fadir, dothe to me fro
hennys forþewar&dtail; as þe likithe."  the fadir withe a
grete gladnesse kiste him; an&dtail; aftir him Regni&dtail; the sone,
that mekly aski&dtail; mercye. MORALITEE. DEre frendes, þis Emperoure is
oure lorde Ihesu Criste; The sone is ecℏ Cristin man; The
Emperesse is holye chirche.  But ofte tyme þe sone,
scil. þe Cristy&ntail; ma&ntail;, is frowar&dtail;, &
contrarye to the wille of go&dtail;, for he obeythe not to his
comaundementes.  Þenne Criste askithe of holye
chirche. wheþer he be his sone or no; an&dtail; holy chirche
seithe, "Ye, lor&dtail;, for of me he Reseyvi&dtail; baptime,
an&dtail; þere fo&rtail; he is thy sone."  an&dtail;
þerfo&rtail; Criste Enformithe vs, an&dtail;
counseilithe vs, by prelatis an&dtail; prechovrs, to leve oure folijs
an&dtail; synnys, an&dtail; that we be not contrarye to his werkes;
an&dtail; he spekithe to vs, seyng thus, Reuertere, Reuertere, sunamitis, et ego suscipiam te , This is to sey, be thow
torni&dtail;, be thow torni&dtail; to me, thow synfulle soule,
an&dtail; I shalle vnderfonge the.  but the synner wolle not be
bowi&dtail; by worde, ne be betynges; & þerefo&rtail; Criste

tibi datum desuper , Þow sholdest have no powe&rtail;
vppo&ntail; me, but yf it we&rtail; yeve&ntail; the fro&mtail; above.
O!  lorde, that ther buþ manye that dothe Crist ayene vpo&ntail;

sone, and went to the Empresse, and praie&dtail; her to telle hym,
wheþer he were his sone, and gote&ntail; of hym.  ¶ She
her&dtail; this, and was gretly greve&dtail;, that he aske&dtail;
suche a thyng of her.  she afferme&dtail; witℏ an othe, that she
was never knowe&ntail; of none omitted other man but of hym, and that he was his Fadir, and he is thi omitted lawfu&llbar; sonne.  ¶ The Emperour
her&dtail; this, and mekely spake to his sone, and sai&dtail;, "O!
goo&dtail; sone, I am thi Fadir, that gate the, and [by
me] supplied from Cambridge MS thou come into this
worl&dtail;, by way of generacio&ntail;, and thou shalt be my&ntail;
heire.  why woldest thou sle me?  and I have norisshe&dtail; the, and
a&llbar; that is my&ntail; is thy&ntail; .  I pray the, cease the of thi this wikkednesse,
and sle me not, for yf and if thou do, it is to the a omitted grete synne afore
go&dtail;."  ¶ The sone toke [no] supplied from Cambridge
MS hede to his Fadirs saiyng, but fro day to day his malice
encrease&dtail;; and strengthe&dtail; hym a&llbar; way to sle his
fadir.  ¶ Whan the Fadir sawe this, he went into a deserte place, and ledde witℏ hym his sone, beryng a swer&dtail; in his
hon&dtail;; and toke it to his sone, and sai&dtail;, "My sone, slee me
here, for here is a prive place, and lesse sclaundre sha&llbar; be to
the here to slee me, than in other another place."  ¶ The sone her&dtail; this, and ano&ntail; cast the
swer&dtail; from hym; and knele&dtail; before his fadir mekely
I-noughe, and aske&dtail; hym omitted mercy, Saiyng, to *hym, "have mercy on me his
fader "A! fader, have mercy on me, have mercy on me , for I have
synne&dtail;, and do to me from hens forwar&dtail; as it liketℏ
the."  ¶ Ano&ntail; the Fadir kisse&dtail; hym, and was right
gla&dtail;; and la&dtail; hym witℏ hym to home to his paleys.  and aftir the dethe of the
fadir, the sone reigne&dtail;; and so in pease and rest he omitted ende&dtail; his ly&ftee;. ¶ Declaracio. Dere Frendes, this Emperour is oure lor&dtail;
Ihesu crist; The fadir is eche criste&ntail;
man; the Empresse is holy chirche.  But ofte sithes the sone, that is,
an eve&llbar; cristene man, [is] frowar&dtail; and contrary to
go&dtail;, for he obeyetℏ not the comaundement.  he asketℏ
of holy chirche yf he be verrely his sone; and holy chirche
aunsweretℏ, and seitℏ, "ye, sir, of me he toke baptyme, and therefore he is his sone."
¶ Crist by prelates and prechours enformetℏ vs, that we shul&dtail; leve synne, and that we be not
contrarie to his preceptes; but he speketℏ to vs, and seitℏ
turne to me, thou synnefu&llbar; wrecche, and I sha&llbar; take the.
but the synfu&llbar; man wille not bow, for wordes ne for betynges;
¶ wherfore our lor&dtail; Ihesu ledetℏ hym in to deserte,
that is, for his synne Adam, the first Fadir, was take out of paradice
in to deserte of this worl&dtail;, and bare witℏ hym the
swer&dtail; of goddes rightwisenesse, that is, that he shol&dtail; dye
for synne that he ha&dtail; done; for yf synne ha&dtail; not be done,
dethe shol&dtail; not have be&ntail;.  Now hathe the sone the
swer&dtail; of power, by the whiche the sone of go&dtail; shul&dtail;
dye; as it is writte&ntail;, thou shul&dtail; not have power in me,
but yf it were yeven to the fro above.  ¶ O!  how many are yit
that crucifie&ntail; crist by her synne!  ¶ Do þou therfore
as the Emperours sone di&dtail;; Cast fro the the swer&dtail; of
wikkednesse, and knele, that is, meke the, in the way of penaunce, and
afore god, thou shalt fynde grace; and so in pease thou shalt ende thi
lyf, and purchace the everlastyng kyngdome of heven.  to the whiche
bryng vs he, that for oure synne dye&dtail; on the roode!  Amen.

0.1:
Story. FReudericus was a Emperoure Regnyng in the citee of Rome, þe
whiche was longe with oute wyf and childe; but at the laste, at
counseil of lordes an&dtail; of wyse men, he weddi&dtail; a faire
damiselle, & dwelte with hir in an vnknowen contree, an&dtail;
gete of hir a childe.  Aftir that, he wolde have comyn to his Empyre,
but he myght not have gete leve of hir ther to, but euer she wolde
sey, that yf he yede, she wolde sle hir selve.  An&dtail; whanne the
Emperour harde this, he studie&dtail; muche, how that he myght beste
goo, an&dtail; passe fro&mtail; hir, with hir goode wille.  he gate
payntours, & he made to be paynte ouer hir hede ij. fai&rtail;
Images; an&dtail; in the frounte of eyþere Image was I-sette a
myrour, in the whiche she myght euery day biholde; & so she dude,
& ha&dtail; so grete delectacio&ntail;, that she for&yogh;at
þe fervente desire that she hadde in hir lorde the Emperour.
whenne the Emperoure sawe this, he yede his weye; an&dtail; aftir his
going, a damesel, that was the ladies sarvaunt, yede preveli,
an&dtail; made foule the glas, in so muche that the lady &yogh;ede aftir the lorde; an&dtail; whenne she ha&dtail; founde
him, she browte [him] a&yogh;e&ntail; with hir.  an&dtail; thenne the
Emperour made muche sorowe in herte for that cas, an&dtail;
studiy&dtail; þerefo&rtail; by what weye, in al that he myght,
how that he myght passe fro hir ayene.  he
purveyde him of a passing faire gurdil, sette aboute withe presious
stonis, an&dtail; in the stonys he made thes wordes to be wreten, "yf
hope we&rtail; not, hert shulde breke."  An&dtail; he yafe þis
gurdil to his wyf, an&dtail; she toke hit Reuerentlye; & she sette
so moche herte in fairnesse of the gyrdille, that she for yate the
love of hir husbonde.  whenne the Emperoure saw this, he yede prively fro hir to his contre, & þe wyf
folowi&dtail; not aftir him, for as ofte as she was I-tempti&dtail; to
go aftir him, as ofte she yede, an&dtail; loky&dtail; o&ntail; the
gyrdil, an&dtail; she Redde on the scriptu&rtail;, seing, yf hope
we&rtail; not, herte sholde tobreke.  She thowte þer with to hir
selfe, "yit I triste to see my husbonde, withe
glorie & comforte."  & thus she livi&dtail;, vndir stedfaste
hope & trist, by many dayes aftir.
0.2:
MORALITEE. DEre Frendes, this Emperoure may be calli&dtail; eche goode
Criste&ntail; ma&ntail;, þe whiche owithe to be Emperour of him
selfe; an&dtail; so he owithe first & furþermost an&dtail;
principalli, to take the wey towar&dtail; his owne contre, & þereto
manfulli to laboure.  what is contree?  Certenly the kyngdome of
hevene, wonne by the passiou&ntail; of crist.  An&dtail; wher
fo&rtail; owe we to laboure þerefore?  Certenlye to that
entente, that we mowe have þere by helpe of soule; as is seide
in the psalme, Saluum me fac, deus quoniam
intraverunt aque vsque ad animam meam , This is to seye,
lorde, make me saffe, for waters, scil. perilis of synnys, have
enteri&dtail; to my sovle.  the wyf is the fleshe, that ofte tyme
holdiþe the soule in his dilectaciouns, for the whiche he may
not come to the euerlastyng lyf; For wher is his conuersacio&ntail;
but in the Empire of hevene? why thenne wolle not the fleshe lete him
passe to that mury contree?  For the fleshe is naturely a-yenste the
sprite.  Do þerfo&rtail; as du&dtail; the Emperoure; huy&rtail;
payntours, scil. men of holy chirche, that conne paynte in the hede of
thin herte two ymages, scil. contrucio&ntail;, & confessio&ntail;,
so that eyþere of hem have a wel I-polishi&dtail; glasse, scil.
a consiens an&dtail; perseveraunce, the whicℏ perseueraunce
amonge alle oþer vertues is I-crowni&dtail;.  & yf thow
be-holde welle thes, þou shalt for&yogh;ite the wey of
inpediment, an&dtail; thow shalt late
þi soule passe frely.  but allas! for ofte tyme while þat
þe soule lyþe in þe way of penaunce towar&dtail;
hevene, þere comythe a servaunt, scil. a shrewde or a frowar&dtail; wil, or a
fleshli delectacio&ntail;, that makitℏ foule the consienns
an&dtail; the perseueracio&ntail;, so that þe soule may not Se go&dtail;, ne his owne
peri&llbar;.  Do ther fo&rtail; as dude the Emperour; yif hir a
Gurdi&llbar;, scil. charite, with presious stonys, scil. lownesse
& chastite; an&dtail; ofte tyme redde the superscripciou&ntail;,
scil. but yf hope we&rtail;, herte shulde breste.  This hope owithe to
be Redressi&dtail; vnto go&dtail;, þat yf þowe do
penaunce, thow shalt come to þe lyf that euermo&rtail; lastithe;
an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; seithe the Apostle, Spe salui facti sumus , This is to seye,
Þorow hope we bethe I-made safe.  An&dtail; yf we do so, with
oute dowte we shulle come to the Euerlastinge lyf, bothe in fleshe
& in soule, aftir the laste dome.  go&dtail; graunte vs þat
for his mercy!  Amen.

50.1:
[ Second Version.  XXXI. ] Addit. MS. 9066. Story. FReudericus reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, that longe was
withoute a wyf and chil&dtail;.  Atte at
the last, by counsaile of his wise men, he wedde&dtail; a right
faire maide&ntail; mayde of ferre countre,
and witℏ her abode in that countre vnknowe&ntail;; and on her
begate gate childre&ntail;.  ¶ Aftir
that, he wol&dtail; go to his Empire, but of her he myght gete no
leve; For and she sai&dtail;, yf he went
fro her, she shol&dtail; wolde slee her
sel&ftee;.  ¶ whan the Emperour her&dtail; this, he doute&dtail;
gretly omitted , and studie&dtail; how he
myght go fro her *witℏ her omitted wille.  ¶ he hire&dtail; his hym payntours, and made hem paynt over on his
[beddys] supplied from Cambridge MS hede ij.  faire
ymages, and in the forhede of eche ymage was put a glasse, in the whiche his wyf myght every day loke, and
have delite.  wherfore the woman ha&dtail; so grete delite in
beholdyng of hem, that she forgate the love of her husbon&dtail;.
¶ whan the Emperour perseive&dtail; that, he wente from her.  But
whan he was *gone from her go , there come a
maide&ntail; mayde prively, and
defoule&dtail; the myrrour mirrours , in so meke&llbar; myche that the wyf a&llbar;
thynges left, and wente aftir her husbon&dtail;; and omitted whan she foun&dtail; hym, she la&dtail;
hym witℏ her agay&ntail;.  ¶ Than the Emperour sorowe&dtail;
gretly; neverthelesse he studie&dtail; by what wey he myght go from
her.  ¶ he ordeyne&dtail; a hym a faire girde&llbar;, and araie&dtail; it witℏ precious stones; and
in every stone he di&dtail; write this reaso&ntail;, ¶ "were not
hope stedfast, hert ofte sithe shol&dtail; brest breke ."  this gurde&llbar; he ga&ftee; to hys
wy&ftee;, and she gladly resceive&dtail; it; and omitted of the gurde&llbar; she ha&dtail; so
moche delite, that she for-gate a&llbar; the love of her
husbon&dtail;.  [Whan the Emperour saw that, priuely he went to his
contre.  And his wyfe folowed neuer after; but as she was in wylle to
go after hire husband,] supplied from Cambridge MS so ofte
sithes omitted she loke&dtail; on the
gurde&llbar;, and re&dtail; the scripture, "were not hope stedfast,
hert ofte sithe shol&dtail; brest."  ¶ Than she thought, "yit I
hope to se my husbonde witℏ myrthe."  and so she live&dtail;
longe, and ende&dtail; her lyf in pease. ¶ Declaracio. My swete frendes ,
this Emperour may be sai&dtail; every goo&dtail; cristen man, that owetℏ to be Emperour of hym
sel&ftee;; ¶ wherfore pryncipally and before a&llbar; thyng he
owetℏ to take a way towar&dtail; his owne countre, and therfore

flessℏ, that ofte sithe beholdetℏ the soule in many

Emperour di&dtail;; heire payntours, that is, men of holy chircℏ,
that can paynte in the hede of thy&ntail; hert ij. ymages, that is,
contriccio&ntail; and confessio&ntail;, so that eche ymage have a

a&llbar; vertues is crowne&dtail;.  for sothe yf thou behol&dtail;
wele in thise myrrours, lightly thou shalt for-yete the way of
Impedyment and lettyng, And so thou shalt suffre thi soule frely to
passe.  ¶ But allas for sorow! for ofte sithes while the soule lietℏ in the way of
penaunce towar&dtail; heve&ntail;, cometℏ the servaunt, that is,
foryetefu&llbar; wille, or
flesshly delectacio&ntail;, and defouletℏ the myrrours, that is,
conscience and perseveraunce, as ofte as it lietℏ in dedely
synne, so that the soule may not se go&dtail;, ne the perile of it
sel&ftee;.  ¶ Do thou therfore as the Emperour di&dtail;; yeve
her a gerde&llbar;, that is, charite, witℏ precious stones, that
is, mekenesse and chastite; and rede ofte the scripture, that is,
¶ Were not hope stedfast, hert ofte sithes wol&dtail; brest.
¶ Hope shol&dtail; a&llbar; way be ha&dtail; in thi kynde to
go&dtail;, for yf I do penaunce here, my hope is to have ever lastyng
ly&ftee;; and that is, that the apposte&llbar; saitℏ, ¶ By
faithe we are made sau&ftee;.  and yf we do so, witℏ out doute
aftir the day of dome, the hert witℏ the soule sha&llbar; ioye in
ever lastyng lyf.  to the whiche brynge vs Ihesu crist!  Amen.

0.1:
PRotheus Reignid an Emperoure in the citee of Rome; an&dtail; he
ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, that childeri&ntail; shulde sustene
he&rtail; faderis in al maner of Nede, scil. yf that theye we&rtail;
of powe&rtail; there to, or Riche&rtail; þa&ntail; hir faderis.
Fel cas, that ther was a kny&yogh;t nami&dtail; andronicus, an&dtail;
he ha&dtail; a faire gentil woma&ntail; to wyf, þe whiche
conseyui&dtail; of him, & bare him a sonne.  The childe throfe,
an&dtail; wel was I-lovi&dtail; a-monge al me&ntail;, for he was gracious
in beholdinge.  Hit happi&dtail;, the kny&yogh;t went o&ntail;
pilgrimage, an&dtail; felle amonge thevis; an&dtail; þer he was
cruely taken, & bounde; an&dtail; thenne he wepte, & saide,
"alas! for what shalle I nowe do, for nowe I am presony&dtail; in a
derke presoune, a-monge straungeres."  An&dtail; as he was in making
of his lamentacio&ntail;, ther come to him a wyse man, an&dtail;
saide, "de&rtail; frende, hast thowe not at home no wyf, nor childe?"
"yis, sir," quo&dtail; he, "I have a wyf, & oo childe."
"soþely," seide that oþer, "thenne I counsaille the, that
thow write to thi wyf, & to thi childe, for thy Redempcio&ntail;,
seing that the law of the Emperour is swiche, that the childeri&ntail;
owithe to sustene an&dtail; Releve hir faderis, in hir grete nedes;
an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; sey to thi childe, that sithen he is thi
childe, that he nowe helpe the; an&dtail; saye to thi wyf, that she
socoure the in thi wrecchidnes, sithe ye bethe bothe oo fleshe."  the
kny&yogh;t wrote letteris in this forme to the wyfe, & to the
sone; an&dtail; whenne the wyf hadde se&ntail; the letteris, she wepte
so so&rtail;, that she was blynde for weping.  An&dtail; the sone in
the same maner made sorowe as muche as he myght be&rtail;,
& saide to his moder, "A! de&rtail; moder, now is woo to yow
I-nowe; neuer the les I wolle go, an&dtail; deliuer my fadir."  "Nay,"
quo&dtail; the moder, "thow sha&llbar; not go, for thow art my Ioye,
& my solas; and yf thow leve me be my self, hit wolle be cause of
my dethe.  An&dtail; also hit may happin withe the by the way, as hit
is withe thi fadre; & so hit shulde be to me doble confucio&ntail;
& woo.  [Thow] hadde lever," quo&dtail; she, "deliuer thi fadir
out of presoune, tha&ntail; to norishe me & helpe me in my nedes,
Sithen I have norishi&dtail; þe fro þe begynnyng of thi
birthe; an&dtail; þerfor þow shalt abide at home witℏ
me, for yf thowe go, I am but dede.  & knowist thow not welle,
that yf eny thinge be yevi&ntail; to two simplely, an&dtail; that
o&ntail; be take or dede, al is in the pow&rtail; of him or hi&rtail;
that is present?"  thenne saide he, "modir, I he&rtail; thi wordes
welle."  þenne saide she, "thowe wot wel, & specialli I wote hit welle, that thow arte his sonne and
my&ntail; eke, for out of my wombe þou passediste.  Now
þin fadir is absent, & I a&mtail; present; þenne I
conclude by goode probacio&ntail;, that þow owist not to go
fro&mtail; me to thi fadir."  Thenne spake þe sone, an&dtail;
saide, "A! de&rtail; modir, thow I be thi sonne, yit my fadir is cause of my
generacio&ntail; in principa&llbar;, as thow erte of my conseyvinge;
& my fadir yede in pilgrimage, an&dtail; thow dwellist at home.
now he is taky&ntail;, & made soget to his Enmyes, & þou
art free; So he dwellithe amonge his
Enmyes, an&dtail; thowe a monge thi frendes; he liggithe strongli
I-bounde, an&dtail; thow ert los.  An&dtail; neuertheles thow erte
blynde, an&dtail; he hathe no light but cheynis, an&dtail; woundes,
& wrecchidnesses; an&dtail; soþely þere fo&rtail; I
wolle go to him, & deliuer him oute."  An&dtail; so hit was
do&ntail; in dede; an&dtail; al me&ntail; þere fo&rtail;
lovi&dtail; him, & commendi&dtail; his vertues, þat so
deliueri&dtail; his fadir fro barette.

1.1:
DEre Frendes, this Emperoure is þe Fadir of hevene; that
ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, that childerin shulde honour an&dtail;
worshipe hir Faderis & hir moderis, an&dtail; sustene hem. but who
is thi fadir, and whoo is thi moder?  Certeinly Crist is ou&rtail;
fade&rtail;, For he hathe to vs a fadirlye affeccio&ntail;, an&dtail;
not a modirly; For ye knowe
welle, þat yf a childe forfete or Trespasse, þe fadir
wolle sternely Repreve him, bete him & scorge him, but the modir
tretithe him li&yogh;tly an&dtail; swetlye. an&dtail; so Criste wolle
suffre vs to be turmenti&dtail;, angri&dtail;, & bete for oure
defavtis, as oure principa&llbar; fadir; & þere fo&rtail;
hit is seyde in Deuto. Nuncquid non ipse est
pater tuus, qui possedit te, & fecit, & creauit te? This is to seye, Wheþere is not he thi fadir, that owithe
þe, & made the, & shope the? scil. Crist, the
punysshe&rtail;.  Bute thy modir is þe worlde, that bihotithe to
the swetnesse & dilectabilities.  Now oure fader yede a
pilgrimage, as is mencio&ntail; made in þe Ps. Extraneus Factus sum fratribus meis , This is to
seye, I a&mtail; made a straunger to my bretherin.  Now Criste is
I-bounde, scorgi&dtail;, an&dtail; crossi&dtail; not in him selfe, but
in his membris; an&dtail; þerefore seithe the Apostle, Ad hebreos, Quicunque est in mortali peccato, iacet in
Carcere diaboli , This is to seye, Who so euer be in dedely
synne, he is in presone of the devil. an&dtail; þerefore oure
fadir wolde, that we shul&dtail; goo, an&dtail; by the thraldo&mtail;,
scil.by doinge of the vij. werkis of mercy, also go and preche, &
shew þe kyngdo&mtail; of go&dtail;. an&dtail; þerby thow
may become the childe of criste, for who so euer prechithe fructuovslye the worde of
go&dtail;, he winithe þe fadir, and biyiþ crist; for he
seithe, Quod vni ex minimis meis fecistis, michi
fecistis , This is to seye, Þat ye doþ to
þe leste of myne, ye dothe to me. but the modir, scil. þe
worlde, letithe not a ma&ntail; folowe crist in pouerte, & in
oþer gode werkes; but he seithe to ma&ntail;, "I may not live,
yf that thow chese, and go þe weye of penaunce, & folowe
criste, that was po&rtail;."  An&dtail; this moder is blynde,
an&dtail; makithe oþere blynde also; an&dtail; seithe Eche day
to me&ntail;, "Come to me, I am present to the; & late vs vse
goodis, & strengithe, & fairhe&dtail;." but, dere fren&dtail;,
yf that thow be a goode kynde childe to go&dtail;, thow wolte
avnswe&rtail; þus, "the fyrste partie is but of the fadir, &
the secounde of the modir; the soule is hi&yogh;t to go&dtail;, &
the body to the worlde, scil. Erthe.  & þerfo&rtail; do not
aftir the worlde, ne abide not age, vnpower, or blyndnesse, for the
oblacio&ntail; that thowe wolde make þenne is the lesse
acceptable to go&dtail;; an&dtail; triste not to the worlde by no wey,
For thenne he wolle desceyve the as thin Enmye, but go to Crist,
an&dtail; thenne thow shalt have euirlastinge lyf.
Ame&ntail;!

0.1:
GOrgonius was an Emperoure Regnynge in the cite of Rome; an&dtail;
he ha&dtail; weddi&dtail; to wyf a yonge gentilwoma&ntail;, the whiche
conseyui&dtail;, an&dtail; browte forthe a faire sone.  An&dtail;
whenne the childe was in age of xx. ye&rtail;, the modir deyi&dtail;;
& he weddi&dtail; anoþere wyf, that lovi&dtail; not the
Emperours sone, but she Reprevide him moche, & shewi&dtail; to him
muche glowmynge che&rtail;.  Whenne the Emperour saw that, he sent his
sonne out of þe Empy&rtail;, for presaunce of his wyf; an&dtail;
whenne the yonge man was put oute of the Empyre, he lerni&dtail; to be
a phisicie&ntail;, that myte be in eny place.  Aftirwar&dtail; hit
happi&dtail;, that his fadir, scil. the Emperoure, fel sike, ande was
ny dede; but what tyme he harde telle that his sone was so goo&dtail;
a phisicione , he sent for him by
letteris, that he shulde come withe oute delay.  Þe sonne
willin>ee; [to] obey to the fadir, he come to him, and saw his
vryne; an&dtail; thenne yaf him medesyne, wherthorowe he was hole.  Aftir that, the wyf of the
Emperoure be ganne to be syke, in so muche that lechis ha&dtail; grete
mystir of hir lyfe.  Whenne the Emperour har&dtail; that, he praide
his sonne, that he shulde hele his wyfe of hir sikenesse an&dtail; in
firmite; an&dtail; the sone saide, "sertenlye, I wolle not putte to
hir no medicinis." "An&dtail; but thow do," quo&dtail; the fadir,
"þou shalte be exili&dtail; fro my companye." Þenne saide
the sonne, "fadir, yf thow do so to me, þou doste to me grete
wronge; for þou knowist welle, that thow di&dtail; putte me for hir love out of the Empi&rtail;,
wherfo&rtail; myn absence was cause of thin infirmitee, an&dtail; of
thi sorow; & thenne, whenne I come ayene, with a little helpe
þou Receyvidist helþe, so hylie comforti&dtail; þe.
my presence was & is cause of hir infirmite, & þerefore
I wolle not entermete me of hir, & whi? for I knowe welle, that
the sy&yogh;te of me wolle greve hir, an&dtail; a leche may ofte tyme
be deceyvi&dtail; also an&dtail; I coveite not, that eny thinge felle
to hir bute goo&dtail;, that she putte blame in me."  Þenne
saide the fadir, "sone, she hathe the same seknesse þat I
hadde." "ye, what þow," seide the sone, "thow hit be the same
sekenes, hit is not the same compleccio&ntail;; for that whiche I dude
to the, þou heilde the þer withe wel paide, for my
presence, an&dtail; the comfortable sygℏt, whe&ntail; þou
sawe me, þat þou gate helthe helde
þe ; An&dtail; þerfore it is beste that she late some
leche dele with hir, that she wolde triste i&ntail;; & so she may
& shalle be hole."

1.1:
DEre Frendes, þis Emperoure is Echon of vs that have
I-take&ntail; the wyf of Cristindome in baptime; for thenne is
þe soule made þe spouse of Criste, of whome he getithe a
sonne, scil.Reso&ntail;, whiche is annexi&dtail; to go&dtail;.  But
Christianyte deiþe, whe&ntail; a ma&ntail; lithe in synnes,
aftir the ma&ntail; wedditℏ anoþer, scil.wickidnesse, as
ofte as a man is Ruli&dtail; & gouerni&dtail; by wille, & not
by Reso&ntail;. An&dtail; so he livithe fleshely, & puttithe awey
Reso&ntail;, & þenne þe soule is sike; for the absens
of Reso&ntail; is cause of the sekenes of the soule.  but the&ntail;
Resone, whiche is gostlye medisyne, is I-browte a-yene by the werkes
of mercy, an&dtail; of consciens, & so is man I-heli&dtail;;
an&dtail; that oþer wyf, scil.frowarde wille or sensualite, is
syk, as ofte as the fleshe is putt downe by Penaunce.  An&dtail;
þerefor we moste be ware howe that we norishe ow&rtail; [lyf];
for the lyf of ma&ntail; is likeni&dtail; nowe to a flou&rtail;, nowe
to hete or warmnes, an&dtail; nowe to a fleinge shadowe, an&dtail;
nowe to a messager that Rynnithe or Ridithe afore, an&dtail; nowe to
an arowe shote to a marke; for of al thes is trays ne folowinge to
an&dtail; [so] it is of a ma&ntail; aftir his dethe.  An&dtail;
þere fo&rtail; lat vs be so busye to amen&dtail; oure lyf, that
we mowe come, an&dtail; take, & have the Ioye of hevene.
Amen!

0.1:
ONias was an Emperoure in the cetee of Rome; an&dtail; he hadde a
faire dovter, that was muche like to him
selfe, an&dtail; the whicℏ he muche lovi&dtail;.  So þer
come a kny&yogh;t to this damse&llbar;, name&dtail; Cornelius,
an&dtail; he stiri&dtail; hir & wowi&dtail; hir, in al that he
my&yogh;t, for synne to be do&ntail;; an&dtail; soone this damiselle,
not havinge mynde of perilis þat myght falle, soone she
consenti&dtail;.  the kny&yogh;t deflowri&dtail; hir; an&dtail; whenne
he ha&dtail; drive a-weye the flow&rtail; of hir virginitee, he lefte
hir, an&dtail; forsoke hir.  the woma&ntail; conseyvi&dtail;,
an&dtail; browte forthe a faire soone.  Anoo&ntail; the kny&yogh;t
took þe childe, & slowe hit; an&dtail; whenne the moder
harde that, she was hiliche greui&dtail; in alle the strenges of hir
herte, an&dtail; wrote to him, & aski&dtail; of him whi he hadde
I-doo suche a wicke&dtail; dede. the kny&yogh;t hadde noo&ntail;
Excusacio&ntail;, ne wolde not lowe him selfe. whenne the Emperoure
harde he&rtail;of, he hadde gret dispite, & was wrothe to him;
& soone he made to be cride a genera&llbar; tornement.  An&dtail;
in the day of the tornement þer were sette by the Emperoure iij.
or iiij. kny&yogh;tes of oo partye, an&dtail; as many in that
oþer syde; an&dtail; thei that we&rtail; in the firste parte
hadde I-putte sheldes in a certeyne place deputte þerefo&rtail;.
 Whenne this was doo&ntail;, Cornelius the kny&yogh;t, that lay by the
damisel, come witℏ the aduersarijs ayenste the Emperour, the
whiche wolde play. he yede to the sheldes wher þei lay,
an&dtail; towchi&dtail; o&ntail; of hem with his spere, the whiche
shelde perteyni&dtail; to a kny&yogh;t þat the Emperoure moche
lovi&dtail;; mevinge, as is maner of playe, that he that owte the
shelde sholde a-Rise, & noo&ntail; oþir; an&dtail;
þerfo&rtail;, as costo&mtail; was, a clene virgine shulde arme
him.  An&dtail; so he yede to the felde, an&dtail; plai&dtail; with
cornely, In so muche that Cornelius was þer grevouslye
woundi&dtail;; but he wa&ntail; the victory, & toke þe
Emperours dowter, an&dtail; ladde hir home a-yene to the
palys.

1.1:
DEre frendes, this Emperoure is þe fadir of hevene; The
dowter is þe soule, I-made to his owne similitude; Cornelius is
the devil, that deseyui&dtail; hir, & slow hir childe,
an&dtail; made al mankynde in subieccio&ntail;.  Now go&dtail;
haviþe iij. scochens, scil. [the] powere, the whiche is the
scocho&ntail; of the fadir; he hathe wisdome, þe which is
þe scochon of the sone; an&dtail; he hathe goodnesse, the wiche
is the scocho&ntail; of the holy gost. Þes iij. sheldes
go&dtail; hathe sette in a place ordeyni&dtail; þerfo&rtail;,
scil. mankynde, whenne that he made him to his owne likenesse.  For
the firste ma&ntail; Ada&mtail; hadde lordshipe ouer alle the bestes
of the Erthe, an&dtail; ther is the shelde of the fadir, scil.
powe&rtail;; þe secounde hadde connyng & knowleche of al
thinges vpo&ntail; erþe, an&dtail; þere was the shelde of
the sone, scil. wisdome; an&dtail; þe firste ma&ntail; was
formi&dtail; in grace, an&dtail; love of gode & of þe
neyboure, an&dtail; þere was the shelde of the holye goste,
scil. grace.  Now þe wicki&dtail; sprite, þe devil,
willynge in his wicki&dtail; obstinacye [to] fite a-yenst go&dtail;,
he come, an&dtail; towchi&dtail; not the shelde of the fadir, &
seide not, Si comederitis, eritis sicut dii
potentes , he seyde not, ye shul be my&yogh;ty as godis, yf
ye ete of hit; Ne he towchi&dtail; not the shelde of the holy gost,
seiyng, Eritis boni vel amantes , yf ye
Ete, ye shul be goo&dtail; or lovyn>ee; but he towchi&dtail; the
shelde of the sone, seiynge, Si comederitis, de
fructu illo eritis sicut dii, scientes bonum et malum ,
þis is to seye, yf ye ete of that frute, ye shalle be as
go&dtail; is, knowinge goode & eville.  An&dtail; þere
fo&rtail;, sithe he towchi&dtail; the shelde of þe sone,
þe sone, scil. Criste, was sent by the Emperour, his fadir, to
fite withe the devil. & þe virgine þat armi&dtail; him
was the virgine of virginis, scil. owre lady seint Marie, of the
whiche he toke armure, scil. man kynde; & þeri&ntail; he
faw&yogh;t with the devil, & his membris, an&dtail; with suffring
of v. sore woundes he wa&ntail; the victorye of hem; an&dtail; browte
the damyselle, þe soule of Adam, vnto the palys of hevene. Ad quod
palacium perducat nos Rex Regum! amen.

0.1:
Clipodius was a wyse Emperour reignynge in the citee of Rome,
an&dtail; his possessio&ntail; was moche; the wiche weddi&dtail; the
dowter of a kynge, calli&dtail; kinge assireorum, & she was faire
an&dtail; glorious in syght, an&dtail; browte
forthe a faire sone; but she dide in hir childebe&dtail;.  An&dtail;
aftir hir dicese, þe Emperoure weddi&dtail; anoþer
woma&ntail;, an&dtail; gate o&ntail; hir a childe; an&dtail; bothe
childerin he sent to fer contree, for to be forsteri&dtail;, &
browte vp. so in a certeyne tyme, the wyf of the Emperou&rtail; saide
to him, "sir, my lorde, hit is x. yere agoo&ntail; sithe I bare a
sone, & sawe him neuer sithe I ba&rtail; him; an&dtail;
þerfore I be-seche yow, þat ye sende after him, that I may
see him, & have sum Ioye of my birthe." Þenne saide the
Emperoure, "Dame, þou wot welle, that I gate a-noþer sone
of my first wyf, an&dtail; he is with him; & þerfor yf we
sen&dtail; for the to&ntail;, the toþer must come also." thenne
saide she, "sir, I assente." Þenne the Emperour sent for
he&mtail;, an&dtail; thei come bothe.  An&dtail; whenne thei we&rtail;
I-come, they we&rtail; to syght of alle me&ntail; faire an&dtail;
welle I-shapi&ntail;, wel I-norsshi&dtail;, & welle
I-norturi&dtail;; an&dtail; thei we&rtail; so like, that vnneþe
the o&ntail; mygℏt be knowe&ntail; fro&mtail; the toþer
with eny ma&ntail;, but onlye of the fadir.  Thenne saide the wyf,
"gode lorde, telle me whiche is my chil&dtail;, for soþely I
know not wheþer of hem is my&ntail;?" Þenne he leyde his
honde vpo&ntail; þe childe that he hadde with the firste wyf,
an&dtail; saide, "lo! this is thi sone." An&dtail; whenne he hadde so
tolde hir, she lovi&dtail; an&dtail; piki&dtail;, fedde an&dtail;
taw&yogh;te this childe, trowing that he ha&dtail; be the same that
she bare; & hilie dispisi&dtail; hir owne sone, trowinge that he
was hir stepso&ntail;.  whenne the Emperoure sawe her gret vnkyndnes,
that she wolde not love bothe y-like, he sai&dtail; to hir, "woman, I
have deseyvi&dtail; the; for that chil&dtail; that thow norisshest so
moche, is not thyne, þat oþere is thi childe, that
þou lovist not."  What dude she but lefte that childe, an&dtail;
was a boute, in al that she my&yogh;t, to plese that oþer.
An&dtail; whenne the Emperoure saw that, he saide to hir, "dame, I have yit
deseyvi&dtail; the, for he is not thi sone; an&dtail; yit thow shalt
not knowe more sekyrnesse of me, but I wolle that thow wite, that
o&ntail; of thes Is thi sone, that thow bare."  Þe&ntail; she
kneli&dtail; downe vpo&ntail; hir knees, an&dtail; sai&dtail;,
"lor&dtail;, for his love that hinge vpo&ntail; the crosse, do tel me
in certe&ntail; whiche of hem is my sone, withe oute
cauillacio&ntail;."  "For sothe," quo&dtail; the Emperou&rtail;, "thou
shalt not know, vnto the tyme that thei come to hir ful age, by cause
that I wolle þat þou love hem bothe I-lyke. For whenne I
saide þis was þi childe, þou lovedest al him, &
nothing Leaf 191 is out of
place.  It should follow leaf 192. the oþer; an&dtail;
whenne I saide þat oþer was thi childe, þou tendeist
al to him, an&dtail; dispisidist þat oþere; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; I wolle, that thow love hem boþe i-lyke welle." an&dtail; so she dude indede, til
tyme that thei come to hir lawful age, an&dtail; mannys degree; &
thenne the Emperoure tolde hir in certeyne whoo was hir childe, wher
thorow she was gladde, an&dtail; ful welle a-payde in
herte.

1.1:
DEre frendes, this Emperoure is oure lorde Ihesu Criste.  Thes too
childeri&ntail; beþe chose&ntail; creatures, & wicki&dtail;
creatours. the moder is .s. holie chirche, þe whiche
norshithe boþe the goode & the evi&llbar; For go&dtail;
wolle not that hit be certeyne to holye chirche, who is choso&ntail;,
an&dtail; who is not; For yf holye chirche knew it, she wolde love
o&ntail;, & hate the oþer, an&dtail; thenne charite shulde
be distroye&dtail;, an&dtail; me&ntail; shulde live in discorde. but
in the day of dome hit shalle be declari&dtail;, who is chose, &
who is not chose; an&dtail; þerfo&rtail; late vs do so in this
worlde, that we mowe be choso&ntail; vnto the fest that euer is
newe&dtail;, an&dtail; neuer wexithe olde. Ad
quod nos perducat Rex vivens in secula! Amen.

0.1:
POlemius was an Emperoure in the cetee of Rome, þe whiche
hadde iij. sonnes, that he moche lovi&dtail;.  So as þis
Emperoure laye in a certeyne nyght in his bedde, he thowte to dispose his Empi&rtail;, & he thou&yogh;t to yeve his
kyngdome to the slowest of his sones. he calli&dtail; to him his
sonnes, & saide, "he that is the sloweste of yow, or most slewthe
is i&ntail;, shall have my kyngdo&mtail; aftir my discese."
"Þenne sha&llbar; I have hit," quo&dtail; the Eldest sone; "for
I a&mtail; so slowe, an&dtail; swiche slewthe is in me, that me hadde
leuer late my fote brynne in the fy&rtail;, whenne I Sitte þer
by, tha&ntail; to withdrawe, & save hit."  "Nay," quo&dtail; the
secounde, "yit am I mo&rtail; worthi thanne þow; for yf case
that my necke we&rtail; in a rope to be hongi&dtail;; an&dtail; yf
þat I hadde my two hondes at wille, an&dtail; in o&ntail;
honde þe Ende of þe Rope, an&dtail; in that oþer
honde a sharpe swerde, I hadde levir dye ande be hongi&dtail;,
þa&ntail; I wolde sty&rtail; my&ntail; arme, an&dtail; kitte the
Rope, whereby I myte be savi&dtail;." "hit is I," quo&dtail; the
thirde, "that shalle Regne aftir my syre, for I passe hem bothe in
slewthe. yf I lygge in my bedde wyde opy&ntail;, & þe Reyne
Rayne vppo&ntail; boþe my&ntail; ye&ntail;, yee, me hadde leuer
lete hit Reyne hem oute of the hede, than I turni&dtail; me
oþere to the Right syde, or to the lyfte syde." Þenne the
Emperoure biquathe his Empi&rtail; to the thirde sone, as for the
slowist.

1.1:
DEre frendes, this Emperoure is the devil, that is kynge an&dtail;
fadir a-bove al childeri&ntail; of pryde.  By the first sone is
vndirstonde the man, that dwellithe in a wicki&dtail; sitee or place,
by the whiche a flavme of fire, scil. of synne, is stirte to him;
& yit it is moche I-sene, that he hadde leuer brynne y&ntail;
synne withe he&mtail;, thanne Remeve fro&mtail; the companye.  By the
secounde sonne is he vndirstonde, that knowithe welle him selve to be
fasteni&dtail; in the cordes & bondes of synne, an&dtail; wolle
not smyte he&mtail; aweye with the swerde of his tonge; an&dtail;
hadde leuer be hongi&dtail; for hem in helle, thanne to be shriven
he&rtail;. bi the thirde sone, vpo&ntail; who&mtail; water dropis, boþ buþ of the ri&yogh;t ye &
of the lyfte, is vndirstonde he that hurithe the doctrine of the ioyes of paradys, an&dtail; of the paynis
& tormentes of helle, an&dtail;
wolle not for slownesse of wytte torne him to the Right syde, scil. to
leve synne, for love of the Ioyes, ne to the left, The scribe
has here by negligence repeated nearly four lines. scil. to
leeve synne, for drede of peynis, but lithe stille in synnys vnmevabely; an&dtail; swiche wolle have the
kyngdo&mtail; of helle, & not of hevene. A
quo nos liberet, et ad quod nos perducat imperator semper iure
Regnans! ame&ntail;.

0.1:
Alexandir was a my&yogh;ti Emperou&rtail; in the citee of Rome,
þe whiche bisegi&dtail; a citee of þe kynges of Egipte; in
tyme of whiche besegein>ee; he loste many knyghtes, an&dtail;
me&ntail; of his hoste; an&dtail; that withe owtin wounde, he knew not
howe; but sodenly euery day the[y] fille downe dede. Alexandir hadde
her of grete wonder, & grete hevinesse þerwithe; an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; he lete be browte to him wyse philesophris, that
we&rtail; wyse & experte in diuerse siens, & he saide to hem,
"goode maisteres, I pray yow shewithe me yov&rtail; witte, &
tellithe me how it is, that my me&ntail; þus deyithe sodenlye,
withoute eny stroke or hurtyn>ee;."  "sir," quo&dtail; o&ntail;,
"hit is no mervayle, for the&rtail; is a cocautrice withe in the
walle; an&dtail; as ofte tyme as she hathe enye syght of youre
me&ntail;, þei bethe dede, thorowe the venyme that passithe
fro&mtail; hir syght."  Þenne saide Alexandir, "Is þer no
Remedy a-yenste that sorye beste?"  "yis," quo&dtail; they, "a goode
Remedye.  late sette a bright myrrour wel I-polyshi&dtail; betwene
your host an&dtail; the cockatrice; an&dtail; thenne, whenne she wolle
loke forthe, she shalle loke in the glas, & hir owne beholdyng
shalle bowe & passe to hir ayene; & she shalle be
deseyui&dtail;, an&dtail; dye, & oure men shul be savi&dtail; fro
dethe."  Þe Emperour didde in dede as the philesophir
conseili&dtail; him; an&dtail; so anoo&ntail; whenne þe myrrour
was I-sette vp, þe cockautrice was slayne, & þey
entri&dtail; into þe citee, & whonne hit.

1.1:
DEre Frendes, this Emperoure may welle be calli&dtail; Eche
Cristin ma&ntail;, that hatℏ an host to-geder of vertuys ; for with oute the host of vertuys may
no ma&ntail; fy&yogh;te gostly.  The sitee, that we owe to be-sege abowte, is þe worlde, in the
whiche is a&ntail; hie castelle, scil. Vanitas
vanitatum , þis is to seye, Vanite of vanytes; & in
the walle, scil. vanite, is a cokautrice, scil. pryde of lyfe; wronge
covetise of ye&ntail;, an&dtail; wronge covetise of fleshe; an&dtail;
thorow this pryde bethe vnnumberable peple in-fecte an&dtail; dede, in
euerlastinge dethe.  An&dtail; þere fo&rtail; ther is a goode
Remedye, scil. to considre thin owne foulnesse, howe that þou naki&dtail; entredist into the worlde,
& with what kynne cloþ þou ert I-cladde i&ntail;
þin endyng.  Yf enye ma&ntail; askithe wherfore & whie a
proude ma&ntail; deyethe þerefo&rtail; euerlastingely? sothely
hit is for the host of vertues failithe; an&dtail; þerfo&rtail;
I saye, sete vp a cle&rtail; myrrour,
scil. an holy conscie&nmacr;s, & by that consciens considre thi
foulenesse, febilnesse, & fragilitee, an&dtail; so thow shalt see
thin owne faute. & þenne, yf the cocautrice be
destroye&dtail;, scil. pryde of lyfe, wronge covetise of ye&ntail;,
an&dtail; wronge covetise of fleshe, certenlye þou shalt entre,
& wynne the citee off hevene, &c.

0.1:
ERaclius was a wise Emperoure Reignynge in the citee of Rome;
an&dtail; he ordeyni&dtail; for a lawe, that yf enye dome we&rtail;
yeve to enye trespassoure, hit shulde stonde, with owte mercy. hit
happi&dtail; in a certeyne tyme, as he satte at his mete, ther come a
straunger from fer contree; an&dtail; he accusi&dtail; a kny&yogh;t of
tresoune, an&dtail; saide that he ha&dtail; slayne a-noþere
knyght of the Emperours. whenne the Emperoure ha&dtail; harde this

EUfemius was a Riche Emperour in the citee of Rome; an&dtail; he
ha&dtail; a sone, & a dowter.  An&dtail; as the Emperoure Rode in

mast&rtail;e, what bymeenyþe this melodie?"  Þenne the
clerke aunsweri&dtail;, an&dtail; saide, "this menithe not elles, but

for thow shalt dye & not live."  Whenne the Emperoure harde

maki&dtail; þe lordes to be calli&dtail;, an&dtail; he saide to
hem, "Dere frendes, I may not passe fro this infirmite, an&dtail;
þerefo&rtail; I wolle make my testament in youre presence;
an&dtail; [God] wot, þat I feele þere is no perile to me,
but that I have not marrij&dtail; my dowter."  an&dtail; þere
fo&rtail; he chargide his sone,
vppo&ntail; his blessyng, afo&rtail; alle þe lordes, þat

ma&ntail; that she is with childe."  "Þis is a goode

An&dtail; whe&ntail; he hadde saide so, the kynge yede, &
openi&dtail; his cofir, wher the tables we&rtail; that he fonde,
an&dtail; the cradille; an&dtail; he yaf hem to him, an&dtail; saide,
"sone, throw art lettere&dtail;, loke, an&dtail; rede thes letteres."
An&dtail; whenne he hadde redde how he was geti&ntail; bi twene the
broþere & þe suster, he cride with an hie voyse,
an&dtail; seide, "Allas! for nowe I see wel that I was goto&ntail;
an&dtail; broute forthe a yene the wille of go&dtail;, in ane Orible
synne, boþe in the sy&yogh;t of go&dtail;, of man, & of
angel.  A! goode lorde, helpe that I we&rtail; a kny&yogh;t, for I
wolle now a-bowte the wordle, for the synne of my fadris."  The kynge
made him kny&yogh;t; an&dtail; thenne he hiri&dtail; a shippe to passe
the water towarde the holy londe.  An&dtail; a grete wynde Ros vp,
& browte the shippe to the havene of the citee wher as dwelte his mod&rtail;, but what citee o&rtail; what
kyngdo&mtail; it was, he knew not.  An&dtail; whenne he was in the
citee, his squie&rtail; so&yogh;te an host, for swiche a worthi kny&yogh;t to be
eside ynne; an&dtail; whenne a certey&ntail; burgeys of the citee sawe
him, seminge so dowty a knyght, he graunti&dtail; to him hostage.
& whenne they hadde I-soupi&dtail;, freudricus seyde to the
burgeyse, "what citee is this, an&dtail; who is lorde thereof?"
thenne saide he, "This is the [citee] of the Emperoure, that yede
oonys to the holye londe, & þere he dide; an&dtail; thenne
become the Empire into the hondes of his sister, by line of heritage;
an&dtail; þerefo&rtail; þer is a duke algates that
wol&dtail; have hir to wyfe, an&dtail; she wolde not consente to him
by no waye; & þerefo&rtail; he hathe conqueri&dtail; al the
Empire by his swerde, excepte this citee, withe The caste&llbar;, in
the whiche caste&llbar; dwellithe the Emperesse."  thenne spake the
yonge kny&yogh;t to the burgeyse, & saide to him, "Dee&rtail; sir,
I pray the hertely to go in myn Eron&dtail;, scil. to go to þe
master of the caste&llbar;, an&dtail; saye to him, that yf he wolle
yeve to me eny wages, I shalle fight for yowe al the hole ye&rtail;."
An&dtail; whenne the burgeys ha&dtail; har&dtail; þes wordes, he
was gla&dtail; an&dtail; Iocounde, & seide, "I am certei&ntail;
that he wolle be Right blithe, & gla&dtail; of thi comynge."
an&dtail; he yede to that master of the caste&llbar;, & saide,
"sir, he&rtail; is in this sitee a semly yonge kny&yogh;te, that was
gesteni&dtail; with me in my&ntail; house al this ny&yogh;t; an&dtail;
he wolle fi&yogh;t for yow alle this ye&rtail;, yf ye wolle yeve to
him competente salarye." Þenne seyde he, "Anoo&ntail; brynge him
to me, Fo[r] I wolde ful gladly þat we hadde many Swiche."  The
kny&yogh;t com to him; & þe stiwarde was þere of wel
apayde, an&dtail; saide to him, "sir, yf þou wolt fi&yogh;te for
þe Empy&rtail; & vs, & abyde with vs, I shalle go for
þe to the lady, & sey þyne erande, that thowe shalte
have þy wylle."  Aftir this, he yede to the lady, & tolde
hir of this kny&yogh;t.  "bringe him hedir," quo&dtail; she, "&
late me see him; & yf he wolle fi&yogh;te for vs, he shalle not
fayle of goo&dtail; mede."  Þenne þe stiwar&dtail; browte
him afo&rtail; hire.  whenne the ladye perceyvi&dtail; him, she caste
hir ye&ntail; mervelovslye vppo&ntail; his persone, neþeles she
hadde no knowleche that he was h[i]r sone; an&dtail; she made covenant
with him, that he shulde abide withe hir a yee&rtail;, & fy&yogh;t
for hir, & for þe Right of the Empire, ayenste the duke.
Anoo&ntail; the kny&yogh;t be ganne to Reyse batail, & to Ride thorow the Empire; an&dtail; whenne the duke
har&dtail; that, he gaderi&dtail; a&ntail; hoste, an&dtail; helde
batail a-yenste him. But the kny&yogh;t bare
him dowtily in the batai&llbar;, an&dtail; ouercome the duke;
an&dtail; or the yeeris Ende come oute, he wanne a-yene alle the londes,
an&dtail; citees, & castelles, that were lost by the duke.
An&dtail; whenne the ye&rtail; was endi&dtail;, he saide to the
Stiwarde, "sir, now is my tyme done, & þerefore I wolde have
my salari; for ye wote in what kynne state I fonde yowe, & how
that I have labouri&dtail; for yowe, & for the ryght of you&rtail;
Empire, an&dtail; þerfo&rtail; yevithe to me that ye hi&yogh;t
me, an&dtail; thenne I wolle forthe in to anoþer contree,
an&dtail; gete me a name."  Þenne saide the stiwarde to him
a-yene, "thow hast deliueri&dtail; this Empire welle an&dtail;
stronglye fro oure Enmyes, an&dtail; haste deservi&dtail; goode mede;
I wolle goo to the ladye, & se what she wolle seye þere to."
he yede in to the chaumb&rtail;, & kneli&dtail; dov&ntail;,
an&dtail; salusi&dtail; hir, an&dtail; sai&dtail;, "worshipfu&llbar;
lady, he&rtail; my wordes. ye knowe wel that ye ha&dtail; loste alle
the Empi&rtail;, the whicℏ this ma&ntail; hathe wonne a-yene,
an&dtail; now he askithe his mede; an&dtail; þerefor, lady,
Rewardithe him wel, an&dtail; not but yf he hathe deserui&dtail; hit
we&llbar;."  Þenne saide the lady, "telle me what is þi
counsei&llbar; that I yeve him, & he sha&llbar; have hit."
"lady," quo&dtail; the stiwarde, "yf ye wolde do aftir my
counsei&llbar;, hit shulde turne vs alle to grete profyte &
worshipe; for the man that þou woldest not take we alle have
sufferi&dtail; grete harme, an&dtail; thow haddist loste alle thyne
Empire; an&dtail; þerfore I wolde counsaile þe, that thow
take to thyne husbonde the yonge kny&yogh;t, for he is semlye, &
wel I-shape an&dtail; þerto gentil, & stronge in bataille."
Þenne saide she, "& yf hit be youre counsei&llbar;, I am
Redy to fulfille hit." thenne this stiwar&dtail; was gla&dtail;
I-nowe, an&dtail; yede oute to þe kny&yogh;t, an&dtail; tolde
him, that hit was plesynge to the lady to have him to husbonde; &
shortly to sey, thei we&rtail; weddi&dtail; to-ged&rtail;.  & at
hir fest we&rtail; alle lordes & ladijs of the Empi&rtail;,
an&dtail; alle thei we&rtail; contente of this mariage, because that
he so deliuerlye & worthely deliueri&dtail; hem fro hir
thraldo&mtail;.  An&dtail; aftir the makynge of this matrimonye,
þey lovi&dtail; to-geder mo&rtail; thanne eny man canne seye.
but the kny&yogh;t vsi&dtail; euery daye,
whenne he shulde goo to mete, to entre in to a prive chaumb&rtail;,
wher as he ha&dtail; leyde þe litle tablis þat we&rtail;
withe him in the cradille; an&dtail; thenne he wolde opynne hem,
an&dtail; rede the scripture of them, howe that he was begoti&ntail;
bitwene broþere & suster; an&dtail; thenne he wolde falle to
the grounde, an&dtail; so&rtail; wepe; & thenne he wolde washe his
face, & come in to the halle, an&dtail; shew þer a
goo&dtail; murye chere.  An&dtail; he was I-lovi&dtail; of a&llbar;
peple, for that he ba&rtail; him so welle in alle his werkes;
an&dtail; ther was noo&ntail; Emperoure
knowy&ntail; afore him, that euere governi&dtail; the Empire so wel.
Happyng in a day, as he Rode o&ntail; huntynge, that ther come a
damise&llbar; of the palays to the lady the Emperesse, an&dtail; saide
to nir, "my lady, hast thow not Offen&dtail; my lorde þe
Emperour?"  "No, for sothe," quo&dtail; the lady, "for ther is
nothinge vndir hevene that I love so moche, an&dtail; fore love I toke
him, an&dtail; made him my lorde; but I wolde wete whi that thow
spekist soo?"  "For sothe," quo&dtail; she, "for euery day afo&rtail;
mete, whenne the bordes e&rtail; sette an&dtail; made redye, The
Emperoure gothe into swiche a chaumb&rtail; gla&dtail; I-nowe, but
whe&ntail; he comythe oute, al his visage is wepingly; an&dtail;
thenne he wasshithe hit, that the wepinge be not I-seene.  An&dtail;
this I have ofte tyme I-seyne, but I note what is the cause."  Thenne
whe&ntail; the Emperesse ha&dtail; harde this, she enteri&dtail; into
that chaumbe&rtail;, an&dtail; sowte a-bowte frome hole to hole, to
loke what she myght fynde þere; an&dtail; at the laste she fonde
in an hole ij. tables; an&dtail; she openi&dtail; hem, an&dtail; Radde
the scripture that she hade wrete&ntail; withe hir owne hondes.
An&dtail; thenne she saide to hir selfe, "how shulde euer thes tablis
come to my lorde, but yf that he we&rtail; my sone?  Owte, allas! for
synne, that euere I was I-bo&rtail;, for I have weddi&dtail; my&ntail;
owne sone!" she felle downe to the grounde, &yogh;elling &
criynge, that hit was sorow to he&rtail;. kny&yogh;tes that we&rtail;
in the halle harde hir voyse, an&dtail; Ranne to hir, an&dtail;
aski&dtail; hir what was the cause of hir criing.  "A! dee&rtail;
an&dtail; gentille kny&yogh;tes," quo&dtail; she, "I am a lost womman
but I see my lorde the sonner."  A-noo&ntail; thei sente to þe
forest, an&dtail; tolde hit to the Emperoure; & saide he most leve
his playe, an&dtail; come home, in a&llbar; the hast that myte be.
An&dtail; so he dude; withe a grete hevines he lefte his playe, &
come home. he wente in to the chaumb&rtail;, & spiri&dtail; of the
ladye what was the cause of hir mornynge. thenne she saide, "I wolle
þat alle that buþ hee&rtail; withe vs go fro&mtail; vs or I telle it the, for hit is a
prevy case that I have to seye to the."  An&dtail; thenne she seide,
"sir, I have made a vowe to go&dtail;, that I sha&llbar; not passe
this bedde, til tyme that thowe telle me in what contre that thowe
were I-bore."  Þenne saide he, "De&rtail; lady, whi spekist
thowe sweche wordes? neþeles, yf I sha&llbar; sey the
soþe, I note in what kyngdo&mtail; or contre that I was borne."
Thenne saide she, "I have also made anoþer vowe, an&dtail; for
to wete or ever I Ete mete, who was thi
fade&rtail; & thi moder?"  Thenne aunsweri&dtail; he, "This canne
I telle, that whanne I was a fanteky&ntail;, I was fonde in a toune,
in a cradyl withi&ntail; hit; & fro that tyme I have
[bene] norisshi&dtail;, norie&dtail;, norturi&dtail;, an&dtail;
tau&yogh;te in the same contre; an&dtail;, lady, mo&rtail; canne I not
telle yow." whenne the Empreis hadde harde thes wordes, she drowe oute
at hir bosome the tables that she fonde, & saide to him, "Sawe ye
neuer thes tables, the whiche I put with the in thi cradil, withe
my&ntail; owne hondes?"  An&dtail; whenne the Emperoure herde thes
wordes, he felle downe o&ntail; a swoune o&ntail; oo syde, an&dtail;
the lady in a-noþer; an&dtail; bothe thei wepte so&rtail;,
an&dtail; Rente hir clothis for sorowe, an&dtail; worde my&yogh;te
nowþer of hem speke.  An&dtail; whenne the sorow was somwhat
shake&ntail; of, þenne saide she to the Emperour, "A! sone myne,
allas! that euer I was borne, an&dtail; woo worthe the oure that euer
I was made in!  Out, allas! for lo! my sone, & sone of my
broþere, is nowe my husbonde. lo! in how many cheynis that
þe devil hathe I-teyde me Inne!"  An&dtail; thenne saide he, "A!
de&rtail; modir, boþe modir & wyf; allas & wo be to me,
wrecche, that so many wrecchidnessis beþe in me!  lorde, that I
ne hadde be dreint, whenne thow castist me in to the see!  A! lorde
go&dtail;, what sorowe we&rtail; I worthi to have, that have
weddi&dtail;! lorde, yf my synnys we&rtail; weyde, bi the whiche I
have servi&dtail; thi wrethe; siþe&ntail; thow thi selfe [hast
saide,] Filius non portabit iniquitatem
patris , The sone shalle not be&rtail; the wickidnesse of the
fadir. but I may not be Excusi&dtail;, for my lyf is endi&dtail; in
wickidnesse.  Allas! therfo&rtail;, that euer I were bre&dtail;!"  An&dtail; thenne saide she,
"Dere sone, sette thi&ntail; hope in thi lorde go&dtail;, for he wolle
not for-sake the synner in nede. late vs be contrite, confessi&dtail;,
& communi&dtail;; an&dtail; aftir that we have Reseyvi&dtail; oure
lorde, late go&dtail; do his wille."  The Emperoure sent aftir a prest, an&dtail; they
we&rtail; bothe shriven at him.  An&dtail; whenne thei we&rtail; bothe
confessi&dtail;, & contrite, þe modir saide to the body of
Crist in thes wordes, "A! lorde go&dtail;, þowe þat
sufferidest passio&ntail; for me in the cros, an&dtail; that now liest
vpo&ntail; the patene of the chalis, in forme of brede, have mercy of
my swete sone, husbonde, & cosy&ntail;, for thi grete mercy, that
he may be clene of his synnys, an&dtail; yelde to the a faire soule,
withe a gladnesse, in to thi dwellynge place that is euermo&rtail;
lastyng."  The&ntail; saide the Emperoure, "A! goode lorde, that
bovtiste me in the crosse, have mercy of my modir in þis nede,
as þou Entredist in to the worlde for love of synnerys,
an&dtail; not for Rightwysmen, & for hem shadist thi presious
blode; an&dtail;, gracious lorde, for-yeve al that euere she hathe
trespassi&dtail; vnto the, an&dtail; take her sprite, an&dtail; brynge
hit to thi&ntail; Endles Ioye.  Amen!"  An&dtail; thenne, whenne alle
this was seide, the body of Crist liyng vpo&ntail; the awter, seyde with a&ntail; hihe voyse, "I made yowe of noute; I have take youre
contricio&ntail; & confessio&ntail;; I for yeve yow fully your
synnis; I Resseyve [yow] fro hens forwarde to my Ioye; an&dtail;
þis day & eueremore I shalle dwelle with yowe." An&dtail;
whe&ntail; thei harde thes wordes, thei fille downe to the grounde,
an&dtail; openi&dtail; hir mouthis to Resceyve the body of Criste;
an&dtail; þere thei Resseyvi&dtail; hit, an&dtail; yelde hir
soulis to go&dtail;, an&dtail; marie&dtail; in at the yates of
hevene.

1.1:
DEre frendis, now takithe hede to me.  This Emperoure is the
fadi&rtail; of hevene, whiche hathe only oo sone, an&dtail; oo
dou&yogh;ter is dou&yogh;ter glorious, havyng
angelis kynde an&dtail; mankynde; but the broþere fili&dtail;
the suster, scil. the devil deceyvi&dtail; the firste fadir
Ada&mtail;, & made him withe childe,—how so? for alle
mankyn&dtail; spronge of him.  Þe sone yede oute of the
Empi&rtail;, whenne that lucifere felle downe fro&mtail; hevene, &
he dide, whenne that he loste the lyf of euere lastyng blisse. the
kny&yogh;t, that norisshe&dtail; þe suster, was moyses, that
hiel&dtail; the olde lawe, bi teching of the whiche lawe he
norisshe&dtail; the peple þat we&rtail; that tyme.  An&dtail;
the ladye chyldi&dtail; in keping of the kny&yogh;te, scil. browte
forthe our kynde, in tyme of the olde lawe, a childe, scil.Crist, of
the virgine marie, of the see&dtail; of daui&dtail; of the modir syde, an&dtail; conseyvi&dtail; by the holy goste,
an&dtail; putte in the cradille, lappi&dtail; withe clothis. tablis
we&rtail; I-putte in the cradil, scil.tresours of wisdo&mtail; &
of connynge; an&dtail; he was I-putte in the tonne of the godhede. the
siluer & þe golde that we&rtail; in the cradi&llbar;, was
the powe&rtail; of the fadir, & wisdo&mtail; of the sone. he was
I-caste into the see, scil. in to this worlde, wher he levi&dtail;
mo&rtail; þanne þritty ye&rtail; in poverte, like to the
floo&dtail; of the see, for [he] was cast in tribulacio&ntail;. The
kny&yogh;t, that toke him to be norisshe&dtail;, is the holye goste,
the whiche descendi&dtail; in likenesse of a dove; an&dtail; Ioℏn
baptiste baptisi&dtail; hem withe his owne hondes, & he yaf him to
the kny&yogh;te, scil. to the godhede, to be norisshe&dtail;, whenne
[he] saide, Ecce!  Agnus dei!  lo!  þe
lambe of go&dtail;!  Qui post me venit, ante me factus est, cuius non
sum dignus calciamenta solvere , He that comithe aftir me,
was I-made afo&rtail; me, of whom I am not worthi to vnloos his shone.
 Aftirwar&dtail; the sone was I-made a kny&yogh;t, whenne he biganne to preche at
xxxti.  yee&rtail;. the sone of the kny&yogh;t accusi&dtail; him to
pilate, seinge, Hic seducit populum dei, [et
Filium Dei] se dicit , Þes desceyvithe the peple,
an&dtail; clepithe him the sone of go&dtail;.  An&dtail; þerefor
sone after he yede, an&dtail; fawte a-yenste the duke, scil. þe
devil, an&dtail; he ouercome him, an&dtail; wa&ntail; the Empi&rtail;
of hevene; an&dtail; so he weddi&dtail; his owne moder, scil. holye
chirche, the whiche is oure gostlye moder.  The Emperoure yede to him
what tyme that Cryste prechi&dtail; of the tree of hevene; an&dtail;
þerfore iewes an&dtail; paynymis wolde have slayne him.
An&dtail; þerefore holye chirche, in maner of sorowing, syngithe
in tyme of the passio&ntail;, Vexilla regis prodeunt , Þe baners
of the kynge shewithe oute.  An&dtail; she fonde the write&ntail;
tables, scil. his passio&ntail;, clerly y-now made by the iiij.
Euaungelistes; an&dtail; ther fo&rtail; she sorowithe, that the
Innocent shol&dtail; be slayne withe oute synne; as holye writte
seithe, Non Est inventus dolus in ore Eius, vt
ipse pro nobis mori deberet , Þere was I-founde no
falshede or gyle in his mothe, that he shulde deye for vs.  An&dtail;
þerefore Eche ma&ntail; owithe to sorowe for his synnys.  The
prest brake the body of Criste in twoo, scil.Crist, whenne he made [a
feste] to his disciplis.  Þe lady felle downe as dede, whenne
that Criste seyde, Tristis est anima mea vsque ad
mortem; Pater, si possibile est, transeat a me calix iste , My soule is hevy or sorye vnto the dethe; fadir, yf it be
possible, lat þis chalys go or passe fro me.  An&dtail; he saide
opinlye to his disciples, hoc Est corpus meum;
hoc facite in meam conmemoracionem , This is to seye, this is
my body; this doþe into my mynde.  An&dtail; so eche of vs
owithe to do, to ete an&dtail; to Receyve the body of Crist, in swiche
clene lyfe, that we mowe entre into þe tabernacles euerlastynge.
 Amen!

0.1:
Story. POlemius was a wise Emperoure Reignynge in the sitee of Rome,
þe wiche weddi&dtail; to wyve þe dowter of the kyng of
tunyke; & þe womma&ntail; was fai&rtail;, & gentill in
shape; an&dtail; she conseyui&dtail; & bare a faire sone.
An&dtail; whenne lordes harde he&rtail; of, þey come Echo&ntail;
aftir oþere to the Emperoure, an&dtail; aski&dtail; of him the
childe to norishe.  An&dtail; thenne the Emperoure seide to hem,
"to-morow sha&llbar; be [a] turnament, an&dtail; who so of yow
wynniþe þere þe victory, he shalle have my sone in
his gouernayle, vndir this conducio&ntail;, þat if he gouerne wele my sone, I shall highly
avaunce him, and if he do not, he shalbe shamely shent."  "sir,"
quo&dtail; thei, "this liketh wele to vs."  So the thridde day
a&llbar; were in the turneament, & pleid; & among a&llbar; othir
the&rtail; was a noble knygℏt, and a hardy, namyd Iosias, and he
gate the victory.  & þerfore he toke the chil&dtail;, &
bare him with him, & sent messangers home afore to his
caste&llbar;, for to make a&llbar; clene, both ynwar&dtail; and
outewar&dtail;, and also a bed in myddis of þe place, for the
chil&dtail;.  & he ordeine&dtail; also vij. craftis abowte it
y-peynt, in the entent þat the childe my&yogh;te, what tyme that
he sholde be waky&dtail;, beholde the craftis, an&dtail; the
Ria&llbar; payntynge yn hem, and haue delectacio&ntail; in hem.  Now
beside þe be&dtail; of the childe was a we&llbar;, and ouer the
we&llbar; was a wyndowe, by the whicℏ ligℏt come yn; and a
man was assigne&dtail; to kepe the key of the do&rtail; of that house.
 But it happy&dtail; in a tyme, þat þe lady lefte þe
do&rtail;, of negligence; an&dtail; whan þe dore was y-lefte
opy&ntail;, ther come a bee&rtail;, and entry&dtail; in to þe
we&llbar;, an&dtail; bathi&dtail; hym in it, þor&yogh; whom
a&llbar; the water was infecte witℏ veny&mtail;, and then he
&yogh;ede his way.  Anoon after come the lor&dtail; and the lady, and

Story. Ciclades regny&dtail; a wise Emperour in þe Cite of Rome,
and ouer a&llbar; thingis he was mercifu&llbar;.  And it happid, as he
went onys by a forest, ther mette with him a poo&rtail; man.  And whan
þe Emperour sawe him, he saide to hym with a grete pyte and mercy,
"Whens art þou, fren&dtail;?"  "Sir," quoþ þe
oþer, "I am your man, and borne in your londe, and fallyn in to
gret myschefe and nede."  "For sothe" quoþ þe Emperour,
"and if I knewe þat þou woldist be a trewe man, I sholde
avaunce þe to grette digniteys and richesses. And what is thi
name, tel me?"  "sir," quoþ he, "Lenticulus.  And I be-hote you
to be a trewe man; and if euer ye find ony othir with me, I wo&llbar;
bynd me to a&llbar; þe peyne þat ye wo&llbar; deme."  And
when þe Emperour hur&dtail; that, He avauncy&dtail; him, and
made him kny&yogh;t, and stiwar&dtail; of a&llbar; his empire.  And
when he was this i-hye&dtail;, he wex prout; and he defye&dtail; hem
þat were worthier þan he, and sette hem at nou&yogh;t, and
simple men & poo&rtail; men he spoile&dtail;.  And yn a tyme, as
he roode yn to þe forest, he commaundi&dtail; to þe
foster, þat he shulde make an hunderitℏ depe diches in
þe forest, and cover them with wele smellin>ee; herbis,
þat þe bestis my&yogh;t fa&llbar; in hem, If it
happi&dtail; hem to renne out of þe forest.  And þe foster
dude as he commaundi&dtail;.  It happi&dtail; afterwar&dtail;,
þat þis stiwar&dtail; roo&dtail; to þe fores&ttee;,
to see þe diches; and as he roo&dtail;, he thowte, "I am riche,
and I-maade a gret lord, and a&llbar; þe Empire is at
my ledyn>ee;."  And with þat prowde þo&yogh;te he smot
þe hors with þe sporis, and sodenlicℏ fel into on of
þe deppist dichis, þat he ordeny&dtail; to be made; and he
my&yogh;te by no way passe out, For he was corpulent and hevy.  and
soone after þis, þer stert in to þe same dicℏ
an hungery lyo&ntail;; and when þe stiwar&dtail; sawe þat,
he was hyely adra&dtail;.  And then soone after, þer fi&llbar;
in an Ape; and after þe Ape, a serpent.  And whenne þe
stiwar&dtail; was þis wallid abowte with theise iij. bestis, he
began to swete for drede.  In þis same tyme þer was in the
cite a poo&rtail; man, namy&dtail; Gwido, and he hadde an asse, with
þe whicℏ asse he wolde go euery day to þe forest, for
to gader sma&llbar; wode; and laade his asse, and lede it to þe
market, and selle it, and so susteyne him and his wife, for mo&rtail;
hadde he not to lyve with.  So this poore man come in a certeyne day
to þe forest, fo&rtail; to gadir stikkys, as he was wony&dtail;.
 And when he come nye þe pitte, þer as þe
stiwar&dtail; was in, The stiwar&dtail; cryde, and saide, "Sir, sir,
come heder, and here me, and þou shalt like it for euer!"
An&dtail; thenne gwido herin>ee;
þe voys of a ma&ntail;, he hadde grette wondir, and come
ne&rtail;, and sai&dtail;, "lo! I am heere; what art þou that
callist me?"  Thenne saide he, "I am," quoþ he, "the
stiwar&dtail; of þe Empire, and þor&yogh; chaunce I am
fa&llbar; he&rtail; into þis dicℏe; and heere is beside me a
lio&ntail;, and an ape, and a serpent, and I ne wote of whom I
sha&llbar; be furst devowry&dtail;.  And þerfor, [for] the love
of go&dtail;, gete a lon>ee; corde, by þe whicℏ I may be
drawy&ntail; out; and y vndirtake, þat I sha&llbar; avaunce
þe and a&llbar; þyne þerfore for euer.  And but I
soone be holpy&ntail;, I sha&llbar; be devowri&dtail; by theise
bestis."  Thenne saide gwido, "Þat were harde to me for to do,
for I haue not to live by, but þat I gadre wode here in þe
forest, þat I se&llbar;; and if I go abowte þis erunde, I
most thenne leve myne owne ocupacio&ntail;; an&dtail; þerfore,
if I haue not of you for my labour, it wo&llbar; be to me and to my
wife gret lost and harme."  Then answeri&dtail; þe
stiwar&dtail;, and saide, "By þe helthe of the Emperour, my
lor&dtail;, and by þe oþe that I haue maade to him, I
sha&llbar; to-morowe avaunce þe and a&llbar; thyne to grete
richesses, If þou wolt do so." quoth gwydo, "I shal do thi
biddin>ee;."  He went home, and fette a lon>ee; rope; and come to
þe pitte, and saide, "Sir stiwarde, howe ! looke vp! for I caste downe a lon>ee;
roope here to the; and þerfore bynde it abowte þi
medi&llbar;, and I shalle drawe þe vp."  And þenne
þe stiwar&dtail; was glad, an&dtail; saide, "Late downe the
corde;" and so he dude. And when þe lyo&ntail; sawe þe
corde maade redy to take him oute, he stirte yn to it.  And whenne
gwido felte a grette wey&yogh;t, he trowi&dtail; þat it hadde
y-be þe stiwar&dtail;; an&dtail; vndir þat trust he drowe
vp þe lio&ntail;; and when þe lio&ntail; was vp, he
maa&dtail; a maner of ioiyn>ee; to him, and þan he ran to
þe wode.  And thenne Gwido sent dow&ntail; þe Roop
a&yogh;en.  And thenne þe Ape stirte in to þe Roope, or
corde, and so gwido drowe vp þe Ape in stede of þe
stiwar&dtail;; and then þe Ape ran a&yogh;en to þe wode.
Thenne þe thirde tyme gwido late þe Roope go downe, and
þe serpent stirte in to it, and was drawy&ntail; vp as were
þe oþer; and maade a maner of thonkin>ee; to þe
man, and &yogh;ede his way to þe wode.  And thenne spake

faire deliuery&dtail; me of theise thre bestis, Nowe late þe
corde fa&llbar;, and I sha&llbar; come vp." the man late þe
corde fa&llbar;, and þe stiwar&dtail; gurde him þer in,
and was drawy&ntail; vp.  Whenne he was vp, he saide to gwido, "come
to-morowe at noon to þe palys, and I sha&llbar; avaunce þe
for euer."  Thenne gwido was gla&dtail;, and went home withoute ony
stickys or wode.  And whenne his wife sawe þat, She askid of
him, whi þat he hadde not gaderi&dtail; stickis, wherby
þat þei my&yogh;te have hire sustynaunce that day.  And
thenne he tolde hire a&llbar; þe processe, as ys saide afore,
How þe stiwar&dtail; fe&llbar; in to þe diche, and howe he
deliuere&dtail; him, and howe he sha&llbar; receyve þerfore his
meede on þe morow.  And when she hadde hurde þes wordis,
she was rigℏt gla&dtail;, and saide, "Late vs nowe be mery, and
in þe morowe aryse, and go fecℏ our meede."  On þe morowe
gwido rose vp, and went to þe palys, an[d] knocki&dtail; at
þe &yogh;ate; and þe porter come, and aski&dtail; þe
cause of his knockyn>ee;.  And thenne saide Gwido, "sir, I pray you,
for goddis love, go to þe stiwar&dtail;, an&dtail; telle him that here
stonditℏ at þe &yogh;ate a poore man, that spake with him
&yogh;isterday in þe forest."  And þe porter hi&yogh;te
for to do it; and &yogh;ede to the stiwar&dtail;, and tolde him howe
þat þer was a poo&rtail; man at þe &yogh;ate, to
abide hym, þat spake with him in the forest.  And when he hadde
saide þis message, þe stiwar&dtail; baa&dtail; him go
a&yogh;en, and telle him, þat he lyetℏ in his he&dtail;,
For þer spake noo&ntail; with him þere; and he sent him
worde, þat he sholde go, þat he neuer sawe hym. An&dtail;
thenne þe porter come to þe &yogh;ate, and tolde to Gwido
the answere of the stiwar&dtail;, an&dtail; howe he baa&dtail;
þat he sholde hye him fro þe &yogh;ate, vp peyne of worse;
For he saide, þat he lye&dtail; in his sawis. And whenne Gwido
hurde þis, he wax ri&yogh;t hevy, and went home, and tolde his
wife, Howe þat þe stiwarde saide.  And thenne his wife, as
a goode woman, comforti&dtail; him, and saide to him, þat he
sholde go an oþer tyme, and preve þe stiwar&dtail;.  When
morowe come, he rose, and went a&yogh;en to þe palys,
prayn>ee; þe porter þat he shulde go a&yogh;en, and say
his erende.  The porter saide, "I wo&llbar; gladly, but I drede
þat it wo&llbar; not profite þe."  He went to þe
stiwar&dtail;, and shewid him þat þat
þat þe poore man was comy&ntail; a&yogh;en.  And
whenne the stiwar&dtail; hurde þat, he went to þe
&yogh;ate in a grete anger; and þer Lenticulus þe stiwarde
bette Gwido þe poore man so soore, þat he lefte him halfe
de&dtail;.  Whenne his wife hurde þis, she come with hire asse,

hon&dtail;; and carey&dtail; hom hire husbon&dtail;, and spen&dtail;
on him a&llbar; þat she my&yogh;te gete, ti&llbar; he hadde his
heltℏ.  And whenne he was hole, he went to þe wode as he
was wony&dtail; to do, for to gadery wode.  And in a certayne tyme, as
þis gwido was in þe wode, he sawe a lyo&ntail; afer, and
x. assis afore him, and a&llbar; þe assis were chargy&dtail;
with diuerse marchandise; and þe lio&ntail; brou&yogh;te
a&llbar; to Gwido.  Gwido dra&dtail;; but when he hadde biholden wel
þe lio&ntail;, he knewe wel in hym selfe þat it was
þe same lio&ntail; þat he savid fro þe dicℏ;
and þe lio&ntail; wold neuer leeve him, til tyme þat
a&llbar; þe assis weere comy&ntail; in to his house; and thenne

tokenyn>ee;. Thenne gwido openy&dtail; þe Fardelys, and he

solde þe marchauntyse, and bou&yogh;t him tenementys and othir

&yogh;it he vsi&dtail; þe wode as he dude afo&rtail;, and
gaderi&dtail; wode.  Hit happi&dtail; in a certayne day, as he went to þe wode, þat he sawe
þe Ape, þe whicℏ he drowe out of þe pitte,
sittin>ee; in þe top of a tre, and with hire tetℏ and

þat who so euer have it, he sha&llbar; haue euermore
ioy witℏ oute hevinesse; The secunde is, that he sha&llbar; haue

Receyve þerfor as muche as it is wortℏ; For if he do

And by vertu of þe sto&ntail; he gate many and gret habundances

sholde come to him.  And when he was y-come, þe Emperour saide

&yogh;isterday ye gafe me a M.  marc for the sto&ntail;, and þis

feitℏ þat þou art holdy&ntail; y&ntail; to me, telle

saide gwido, "sir, by þe feitℏ þat I am boundy&ntail;
ynne to you, I sha&llbar; te&llbar; you þe sotℏ.  Your

þere, and fro þe venymous
bestis þat he was amon>ee;; an&dtail; he saide þat he

And howe þat þe kynge of naplis strongly þerfore

 The kin>ee; was herewith hiely glad, for his do&yogh;ter was
