more pale in the one partie than in the other.  ¶ Than went out a
lite&llbar; Bridde, coloure&dtail; witℏ double coloures, and
beside the bridde ij.  Bestes, the whicℏ norisshe&dtail; togedre
the bridde witℏ her hete.  after that come dyuerse other bestes,
and bowe&dtail; her hedes to the bridde.  than dyuerse briddes come
to-gedre, and songe so swetely, that the Emperour was wake&dtail; of
his slepe.  ¶ Than the Emperour calle&dtail; to hym dyvynours,
and the wisest men of a&llbar; his Empire, and sai&dtail; to hem, "I
sawe a dreme; seitℏ amonge you the interpretacio&ntail;
thereo&ftee;, and ye sha&llbar; haue grete mede of me, or els ye
shu&llbar; be dede."  ¶ Thei sei&dtail;, "si&rtail;, telle vs the
dreme."  The Emperou&rtail; tol&dtail; hem the dreme as is before sai&dtail;.  ¶ And than
thei ano&ntail; witℏ a gla&dtail; chere sai&dtail;, "Sir, the dreme is goo&dtail;.  ¶ The firmament, that is and was in
more clernesse, is the Empire, that from hens forwar&dtail; sha&llbar;
be put in more rest.  ¶ The mone, that was more pale, is the
Empresse, that for concepcio&ntail; is more discoloure&dtail;.  The
lite&llbar; bridde, that went out, betokenetℏ a right faire sone,
that she sha&llbar; bryng forthe, whan tyme come.  The two bestes, by
the whiche the bridde was norisshe&dtail;, are alle wise men and
riche, that shu&llbar; obeye to the chil&dtail; in alle thyng.  the
bestes, that bowe&dtail; her hedes to hym, are moche other folke, the
whiche yit di&dtail; no homage to your sone; and in a&llbar; thynge
they sha&llbar; be vndir fote.  ¶ The briddes, that songe&ntail; so meryly, is a&llbar; the Empire of
Rome, that sha&llbar; Ioye the birthe of the chil&dtail;."  ¶ The
Emperour was gretly glade&dtail; of her interpretacio&ntail;.  After
this the Empresse brought forthe a chil&dtail;.  ¶ whan the kyng
of pule her&dtail; this, he thought witℏ in hym sel&ftee;, "I
have longe hol&dtail; werre ayenst the Emperour; It may not be, but
whan the sone sha&llbar; come to lawfu&llbar; age, it sha&llbar; be
tolde hym that I have alway foughte&ntail; ayenst his fadir.  now he
is a chil&dtail;, ¶ Therfore it is now better to me to be in
pease, that whan he cometℏ to age, he have no thynge ayenst me."
¶ The kyng ano&ntail; wrote to the Emperour for pease.  The Emperour seyng that he di&dtail; this because of drede
more than for love, ¶ he wrote agay&ntail; to hym, and
sai&dtail;, If that he wol&dtail; make hym suerte of pease, and bynde
hym sel&ftee; to hym in servage, and do to hym homage, and yel&dtail;
the rentes, he shul&dtail; take hym to pease.  ¶ The kyng
calle&dtail; to hym his counsaile, and tol&dtail; hem what the
Emperour sai&dtail;.  Than the wise men sai&dtail;, "It is goo&dtail;
to fulfi&llbar; the Emperours wille in a&llbar; thyng.  First he
asketℏ of you suerte; To that we say, ye haue a faire doughtir,
and the Emperou&rtail; hatℏ a sone; lette matrymonye be made
betwixe hem, and so pease to be made withe oute&ntail; ende.  ¶
Also the Emperour asketℏ homage and rentes; it is goo&dtail; to
fulfi&llbar; hem."  ¶ Than the kyng sent messangers to the
Emperour, that he wol&dtail; fulfi&llbar; his wille in a&llbar;
thynge, and that he wol&dtail; yeve his doughtir to his sone, to be
his wy&ftee;.  ¶ The Emperour sent agay&ntail;, and sei&dtail;,
"yf thi doughtir be a maide&ntail; from her birthe to this day, he
wol&dtail; consent that his sone shul&dtail; haue her."  ¶ The
doughtir was a maide&ntail;.  the kyng her fadir ano&ntail; made redy
a shippe, and put her the&rtail; in, witℏ knyghtes and ladies,
for to lede her to the Emperour.  ¶ Whan thei were in the shippe sailyng, there arose on hem a grete tempest, that a&llbar; were drowne&dtail;, oute take the
maide&ntail;, for she put a grete hope in go&dtail;.  and agenst
Eve&ntail; the tempest sease&dtail;.  ano&ntail; ¶ A grete whale
folowe&dtail; the shippe, for to devowre the maide&ntail;; and she was
sore aferde; and whan it was nyght she smote fire of the stone, and
made a grete fire; and as longe as the nyght laste&dtail;, the whale
durst not come nere the shippe.  ¶ But aboute the tyme of the
nyght whan the cokke crewe, the maide&ntail; wexe slepie, and sore
vexe&dtail;, and fille on slepe; and while she slept the fire went
out, and the maide&ntail; was swalowe&dtail; witℏ in the whale.
and the maide&ntail;, while she satte in the whales bely, she made a fire witℏ in, and
witℏ her kny&ftee; she wounde&dtail; the whale, of the whiche he
toke the dethe; and ano&ntail; he swamme to lon&dtail;.  ¶ It
befe&llbar; so that tyme, there was an Erle, whos name was Perius,
dwellyng by the see; and as he went to the see side warde, he sawe a
grete whale comyng to lon&dtail;.  than he ba&dtail; a&llbar; his
strengest men go smyte the whale on every side.  ¶ Whan the
maide&ntail; witℏ in her&dtail; the strokes, she crie&dtail;
witℏ an higℏ voice, ¶ "O! ye genti&lbar; men, have mercy on me, for I am a kynges
doughtir, and a maide&ntail; sethe my birtℏ!"  ¶ The Erle,
whan he her&dtail; this, sore mervaile&dtail;, and opene&dtail; the
whale, and drew the maide&ntail; out.  than the maide&ntail;
tol&dtail; hem how it was witℏ her.  ¶ whan the Erle
her&dtail; this, he was gla&dtail;, and hel&dtail; the maide&ntail;
witℏ hym a certay&ntail; tyme, tille she was comforte&dtail;.
than he sent her to the Emperour.  ¶ whan he ha&dtail; her&dtail;
how she ascape&dtail; the see, he ha&dtail; of her grete pite, and
sai&dtail;, ¶ "O! goo&dtail; maide&ntail;, thou hast
suffre&dtail; many aduersitees for love of my sone; neverthelesse I
sha&llbar; prove, whether thou be worthi to be my sonnes wi&ftee; or
not."  ¶ Than the Emperour di&dtail; make iij. vessels.  ¶
The first vesse&llbar; was of pure gol&dtail; and precious stones, and
witℏ in it was fu&llbar; of de&dtail; mennes bones; and witℏ
oute was this scripture, he that sha&llbar; chese me, In me sha&llbar;
fynde that he hatℏ deserve&dtail;.  ¶ The secon&dtail;
vesse&llbar; was of pure siluer and of precious stones, and fu&llbar;
of erthe; and witℏ out this scripture, he that sha&llbar; chese
me, In me sha&llbar; fynde that his nature desiretℏ.  ¶ The thirde vesse&llbar; was of lede, and
fu&llbar; of nobils and precious stones witℏ in; and witℏ
out was this scripture, he that sha&llbar; chese me, in me sha&llbar;
fynde that go&dtail; hatℏ dispose&dtail; for hym.  ¶ Thise
iij. vessels the Emperour shewe&dtail; to the maide&ntail;, and
sai&dtail;, "thise are iij. noble vessels; yf thou chese one of thise,
in the whicℏ is profite and availe, thou shalt have my sone; and
yf thou chese that is not profitable to hym, ne to none other, thou
shalt not have my sone."  ¶ The maide&ntail;, whan she sawe the
vessels, she lift vp her hondes to go&dtail;, and sai&dtail;, ¶
"Thou, lor&dtail;, that alle thynge knowest, graunte me grace so to
chese, that of the Emperours sone I may have Ioye!"  ¶ Than she
behel&dtail; the first vesse&llbar;, and redde the
superscripcio&ntail;, and sai&dtail;, "what have I deserve&dtail; to
have so precious a vesse&llbar;? what is witℏ in I wote never vtterly; Neverthelesse it shynetℏ
witℏ out of fyne gol&dtail;."  Than she sai&dtail;, "this
vesse&llbar; in no wise wille I chese."  ¶ Than she loke&dtail;
on the secon&dtail; vesse&llbar;, and redde the scripture that was
the&rtail; on, he that chesetℏ me, sha&llbar; fynde that his
nature desiretℏ.  ¶ She thought in her sel&ftee;, "If I
chese this, I wote not what is witℏ in But that nature desiretℏ.  Nature desiretℏ alway delectacio&ntail; of
flessℏ, therfore this vesse&llbar; in no wise I wille chese."
¶ Afterwar&dtail; she loke&dtail; on the thirde vesse&llbar;,
that was of lede, and that was fu&llbar; of nobles and precious
stones; and she redde the scripture, that was this, he that
chesetℏ me, in me sha&llbar; fynde that go&dtail; hathe
dispose&dtail;.  ¶ She thought witℏ in her sel&ftee;, "this
vesse&llbar; is not meke&llbar; precious, and neverthelesse the
scripture seitℏ, he that chesetℏ me, in me sha&llbar; fynde
that god hatℏ dispose&dtail;; And it is in certay&ntail; god
ordeyne&dtail; never eve&llbar; therfore this vesse&llbar; I wolle
chese."  ¶ The Emperour, whan he her&dtail; this, he sai&dtail;,
"O! goode maide&ntail;, open the vesse&llbar;, that we mow se yf thou
have wele chose&ntail;." whan it was ope&ntail;, it was fu&llbar; of
gol&dtail; and precious stones.  ¶ Than he sai&dtail;, "O!
goo&dtail; maide&ntail;, thou hast wisely chose&ntail;, therfore thou
shalt have my sone."  and so he ordeyne&dtail; the day of the weddyng,
in the whiche was grete Ioye.  ¶ And after the dissease of the
Fadir, the sone reigne&dtail; as Emperour, and endi&dtail; his
ly&ftee; in pease. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperou&rtail; is the fadir of
heve&ntail;, that longe before the sone toke flesshe, for the whiche
many perisshe&dtail; , in as meke&llbar; as
thei went to helle before the Incarnacio&ntail; of Ihesu crist.
¶ The Empresse, that conseivi&dtail; a sone, is blisse&dtail; mary.  The firmament, that was put in more clerenesse, Illumynetℏ
the worl&dtail; by concepcio&ntail; of goddes sone.  The pale mone is
the face of the blisse&dtail; virgyne mary, that was shadowe&dtail;
witℏ the holy gost.  ¶ The lite&llbar; bridde, that went out
of the one partie, forsothe is crist.  The ij. bestes were the Oxe and
the Asse.  The bestes, that come from ferre countre, are the herdemen,
to the whiche the Aunge&llbar; sei&dtail;, ¶ "Behol&dtail;, I
shew to you grete Ioye, for this day is bor&ntail; the savyour of the
worl&dtail;."  ¶ The briddes, that songe so swetly, are the
aungels of go&dtail;, that songe&ntail;, Ioye be to go&dtail; above
and pease to men, of goo&dtail; wille in the erthe.  ¶ The kyng
of pule is a&llbar; mankyn&dtail;, that whan he was in the power of
the fen&dtail;, man was contrarye to go&dtail;.  ¶ But whan our
lor&dtail; was bor&ntail;, ano&ntail; man enclyne&dtail; to go&dtail;,
and sente for to have pease, whan eche of vs asketℏ baptyme.  ¶ Also the kyng ya&ftee; his
doughtir to the sone of the Emperou&rtail; in Matrymonye.  So crist is
redy to take thi soule to his spouse, but before or thou come to the
paleys of heve&ntail;, thou behovest to passe the see of this worl&dtail;, in a bote of holy
ly&ftee;.  but whan thou art in thi bote, there arisetℏ a grete
tempest, that is, tribulacio&ntail; of the worl&dtail;,
temptacio&ntail; of the flessℏ, and suggestio&ntail; of the
fende, that drownetℏ ofte sithes the vertues *and the grace that
thou resceivest in thi baptyme; for that thou shalt in no maner falle
out of the shippe of charite.  ¶ Also the grete whale, that
folowe&dtail; the maide&ntail;, is By an
oversight of the scribe, nearly four lines are repeated here, but with
some variations difficult to account for if the MS was merely a
transcript. Thus for 'shippe' he writes 'bote', and for 'maner' he has
'wise.' The repetition is given in the text, the words firstly written
are as follows: "that thou resceivest in the baptyme not for that in
no wise falle not out of the bote of charitee ¶ The grete whale
that folowede the maidene is" the deve&llbar;, that nyght and
day is besy to drowne the soule in synne. do thou therfore as the
maide&ntail; di&dtail;; Smyte fire of charite of the stone, that is,
of crist, and the deve&llbar; sha&llbar; not noye the.  ¶ But
many begynne wele like the maide&ntail;, but afterwar&dtail; thei were
wery of goo&dtail; werkes, and slepe&ntail; in synnes; and ano&ntail;
the deve&llbar; swolowetℏ the synner.  ¶ If thou fele thi
sel&ftee; in suche li&ftee;, that is, in the power of the fende, do as
the maide&ntail; di&dtail;; witℏ the kny&ftee; of bitter penaunce
smyte the deve&llbar;, an&dtail; light vp fire of charitee, and he sha&llbar; cast the to lon&dtail; of goo&dtail;
ly&ftee;.  ¶ The Erle, that come witℏ his servauntes to sle
the whale, Is a discrete confessour, dwellyng by the see, that is, the
worl&dtail;, the whiche is redy witℏ wordes of holy writte for to
slee the deve&llbar;, that is, for to put away his power, and to
delyver hym fro the.  ¶ Do thou therfore as the maide&ntail;
di&dtail;, Cryng witℏ an higℏ voise, beyng a-know of thi
synnes to thi confessour; and so maist thou be norisshe&dtail; in
goo&dtail; werkes from the power of the deve&llbar;, and be sent to
the kyngdo&mtail; of heve&ntail;.  ¶ The Emperour shewe&dtail;
the maide&ntail; iij.  vessels, that is, go&dtail; puttetℏ before
man lyf and dethe, goode and Eve&llbar;; whiche he chesetℏ, that
he sha&llbar; have.  ¶ wherfore Salamo&ntail; seitℏ, before man is lyf and dethe; that liketℏ hym
sha&llbar; be geve&ntail; hym; neverthelesse we wote not whether we be worthi
ly&ftee; or dethe.  ¶ By the first vesse&llbar; of gol&dtail;,
fu&llbar; of dede mennes bones, we sha&llbar; vndirston&dtail; the
worl&dtail; or worldly men, as are thise riche men that shyne&ntail;
witℏ out as gol&dtail;, but witℏ in thei are fulle of dede
mennes bones, that is, a&llbar; the werkes that thei have done in this worl&dtail; thei are dede as vnto
go&dtail;, by her dedely synnes.  If thou may chese suche ly&ftee;,
than shalt thou fynde as thou hast deserve&dtail;, and that is helle.
suche are like gay sepulcres, that witℏ oute are araie&dtail;
right faire, and that somtyme witℏ clothes of silke and of
gol&dtail; are covere&dtail; and hille&dtail;, but witℏ in thei
are but drye bones.  ¶ By the secon&dtail; vesse&llbar; of siluer
we shu&llbar; vndirstonde domysmen, wisemen, and myghty men of the
worl&dtail;, that shyne&ntail; in her speche as it were siluer, but
witℏ in thei are wormes and erthe.  ¶ By the third
vesse&llbar; of lede we shulle vndirston&dtail; a symple ly&ftee;,
that are tho that are goddes chose&ntail; childre&ntail;; for thei
chose&ntail; a symple vesture, and a meke, and are subiecte to
obedience for go&dtail;. ¶ Sucℏ bere&ntail; precious stones, that be meritorie
werkes, pleasyng to go&dtail;, for the whiche at the day of dome thei
shu&llbar; be wedde&dtail; to go&dtail;, and sha&llbar; have the
heritage of the kyngdome of heve&ntail;.  to the whiche go&dtail;
brynge vs!  Amen.

Antonius regnyd a wise Emperour in þe cite of Rome; and as
he went on a tyme by þe see-syde, he sawe howe þat pirati,
scil. thevis of þe see, hadde taken the sone of a gret
my&yogh;ty man, And brou&yogh;t him in to þe priso&ntail;
o&ftee; þe Emperour, faste y-bounde. This yon>ee; man wrote to
his fadir, prayin>ee; him to bey him out; But þe fadir sent
word ayen, and saide, That he wold not bye him, ne pay no goode for
him.  And when þe yon>ee; man hurde þe wordis, he wepte
soo&rtail;, þat noon migℏt confort him.  And þe
Emperour hadde a dowter, þat vsi&dtail; euery day to visite
þis priso&ntail;, And to comforte þe yon>ee; man in
a&llbar; þat she my&yogh;te; And then þe yong man wolde
saie to hire þus, "what ioy or comforte shulde I make, þat
sitte I-bounde in priso&ntail; fro sigℏt of a&llbar; men, And
also my fadir is so vnkynde, þat he wo&llbar; not pay my
raunso&mtail; for me?"  This mayde hadde of him gret pyte, in so
mocℏ þat she seyde, "I haue gret sorowe for þe in
myne herte; and þerfore, if þou wolt graunt me oo
thin>ee; þat I sha&llbar; aske of þe, I sha&llbar; deliuer þe fro a&llbar; þis Angre,
scil. þat þou wedde me, if I deliuer þe."
"&YOGH;is," quoþ he, "and þerto I &yogh;ive þe my
truthe."  Thenne she deliueryd him out of priso&ntail;, And stale awey
with him to his fadir.  And whe&ntail; þe fadir sawe his sone,
and þe damese&llbar; with him, he askid of him wherto she was with him.  "Sir," quoþ he, "for she
deliueryd me out of priso&ntail;, And þerfore she sha&llbar; be
my wy&ftee;."  Þenne saide þe fadir, "I wolle not assent
þerto, by no maner, þat she be þi wife, And
þat for two cawsis; The furste cause is þis, for she knewe
wele þat hi&rtail; fadir my&yogh;te haue had for þi
ranso&ntail; grete goodis, and sithe she deliuered þe so frely,
she du&dtail; grete preiudice and harme to hire fadir; And sithe she
is vnkynde and fals to him, no doute of she may not be iuste to
þe.  That othir cause is this, þat whenne she deliuered
þe, it was not for cause of pyte, it was for cause of lust; For
whenne she deliuered þe, she took þi trowthe þat she
shulde be þi wife; And þerfore, sithe she dude it for
luste of flesℏ, þou shalt neuer haue hire to wife."  Thenne
spake þe dameselle to þe furst reso&ntail; and cas, and
saide, "Sir, þer þou seiyst I was vnkynde to my fadir,
þat is not sotℏ; for my fadir is a riche lord, and
neditℏ not of his goode, For he was poore and simpi&llbar;, And
hadde nothin>ee;, And þerfore, for þe grete pyte that I
hadde of him, and of his gret nede, I tooke of me boldly to socour
him.  But þou þat bigat him, þou forsoke him, and
denyed him; And so I dude no&ntail; harme to my Fadir; for my fadir
was riche y-nowe, And of this sone he my&yogh;te haue hadde no
mo&rtail; but haue pynyd him in priso&ntail;, For þou saidist,
þat þou woldist not pay for him; And so I was mo&rtail;
kynde to þi sone þan þi selfe, And þerfore he
is mo&rtail; holde&ntail; to me than to þe. To þat
oþer reso&ntail;, wher as þou saiest þat I dude it
more by cause of luste, I say that it is not sotℏly saide of
þe, For luste risitℏ of Fairnesse of a ma&ntail;, or ellis
for his strengℏt; But þi sone was not stren>ee;, for
þe disese þat he had in prisone toke if from him, Ne he was not faire, for he was
a&llbar; disfiguri&dtail; in þe priso&ntail;; and þerfore
I say, only pyte mevid me to do as I dude, & not luste." Thenne
spake þe sone to þe fadir, and saide, "Fadir, whenne
þat I was in peri&llbar; of perisshin>ee;, I wrote to
þe, for to be deliuered of þe, And þou woldist not
do it; But þis dameselle deliuered me fro dethe, & savid me,
and þerfore douteles she sha&llbar; be my wife."  Anoon he
weddid þe dameselle, and in faire pes endid, &c.

66.1:
MORALITE. Deere frendis, þis Emperour is the Fadir of hevene, þe
whicℏ regnyd alway in hevene.  The childe, þat was y-take,
is a&llbar; mankynde, take by develis for þe synne of þe
furst fadir Adam; the whicℏ mankynde was y-put in þe
priso&ntail; of helle, and holdy&ntail; in grete sorowe.  The fadir
wolde not bye him, scil. þe wordle, þe whicℏ is his
fadir, in þe same maner, for by him he is sustenyd. The
dou&yogh;ter, þat is so faire, is þe godhede, when he come
dow&ntail; fro heuene to erthe, and ioyne&dtail; him to manhede, when
he too&ktee; flessℏ and bloode in þe virgine marie; and so
he made gostely matrimonye witℏ ma&ntail;, And he deliueryd vs
vndir þis condicio&ntail;, þat our soule shulde be his
spouse; as witnessitℏ þe wordis of Osea, Desponsabo eam mihi , I sha&llbar; wedde hire to
me.  And so he lefte þe courte of heuene, and of angelis, and
dwelte with vs here in þis wordle.  but þe fadir, scil.
þe wordle, grucchitℏ ayenst vs, And wol&dtail; not
þat þe soule we&rtail; þe spouse to crist, but
þat we serue a&llbar; to it.  And if þat we plese the
wordle, Certenly we fa&llbar; into þe gilder of þe devel,
For a&llbar; þe wordle is sette in
wickidnesse; And þerfore lat vs fle þe wordle, and take
refute in criste, and by good Argument we shu&llbar; haue þe
kyngdo&mtail; of heuene. Ad quod perducat &c.

0.1:
Story. Donatus regnyd Emperour in þe cite of Rome; And he dude to
be sette in þe temple iij. ymagis, And on of hem hadde a finger
rechin>ee; to þe peple, And in his fynger a ryn>ee; of
golde; And an oþer ymage a berd of golde; And þe thirde
hadde a mantelle of purpure.  whenne þes ymages were y-maade,
the Emperour commaundid, vp peyne of detℏ, þat noon shold
spoile hem, ne do hem harme ne wron>ee;, scil. of þe
ryn>ee;, of the berd, or of þe mantelle. Hit happid in a

"we be&ntail; redy," quoþ thei, "to do this deede redely." The

þe meene ty&mtail; þe stiwar&dtail; hadde gret desire to

anoo&ntail; þei sette hondis in him.  And he lokid, and ravid, and cryde out , "what wo&llbar; ye do? Nolite!  Nolite! do not so! do not so! for my
lord baad it shulde be Fulgencius.  &YOGH;e wo&llbar; be lorne for me;

ovy&ntail;; And say þou, sin>ee; þou, þou shalt

at þe Reuerence of god, tellitℏ me what þe
comaundement was?"  "Forsothe," quoþ thei, "we were chargid
þat we shulde take him þat com furst to vs in þe

savid him.  he tooke his leeve of þe werkeme&ntail;, and went

þat þus hatℏ savid me fro detℏ."  Thenne saide

"Sir," quoþ þe childe, "I trowe þat &yogh;e fond
neuer falshede in me &yogh;it, And þerfore I haue gret merveile
in my spiritis, whi þat ye ordeynyd sucℏ a detℏ for
me, And I am your owne brothir sone."  "Sone," quoþ þe
Emperour, "it is no merveil, and þat þou shalt wele see

the Empire, and hast tolde þat I was infecte with lepre, And
þerof com fro me so abhominabil stencℏ, þat no man
my&yogh;te feele it; and in tokne þerof thow turnist away fro me
thyne he&dtail;, when þou brou&yogh;tist me the cuppe.  And for
I sawe þis with myne ye&ntail;, therfor I ordeyny&dtail;
sucℏ a detℏ, And &yogh;it wol ordeyne for the, but þou
conne þe better excuse the."  Then saide Fulgencius, "sir, if it
lyke you, huritℏ what I sha&llbar; say, And ye shu&llbar;
he&rtail; a foule conspiracio&ntail; and trayne, þat ye neuer
hurde suche on bifo&rtail;.  The stiward, þat is nowe ded, com
to me, and saide, þat ye saide to him, þat my brethe
stanke so foule, þat it was dispite to you my presence; And
þerfore he conseilid me, þat I shulde, when I brou&yogh;t

þat it is no lesin>ee; þat I say vnto you."  The
Emperour gafe goode credence to his wordis, and saide, "A!  Dee&rtail;
frend, the stiward is fally&ntail; in his owne diche, by þe
Rigℏt wisdo&mtail; of god. This false ordinaunce hadde he maade,
for envy that he hadde to þe. Sone, be a goode ma&ntail;, for
þou art moche bondy&ntail; to god, þat thus hatℏ
kepte the fro dethe."

1.1:
Deere frendis, þis Emperour may be callid a prelat of hooly.

scil. tethinges of a&llbar; trewe gety&ntail; goodes þat he

shulde live. Fulgencius. scil. þe goode cristy&ntail; ma&ntail;,
þat is true mynyst&rtail; to god, And the prelat, is moche lovid
of god, and wele rewardid, But the stiward is Envious at it, scil.
euery wickid ma&ntail;, þat be&ntail; membris of the
devi&llbar;, as is cay&mtail;.  sucℏ men ofte tyme turnitℏ
þe hertis of trewe cristy&ntail; me&ntail;, seyin>ee; that
þe prelat is smety&ntail; with
lipre, scil. neithir plesinge to god ne to man; And that is

That neuer sha&llbar; myssé!  Ame&ntail;.

0.1:
Story. Annuus reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, the whiche amonge
a&llbar; the goodes of the worl&dtail; he love&dtail; meke&llbar; to
playe witℏ houndes and hawkes.  ¶ It fille ones, that he
went to a forest, forto hunte the hert; and sone he sawe an herte come
rynnyng before hym, and houndes rynnyng aftir hym, in so meke&llbar;
that he was left behynde, that he saw neither the herte ne the
houndes; and so he beleft alone, for a&llbar; his servauntes
folowe&dtail; the herte.  and he was meke&llbar; desolate and hevy,
for he sawe no man; And ano&ntail; smote the horse witℏ the
sporres, agay&ntail; none, and he rode thurgℏ a&llbar; the
forest, and founde no man.  ¶ But agay&ntail; Eve&ntail; come
rynnyng a lyo&ntail;, haltyng on his right foote, and come to hym.
the Emperour was afer&dtail;, and wol&dtail; have fledde, but the
lyo&ntail; toke hym by the foote, and shewe&dtail; to hym his hurt on
his foote.  whan the Emperour vndirstode that, he went downe of his horse, and drew out the sharpe
thor&ntail; out of the lyons foote; and after that he gadre&dtail;
herbes, witℏ the whiche he hele&dtail; his foote.  ¶ Whan
the lio&ntail; was hole, he la&dtail; hym to his cave, and there he
was a&llbar; nyght.  and on the morow he bowe&dtail; his hede to the
lyo&ntail;, and toke his horse, and rode a&llbar; that day, and coude
fynde in no wise passyng out of the forest.  ¶ he sawe that, and
went agay&ntail; to the lions denne.  the lyo&ntail; was out, but
agay&ntail; Eve&ntail; he come, and brought witℏ hym. ij. fatte
shepe; and whan he foun&dtail; the Emperour, after his kynde he made
hym goo&dtail; che&rtail;, and offre&dtail; hym botℏ the shepe.
¶ The Emperour was hungry, bicause he ha&dtail; not ete&ntail; of
a&llbar; day; he toke an Ire&ntail;, and smote fire of a stone, and
araie&dtail; hym flessℏ, and Ete, and dranke watir of the floode;
and so he lay a&llbar; nyght witℏ the lyo&ntail;.  ¶ on the
day folowyng he lept on his palfray, and rode a&llbar; day, and coude
fynde no goyng out of the forest, wherfore he was hevy and sory.
¶ Efte sones he went to the lyons denne, but he foun&dtail; not
the lyo&ntail;; and agay&ntail; Eve&ntail; come a female Bere to hym;
and whan he sawe her, he was gretely afer&dtail;.  but the Bere made
hym chere in her maner, and of the pray that she ha&dtail; gote&ntail;
and take, she laye&dtail; it before hym.  he smote fire, and
araie&dtail; it, and ete; and after that he ha&dtail; ete&ntail;, thei laye&ntail; bothe to-gedre.  and the
Emperour knew her flesshly, and she brought fortℏ a sone, like
the Emperour.  than the Emperour wol&dtail; have fle&dtail;, but he
durst not, for the bere; But efte sones he knew her, and
she brought forthe the seconde sone, that also was like the Emperour.
¶ The thir&dtail; tyme he knew her, and she brought forthe a
doughtir, that was like the modir, the bere. that sawe the Emperour,
and was wondir sory.  ¶ It fille on a day, that whan the Bere was
ferre gone, for to take her praye, the Emperour toke his .ij. sones,
that he ha&dtail; gote&ntail; of the Bere, witℏ hym, and fledde;
and whan he was in fleyng, The lyo&ntail;, that he hadde hele&dtail;
before, come agay&ntail; hym, and ledde hym out of the forest.  ¶
The Bere come home, and whan she foun&dtail; not the Emperour, she
ranne fast witℏ her doughtir.  and [whan] she sawe the lyo&ntail;
by hym, she was aferde, and durst not come nere hym; but toke her
doughtir, and rent her a&llbar; to peces, and went agay&ntail; to her
place.  ¶ The Emperour, whan he was come out of the forest by the
lyo&ntail;, he was right gladde; And than the lyo&ntail; went from
hym. ¶ Than the Emperour went to his owne Caste&llbar;, witℏ
his .ij. sones. the dukes and the lordes and a&llbar; other wise men
were right gladde, for of .iij. yere thei ha&dtail; not sene the
Emperour.  the sones, whan thei were come to age, were made knyghtes, and were
stronge werriours, and wente aboute in many straunge londes, and
gote&ntail; meke&llbar; goo&dtail; by dynte of swer&dtail;; and aftir
in pease thei ende&dtail; her lyves. and bothe thei die&dtail; on one
day, and in one grave were burie&dtail;; and on the stone of her grave
was this scripture, ¶ Here lietℏ .ij. sones of the Bere,
whiche the Emperour gate witℏ drede.
0.2:
¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour may be sai&dtail; every
criste&ntail; man that is vay&ntail;, waveryng, and erryng fro the
faithe, that playetℏ witℏ houndes, that is, with lustes of
the flessℏ, that in no maner rente&ntail; the soule. the herte
rynnetℏ before such one, that is, the vanyte of the worl&dtail;.
that man vnwise folowitℏ witℏ a&llbar; his myght, in so
meke&llbar; that he lyvetℏ alone, witℏ out any vertu. after
this he gothe alone into the forest of this worl&dtail;, ¶ whan
vtterly he puttetℏ a&llbar; his witte and vndirstondyng in it, in
so meke&llbar; that he maketℏ no force of go&dtail;, ne of thyng
that longetℏ to go&dtail;. ¶ But the lyo&ntail; haltyng
cometℏ agay&ntail; hym.  ¶ This lyo&ntail; is crist, that
haltetℏ in the foote, that is, in man that is his membre ; for he is hede, and we are his membres.
man haltetℏ as ofte as he lyvetℏ in poverte, or in tribulacion.  ¶ Do thou
therfore as the Emperou&rtail; di&dtail;; come dow&ntail; of the horse
of pride, and the thorne of poverte, or of
tribulacio&ntail; do thou therfore drawe out fro hym, That is, yeve
hym almesse, and shew to hym the way of helthe, and than hast thou
drawe&ntail; out þe thorne of the foote; as our lor&dtail;
seitℏ, ¶ That ye done to one of the lest of myne, ye done it
to me. ¶ Afterwar&dtail; the lyo&ntail; fedde the knyght in the
forest.  So crist forsaketℏ not a synner, but that he fedetℏ
hym witℏ his grace, that he falle not into helle; as it is
writte&ntail; in the psalme, ¶ I am witℏ hym in tribulacio&ntail;.  Therefo&rtail; he yevetℏ
to the synner .ij.  Shepe, that is, tyme of penaunce, and tyme, that
is, grace, of rysyng, by the whicℏ he may gostly be
susteyne&dtail;.  ¶ But often aftir, this wrecche&dtail; man that
knowetℏ not the way out of the forest, that is, out of the
worl&dtail;, he knowetℏ not what detℏ he sha&llbar; dye, or
where, or how, but rynnetℏ to the Bere, that is, to the flesshly
lustes; witℏ the whiche he dothe synne als ofte as he
assentetℏ to flesshly lustes, witℏ the whiche he dothe
synne, that is, he hathe delite of the bere, of the whiche he hathe
gote&ntail; .ij.  Sones and a doughtir.  ¶ The .ij. sones are
concupiscence of ly&ftee; and concupiscence of Eye&ntail;, that are
likene&dtail; to a synner.  ¶ The doughtir, that was like to the
Bere, is the sensualite in man, that is alway redy to eve&llbar; as is
in Genesyes writte&ntail;, The wittes of man are a&llbar; way prone to
eve&llbar; at a&llbar; tymes. wherfor god sai&dtail;, It ever
forthynketℏ me, that I made man; I sha&llbar; for-do hym, that
is, the steryng of the sensualite are done away by cristes
passio&ntail;. do thou therfore as the Emperour di&dtail;; flee
witℏ thi .ij. sones to a discrete confessour; and yf the bere,
that is, flesshly lust, folow the witℏ the sensualite, drede not,
but have a&llbar; way god in thy eye&ntail;.  ¶ Than ano&ntail;
the lio&ntail;, that is, crist, sha&llbar; come to the agay&ntail;, yf
thou calle hym, ¶ wherfor he seitℏ, seketℏ, and ye
shu&llbar; fynde; knokketℏ, and it sha&llbar; be opene&dtail; to
you. and yf god be witℏ you, the bere sha&llbar; flee, that is,
temptacio&ntail; and so shalt thou come to the chirche, that is,
fightyng, in the whiche thou shalt be resceive&dtail;; of the whiche
comyng from synne and doyng of penaunce is a more new Ioye in hevene
to aungels, than of nyntye and nyne rightfu&llbar; men that neden no
penaunce.  ¶ The .ij. sones sha&llbar; be .ij. knyghtes, workyng
goo&dtail; werkes, witℏ the whiche thei shu&llbar; do dyverse
batailes ayenst the deve&llbar;; and after thei shu&llbar; be
burie&dtail; in oo tombe, that is, in perfite charitee, for the
whicℏ man sha&llbar; have the kyngdome prove of
heve&ntail;.  Amen.
