0.1:
Story. DArius reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, a fu&llbar; wise man,
that ha&dtail; a Citee wele walle&dtail;, in the whiche was a belle
hange&dtail; in the myddes; and as ofte as he shul&dtail; go to
bataile, or out of the Citee, to take his pray, the belle shulde be
ronge&ntail; of a maide&ntail;.  ¶ It befelle in shorte tyme,
that dragons and venemous bestes veneme&dtail; men, and thus thei
didde&ntail; ofte; wherfore the Citee was nye distroye&dtail;, and
nere han&dtail; a&llbar; perisshe&dtail;.  ¶ The wise men of the
Citee witℏ one assent and counseile went to the Emperour, and
sai&dtail;, "Sir, what sha&llbar; we do?  behol&dtail; our goodes are
distroie&dtail; in the Citee, and brought to nought, and ye and we are
in poynt to be lost, for dragons and venemous bestes distroie&ntail;
vs. lette vs ordeyne some goo&dtail; counseile, or els we shulle alle
perissℏ."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "how may we defende
vs?"  Than one of hem sei&dtail;, "heretℏ my counseile, and ye
shulle not forthynke it.  ¶ Sir, there is a lyo&ntail; in your
paleys; sette vp a crosse, and hange the lio&ntail; ther on; and whan the drago&ntail; and the venemous bestes shu&llbar;
se the lyo&ntail; on the crosse, for fere thei shu&llbar; not
nygℏ vs, ne noye vs." ¶ Than sei&dtail; the Emperour, "this
pleasetℏ me wele." and so thei didde&ntail; the lyo&ntail; on the
crosse; ¶ And whan the venemous bestes sawe the lyo&ntail; on the
crosse, thei come no more to the Citee, but fle&dtail; for
fere.
0.2:
¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is the Fadir of
heve&ntail;. the Citee wele walle&dtail; is the soule, sette aboute
witℏ vertues, whan god fourme&dtail; it to his liknesse.  ¶
The belle is a clene conscience, that leditℏ a man whan he
sha&llbar; go to bataile agay&ntail; the deve&llbar;, and armetℏ
hym witℏ goo&dtail; werkes. but this belle sha&llbar; no man
Rynge but a maide&ntail;, that is, reso&ntail;, that steretℏ to
a&llbar; rightwisenesse. ¶ The drago&ntail;, that flew witℏ
the fire, is the voluptuous flessℏ, that beretℏ the fire of
glotonye and lechery, that brent Adam oure first fadir, whan he ete of
the apple that was for-bode. the venemous bestes, that venyme a&llbar;
folke, are fendes , that for the more parte
distroie&ntail; a&llbar; man kynde.  ¶ That sawe the wise men,
that is, the prophetes and patriarkes sorowe&dtail;, and crie&dtail;
to go&dtail; for help. ¶ Therfore it was counseile&dtail;, that
the lyo&ntail;, that is, crist, shul&dtail; be put on the crosse; as
it was prophecie&dtail;, It is spedfu&llbar; that one dye for the
peple, that alle the folke perissℏ not.  ¶ Thei
toke crist, the lyo&ntail;, and put hym o&ntail; the crosse; wherfore
the venemous bestes, that are fendes, that drede&ntail; to come to
criste&ntail; folke, flee&ntail;. and so, by the help of god,
criste&ntail; folke shu&llbar; ever be in ever lastyng blisse with out
ende.

71.1:
Second Version.  19. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Darius regned in Rome a fu&llbar; wise man þat had a Cite
wele walled In þe whiche A Belle hanged in the myddes / & as
oft as he sholde go to þe bataile or out of þe Cite to
take his pray / the belle sholde be ron>ee; of a mayde / It
byfe&llbar; with in A short tyme þat dragons & venem[e]s
bestes venemy&dtail; me&nmacr; & þus þei dyed oft,
Wherfor the Cite was nye distroye&dtail;, þat nerehand a&llbar;
perisshed.  The wise men of þe Cite with counceile & assent
went to the Emperour & seyde / "Sir, what sha&llbar; we do?
Beholde how our goodes be distroyed & the Cite brought to noght,
& we Are in poynt to be loste for þe drago&ntail; &
þe venomes wormes / lorde, helpe vs, or ellys sey vs some goode
councei&llbar;, or ellys we shole perisshe" / The Emperour seyde /
"how mow we diffende vs?" / Than one of hem seyde, "herith my
councei&llbar;, & ye shu&llbar; not ouerþink it / Sir,
þer is A lyo&nmacr; in your palys; sit vp a crosse & hang þe lyo&nmacr; / And whan þe drago&nmacr; & the venomes bestes shu&llbar; se
þe lyo&nmacr; on þe crosse, for fere þei shu&llbar;
not noye vs."  Than seyde þe Emperour, "þis plesyth me
well," & so thei did þe lyo&nmacr; on the crosse / And whan
þe venomes bestes saw þe lyo&nmacr; on þe crosse
thei come no more to þe Cite, but fled for fere.

0.1:
Story. MEnelaus reigne&dtail; in 'the Citee of Rome, that was right
mercifu&llbar;; therfore he made a law, that yf a mysdoer were take,
and put into priso&ntail;, yf he myght ascape, and flee to the paleys,
he shul&dtail; have refute, witℏ out any contradiccio&ntail;.
¶ It fille, that there was a man-sleer take&ntail;, and put into
priso&ntail;, and put to his diete; wherfore he sorowe&dtail; gretly,
that he was put fro mannes sight, and fro the light of the sonne, save
a lite&llbar; wyndowe, by the whiche [the light shone in; by the
whiche] light he toke his mete 'and his drynke of the kepers euery
day, and ete at a certay&ntail; houre. ¶ And whan the keper of
the priso&ntail; was gone away, a Nightyngale was wonte to come in
atte wyndow, and synge wondir swetly; of the whiche songe the knyght
was gretly comforte&dtail;. and after the songe, the bri&dtail;
fleigℏ into the knyghtes skirte, and the knyght every day fedde
the bridde witℏ a porcio&ntail; of his mete.  ¶ After this
it felle vpon a day, that the knyght was wondir hevy, and sai&dtail;
to the bridde sittyng in his skirte thise wordes, ¶ "O!
goo&dtail; bridde, what shalt thou yeve me, that have so many 'a day
I-fedde the?  bryng me into memorie, for thou art goddes creature, and
I also."  ¶ whan the bridde ha&dtail; her&dtail; this, he flew forthe. and
the thir&dtail; day he come ayene, and brought in his mouthe a
precious stone, and lette it falle into the knyghtes skirte, and flew
forthe.  The knyght, whan he sawe the stone, he ha&dtail; grete
mervaile.  ¶ After it happe&dtail; to falle on his feters, and
ano&ntail; a&llbar; the Ire&ntail;, that he was boun&dtail; in, was
broke&ntail; therwitℏ.  ¶ The knyght, whan he saw this, he
was right gla&dtail;, and arose, and touche&dtail; the dore witℏ
the stone, the whiche 'opene&dtail;; and ano&ntail; he went out, and
ranne to the paleys.  ¶ The Iayle&rtail; 'sawe this, and whan he
perseive&dtail; it, he blew iij. blastes with an horne, and brought
a&llbar; out of the Citee, and sai&dtail;, "se the thee&ftee;! folow
ye hym!"  and a&llbar; thei folowe&dtail;, but the keper ranne before.
 ¶ The knyght sawe that, and shotte to hym witℏ an arowe,
and slougℏ hym; and so the knyght ranne to the paleys, and there
he foun&dtail; refute, aftir the lawe.
0.2:
Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperou&rtail; is the Fadir of
heve&ntail;, that ordeyne&dtail; this lawe, that who so is a
man-sleer, that is, a synner, that by contricio&ntail; and
confessio&ntail; may ascape to the paleys of holy chirche, [he]
sha&llbar; have perpetue&llbar; refresshyng.  ¶ This knyght is a
synner in dedely [synne] bounde&ntail;, and therfore by goddes law he
shul&dtail; be deme&dtail; to the priso&ntail; of helle, yf he passe
so out of this worl&dtail;, and boun&dtail; witℏ dyverse cheynes,
that is, witℏ many synnes. wherfore suche one owetℏ meke&llbar; to sorow, and
alway wepe.  ¶ The keper of the priso&ntail; is the deve&llbar;e,
that suche one hathe sette faste bounde in synne, and mynystretℏ
to hym of delites and vices, that he go not fro hym.  ¶ The
bridde, that songe so swetely, is the voice of go&dtail;, that
seitℏ to a synner, Turne agay&ntail;, turne agay&ntail;, thou
wrecche, that is, a synfu&llbar; soule, and I sha&llbar; take the.
whan a&llbar; man-kynde went to helle before the comyng of crist,
¶ There come a bridde, that was the godhede, and brought
witℏ hym a stone, that was crist; as he sai&dtail; hym sel&ftee;,
I am a stone. the soule of crist witℏ the godhede discende&dtail;
to helle, and brought witℏ hym mankyn&dtail;. therfore yf any of
you be in dedely synne, lette hym touche his synne witℏ þe
stone, that is, witℏ the vertu of crist, in contricio&ntail; and
confessio&ntail;, and witℏ oute doute the chaynes of synne
sha&llbar; be broke&ntail;, and the dore of the grace of go&dtail; be
opene&dtail;; and so sha&llbar; he have fleyng to the paleys of holy
chirche.  ¶ And yf the keper of the priso&ntail;, that is, the
fende, blowe witℏ his horne o&ftee; pride, Covetise, and lechery,
and stere a&llbar; vices agay&ntail; the, thou shalt smyte hym
witℏ the arowe of penaunce; and witℏ out doute he sha&llbar;
flee fro the, and so thou shalt have the paleys of the kyngdome of
heve&ntail;, by this blisse&dtail; stone.  Iesu crist brynge vs to the
blisse of heve&ntail;!

72.1:
Second Version.  9. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Menelaus regned in Rome þat was right mercyfu&llbar;;
þerfor he made a lawe þat if a miller were take and put in
prison if he myght scape & fle to the palays, he shol&dtail; haue
refute with out eny contradiction / It fi&llbar; þat þer
was A man-sleer take & put in pryson & put to his diete /
wherfor he sorowed gretely þat he was put out of mannes sight /
& priue&dtail; fro the lyght of the sonne / saue a lyty&llbar;
wyndowe, by þe whych the lyght shone in / By the whiche lyght he
toke his mete & ete / The keper of the pryso&nmacr; euery day
brought hym his mete at a certey&nmacr; oure / An&dtail; whan the
keper of þe pryso&nmacr; was gone-a-way A nyghtyngale was wont
to come in at the wyndowe & syn>ee; wonder swetely, of þe
which song the knyght was gretely comfortyd / And after the son>ee;
þe byrd flye in to þe knyghtes skyrte; & þe
knyght euery day fed þe byrd with a porcion of his mete.  After
this It fy&llbar; on a day þat þe knyght was wondyr heuy
& seyde to the byrde syttyn>ee; in his skyrte þes wordes,
"O good byrd, what shalt þou gefe me þat so many dayes
haue fed þe? Bryn>ee; in to memory for þou art goddys creature & I
also" / Whan the byrd had herd þis he fly forthe / And the
.iij. day he come a-gayne / &
brought in his mowthe a stone & lete it fa&llbar; in the knyghtes
lappe & fly forth.  The knyght whan he sawe the stone he had grete
meruayle / After it happed to falle on his feters, And a-no&nmacr;
a&llbar; the Eron þat he was bound with was broke / The knyght
whan he sawe þis he was ryght glad, & rose & touched the
dores with the stone, þe whyche were openy&dtail; A-none: he
went out & ran to þe paleys.  The Iayler, whan he perceyuyd
this, he blewe .iij.  with an horne & brought a&llbar; out of the
Cite / And seyde, "Se þe þefe, Folow ye hym!"  And
a&llbar; folowed hym, but þe keper ran by-fore / the knyght sawe
that & shot at hym An Arowe & slowe hym, & so the knyght
ran to þe [paleys], & ther he fonde refute After þe
lawe.

0.1:
Story. Calepondinus in Rome reigne&dtail;, that toke a maide&ntail; to
wyf, that conseive&dtail;, and brought fortℏ a faire childe.  The
chil&dtail; wexe&dtail;, and was put to scole.  ¶ Whan he was xx.
wynter of age, he desire&dtail; 'the heritage of his Fadir, and
sei&dtail; to his Fadir, ¶ "Sir, ye are olde, and mow not rewle
the Empire; yf ye ga&ftee; me the Empire, it shul&dtail; be youre
profite."  ¶ The Emperour sei&dtail;, "sone, there is now grete hungir in the Empire, and I drede, yf I yeve the
the Empire and the power, yf I ha&dtail; nede, haply thou shuldest
denye me my wille." ¶ The Empresse, that love&dtail; more her
sone than her husbon&dtail; sai&dtail;, "sir that may not be, for ye
have but oo sone, and therfore I trow alway that he wille fulfille
your wille; wherfore it is goo&dtail; to you to graunte hym the
Empire."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "I wille have of hym an
obligacio&ntail;, that what houre he risetℏ hym sel&ftee; ayenst
me, and fulfille not my wille, whan reaso&ntail; is, I sha&llbar;
depreve hym of the Empire." the sone graunte&dtail;, and made an
obligacio&ntail;, and seale&dtail; it.  ¶ Whan this was done, the
Emperour was put from his dignyte, and his sone was crowne&dtail;.
¶ whan he was made Emperour, he was reise&dtail; in to pride, in
so meke&llbar; that he neither dre&dtail; go&dtail; ne man, and
di&dtail; many wronges; and the fadir suffre&dtail; hym paciently.
¶ It happe&dtail; aftirwar&dtail;, that there was a grete hungir
in the lan&dtail;, and the olde Emperour began to nede; and wente to
his sone, and aske&dtail; his sustenaunce of hym, and for a tyme he
sent hym.  but in a short tyme aftir, the fadir was greuously sike,
and calle&dtail; to hym his sone, and sai&dtail;, ¶ My sone, I
have grete thirst; yeve me a draught of thi must." the sone
aunswere&dtail;, "I sha&llbar; not, for must is not goo&dtail; for thi
complexio&ntail;."  ¶ The fadir sai&dtail;, "yeve me of anoþer tonne of wyne." than the sone sei&dtail;,
"nay, for it is not clere I-nougℏ and yf it shul&dtail; now be
touche&dtail;, the wyne myght be trouble&dtail;; and therfore I wille
not touche it, tille I se it clere I-now." ¶ The Fadir
sei&dtail;, "yeve me of the thir&dtail; tonne." he sai&dtail;, "naye,
for the wyne is stronge and myghty, and therfore it is not worthe for
the sike."  ¶ "yeve me than," he sai&dtail;, "of the fourthe
tonne." the sonne sei&dtail;, "nay, for it is to feble, and witℏ
out sustentacio&ntail; or comforte.  It must be wyne confortati&ftee;
that shul&dtail; be yeven to the sike."  ¶ The fadir sei&dtail;,
"yeve me therfore of the fifte tonne." he aunswere&dtail;, "nay, for
drastes that are in the tonne; and suche is not worthe to a sike man,
scarsely for hogges." ¶ Whan the Fadir sawe he
myght not have, he suffre&dtail; paciently tille he were hole; and
than the Fadir went to the kyn>ee; of Jerusalem, and playne&dtail;
to hym of his sone, and shewe&dtail; to hym an obligacio&ntail;, that
he myght put out his sone, witℏ out any contradiccio&ntail;.
¶ The kyng her&dtail; this, and calle&dtail; his sone, to
aunswere to the Fadir.  ¶ whan the sone might not resonably
aunswere, the kyng depreve&dtail; hym of the Empire, and
restore&dtail; agay&ntail; the Fadir.  and than a&llbar; praise&dtail;
the kyng, for he ha&dtail; so rightfully yove&ntail; the dome.
0.2:
¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is crist, the sone of
man, to whom is yove&ntail; the Empire of a&llbar; this worl&dtail;;
But in the gifte he toke of hym an obligacio&ntail;, his Baptyme, that
he shul&dtail; forsake the pompe and a&llbar; the pride of it.  ¶
The olde Emperour, that is, crist, is sike, as ofte as criste&ntail;
man or woman falletℏ in dedely synne, and breketℏ his
comaundementis; wherfore gretly he thrustetℏ the helthe of oure
soules, and asketℏ of vs our yonge age.  ¶ But frowar&dtail;
man aunsweretℏ, I may not yeve to go&dtail; my yonge soukyng age,
for it is must, that is, over sone to assay the way of go&dtail;; and
that is not trew, for a childe of oo daies age is not witℏ out
synne. ¶ Wherfore Seint Gregory telletℏ, that a childe of v.
yere of age the fendes token out of his
Fadirs lappe.  yf god may not have of the must of so yonge age, he
asketℏ the age of eldre childhode, that is, of x. or xii. yere.
¶ But frowar&dtail; man aunsweretℏ, and seitℏ, the wyne
is not clere I-now, that is, the chil&dtail; is not apte to serve
go&dtail;, in that he is inparfite ;
¶ For yf he be stere&dtail; to go&dtail;, he must be
trouble&dtail; in his body.  that is agay&ntail; the doctryne of the
wise man, that seitℏ, he that lovetℏ his sone,
chastisetℏ hym, and delyueretℏ his soule fro helle.  ¶
Also he asketℏ wyne of the thir&dtail; tonne, that is, of the
tonne of yonge mannes age.  but man contrarious aunsweretℏ, the
wyne is over myghty, it is not goo&dtail;; for a felle man, that is,
yonge man, is stronge and myghty, therfore he owetℏ to spende it
aboute worldly thynges, and not in penaunce, for he myght be made
feble. ¶ Also he asketℏ wyne of the fourthe tonne, that is,
of age, that is, that thou yevest hym service in the service of god.
but frowar&dtail; man aunsweretℏ, and seitℏ, man in his olde
age is feble, and may not fast, Ne do penaunce, for suche shuld be
cause of his dethe. ¶ Also he asketℏ of the fifte tonne,
that is, of the ol&dtail; man, that may not goo witℏ oute a staffe, yit he
asketℏ of man that state, that he turne to hym.  ¶
Frowar&dtail; man aunsweretℏ, and seitℏ, this wyne is over
feble, for yf he faste&dtail; oo day, it behove&dtail; hym to make his grave ; And lawe wille not that an vnmyghty
man shul&dtail; slee hym sel&ftee;.  ¶ Also he aske&dtail; of the
vj. tonne, whan man for el&dtail; or
blyndnesse may no further walke to synne, and myght failetℏ hym for to do evel.  ¶ God asketℏ drynke of suche
one, that is, the helthe of his soule; But wrecche&dtail; man, that is
put in dispaire, seitℏ, Allas!  allas!  while I myght serve god I
wol&dtail; not, and now dwelle&ntail; in me the drestes of a&llbar;
goodnesse.  wherto shul&dtail; I now be turne&dtail; to my go&dtail;?
¶ But allas!  many ther be&ntail;, that wille yeve hym no wyne.
wherfore crist playne&dtail; to the kyng of Jerusalem; and therfore
shul&dtail; suche gone into everlastyng turment, and rightwise men in
to everlastyng blisse.

73.1:
Second Version.  10. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Calepodius in Rome regne&dtail; þat toke A mayde to wyfe
þat conceyuyd & brought forthe A fayre chylde.  The Childe
wax & was put to scole / Whan he was of xx wynty&rtail; age he
desyryd his faders herytage & seyde to his fader, "Syr, ye are old
& ye con not rule the Empyre, yf ye yafe to me the Empyre / It
sholde be your profyt" / The Emperour seyde, "Sone, þer is now
grete hungre in the Empyre, And I drede if I gafe to þe the Empyre &
þe power / If I had nede happyly þou sholdyst denye me of
my wylle" The Emperice, þat louyd her son more than her husband,
seyde, "syr, þat may not be, for ye haue but o sone, And
þerfor I trow þat he wole Alway folow your wy&llbar; /
Wherfor It is good to you to graunt hym þe Empyre."  The
Emperour seyde, "I wole haue of hym an obligacio&ntail;, þat
what oure he reysyth hym-selfe a-gayne me & fulfy&llbar; not my
wy&llbar; whan reson is, I sha&llbar; priue hym of the Empyre"/ The
sone grauntyd & made an obligacion & selyd it / Whan this was
done / The Emperour was put fro his dignyte / And his sone was
crowned. whan he was made Emperour he was reysyd in-to pryde, In so
mych he dred God ne man, And dyd many wronges.  And þe fader
suffred hym pacyently / It happed after þat þer was a
grete hungre in the lond / And the olde Emperour bygan to haue nede /
& want to his sone & asked of hym his sustenaunce / & for
a tyme he sent hym.  But in A shorte tyme after the fader was
greuously syke / & calle&dtail; his sone & seyde / "A, my
sone, I haue grete þryst / Gyf me A draught of thi wyne moste" /
the sone Answerd / "I sha&llbar; not, for muste is not good for thi complexion"
/ The fader sayde, "þan gyf me of A-noþer ton of wyne" /
The sone seyde / "Nay / It is not clere y-noghe / & if it sholde
now be touched the wyne myght be troubled, And therfor I wol not
touche it / Ty&llbar; I se it clere I-nogh" / The fader sayde / "Gyf
me of the .iij. tonne" / he seyde, "Nay, for the wyne is stron>ee;
& mighty, And therfor It is not worthe for þe syke" / "Gyf
me, þan" / he seyde, "the .iiij. tonne" / The Sone seyde, "Nay,
for it is feble & with out susten awnce or comfort / It most be wyne comfortable þat
shol&dtail; be yeue to the syke" / Therfor the fader seyde, "Gyf me of
.v. tonne." he answerde, "Nay, for drastes are in the tonne, &
such is not worthe for A ma&nmacr;, scarsely for hogges" / Whan the
fader sawe he myght not haue / he suffred pacyently ty&llbar; he waxe
hole, And than he want to the Kyn>ee; of Ierhusalem, &
playne&dtail; to hym of his sone & shewed hym an obligacion
þat he myght put out his sone with out contradictio&nmacr; / The
kyn>ee; herde þis & called to hym the sone to answere the
fader / Whan þe sone myght not resonably Answere / The kyn>ee;
pryued hym of the Empyre, And restoryd Agayne the fader, And than
a&llbar; preysyd the kyn>ee; for he had so wysely geuen the
dome.

0.1:
Story. Alexander the Emperour was so stronge and myghty, that none in his
tyme myght overcome hym; and this Emperour ha&dtail; Aristotil to his
maister, that taught hym in a&llbar; wysedo&mtail; and konnyng.
¶ That saw the quene of the Northe, and norisshe&dtail; her
doughtir with venyme, fro the tyme of her birthe, that whan she come
to lawfu&llbar; age, she was so faire, that she was lovesome to
a&llbar;. ¶ After, she sent her to Alexandre, that she myght be
his concubyne; and whan he saw her, ano&ntail; he was take in her
love, and wol&dtail; have synne&dtail; witℏ her.  ¶ That
perseive&dtail; Aristoti&llbar;, and sai&dtail; to hym, "Touche her
not, for yf ye do, ye sha&llbar; be dede ano&ntail;; For a&llbar; her
lyf-tyme she hatℏ ben norisshe&dtail; witℏ venyme, and that
I sha&llbar; prove ano&ntail;.  here is one that sha&llbar; be dede by
the lawe; lette hym slepe witℏ her, and than shulle ye se whether
I sey sothe." and so it was done. ano&ntail; as he kisse&dtail;
he&rtail;, he fille downe dede. ¶ Alexandre praise&dtail; his
maister, for he delyvere&dtail; hym fro the dethe. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour may be sai&dtail; every
man that is stronge and myghty, by the vertu of the baptyme.  The
quene is habundaunce of tho thynges that seketℏ man to slee.
¶ The maide, that was venyme&dtail;, is glotonye and lechery, by
the whiche many are slay&ntail;.  ¶ Aristoti&llbar; is
reaso&ntail;, that seitℏ a&llbar; way ayenst synne.  The man,
that is dampne&dtail; by the lawe, is frowar&dtail; man, that a&llbar;
way synnetℏ witℏ glotonye and lechery.  therfore it is to
flee, that we be sobre in mete and dryn&ktee;, that we mowe come to
everlastyng mede, the whiche is eterna&llbar;.
Amen.

74.1:
Second Version.  20. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Alexandre the Emperour was so myghty þat no man in his tyme
myght ouercome hym, & had Aristoti&llbar; to his mayster, that
taught hym a&llbar; wisdo&mmacr; & konyn>ee;.  that sawe
þe quene of the northe & norisshed her doughter with venom
fro þe tyme of her yon>ee; age þat whan she come to
lawfu&llbar; age she was so fayre a creature & loueso&mtail; to
a&llbar;: After she sent he&rtail; to Alysand&rtail; that she myght be
his / & [he] wolde haue synned with he&rtail;: þat perceyued
Aristoti&llbar; & seyde to hym, "touche he&rtail; not, for if ye
do ye shu&llbar; be dede Anone / for a&llbar; her lyf tyme she hathe
be norisshed with venom / & þat sha&llbar; I preve Anone /
here is one þat sha&llbar; be dede by þe lawe / let hym
slepe with her, & þan shu&llbar; ye see whe&rtail; I sey sothe" / & so it was do&nmacr;.  Anone as he kyssed her he
fi&llbar; dow&nmacr; dede / Alisaundre praysy&dtail; his mayster for
[he] delyuerd hym so fro that deþe.

0.1:
Story. Flosculus reigne&dtail; in Rome, that ha&dtail; a sone that was
wode, that dyverse daies rent his membres.  the Fadir sawe that, and
ya&ftee; hym venyme, and ha&dtail; lever slee him softly than he
shul&dtail; so rente hym sel&ftee; dyverse daies.  The modir sawe
that, and was right sory; She wente to the domesman, and playne&dtail;
on her husbon&dtail;, that he ha&dtail; slay&ntail; his sone.  ¶
The fadir before the domesman aunswere&dtail;, and sai&dtail;, "it was
a werke of charitee, and that for this skille.  ¶ My sone a&llbar; to-rente hym
sel&ftee;, and so of longe tyme he suffre&dtail; many wrecchednesse.
¶ I, that was his Fadir, seyng that, I chase rather to slee hym,
than longe tyme to se hym in sorow." Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is the worl&dtail;.  The sone,
that rent hym sel&ftee;, is a doer of penaunce, the whiche tametℏ
his flessℏ.  ¶ But oure Fadir, the whiche is the
worl&dtail;, by the whiche we are susteyne&dtail; bodely, yevetℏ
vs venymes o&ftee; the erthe of our birthe, by the whiche ofte sithes
we are dede.  ¶ But oure modir, that is holy chirche,
accusetℏ the worl&dtail; to go&dtail;.  therfore flee we the
worl&dtail;, that oure modir, holy chirche, may have of vs solace,
grete ioye, and gladnesse.

75.1:
Second Version.  21. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Plosculus regned in Rome that had a sone þat was wode,
þat dyuers dayes rent his membres / The fader saw that & gaf
hym venym & had leuyr sle hym þan he sholde rend hym-self so
dyuers dayes / The mode&rtail; saw þat & was right sory; she
went to the domesman & pleynyd of her husbande þat he had
slayne his sone / The fader by-fore þe domesman Answerde &
seide, "It was a werk of charite & þerfor this sky&llbar; /
My sone a&llbar;-to-rent hym sel&ftee;, & so lon>ee; ty&mmacr; he suffred many wikydnesses / I, þat was his
fader, seeing þat / I chase raþer for to sle hym þan
lon>ee; tyme for to see hym in sorow.

0.1:
PRomius reigne&dtail; in Rome, that ha&dtail; a faire wy&ftee;;
the whiche, whan she stode ones in a wyndowe of the Caste&llbar;, she
saw ij. knyghtes in a medow vndir the Caste&llbar; [fightynge]
to-gedre; the one knyght was right faire, in so meke&llbar; that the
lady was take&ntail; in his love.  ¶ Whan
the bataile was done, the knyght that the lady love&dtail; so wele,
ha&dtail; the victorie; the lady for love be-gan to langour. ¶
The Emperour was right hevy, and sent ano&ntail; for leches, forto see
the state of the lady; and thei seide&ntail;, "there is none other
sikenesse in her, but that she lovetℏ some man over meke&llbar;."
¶ The Emperour sai&dtail; to his wy&ftee;, "I pray the, name hym
that thou lovest more than me."  ¶ She sai&dtail;, "that faire
knyght I love so meke&llbar;, that but I have his love, I sha&llbar;
be dede."  ¶ Than the Emperour sai&dtail; to the leches, "I pray
you, that ye save her ly&ftee;."  Thei sei&dtail;, "there is no way,
but one slee that knyght that ha&dtail; the victorye, and anoynte her
witℏ his bloo&dtail;."  ¶ Thei slowe the knyght, and
anoynte&dtail; her; and ano&ntail; the temptacio&ntail; sease&dtail;,
and she was hole of her sikenesse.

76.1:
Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is Adam, the first Fadir. ¶ The wyf, that was so
faire, it is his soule.  the ij. knyghtes that foughte&ntail;, was god
and the aunge&llbar;.  The fightyng was, whan the aunge&llbar;
wol&dtail; be like go&dtail;, and aboue go&dtail;; but go&dtail;
ha&dtail; the victorie. ¶ This sawe the quene, that is, the
soule, and ano&ntail; she brente in the love of go&dtail;; wherfore
she was sike , in so meke&llbar; that she
shul&dtail; dye.  But the myghty knyght, that is, crist, is
slay&ntail;, and witℏ his bloo&dtail; we are an-oynte&dtail;, and
are made hole.

0.1:
Story. LEnyncius reigne&dtail; in Rome, the whicℏ as he rode by a
forest, mette witℏ a poore man, and sei&dtail; to hym, "fro whens
comest thou, and what art thou?"  he sai&dtail;, "I come fro the next
Citee, and am your man."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "yf thou
wilte be a goo&dtail; man, and a trew, I sha&llbar; promote the to
grete richesse."  he sai&dtail;, "ye, lor&dtail;."  Ano&ntail; the
Emperour made hym a knyght, and sone he rode into pride; wherfore he
gadre&dtail; to hym many of the grete men of the empire, and
conspire&dtail; witℏ hem, that he wol&dtail; vsurpe the Empire.
whan the Emperour wist that, ano&ntail; he put hym out, and alle that
hel&dtail; witℏ hym; and wol&dtail; no lenger lette hym dwelle in
his Empire, but ordeyne&dtail; other in her stede, and yaf hem a&llbar; her landes, and a&llbar; her mevable
goodes.  ¶ Whan they her&dtail; that straungers ha&dtail; her
goodes, thei conspire&dtail; ayenst hem, and praie&dtail; hem to the
fest, and sette before hem v. messe; and every messe was
envenyme&dtail;, and a&llbar; that ete of the messes were dede.
¶ The Emperour calle&dtail; his sonnes, and aske&dtail;, what
were to do of the dede? his Eldest sone sai&dtail;, "ye are my Fadir,
and gretly I am greve&dtail; for your hevynesse.  I yeve you this
counseile.  ¶ A lite&llbar; kyngdo&mtail; is here not ferre fro
you, in the whiche is a fu&llbar; faire maide&ntail;, the whicℏ
hatℏ a noble gardy&ntail;; In the whicℏ gardey&ntail; is a
welle of watir of suche vertu, that yf it be sprynge&dtail; on the
dede body, it sha&llbar; lyve agay&ntail;.  ¶ Therfore I
sha&llbar; go to this kyngdome, and sha&llbar; gete the watir of this
welle, by the whiche the dede mow arise to ly&ftee;."  ¶ And
ano&ntail; he went to the kyngdo&mtail;, and gate the wille of the
maide&ntail;; and went into the gardy&ntail;, and foun&dtail; the
welle. wherfore he di&dtail; make v. pittes right depe, by the whiche
the watir of the welle ranne to the bodies of the dede men; and
ano&ntail; thei risse&ntail;.  and whan this was done and sene, ¶
The sone of the Emperour ladde hym and a&llbar; they&mtail; to
his Fadir.  ¶ The Emperour, whan he sawe hem, he was gla&dtail;,
and for ioye crowne&dtail; his sone. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is the Fadir of
heve&ntail;.  The poore man, that was promote&dtail; to grete dignite,
is lucifer, that o&ftee; nought was made, that is, of no matir.
¶ Therfore of that he was so proude, in so meke&llbar; that he
wol&dtail; be like god, ye, and more; and therfo&rtail; he was cast
out of heve&ntail;, witℏ a&llbar; they&mtail; that
consente&dtail; to hym, and man is promote&dtail; to that dignyte in
her stede.  ¶ The fendes, whan thei sawe this, thei praie&dtail;
Adam and Eve to a fest, whan thei ete&ntail; of the apple agay&ntail;
goddes precepte by her steryng, and sai&dtail;, ¶ What houre ye
ete of the frute of this tree, ye shu&llbar; be as goddes. wherfore in
this fest was mynystre&dtail; to hem v. messes, That is, of the v.
wittes, the whiche a&llbar; accorde&dtail; to ete of the apple; and
therfore a&llbar; thei were enfecte, for the whiche man die&dtail;.
¶ This her&dtail; the sone of the Fadir of heve&ntail;, and was
stere&dtail; to mercy, and descende&dtail; fro heve&ntail; into this
worl&dtail;; and come to the maide&ntail;, that is, Marie, and there
he foun&dtail; the welle of mankyn&dtail;, the whiche was Ioyne&dtail;
to the godhede.  ¶ Aftir this he di&dtail; make v. pittes, that
is, v. woundes in his bodye, by the whiche ranne bloo&dtail; and
watir, that made a&llbar; mankynde to lyve agay&ntail;, that
sha&llbar; be saved, and ledde home agay&ntail; to the hevenly paleys.
 To the whiche brynge vs Iesu Crist!  Amen.

77.1:
Second Version.  22. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Lemicius regned in the Cite of Rome / the which, as he rode by a
foreste, mete with a pore man & seyde to hym, "fro whens comyst
þou & what art þou?" he seyde, "I come fro þe
nexte Cite/ & I am your man" / The Emperour sayde, "if þou
wilt be A good man & trew, I sha&llbar; promote the to richesse" /
he seyde, "ye, lorde" / A-none þe Emperour made hym knyght,
& sone he rose in-to pride / Wherfor he gadred to hym many of
þe grete me&nmacr; of the Empire & conspirid with hem
þat he wolde vsurpe the Empire / Whan þe Emperour wist of
þat / Anone he put hym out & a&llbar; þat helde with
hym / & wolde no lenger let hym dwelle in his Empire, but ordeynyd oþer in his stede, & ga&ftee; hem his landes,
& a&llbar; her meuable
goodys / whan thei harde / þat straungers had her goodes Thei
conspirid a-gayne hem & prayed hem to þe feste & sette
by-fore hem v. messes, & euery messe was venymed, & a&llbar;
þat ete of þe messes were dede / The Emperour calle&dtail;
/ his sones [&] seyde, "ye Are my fader, & gretely I am greuyd for
your heuynes / I gy&ftee; yow this councei&llbar; / A lyti&llbar;
kyngdome is here bysyde, not ferre fro yow, in the which is a
we&llbar; of water of suche vertu þat if it be sprengli&dtail;
on the dede body It sha&llbar; leve agay&nmacr; / þerfor I
sha&llbar; go to this kyngedome & gete me water of þis welle
by þe whiche þe dede mow rise to ly&ftee; / And anone he
went to þe kyngdome & gate þe we&llbar; of the mayde /
& went in to þe garde&nmacr; & fonde þe we&llbar;:
wherfor he made .v. pittes fu&llbar; depe, by the which þe water
of þe we&llbar; ranne to þe bodyes of þe dede men,
& Anone thei rise&nmacr;.  And [when] this was sene The sone of
þe Emperour led hem a&llbar; with hym to his fader.  þe
Emperour whan he saw hem he was gladde & for Ioy crownyd his
sone.

0.1:
Story. VOmias reigne&dtail; in Rome, that toke a faire
&mtail;ai&dtail;e&ntail; to wy&ftee;, the whiche conseive&dtail;, and
brought forthe a faire sone. ¶ wise men come to the Emperour,
forto have his sone to norissℏ. ¶
Than the Emperour sent out a messanger þurgℏ a&llbar; the
Citee, that in whos house were founde fire and watir, shul&dtail; have his sone to norissℏ. ¶ whan this was
publisshe&dtail;, many ordeyne&dtail; hem fire and watir.  ¶ The
Emperour di&dtail; crie also, that he that hadde the childe to kepe,
and norisshe&dtail; hym clenly and purely, he shul&dtail; be
promote&dtail; to grete dignyte, and els he shul&dtail; be
dampne&dtail; to wikke&dtail; dethe.  ¶ Ano&ntail;, while thei
slept, come a Tyraunte, whos name was Eulopius, that sleke&dtail; the
fire and cast watir out of the house.  But amonge hem was a man that
hight Ionathas, that a&llbar; nyght labore&dtail; that fire and watir
shul&dtail; not faile, but þat he shol&dtail; alway have bothe
redy. ¶ whan morow was come, the messanger went aboute the Citee,
to loke in whos house he myght fynde fire and watir; but whan he hadde
gone aboute the Citiee, in the house a&llbar; only of Ionathas he
founde fire and watir; and so the Emperours sone was yeve to hym for
to norissℏ, vndir the forme aforsei&dtail;.  ¶ Ionathas toke
the chil&dtail;, and hire&dtail; masons, that thei shol&dtail;
enhaunse his Chambre witℏ morter and stone; and whan the chambre
was redy, he calle&dtail; to hym payntours, and made his chambre to be
paynte&dtail; ¶ In this form.  in the walle, on the right side,
he paynte&dtail; x. ymages, and aboue the ymages this scripture was
writte&ntail;, ¶ he that foulethe not thise ymages, sha&llbar; have a golde&ntail; crowne of the Emperour; And yf he foule of the ymages, he sha&llbar; be condempne&dtail; to a foule
dethe.  ¶ Than on the dore he made to be drawe&ntail; a
golde&ntail; chaier, and hym sel&ftee; sittyng ther in, crowne&dtail;
witℏ a crowne of gol&dtail;; and aboue his hede was
writte&ntail;, thus sha&llbar; be crowne&dtail;, that wele
norisshetℏ the Emperours sone.  And whan a&llbar; this was made,
¶ Ionathas was ofte sithe tempte&dtail; forto defoule the ymages,
but whan he redde the scripture, ano&ntail; he ha&dtail; drede that he
shul&dtail; dye an eve&llbar; dethe; and so a&llbar; the
temptacio&ntail; went a-way. and also whan he sawe writte&ntail; over
the ymages hedes the mede of the crowne, more and more he
studie&dtail; for to worshippe the ymages, and forto kepe hem in
fairenesse.  And whan the chil&dtail; was not wele norisshe&dtail;, he
ranne swiftly to the perisshyng of the Enemye; and whan he saw hym
sel&ftee; shol&dtail; be hange&dtail;, he dre&dtail; gretely, and
a&llbar; the defautes of the norisshyng, as to the
chil&dtail;, he amende&dtail;.  ¶ But whan he sawe the
golde&ntail; chaire, and hym self crowne&dtail; with a crowne of
gol&dtail;, and above his hede was writte&ntail;, ¶ Thus he
sha&llbar; be worshippe&dtail;, that wele and clene sha&llbar;
norissℏ the sone of the Emperour, ¶ And than he ha&dtail; so
moche ioye of the picture of þe Chaire, that a&llbar; his lyf aftir he norisshe&dtail;
wele the chil&dtail;.  The Emperour, whan he her&dtail; this, he sent
for hym and for his sone, and promote&dtail; hem to grete
dignytee.
0.2:
¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is the Fadir of
heve&ntail;.  The Empresse is blisse&dtail; marie; the chil&dtail; is
Iesus.  the messanger, that was sent, is Seint Ioℏn Baptist, that
he shul&dtail; shew his comyng; wherfore the wise men, that were the
patriarkes and the prophetes, desire&dtail; gretly to norissℏ
hym; and se hym; and thei sawe hym not, for fire and watir was in hem
extyncte.  ¶ By fire is vndirston&dtail; the holy gost, that
appere&dtail; not yit to hem as it di&dtail; to the appostels, ne thei
were not wasshe&ntail; witℏ the watir of baptyme, as cristen men
are now.  ¶ Or els by fire thou may vndirston&dtail; parfite
charite, and by watir trew contriccio&ntail;.  this ij. fallen in
many, and therfore thei mow not have the chil&dtail; Iesu in her
hertes.  ¶ Ionathas, that wake&dtail;, is a goo&dtail; cristen
man, þat a&llbar; way in goo&dtail; werkes studietℏ to
wake, and a&llbar; way to offre to god for his synnes the fire of
charitee, and the water of contriccio&ntail;.  ¶ But ofte sithe
the tyraunt, that is, the devel, puttetℏ out the fire of charitee
and the watir of contriccio&ntail;, and castetℏ it ferre a-way
fro the hertes of many; therfore thei that are thus defame&dtail;, may
not norissℏ the chil&dtail; Iesu.  Therfore do thou as Ionathas
di&dtail;; wake, and pray, that þou entre not into
temptacio&ntail;; and calle to the trew expositours, that is, discrete
confessours or prelates, that may rise vp in thy&ntail; herte a
stone&ntail; chambre, and seker feitℏ and hope for the wyndowes.
than calle to the payntours, that mowe peynt in thyn hert x. ymages,
that is, the x. comaundementes; and than yf thou kepe wele his
preceptis, witℏ out doute in tyme to come thou shalt be
crowne&dtail;, and not be dampned to ever lastyng dethe.  ¶ And
the golde&ntail; chaire must be in the dore of thyn hert, that is to
sey, yf thou norissℏ wele the chil&dtail; Iesu, thou shalt have a
chaire in heve&ntail;.  and have myn&dtail;, yf thou norissℏ hym
eve&llbar;, thou shalt be hange&dtail; in the gibbette of Helle, but
thou amende the. Therfore studie we so to
norissℏ the chil&dtail; Iesu, by meritorie werkes, that we mow come
to the mede that is everlastyng without ende.

78.1:
Second Version.  24. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Remilus regned in Rome þat toke a fayre mayde to wy&ftee;,
þe which conceyuyd & brought forthe a fayre sone / Wyse men
come to þe Emperour for to haue his childe to norisshe.  Than
the Emperour ano&nmacr; sent out a messange&rtail; þorogh
a&llbar; the Cite, þat [he] in whos hous ware founde fyre or
water sholde haue his sone to norisshe.  When þis was publisshe&dtail; many ordeynyd hym fyre
& water / The Emperour dyd cry also þat [if] he þat
had þe childe to kepe norisshed hym clenly & purely he
sholde be promoty&dtail; to grete dignyte, & ellis he sholde be
dampny&dtail; to þe wikkyd deþe / Anone while þei
slept come a tyraunte whos name was Eulopius / þat slekkyd
þe fyre & caste water out of the houses / But A-mon>ee;
hem was a man hyght Ionathas that a&llbar; nyght labouryd þat
fyre & water sholde not fayle // But þere he shol&dtail;
alway haue bothe redy / Whan mor&nmacr; was comyn the messanger went
aboute þe Cite to loke in whos hous he myght fynde fyre &
water / But whan he had gone aboute þe Cite, in þe hous
a&llbar; only of Ionathas he fonde fyre & water, & so þe
Emperours sone was yove to hym for to norisse vnder þe forme
by-fore seyde / Ionathas toke þe childe, and hirid masyns that
thei sholde haunse his chambre with morter & stone, & whan the
chambre was redy he called to hym peyntours & made his chambre to
be payntyd in þis fourme / In þe wa&llbar; of þe
right syde he payntyd x ymages / & a-boue þes ymages
þis scriptur was wryte / "he þat foulyth not þes ymages sha&llbar; haue A
goldy&nmacr; crow&nmacr; of þe Emperour. And if he foule þe ymages he sha&llbar; be condempnyd to a foule
deþe /" Than on þe dore he made to be drawe A goldy&nmacr;
cheyre, & hym-self syttyn>ee; þer-in crownid with a crowne
of golde / & a-boue his hede was wryte þis / "þus
sha&llbar; he be crownyd þat norisshith wele þe Emperours
sone" / & whan a&llbar; þis was made / Ionathas was oft tyme temptyde to defoule þe ymages / But whan he red þe
scripture, he dred þat he shold dye an euy&llbar; dethe, &
so a&llbar; þe temptacio&nmacr; went A-way.  And also whan he
sawe wryte&nmacr; on þe ymages hedes þe mede of þe
crowne, more & more he studyed for to worship þe ymage,
& for to kepe hem in fayrenes / & Whan þe child was not
wele gouernyd & norisshed he ranne swyftly to þe perisshyng
of þe enemy, And whan he saw hymsel&ftee; sholde be hanged / he
drede gretely & a&llbar; þe defautes of þe
norisshyn>ee; as to þe childe he Amendyd // But whan he sawe
þe goldyn chayre & hymsel&ftee; crowned with a crowne of
golde, & red þe superscripcio&nmacr; / "Thus he sha&llbar;
do worship þat wele & clene norisshith þe sone of
þe Emperour" / & þan he had so myche Ioy of þe
picture of þe chayer þat a&llbar; his ly&ftee; after he
norisshed right wele þe chil&dtail; after.  The Emperour, whan he hard this he sent for hym, & for his sone
promotid hym to grete dignite.

0.1:
Story. Fulgencius reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, the whiche in
merveillous maner love&dtail; his peple, in so meke&llbar; þat
he made to be crie&dtail; thurgℏ a&llbar; his Empire, that
a&llbar; men shul&dtail; come of every nacio&ntail; at a certay&ntail;
day to his paleys, and what so ever thei aske&dtail;, a&llbar; thei
shul&dtail; have, aftir 'her astate.  ¶ Dukes and other grete
lordes, whan thei her&dtail; this, thei were right gla&dtail;, and
come in a grete multitude; and eche by hem sel&ftee; put forthe his
peticio&ntail;, and ha&dtail; it. and so a&llbar; the Empire nere
han&dtail; was devide&dtail; amonge hem; and eche man ioye&dtail;, and
went home to his owne, and toke seisy&ntail; in his londes, and
tenementes, and mevable goodes, that thei hadde&ntail; of the
Emperour.  ¶ After þis, poore men and symple wente
to-gedre, and sai&dtail;, "a como&ntail; crie is made, that a&llbar;
sha&llbar; come to the Emperours paleys, no persone out take.  Riche
men and myghty men have come afore vs, and have resceive&dtail; benefice, after her
wille, and therfore go we now, and we shu&llbar; have goodes of the
Emperour."  that her&dtail; thei, and sai&dtail;, "this is a goo&dtail; counsaile,
and a profitable." and a&llbar; anon thei wenten, and stode atte gate
of the paleys, criyng that it shul&dtail; be mynystre&dtail; to hem,
as the crie was made.  ¶ Whan the Emperour her&dtail; the crie,
he come downe of his see, and sai&dtail; to hem, ¶ Frendes, I
have her&dtail; youre crie. it is sothe that the crie is by me made,
and that a&llbar; indifferently shul&dtail; come, and what thei
aske&dtail; thei shul&dtail; have. but riche men and mighty men
shul&dtail; come before you, and thei ha&dtail; a&llbar;, out take my
paleys; and yf thei ha&dtail; aske&dtail; my paleys, thei shul&dtail;
have ha&dtail; it; and therfore I have nought for to yeve you."
¶ Thei sai&dtail;, "a! lor&dtail;, have mercy on vs, and lette vs
not go voide away; for certaynly it was oure blame that we come not
before, witℏ the riche men and myghty. but sithen it is thus, we
aske your grace, that we may have somewhat, by the whiche we may
live."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "here me. a&llbar;
þougℏ I have yove&ntail; to riche men and myghty, that come
before you, londes and tenementes, neverthelesse I have holde&ntail;
the lordshippes in my&ntail; han&dtail; of a&llbar; the landes, and
hal&ftee; that I yeve to you, so that thei be now servauntes to you,
and obedient."  ¶ The poore men, whan thei har&dtail; this, they
were right gla&dtail;, and bowe&dtail; downe her hedes to the Emperour, and lowly and mekely thanke&dtail; hym, and
sai&dtail;, "we are come late, and are made lordes of other!" whan
this was sai&dtail;, thei went home ayene.  ¶ The riche men and
the grete, whan thei her&dtail; this, thei were gretely stere&dtail;
witℏ in hem sel&ftee;, and sai&dtail; to-gedre, ¶ Allas! how
is this mynystre&dtail; to vs, that thei that were wonte to be our
chorles and seruauntes in a&llbar; thyng, now are made oure lordes. Go
we a&llbar; ano&ntail; to the Emperour, and be-thynke vs a remedye."
thei saide&ntail; a&llbar;, "it is a goo&dtail; counsaile."  ¶
Ano&ntail; thei wente to the Emperour, and saide&ntail;, "Sir, what is
that our servauntes now are made our lordes? we pray you, that it be
not so."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "frendes, I do you no
wronge. was not the crie made como&ntail;, what some ever ye
aske&dtail; of me, ye shul&dtail; have? and ye aske&dtail; but londes,
and rentes, and dignytees, and worshippes, and a&llbar; I graunte you
at your wille, in so meke&llbar; that to my sel&ftee; I hel&dtail;
right nought; and eche of you, whan he went fro me, ye were right wele
apaie&dtail;. ¶ Aftir you come poore men and symple, and
aske&dtail; of me some goodes, aftir the vertu of the crie. and I ha&dtail; no thynge to
yeve hem. before I yave a&llbar; to you, out take the lordshippe that
I hel&dtail; in my han&dtail;; and whan the poore men crie&dtail; on
me, I ha&dtail; no thyng forto yeve hem but lordshippe above you. and therfore ye
ought not to blame me in no thyng, for that ye aske&dtail;, ye
ha&dtail;."  ¶ Than sei&dtail; thei, "A! lor&dtail;, we pray the
effectually of youre counsaile in this parte,
and help."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "yf ye wille assent to my
counsaile, I sha&llbar; yeve you a prophitable counsaile."  Thei
sai&dtail;, "ye, lor&dtail;, we are redy to fulfille what so ever ye
say to vs for our profite."  ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;, "ye have
by me many londes and tenementes, witℏ other goodes I-now
habundauntly; Therfore partetℏ witℏ the poore." and so
gladly they di&dtail;, and devide&dtail; her goodes amonge poore men
and symple; and so he graunte&dtail; hem lordshippe. and so bothe were pai&dtail;; and the Emperour was
praise&dtail; of a&llbar; his peple, that so wisely brought to
accor&dtail; bothe the parties.
0.2:
¶ Declaracio. ¶ This Emperour is our lor&dtail; Iesu
crist, that by his prophetes, patriarkes, and appostels made to be
proclame&dtail;, that a&llbar; men shul&dtail; come and aske ever
lastyng ioye, and witℏ outen doute thei shul&dtail; have it.
¶ But grete men and mighty of this worl&dtail; aske&ntail; no
thyng els but transitorie thynges and failyng, as are worldly goodes;
for the worl&dtail; passetℏ, and his concupiscence. for he
ga&ftee; to hem so meke&llbar;, that he kept no thyng to hym
sel&ftee;; for he sai&dtail;, briddes of heve&ntail; have nestes,
foxes have dennes, but the sone of a maide hatℏ not wherto he may
lay his hede.  ¶ Poore men are tho that are meke of hert; ¶
Of whiche poore men speketℏ ou&rtail; saviour, and seitℏ,
¶ Blisse&dtail; be the poore of sprite, for enheriters of the
kyngdo&mtail; of heven. and so it folowetℏ, that poore men
sha&llbar; have lordshippe aboue riche men and myghty of this
worl&dtail;.  What is than forto do riche men? forsothe that thei
divide her tempora&llbar; goodes to poore men; as it is writte&ntail;,
¶ yeve almesse, and a&llbar; þyng sha&llbar; be clene to
you. and so ye may gete hal&ftee; the kyngdo&mtail; of heve&ntail;; to
the whiche brynge vs he that reignetℏ witℏ oute&ntail; ende!
 Ame&ntail;.

79.1:
Second Version.  26. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Fulgencius regned in þe Cite of Rome / þe which in
meruelous maner louyd his peple, in so mych he made to be crye&dtail;
þorogh out a&llbar; þe Empire / þat a&llbar; men
sholde come of eny natio&ntail; at a certey&nmacr; day to his paleis /
And what so euer þei asky&dtail;, a&llbar; thei shold have after
his state / Dukes & oþer grete lordys whan þei hard
þis þei were right gladde & come in A grete multitude,
& eche by hemsel&ftee; put forþe his peticio&ntail;, &
had it, so a&llbar; þe Empire nere hande was dyuydyd a-mong hem,
& eche man ioyed and went home to his owne & toke sesy&nmacr;
in his landes & tenementes & meuable goodes þat
þei had of þe Emperour / After þis pore me&ntail;
& sengle come to-geder &
seyde&nmacr; / "A comyn cry is þat a&llbar; shold come to
þe Emperours paleys, no perso&nmacr; out-take / Riche men &
myghty me&nmacr; haue come by-fore vs & haue receyuyd benefice
after hi&rtail; wi&llbar; // þerfor go we nowe & we shu&llbar; haue goodes of þe Emperour as þei
haddy&nmacr;."  Thei þat herde þis seyde, "þis is
goode councei&llbar; & a profitable" / & Anone a&llbar; went
& stode at þe yate of þe paleis cryeng þat it
shold be ministrid to hem As þe cry was made / Whan the Emperour
harde þe crye he come dou&nmacr; of his sete and seyde to hem //
"Frendes, I haue herde your crye / It is soþe þat þe
cry is by me made & þat a&llbar; indifferently sholde come /
& what þei asky&dtail; þei sholde haue / Riche men
& myghti men haue come byfore yow & a&llbar; þat I haue,
out-take my paleis, I haue geue hem / & if þei Askyd my
paleis þei had had it; þerfor I haue noght for to geue
yow" / þei seyde, "A, lorde, haue mercy on vs, & let not vs
go voyde A-way, for certaynly it was our blame þat we come not
to-fore with þe riche men and myghti / But sethe it is
þus, we aske your grace þat we mowe haue some what by
þe whiche we mow leve" / The Emperour seyde, "here me;
þogh a&llbar; I haue youe to riche men & myghty þat
come by-fore yowe landes & tenement&yogh;, neuerþeles I haue
hold þe lordschip in myn hande of a&llbar; þe landes,
& half I geue to you, so þat þei be now seruauntes to
yow obedyent" / The po&rtail; me&ntail; whan þei herd þis
þei were right gladde & bowi&dtail; dou&ntail; he&rtail;
hedes to þe Emperour, & lowly & mekely
þonky&dtail; hym & seyde, "We Are come late, & made lordes of oþer."
Whan þis was seyde þei went home a-gay&nmacr; / The riche
men & þe grete herd þis & were gretely styrid with
in hem-sel&ftee;, & made a comyn parlament with in hem-sel&ftee;
& seyde to-geder, "Alas! how is it ministrid to vs? þei
þat were wont to be charlys & seruauntes in a&llbar;
þin>ee; now Are made our lorde[s], Go we a&llbar; A-none to
þe Emperour to-geder, & be-þink vs on some remedy."
þei seyde a&llbar;, "It is a good councei&llbar;" / Anone
þei went & seyde to þe Emperour / "Sir, how is it
þat our seruauntes now are made our lordes?  We pray yow
þat it be not so" / The Emperour seide, "Frendes, I do yow no
wron>ee; / Was not þe cry made comy&nmacr; þat what so euer ye askyd ye sholde haue, and ye
askyd but landes & tenement&yogh; & dignites & worshippis,
& a&llbar; I graunt yow at your wi&llbar;, In so mych þat to
my-sel&ftee; I helde right noght, & eche of yow whan ye went fro
me were right gladde.  After yow come pore me&nmacr; & simple
& askyd of me some goodes after þe vertu of þe crye /
And I had no þing for to geue hem but lordship aboue yow / & þerfor ye ow not to
blame me noþing, for þat ye askyd ye had" / þan
þei seyde, "A, lorde / We pray þe of councei&llbar; &
of helpe in þis parte."  The Emperour seyde, "if ye wole Assent
to my councei&llbar;, I sha&llbar; geue yow A profitable
councei&llbar;. þei seyde, "ye, lorde, we A&rtail; redy to
fulfi&llbar; what so euer þou seyst to vs for our profit" / The
Emperour seide, "ye haue of me landes & tenement&yogh; with
oþer goodes y-nogh Abundauntly; þerfor partith with
þe pore," & so gladly þei dyd & dyuydyd her goodes
a-mong pore me&nmacr; & simple, & so he graunty&dtail; hem
lordship.  And so bothe were paid, & the Emperour gretly preysyd
of a&llbar; his peple þat so wysely had made a-corde with
boþe parties.

0.1:
Story. DOmyciane reigne&dtail; in the Citee of Rome, that was a wise man,
and ha&dtail; many possessions.  This Emperour had ij. doughtirs, one
faire, a nothe&rtail; bla&ktee;.  ¶ he di&dtail; crie
thurgℏ his Empire, that who so wol&dtail; wedde his faire
doughtir, shul&dtail; no thyng haue witℏ her but her fairenesse;
And who so wol&dtail; his bla&ktee; doughtir to wyf, shul&dtail; have
a&llbar; his Empire witℏ her, after his dissease.  ¶ And
whan the crie was made, moche peple come to the Emperours paleys, and
aske&dtail; the faire doughtir to wy&ftee;.  The Emperour sai&dtail;,
"ye wote not what ye aske, For, by the crowne of my hede, ye
shu&llbar; nought have witℏ my doughtir that is faire but only
her fairenesse; yf ye desire þe other doughtir, I shalle yeve
a&llbar; my Empire witℏ her, after my dissease."  ¶ The
grete men, whan thei her&dtail; this, thei wol&dtail; not assente to
his saiyng.  ¶ Whan the Emperour her&dtail; this, he sai&dtail;
to hem, "Frendes, ye are many; and yf I graunte&dtail; my faire doughtir to one of you, and not to another, there
shul&dtail; be betwixe you stry&ftee; and debate.  Therfore gothe, and
make a turnement amonge you for her love, and he sha&llbar; have the
victorie, sha&llbar; haue her to wyf."  ¶ Thei herde this, and
were gla&dtail;; and wente&ntail; and made&ntail; not only a turnement
but a bataile, for the maidens love; wherfore many were dede in the
bataile, but one ha&dtail; the victorie, and wedde&dtail; the
maide&ntail;.  ¶ whan the secon&dtail; doughtir, that was
bla&ktee;, sawe that her sustir was wedde&dtail; witℏ so
meke&llbar; myrthe and gladnesse, she sorowe&dtail; meke&llbar;, and
every day wept bitterly.  ¶ whan the Emperour her&dtail; this, he
came to his doughtir, and sai&dtail;, "O! my my dere doughtir, for
what thyng is thi soule turmente&dtail;?"  She sai&dtail;, ¶ "O!
my reverent fadir, it is no wondir that I thus sorow, for my sustir is
marrie&dtail; witℏ so grete worshippe and gladnesse, and a&llbar;
that sha&llbar; see me, sha&llbar; hate my felishippe; and therfore
what is best to be done, vtterly I wote never."  ¶ The Emperour
sai&dtail;, "o! my dere doughtir, a&llbar; that is my&ntail; is
thy&ntail;, And thou knowest wele, that he that hathe wedde&dtail; thi sustir , hath no thynge witℏ her but
her fairenesse; ¶ And therfore I sha&llbar; do crie by kyngdomes
and castels, that who so wille wedde the, I sha&llbar; make hym a
lettre vndre my seale, that after my dissease he sha&llbar; have my
Empire." Whan she her&dtail; this, she was comforte&dtail;.
¶ And whan the crie was made, of a persone of the Emperours,
there come a gentile knyght that hight lambert, and aske&dtail; of the
Emperour his bla&ktee; doughtir to wy&ftee;; and he graunte&dtail;
hym, witℏ her grete ioye, and he wedde&dtail; her.  And whan the
Emperour was dede, he was made Emperour. ¶ Declaracio. Frendes, this Emperour is our lor&dtail; Ihesu
crist, that hathe .ij. doughtirs, one faire, that is, the worlde, the
whiche is fu&llbar; faire to many a man, and the other doughtir
bla&ktee;, that is, poverte or tribulacio&ntail;, that few men desiren
for to wedde. Neverthelesse a como&ntail; crie is made, by holy
scripture, that in the worl&dtail; thou shalt no thyng have but her
fairenesse, that is, the vanyte of the worl&dtail;, that sone
passetℏ away, as the fairenesse of man.  ¶ But thei that
take wilfu&llbar; poverte and tribulacio&ntail;, for the love of Ihesu
crist, withoute&ntail; doute thei sha&llbar; have the kyngdo&mtail; of
heve&ntail;; as crist saitℏ, ¶ ye that have forsake a&llbar;
thyng, and haue folowe&dtail; me, ye sha&llbar; have an hundre&dtail;
fol&dtail; more, and ever lastyng blisse therto.  Many noble men and
grete, in a passyng nombre, come for the first faire doughtir, that
is, for the worl&dtail;, and witℏ labour sechen it, and sometyme
fighte&ntail; by lon&dtail; and watir, that is, whan thei putte&ntail;
a&llbar; her studie in worldly thynges; so that for the worl&dtail;
many a man is dede, witℏ outen nombre.  for alle that is in the
worl&dtail; either it is pride of ly&ftee;, or concupiscance of
eye&ntail;, or concupiscence of flessℏ, for a&llbar; the
worl&dtail; is but in wikkednesse.  but he that weddi&dtail; the faire
doughtir, for sothe is he, that witℏ a&llbar; his desire and
assent strengthitℏ hym for to wedde the worl&dtail;, and in no
maner wolle leve it, as the Avarous man, and covetous man.  ¶ But
he that weddeth the bla&ktee; doughtir, is a goo&dtail; cristen man,
that for the love of the kyngdo&mtail; of heve&ntail; levetℏ
a&llbar; worldly thynges, and dispisetℏ hym sel&ftee; bodely, and obeyetℏ to his souerayns in a&llbar; thynges.
forsothe suche one sha&llbar; have the Empire of the kyngdo&mtail; of
heve&ntail;; to the whiche bryng vs Ihesu crist!
Amen.

80.1:
Second Version.  27. Cambr. MS. Kk. 1. 6. Domiciane regned in þe Cite of Rome þat was A wise
man, & his pocessio&nmacr; was myche.  This Emperour had
.ij. doghters, o&nmacr; fayre, a-noþer blak: he did crye
þorogh his Empire þat who so wol&dtail; wedde his fayre
doghter sholde haue no þyng but her fayrenes, & who so wold
haue þe bla&ktee; doghter to wy&ftee; shol&dtail; haue a&llbar;
his Empire after his dissece / And whan þe cry was made mych
peple come to þe pales & askyd þe fayre doghtur to
wy&ftee;.  The Emperour seyde, "ye wote not what ye aske, for by
þe crowne of my&nmacr; hede, ye shu&llbar; haue with my fayre
doghter but a&llbar; only her fayrenesse, but if ye desyre þat
oþer I sha&llbar; geue yow a&llbar; my&nmacr; Empire after my
decece.  The grete me&nmacr; whan þei her&dtail; þis
þei wolde not Assent to his sayen>ee; / Whan þe Emperour
herd þis he seyde to hem / "Frendes, ye are meny, & if I
grauntyd my fayre doghter to one of yow & not anoþer / þat shol&dtail; be by-twix you stry&ftee; & debate /
þerfor gothe and make A turnament A-mon>ee; yow for her love,
& he þat hath þe victory sha&llbar; haue her to
wy&ftee;" / þei herde þis & were right glad, &
made not only A turnament but a bataile for þe maydes loue. Wherefor in þe bataile
meny were dede but one had þe victory & wedded þe
mayde / Whan þe secon&dtail; doughtur þat was bla&ktee;
herd þat hi&rtail; sustyr was weddyd with myrthe & gladnes
she sorowyd mych & euery day wept / whan þe Emperour herde
þis he come to his doughter & seyde, "O my dere doughter,
for what þing is þi soule turmenty&dtail;?" / She seyde,
"O my reuerent fader, it is no wonder þat I thus make sorowe for
my suster is maried with grete worship & gladnes, & a&llbar;
þat shu&llbar; se me shu&llbar; hate my felawship, &
þerfor what is best to do vtterly I note."  The Emperour seyde,
"O my dere doughter, a&llbar; þat is my&nmacr; is
þi&nmacr; / & þou knowest wele he þat hathe
weddyd þi suster hath no þin>ee; with her but he&rtail;
fayrenes / & þerfor I sha&llbar; do cry by kyndomes &
castels þat whoso wi&llbar; wedde þe I sha&llbar; make hym
A letter vnder my sele þat after my decece he sha&llbar; haue
a&llbar; my&nmacr; Empire" / Whan she hard þis she was
comforty&dtail; / And whan þe crye was made of a persone of
þe Emperours / Ther come A genti&llbar; knyght, þat hyght
Lamberte, & askyd of þe Emperour his blak doughtur to
wy&ftee;, & he graunty&dtail; hym, & with grete Ioy he weddyd
he&rtail; / & whan þe Emperour was dede he was made
Emperour.

0.1:
Story. Antonyus in the Citee of Rome reigne&dtail;, a man right wise,
that ha&dtail; a faire doughtir, that hight Ierabelle, and was
desire&dtail; of many.  Neverthelesse she made a vowe to go&dtail;,
that she shul&dtail; never take husbon&dtail;, but yf he myght do
.iij. thynges, ¶ That is, [fyrst] to chaunge the wynde fro the
Northe in to the Est, whan her fadir wol&dtail;.  The secon&dtail;
was, to mete a&llbar; the Elementes, as vnto the brede and lengthe,
and how many fete a&llbar; the Elementes conteyne&dtail;. ¶ The
thirde was, that he shul&dtail; bere fire in his boso&mtail;, by the
bare flessℏ, witℏ out brennyng of his flessℏ.  many grete men,
whan thei ha&dtail; her&dtail; her vowe, they wol&dtail; not besy hem
for to have her; and so she dwelle&dtail; many yeres in her
maydenhode.  ¶ There was that tyme in ferre countrees a gentile
knyght, whose name was Plebeus , that on a
tyme as he lay in his bedde, he thought witℏ in hym sel&ftee;, "I
am but a poore knyght; yf I myght by any mean have the Emperours doughtir, I shul&dtail; not a&llbar;
only be promote&dtail; to richesse, but also a&llbar; my kynrede."
than he went to the Emperours paleys, and knokke&dtail; at the gate.
The porter aske&dtail;, whi he knokked?  ¶ he sai&dtail;, "I am a
knyght of ferre countre, and plebeus is my name; and I am come for to
have the Emperours doughtir to wy&ftee;."  The porter sai&dtail;,
"have kepyn>ee; of thi sel&ftee;, and wete wele, that no man
sha&llbar; have the doughtir of my lor&dtail; but yf he do .iij.
thynges. ¶ One is, that he chaunge the wynde; mete the Elementes;
and bere fire in his boso&mtail; witℏ out hurtyng; and he that
puttetℏ hym to thise thynges, and failetℏ, he sha&llbar;
lose his hede."  The knyght sai&dtail;, "before I come hedir I herde
this processe, but witℏ oute&ntail; doute I sha&llbar; fulfille
the peticio&ntail; of the maide&ntail;."  ¶ Whan the porter
her&dtail; this, he lette hym entre; and [he] come, and stode before
the Emperour, and aske&dtail; the maide&ntail; to wy&ftee;.  The
Emperour sai&dtail;, "Yf thou wilte fulfille the peticio&ntail; of my
doughtir, thou shalt have her to wy&ftee;."  he sai&dtail;, "sir, I am
redy to fulfille [hem.] iij. thynges there be that your doughter
wol&dtail; have fulfille&dtail;.  The first is, to chaunge the wynde
fro þe northe into the Est; lo!  I am redy for to prove that."
The knyght ha&dtail; an horse, that was wode; and yaf hym a
dryn&ktee;, by vertu of the whiche dryn&ktee; he was delyuere&dtail;
of his woodnesse.  ¶ Whan this was done, he put his
hede towar&dtail; the Est, an&dtail; sai&dtail;, "sir, behol&dtail;
the wynde is turne&dtail; from the Northe into the Est."  The Emperour
sai&dtail;, "what is that to chaunge the wynde?"  he sai&dtail;, "yis,
sir, what is the lyf of man or of any best but a lite&llbar; wynde?
for as longe as my&ntail; horse was woo&dtail;, so longe it was in the
northe, for a&llbar; evels cometℏ out of the Northe.  I ya&ftee;
hym a drynke, that his woodnesse shul&dtail; cease, and now he hathe
his hede in the Est, and is redy forto bere alle burthons.  and so the
wynde is chaunge&dtail; fro the northe in to the Est."  ¶ The
Emperour sai&dtail;, "forsothe thou hast wele prove&dtail; the first
peticio&ntail;; lette vs now se; for the secon&dtail; peticio&ntail;
is this, forto mete the .iiij. Elementes, after a&llbar;e her
divisions."  ¶ "Se now, that I sha&llbar; clerely prove it."
Ano&ntail; he made his Squyer to light
dow&ntail; on the groun&dtail;, an&dtail; he beganne to mete fro the
hede vnto the fete, the lengtℏ and the brede, and the depnesse.
whan this was do&ntail;, he sai&dtail; to þe Emperour, ¶
"Sir, leve me, there are not .vij. fete and an hal&ftee; fully in
lengtℏ of the elementes a&llbar;, and so many in brede."  what is
that to þe .iiij. elementes?" sai&dtail; þe Emperour.
¶ The knyght sai&dtail;, "sir, it is wele know to you, that in
man is .iiij. Elementes; and sithe I have mote&ntail; the membres of my squyers body, so I
have the Elementes; and so, as me semetℏ, is assoile&dtail; the
secon&dtail; peticio&ntail;." ¶ The Emperour sai&dtail;,
"forsothe, right wele thou hast prove&dtail; it; go now to the thirde
peticio&ntail;."  the knyght sai&dtail;, "I am redy to fulfille
a&llbar; your wille."  ¶ Ano&ntail; he toke a brennyng cole, and
.iij. daies he bare it in his boso&mtail;, witℏ out brennyng or
hurtyng of his flessℏ.  ¶ This saw the Emperour, and saide,
"Say me, frende, how may this be, for the other .ij. clerly I sey, but
how it may be of the fire, vtterly I wote never."  ¶ he
sai&dtail;, "sir, my modir yaf me a precious stone, by vertu of
þe whicℏ the fire may not noye me."  the Emperour heryng
this, was gretly gla&dtail;, and sai&dtail;, "for sothe, wisely thou
hast fulfille&dtail; the peticions of my doughtir, and therfore thou
shalt have her to wy&ftee;." and ano&ntail; the Emperour made a crie,
that a&llbar; shol&dtail; come to the weddyng.  and many come, and the
weddyng was celebrate witℏ grete ioye; and so bothe thei
ledde&ntail; and live&dtail; in pease, and yelde&dtail; her soules to
go&dtail;. ¶ Declaracio. ¶ Dere frendes, this Emperou&rtail; is our
lor&dtail; Ihesu crist.  the faire and the glorious doughtir, that
made the vowe, for sothe it is the grace of [the] hevenly kyng[dome],
that no man may haue but yf he do .iij. thynges.  ¶ The first is,
to chaunge the wynde fro the nortℏ into the Est, that is forto
sey, to chaunge his ly&ftee; fro wikke&dtail; into goo&dtail;, and that is to chaunge the
wynde; as Job saitℏ, ¶ My li&ftee; is a wynde.  The
secon&dtail; is to mete the elementes.  This metyng is nought els but
the way of contricio&ntail; and confessio&ntail;, and forto se and
mete, what and how meke&llbar; thou hast trespasse&dtail; ayenst
go&dtail;.  ¶ The squyer, that lay on the erthe, for sothe is thi
body, that owetℏ to be meke to the spirite, as ofte as he wille
mete it by way of penaunce; and so thou shalt fyn&dtail; . iv . fete, that is, the Fadir, the sone, and þe
holy gost, and a&llbar; seyntes to thi plesaunce, after thou hast mote&ntail; thi way by penaunce; for it is
a more fressℏ ioye of oo synner that
dotℏ penaunce for his synne, than of many other that nede no
penaunce. the .iij. is to bere fire.  This fire is goddes grace, that
savetℏ man from brennyng of synne; for whi? oure modir, holy
chirche, ya&ftee; vs a stone, that is, cristendo&mtail;, by vertu of
the whiche we sha&llbar; have the faire glorious maide&ntail;, that
is, ever lastyng ly&ftee;. to the whicℏ bryng vs that noble and
blisse&dtail; Emperour Jhesu crist!  Amen.
